We arrived at the cafe around 12pm on Sunday and the cafe was busy, but we were seated quickly. There was a lot more space after 1pm.

I got the brekkie bagel, which was good, but they ran out of everything bagels. The latte tasted strong and a bit bitter.

There is 1 bathroom and it is clean, but there was always a line. Overall it was a cute cafe!

Ambiance is super nice - small space with large windows bringing in a ton of natural lighting but the food was ... surprising SO bad.

My first bad meal since I landed in NY 3 weeks ago  I got an avocado toast to go and it's as hard as a brick (see video). I can't believe they're serving something of this quality lol especially for like $18. Wild.

Besides that, the matcha latte was just okay - could've used more matcha and less milk.

1 year later, still 5/5 stars. I really enjoy coming here for my daily coffee. The friendly and knowledgeable staff have always made it a pleasant experience. Ditch the DD and Starbucks $$, this is way better.
Thank you @ InCommon NYC.

Cute little coffee shop that I stopped at to get lunch. It's pretty small and can get crammed so I personally wouldn't sit here to eat. I got an egg and cheese sandwich on an everything bagel and it was good but pretty average. I'm sure the other things on their menu are better but I was in a hurry. The staff was nice and accommodating of my vegetarian request.

Really cute cafe with delicious food and coffee. Wonderful service as well. Only con was that they were out of several menu items at around 1pm which was a disappointing, especially because both our original choices were unavailable. However, the avocado toast and Caesar salad were both sizable + tasty. A little pricier than most cafes but the portions made up for it. Will be back!

This place is soo good! A must try in NYC!! I've been in NYC for the last 48 hours and this is easily the BEST meal I've had. The customer service is absolutely PHENOMENAL. If I could give this place more than 5 stars, I would. This cafe is in a great location and the lighting and atmosphere were perfect. Also the music, wow!! 10/10 such good coffee shop music. Ready to give this place ALL my money!!

Now to the food: The granola bowl we ordered was delicious, perfect mix of granola, chia seed pudding, fruits, and ricotta. I have to give a special shout-out to the owner (Tass), he made the experience there so great. He was extremely sweet and genuinely was interested in where we were from and told us about where he was from (Australia) and how long he's been in NY and etc. He served us with so much kindness and I truly felt like he cared about the customers and their experience.

We ended our meal with a matcha latte and some SUPER delicious chocolate chip cookies. New York has a plethora of coffee shops/dessert places but these chocolate chip cookies were OUT OF THIS WORLD. So soft and packed with flavor. I'm legit coming here one more time before leaving for those cookies and some coffee. (They were so good I didn't even get a chance to snap a picture). This place is literally a HIDDEN GEM.

100/10 best spot, best service, best music, best food. If you haven't yet, go check it out! :)

Tips:
- No laptop policy
- Talking atmosphere
- Yes for takeout
- Iced latte is great
- Iced matcha is not good

Food was 4/5 but service was closer to 0/5 when we sat down. The ambience was modern. However from being pushed to wait, rushed to sit down, rushed to order, rushed to eat, and signaled to pay, and not laptop friendly, this cafe is not one to enjoy your time in. It's more of a grab and go experience. Basically like a fast food experience but more pricey ($19 avocado toast with egg). We were served by a man with a European accent and it was a bit awkward to see him physically touch another customer

We got the avocado toast and that tasted good and hopefully is an inspiration to what I make at home

Came here for breakfast and the vibes are great and food is delicious.

The cafe itself is super cute and has amazing decor. Though I came early on a Thursday morning, it was still pretty packed, but my friend and I were able to snag a table by the window.

One thing that surprised me was that it was a full service type "restaurant" -- the staff came to you to take your order. They were incredibly friendly and helpful with the menu.

I ordered the shakshuka eggs (chose over hard) and it was delicious. Incredibly savory and exactly what I wanted that morning. Next time want to try something sweet (i.e., the whipped riccotta toast looked delicious on many plates around the restaurant).

Long story short -- will be back!

Lovely ambiance and friendly staff! I stopped by on a Monday morning with my family and it was pretty crowded. Luckily, we were still seated with a table for 5 almost immediately.

The cafe looked trendy and clean as well, great for photo opps or cute brunches. They also have a to-go line that would work great for a quick mid-morning meal.

The iced matcha with almond milk was light yet creamy, not too sweet, and overall a great drink!

The granola bowl was beautiful and had lots of granola paired with fresh fruits, chia seeds with yogurt, and a drizzle of honey. The granola was truly the star of the show--very crunchy and tasty! It had a combination of oats and seeds that make it super hearty and nutty.

Overall great experience :)

The owner resembles russel brand if he were healthy and happy. The crowd, no one over 35 and all talking over an Australian coffee or work matters.
I approached the line to order, and the owner, with a beaming smile on his face, asked how my Monday is going. He took my order and mentioned my iced coffee is on the house because of my positive energy. We love places like this gem! It's been in town for one year, and conveniently located right next to Hudson yards off the 7. I will be coming back here, a lot. The food was incredible, and black iced coffee, super smooth.
The pictures really don't speak the volumes that this food tastes. You should go out of your way to stop in if anything for the wonderful people working here :)!

My boyfriend and I ordered regular black cold brews a bit later in the day. The black cold brew was absolutely delicious (which is saying a lot because I'm a latte girl).

I ordered the cold brew instead of the latte as a "panic order" because the barista said they were out of ice. That really threw me off so I just ordered whatever I thought they would have. The cold brew came out of a little glass jug and was a really nice dark color... but she ran out while pouring my coffee. So I got significantly less coffee, and was still charged for a large which kinda sucked. If you are going to go, I'd recommend going earlier in the morning when they still have some products. Hopefully it was just an off day!

A sleek and modern cafe. There were indoor and outdoor seatings. Staffs were very friendly and attentive, they kept refilling our glasses of water which I truly appreciate. The coffee here are more on the acidic side, at least the flat white and latte were. I had the ham and cheese on a croissant with an egg added, it was delicious. I was pretty happy that it wasn't just two slices of ham, there were a generous amount in my sandwich which made me a happy camper. My husband order the eggs benedict, the sourdough bread was toasted perfectly and went really well with the eggs. Overall, recommend.

Walking by this place I didn't think it had good food but I was so wrong! The cafe is aesthetically pleasing  with the option to order to go or to stay. The staff were all so nice and went out of their way to accommodate seating for my group during the lunch rush. I ordered the Turkey sandwich which was so good! The bread was crunchy and toasted well. The sauce in the sandwich was a good contrast to the rest of the sandwich. I will definitely come back to try their coffee and other sandwiches !

Can I just say this place was breath taking from the second we walked in the care was immaculate. Food was cooked perfectly and tasted so good!! This coffee tho! Some places around did not have both good food and coffee... this place deff has both!!

Ok service? Literally best I've experienced in NYC. They're so kind and genuine here! You can tell they really enjoy their jobs and seek to connect, rather than just serve. If you don't come for the great coffee and toasts, come for the service alone. A new favorite cafe of mine!

Side note: not a workplace cafe, but a great place for a quick sip or bite.

Super cute coffee shop with great food, coffee and service!  

Whipped ricotta toast was great savory sweet brunch item.

The perfect place to stop by for a treat and cup of delicious coffee. The interior is cozy and warm, and service is just lovely. The owner is super friendly and makes you feel so welcome! The drinks were really good; we got a mocha and cappuccino. Will definitely be coming back to try the pastries and food and for more coffee!

I really loved this place, it's been a rainy day today so I didn't want to go far for some brunch. A bit of a queue but the guy in charge was really lovely and kept checking on us, had all our names down in order. When I got in, the service was really good and the food was delicious. Kept me full until after a matinee show. Would highly recommend.

This place smelled amazing walking by so my friends and I stopped for some lattes. One of the workers was trying to give good service by getting our orders fast but i felt rushed. I knew for sure I was rushed when they messed up two orders and my matcha latte ended up tasting like bitter ice water.I would understand if they were packed but we were the only group in there for drinks

TLDR. Very friendly somewhat pricey Aussie brekkie.

Our large flat whites were perfect, although I was hoping for more originality in the foam art.

A shakshuka on sourdough was beautifully plated. Came to $20 with a second egg. The yolks just beginning to solidify, the sauce savory.

All staff warm and friendly. A real pleasure.

Nice spot in Hudson Commons. Ham & Cheese Croissant and a Turkey Sandwich (That was supposed to be Tuna, but whatever we're low maintenance. It was fantastic!) Don't get the comments about rude or abrupt staff; everyone was great while we were there. Had to wait about 10 mins on a Friday at 11:30. No big deal. Highly recommended!

Food is delicious, the place is beautiful with all the natural morning light you would want, music is the perfect jazz meets alternative. The chai was so delicious, the bagel sandwich was really yummy!

Amazing vibes and amazing food! Thank you to the Aussie owner! We will be back next time we're in NYC.
Your Kentucky friends

That's is the place you want to remember and recommend ! Great owner, great staff, great ambiance, great food .... Love it !!!

Got there with a group of 8, the owner just made us feel like home !! He managed to get us seating in no longer time that a small latte !!!

Give it a try ! Ciao

I had the shakshuka toast. The flavors were great, with lots of warm spices and a perfectly poached egg. The prices are definitely a bit too high, but the quality is very high. The food was ready in a flash. There isn't much seating, so I'd recommend getting takeout.

I ordered an iced mocha and a brekkie bagel. The iced mocha was a bit bitter but decent, and the bagel sandwich was delicious though I didn't taste much of the aioli sauce. The space is quite small and there was constantly a line for the one restroom. Overall, the food and vibe were great, but everything was a bit overpriced.

This cafe is a must go! The food is absolutely delicious. We had the avocado toast, the shakshuka toast, and the lamington and I was in heaven. The ambiance is very welcoming and charming. The service we received was so amazing and we will definitely be back again. They made us feel welcomed and gave us an amazing experience!

Guy who I think had an European accent was very pushy and passive-aggressive. I felt very rushed to finish my food.

While we were middle on conversation, he gave a hand signal to kick us out, even though we didn't stay there for more than 20 minutes and most of the customers there stayed longer than us. He also gave us the receipt very quickly. When we left to pay, his last words were "here is economical," which isn't a professional way to talk to customers.

The food was overhyped and overpriced. We ordered the avocado toast and some coffee.

The other staff weren't as rude/pushy. They even smiled. Regardless, I am not coming back again.

This place BLINDSIDED me. My new favorite in Manhattan. Of course I discover it the day before i leave, or else I would have haunted it regularly. TAKE MY MONEY!!

I think this transported-from-Australia cafe is still relatively new but it seems like a steady stream of locals have already found out about it. It was buzzing when I walked in, and the baristas and owner seemed on good conversational terms with quite a few customers.

The space isn't huge but somehow the floor to ceiling windows and lighting and thoughtful arrangement of the shop makes it seem roomy, breathable and inviting. I love the minimal aesthetic. All the baristas and workers have a hip and friendly vibe.

I ordered a small cappuccino to go and was ready to walk to my next destination when I took a sip and gasped audibly LOL. I did not expect such a hip-looking trendy cafe to also have such good coffee. So I went back to inquire about what beans they use (the nice barista told me it's Gumption from australia , apparently it was the owners' fav beans back there and when they found a branch was roasting in Brooklyn they brought it over here). And I ordered a flat white, which was absolutely stunning.

Literally everything I had from here was flawlessly executed. Would definitely come back for more.

Amazing and outstanding experience.  I went with "my girlfriend" .  We were going to watch the Argentina game  and we decided to go eat breakfast first.  Great for a first date breakfast The atmosphere was great.. very helpful and friendly staff.
The food was great!!!  
I will definitely come back
Good food. Super staff - fast and very friendly.Tas could not have been more hospitable.

Great service and food! The waiter cared very much about our food and experience--we actually thought he was the manager or owner.  The cappucino was excellent,  reminiscent of the ones we had in Rome.  Husband had mocha, also good but he thought it could be a tad sweeter.  Very flavorful food, croissant with ham and cheese really good, bagel sandwich great.  They want everyone to enjoy the place, so no parking with your laptop.  In fact, they have a no-laptop policy.  Will def return.

I would give this place 10/10 or 100/100 whatever the full score is. This cafe combines food, coffee, bakery without compromising one another.

I tried their oat milk cold brew and it was divine. Dark roasted cold brew was not diluted by oat milk, which was so amazing. Also ordered banana bread and it was moist, wholesome and filling. Not too sweet.

I will definitely go back and try their lunch menu!

Update 5/19 .. I want to start by saying these people have mastered food & coffee. The menu options pair very well with the delicious coffee. I love their spicy tuna sandwich, it feels wholesome and made with great quality ingredients. The bread is toasted to perfection.

My husband & I always come here on days when we are working from home for a quick coffee date. I often see mums come in with their strollers and enjoy a quick meal over here.

The barista (won't share her name) went out of her way to get me a bag of decaf coffee beans. Everyone is super nice and chatty, which I love. Every time I visit this place I walk out with a smile, cause you know they give the best service. Can't wait to come here once baby girl arrives this summer. Needless to say I'm sticking with the decaf coffee for sometime.

Hoping that they soon start to keep their cafe open on the weekends.

I recently visited this cafe, and while the ambiance was pleasant, I was extremely disappointed by the staff's attitude. Their rudeness completely overshadowed any positive aspects of the experience. I won't be returning anytime soon.

A snazzy new Aussie coffee shop feels just like what this extension of Hudson Yards/Manhattan West neighborhood needs. Great indoor space and tables outside.
Are and drank:
Hot chocolate
Olive oil lemon cake
Total: $11:43 with tax
The hot chocolate was beautifully served, on the lighter side.
Olive oil cake was delicious
As the Australians have a reputation for great coffee I am headed back for a cuppa.

I have absolutely nothing negative to say about this place. We came when they got a little busy and they were very kind and accommodating as they tried to get us in. Seating opens up quickly so we didn't have to wait too long. Their flat white and latte was made well and the food came out quickly. While they were out of a few things, the shashuka toast was quite innovative and I throughly enjoyed it.

Great place to slow down, enjoy a tasty breakfast and relax. I love the Shakshuka taste, especially the blend of goat cheese and tomato. The soft boiled egg added a lot of tenderness and freshness to the toast. Staff were super friendly and welcoming as well.

The experience here is very similar to my experience going to Ichiran in Japan.

The prices are not cheap ($22 for standard bowl, around $30 if you add their meat/egg/mushroom/scallion/nori set), but the portions are massive and you do not pay tip.

I came here in a party of 2 on an early Sunday afternoon. We waited about 30 minutes in the line outside, then ordered on iPads inside and then waited another 10 or so minutes before being seated inside.

The ramen is very customizable, from the noodle firmness to the broth richness, spicy level, and amount of garlic. I highly recommend getting the soft egg because the yolk is so jammy and soaks up all of the delicious broth.

The noodles here are the thin type-- I usually prefer thick noodles but I was glad that you could customize how firm/soft you want your noodles to be.

All of the ingredients are very fresh and they give a massive portion of tasty broth.

I was already hungry when I got to the restaurant and waiting in line made me even hungrier, but by the end of my bowl I was completely stuffed!

If I am ever unsure of what ramen restaurant to eat at or just not in the mood to try a new place, Ichiran is a reliable spot where I know I can always get a good meal.

Ramen was good, but you have to wait in line outdoors to be seated, and at the booths, the partitions don't move in a way that you can see your friends better. I've heard that other ichirans do have the moveable partitions, so that was a bummer!

The portion size is big, but I wouldn't say it's quite worth the nearly $30 price tag to have the standard toppings that most ramens would come with.

Overall rating: 4.4

This place is so overhyped. I've been wanting to go here because I saw a LINE of people outside it a few years ago. I was very hopefully. I somehow went here with a friend and talking was very hard.

I like the solo experience but it was very confusing on ordering, how to order, lack of information, paying etc. I wish there were clearer instructions on what to do for newbies. I love ramen, but bc of the lack of communication - I knew I had to finish it or waste it. I didn't love that the eggs weren't jammy.

I'm not sure if I would recommend this place because I've been to SO MANY other better ramen spots. But it was decent & not terrible.

Ichiran in New York is an absolute gem! I don't usually like going out for ramen but I LOVE ichiran

Despite waiting for an hour on a weekday (in the rain!)  the food is consistent with the other locations in hong kong and tokyo. The service at Ichiran is impressively quick and efficient, ensuring that the wait time is kept to a minimum. The ordering process, with pen and paper, is a unique and hassle-free way to customize your ramen exactly to your liking, from the richness of the broth to the firmness of the noodles.

The ambiance at Ichiran is minimalistic and cozy, allowing you to fully immerse yourself in the ramen experience

Regenerate

I want to preface that if you're a big foodie who don't mind waiting in lines, this place is worth it. My friend and I waited an hour on a saturday night. They don't take reservations. I have to say, its as good as their japanese locations. The broth was so clean and not salty. The noodles had a bite and everything was very delicate. Definitely the best ramen I've had in the states.

I am put off by the dining experience here. Why even bother to bring a party when you're separated by partitions that block your peripheral vision? Also, when they let you inside, they confront you immediately with an utterly charmless iPad menu, right after leaving the line outside where you've probably been on your phone.

But even putting that aside, the ramen here doesn't live up to what restaurant ramen can be. My brother ordered a tonkotsu ramen, while I went with veggie ramen. Props on the broth - it was clear, yet packed with umami. On the other hand, it was also pushing the edge of saltiness, even for restaurant food, and especially for Japanese food. My brother also commented on the saltiness of his tonkotsu broth. In addition, the noodles were thin and had no texture profile. (I ordered the default firmness.) All in all, between a near overpowering broth and noodles that seemed very standard, the only place I was getting nuance was from the occasional scallion or mushroom in my bowl.

Ichiran is a hyped up ramen spot, and for a very good reason. When I came here, there was a line (as expected), but fortunately, the line isn't too bad. While waiting, you fill out a form with your order so that when you're seated, they can prepare it right away. Now, throughout the whole experience, food, decor, etc., everything was exactly like the Ichiran I experienced in Japan.

One thing that was different was that in this restaurant it's traditionally set up to be single stall booths for you to dine, however at this location, you can move a wall to chat with your friend or companion while dining. In regards to the food, it was phenomenal. Exactly like Japan, the broth is so rich and flavorful and I love how you can customize everything to your taste--from the saltiness, to the oiliness, to your toppings. Portions are great and you will be sure to be left full. I highly highly recommend to go with the set and get the pork as well as order a boiled egg! Would absolutely love to come back time and time again.

Is it expensive to come here? Yes. Is the wait in line very long? Also yes. Is the experience somewhat strange and off putting? Yet another yes. While this experience is not for everyone, I for one actually enjoyed the experience. Because for once, without people chatting with you, you can completely focus on the food in front of you. When you start focusing on the food, you start noticing the little touches that you might miss in a standard restaurant setting. The broth was very rich, and yet, not super heavy and dense. The noodles had the right balance of chew and springy texture. The slices of pork were tender and the egg had that perfect jellied yolk on the inside. Yes, the lack of human contact makes the meal feel cold and off putting at times, but it allowed me a moment with my food that you can never get anywhere else. Definitely worth a try if you are in the area :)

I had been meaning to try this ramen spot for the longest! I was in the area having a solo day and it felt like the perfect spot to go to.

Service is quick and easy. You're greeted and asked if you want to dine in or take out and you order on the iPad, pay then given your ticket. The ramen is customizable! I'm a believer in "im going to add rice to my soup even if it already has carbs" person and had to try the sticky rice which was yummy. The ramen was delicious and fresh! The pork, delicious!

As an introvert who has no problem dining alone this way of dining felt nice! The vibe is chill some people are alone others are sitting next to their friends. All the workers are friendly.

Overall great experience and would definitely return for the Ramen.

This place is an introvert's paradise. You come in, order your ramen at the front and wait to be seated at an open booth (I believe the original location in Japan allows you to order the ramen through a machine instead of a cashier). The booths are all single-seat and has dividers between you and the people next to you. You're here for one thing and one thing only, the ramen.

Sit down and hand your ticket to the servers and reach through the window and receive your food shortly after, without ever having to interact with anyone.

The ramen itself was good and the tonkotsu broth was rich and flavorful. I wouldn't say it was amazing, but you're here more for the experience. It was still good ramen, nonetheless. The meat was the star of the show, beautifully seared and tender. I did wish the egg was soft-boiled instead of hard-boiled, though.

Finished? Just get up and leave. Simple. Easy. Efficient.

Really great all the way around. I went with the recommended spice level, oil, noodle. Probably could have gone a bit spicier, but you could taste the spice with the recommended level. I really enjoyed the experience, I went at a slightly odd time, 4pm and had no wait. Liked it so much, I am considering going again before I head home ‍

I had Ichiran in Japan but ny husband hasn't. So we  decided to try it here in NYC. Came on a Friday night around 7:30 pm and the queue had 15 folks ahead.
The line moved quite fast and we ordered the combo set $30 and matcha pudding $9. This place is not intended for socializing as one shall eat alone in silence inside a booth and get out once done.
I understand there is inflation but $30 for a bowl of ramen is high, IMO. Broth was rich and flavorful. 4 thin slices of tender pork. Overall, it was ok.

I came here the first time last year, and it was a pleasant surprise. There's not much choice in the menu, it's simply ramen with some toppings and you can choose some extras, together with spicy, salt and oil levels. I have returned at least 7 times and their quality is solid, they never got my order wrong either.

The best ramen in New York City in my opinion. It s no frills no fuss. The flavor is flawless.
The pork broth is full of flavor and rich- but what is even better is you can customize if you want it more oily or less oily. I always go for the less oily (light) option and at other ramen spots it's the heaviness that throws me off which Ichiran has promptly fixed.
The noodles are perfect and Al dente and the pork belly is soft like butter. I don't usually get the recommended sides (for an additional $7.25) but they are sufficient if one wants seaweed, egg,  mushrooms and scallions on the side.
It s very popular too, we saw a line around the block on our way out.
The reason I took a star off is because I found it a little pricey ($22 for ramen with no add ons, $29.25 for ramen with recommended add ons mentioned above)
Ordered delivery. The ramen was perfect and packaged beautifully... Great meal and options!

Pleasantly surprised! I was honestly skeptical of coming here, given its popular reputation in Japan. But I was still excited to try because I love tonkotsu ramen and have always wanted to try Ichiran in Japan.

Upon entering, you'll be greeted by a host(ess) and two kiosks for ordering. There are two options for ramen: tonkotsu and veggie. You make your ramen, dessert, and drink selections at the kiosk and pay, then they will print an order/seat number for you. You'll take that, along with an order form, to your personal booth.

At the booth, you can customize how you like your ramen on the order form. Customizations include dashi (saltiness), richness (oil amount), minced garlic, scallions, chashu, original spicy red sauce level, and noodle texture. You can also indicate if you want to order the recommended toppings set (chashu, soft boiled egg, dried seaweed, scallion, and kikurage mushrooms), as well as other toppings and sides like yakibuta or rice.

Once you're ready, a staff member will take your sheet. You never see this person other than their hands. Between limited interaction with staff and partitions between your neighbors, Ichiran is the perfect solo meal.

Even though the price tag is steep, I thought my tonkotsu ramen was really, really good. Between the aromatic broth and the rich, spicy original red sauce, it's addicting. And because I customized it to my preferences, the amount of saltiness and richness was just right. The amount of noodles, chashu, and other ingredients was ideal too. I found myself satisfied but not revoltingly full. The only thing I would change for next time is not to order a matcha green tea (between the water and the broth, there was more than enough liquid for me).

Efficient, delicious, no frills - my experience at Ichiran Midtown makes me eager to try Ichiran in Japan.

I can see this being very popular for someone who is busy or grabbing a quick lunch during the work day. Sitting alone undisturbed: an introvert's dream. I did come with a friend, so I think I would've appreciated if we had the option to lift the barrier in between seats.

The ramen was very good. I definitely recommend it if you like thin noodles.

I think this is something that is worth trying once as a tourist, and eating more often if you're in the area, but maybe not more than 1-2x as a tourist.

This is some of the best ramen i've ever had. They specialize in one type of ramen that you can customize and it's definitely worth a stop.

I came around 8:15pm on a weekday with a friend and was still seated around 8:45pm. Even though there's usually a wait outside, they'll still seat you as long as you're there about 15-20 mins before close. Once you're in line, they'll give you a card to fill out for your ramen preference and you order/pay on an ipad before being seated. It's $22 before tax for the tonkatsu ramen but they have a no tipping policy which is really unique.

Once you're inside, you'll be seated at an individual booth with dividers on the side. This makes it the perfect place to come eat alone, so just know that going in as you won't be able to socialize much. You'll get your ramen handed to you from the screen in front and once you take a bite, you'll realize the wait was worth it. The broth is so flavorful yet clean tasting, and the noodles are the perfect texture. The chashu is also so tender and not too fatty which I prefer.

It's definitely not the cheapest bowl of ramen i've had, but I think it's worth a stop. Don't let the line deter you as it moves relatively quickly, but if you want to be seated fast I highly recommend coming alone. It's harder for seats right next to each other to open up so the singles would usually be seated right away.

NUFF SAID!!! There IS a reason this place has a line. No worries though. A good 20-30 in line and your lips will be caressing a spoon filled with THE MOST delectable TONKATSU Ramen, you'll have this side of the Yangtze. You're Welcome

I didn't get to experience the "booth" while in Japan so I had to go while in NYC!

**This is NOT for large parties nor is it for dinner conversations with friends. It's about the Japanese culture of quick (but delicious) meal to feed your soul after a busy day. You sit at a booth for one. Our party of 3 sat in booths next to each other so we were able to chat but it's all about the ramen  

A quick walk from our hotel, we arrived around 7:15 pm on a Tuesday night and queues up. They are very efficient in handling long lines so be polite and patient. (It does move quickly-we waited about 20 minutes) We were handed a paper to customize our ramen but you really order at the iPads once you get inside ‍(I was able to add an egg, seaweed, matcha ice tea to my tonkatsu ramen) Once you get inside the small foyer, you are directed to a kiosk to complete and pay for your order. Receipts are printed and handed to you to give to the server at the booth.

At the booth, the back "panel" opens and a server takes your receipts and comes back with your order. There's a button to call for help. I did find that my sides took a while and would have been nice to come at the same time. The broth was amazing!! So rich and deep. Be sure to stir the chili powder so it's incorporated. The noodles were al dente but got soggy near the end so eat quickly.

We didn't feel rushed and the meal was wonderfully satisfying. It was definitely worth the experience

Wow! This place is very delicious.
There is a line but it goes by quick. We went on a Sunday afternoon and waited about 30 minutes. The line situation can be confusing and allows for b people to butt the like because of the gap for the garage. Once inside, the staff was very courteous. Food was good, a bit salty for me towards the end.

Some of the best ramen broths I have ever had! So rich and flavorful!!! They are VERY generous with the chashu pork and noodles. I love that the pork was still tender without being overly fatty! Very enjoyable.

Coming to NYC, this was the #1 restaurant so many people recommended to me. This is a ramen chain straight from Japan and there's only a couple in the states. Even on a humid sunny summer day in Manhattan, I was determined to come here.

FUN FACT: In 2016, it became the first ramen shop to receive a Michelin Star! Very deserved.

Here were my ramen order preferences:
+ Medium Dashi
+ Firm Noodles
+ Rich Richness
+ 1/2 Clove Garlic
+ with Chashu

This has been on my list to try in NY for awhile. I was so happy to come at around noon and there was no wait! You eat in individual stalls (perfect for slurping and wiping away runny noses in private lol). Ramen was so good and the broth was rich and full of flavor. You order at the front via a tablet and then they'll tell you which stall you're at. Water is self served. Experience was great. Definitely coming back when I'm back in NY.

This was our last stop in NYC and it didn't let us down. The last time we have been here was four years ago before the pandemic.

This location opens at 11am and there was a 8 people line when we arrived around 11:05am. It didn't take too long for us to get in. The whole ordering process was very smooth. You order everything at the entrance using an iPad. You can also order more food at the seat.

We ordered a recommended set and a classic set. The food came within 5 mins after the server took our order slips. We also ordered a Match beer which I would not recommend, because of the price ($10 for a small glass) and the fact that it lacked Match flavor. The ramen and the broth were very delicious. The chashu tasted alright so I would not recommend to order more meat.

Overall it was a pleasant and enjoyable experience and I would definitely come again!

Definitely reminiscent of the Ichiran in Japan, I would say the broth is SLIGHTLY less flavorful than the one in Japan and they give less meat portions here, but very very close. At about $30 a bowl, if you're missing Japan OR you've really wanted to try Ichiran, I say go.

THE BEST RAMEN hands down! It's my favorite chain in Japan. I live in Boston and whenever I make a trip to NYC I must visit one of the ichiran locations. I've been to all 3. You're able to customize your ramen bowl (chewiness of noodles, thickness of broth, amount of spice, etc), but I always choose the standard recommended options. Sometimes I add an egg or nori. The broth is a bit salty but it's really unique, you cannot find a bowl like this anywhere else. The noodles are chewy and so fresh. Don't be afraid to add some spice too. When I'm feeling fancy I end the meal with a matcha pudding. It is lovely.

Pros:
- cool vibe, it's quite an experience. You can sit alone in comfort if you'd like.
- feels like you're in Japan
- delicious food, and always consistent
- NYC is the only place you can find this in the US
- take home kits available for purchase

Cons:
- quite pricey for a bowl of ramen, although tip is included
- there can be a long line, depending on the time of day

Yum!!! Couldn't get reservations to Tonchin so we had Ichiran.  This is a chain from Japan and we've also had it there.  Ordering and payment is done when you enter, then you are escorted to individual booths. There you fill out on a paper which accompaniments you want such as green onions, chasu, or woodear mushroom.  Then you select the heat you want and how you want your noodles done.  The person on the other side opens a small bamboo curtain and takes your order. Food comes very quickly!
A very efficient way to feed a lot of people, there's no lingering while patrons chat over their ramen. Focus on food, eat, then leave.  It's a great experience, very casual.  I will say the price was eye watering for a bowl of ramen but there was a lot of food, it's NYC, and no tipping!

10 years ago, I had the best ramen in my life in Japan at an Ichiran so I make sure to stop by here on this New York trip. There's many ramen places to choose from in Japan so although the place was popular and busy, there was never a wait to be seated since everybody is in a rush to just eat and go. Came here on a Sunday night and the line was out the door, when you think you've reached the end, keep going, there's a gap to not block the parking lot, but the line continues. Ahh at last, after an hour of waiting in line. This location has a digital kiosk that you order and pay first before taking a seat where other location gives you a paper to fill out your custom order and you take a ticket to go up to a cashier  to pay afterwards.

A damn delicious bowl of ramen is about $20, they don't accept tips. You can order extra noodles for a small fee. Love at first sip, so incredibly mind-blowing as I remembered it nearly a decade ago.

Tell me about your experience if you've been here or is going to after reading this review:)

A true, Japanese ramen spot experience!

Ichiran is meant to be more of an individual dining experience. I first ordered on the tablet and then we were told to be seated at each individual booth where we hand our receipt to our chef in front of us. From this moment on, it took about 10 minutes or less to get my piping bowl of ramen. There is also a blind they pull down so that you have privacy while eating. On the table, there is a button you can press if you want to order more. Water cups are located beside the wall.

This style of dining is great for individual diners as everyone eats in their individual "cubicle".

The broth was rich and delicious. The ramen noodles were okay for me- a bit too thin but everyone has their own preferences. The texture was spot-on- not too chewy or hard.

Pro tip: Come early as this place can get super busy plus there are no reservation opportunities.

Quick, no frills and my own little booth tucked away in the back to get some silence after a long day of virtual meetings? The perfect way to spend an early dinner after work if you ask me.

Of course the ramen is the highlight of the show and the simplicity of the menu is the best. The spicier broth and the chasu are a great compliment to the tasty noodles and the mushrooms in this big bowl of comfort. I do wish the egg were marinated, but nonetheless still a great option to have. A great flavorful portion filled with many of your favorite ramen fixins.

This is a must to visit when you just need to sit alone and dine without the fuss of waiters or other diners around. They just opened up a second location in midtown which is a great option to have, now just hoping for another further uptown!

Having a bad day and just want to eat in peace? Go to Ichiran!

Ambiance (5/5): If you're going with family or friends and want to chat over food, Ichiran's probably not the place to be. However, if you simply want to enjoy your food with little interaction, definitely pay a visit here. The seating arrangement is similar to individual cubicles, where you don't have to engage in conversation with your neighbors if you don't want to. In fact, the most interaction you'll have with the staff is when they confirm your orders, deliver your food, and take your payment.

Service (5/5): Just because there's little interaction doesn't mean the service isn't good. Everyone was very friendly and ensured that you enjoyed your experience.

Food (5/5): I wish I had brought home the Take-Home Ramen Kits from Ichiran... I had a major craving for another bowl of Ichiran after returning home. Although I'm not a big fan of thin noodles, Ichiran's noodles were the perfect match for their flavorful broth. The kick from the Spicy Seasoning made the soup addictive; I had to finish it all. I also ordered their soft-boiled egg, which could be skipped since it didn't necessarily add to the overall flavor of the bowl.

I heard the wait can get pretty crazy, which is understandable since there are only a handful of seats available at once. Regardless, if you're in the area, please do pay a visit!

My husband and I had Ichiran for the first time when we went to Japan a few years ago during pre-pandemic times. It was so good that we dined twice (at separate locations). I was a little apprehensive that it wouldn't taste the same here in the US, but I was totally proven wrong!

There are two types of ramen: the classic tonkatsu (pork) broth ramen and the veggie ramen. There are also optional add-ons such as premium marinated pork, kikurage mushrooms, and soft boiled eggs. As for beverages, they have the typical sodas plus Caplico and Ramune (Japanese soda), sake, and Asahi Super Dry beer. When ordering your ramen, a sheet is presented for you to circle off your preferences from flavor strength or noodle texture, allowing you to customize your bowl to your liking.

As other reviewers mentioned, Ichiran is an introvert's dream due to its private ramen style booth dining. A call button is available at each booth in case you're in need of service or would like to order additional items.

Prices are higher than one would expect for a bowl of ramen, but let's blame it on #inflation.

Stopped by for a bite and made it right before the lunch rush. I had heard this place was fairly busy, bringing in people from all over to try their tonkatsu ramen. This place was well worth the travel. With ramen made customizable to your liking, I got a rich broth with a nice spice that wasn't too overwhelming, served with the most tender pork I've ever had. The portion sizes were large with options to add more if needed. An ideal please for solo dining, as everyone is sat in individual booths for a personalized experience. I will definitely be back!
Very good but, pricey!! They should also add some heat lamps to the outside line area.
Popped by with some friends to try out something new. The service was good, it was a weekday so not too loud or busy. The food was decent, not the most flavorful in my opinion but still a nice bowl.

Their ramen is very consistent and reliably high quality!! I came here on a Wednesday night and there was no wait.

I like to get my noodles extra firm and spice level 4, which is enough for just a kick without losing the flavor.

Service was quick. I would come here again!

The line for this place gets a little confusing, as you order on the screen up front then line back up for a seat. The seats are all individual and a chef hands you your ramen through a screen. You get to choose how much flavor and spice you want up front, along with any sides. There is also an option to order more once seated. The restaurant in a way builds tip into the price. Overall, good ramen spot.

Now instead of ordering at your seat, you order at tablets at the entrance. Then the staff direct you to free seats available and once seated, they'll take your receipt and bring you whatever you ordered. I think you can also order additional items at your seat, as I saw ordering sheets hung on the side.

Ramen here is kind of expensive at almost $20 for a bowl (includes charsiu but no egg). Their spicy seasoning isn't too bad, medium was okay for me. Just be sure to mix it well beforehand.

I wanted to try this place in Japan but couldn't so I tried it in NY. Honestly way too expensive ($30) for what it is but the flavor alone gives this place 4 stars for me. Very well crafted ramen, just wish it wasn't so pricey. Fun experience with the solo eating booths too. Great ambiance inside. Be careful though, tends to be a line outside almost always!

An introvert's dream restaurant! As a solo traveler, this was the perfect spot to grab a meal without feeling self-conscious. Enjoy your ramen in your own booth, call your server using a button, and order without even having to talk to anyone!

What I got:
- Classic Tonkatsu Ramen with Mild Spice

Final thoughts:
The space isn't completely silent as people still come in groups, but most solo diners can be seen wearing headphones or doing their own thing. The ramen itself I found had a very flavorful and rich broth. The hidden no tare (spice) that comes with the ramen is made of over 30 spices aged over several days so it added a nice kick. I did find that the noodles were still on the softer side even when I ordered them medium so I'd get firm if you like your noodles with a bit of a bite.

A good meal that met expectations even though it is now a chain with multiple locations.

For $31 (tonkatsu + toppings), the value per meal is brutal.
The experience at the individual seats was unique but thats about it. My server even forgot the toppings till i asked about it so i was even more initially shellshocked by what i actually got. Ultimately, even if you're in the vicinity i dont think its worth the visit

Ichiran
The solo booth ramen spot. Getting in around 5pm weekday was a quick check in. There's a checklist of what to order and the employees serve you what you checked off. In black and white, you get what you order. Broth was so rich!! The meat was very tender and the noodles was the right amount of chewiness. The topping set with the noodles was the right amount. The side dish of meat, is basically the same topping on the ramen set. I thought it would be different but not so much. It was too much meat to finish. Overall, good spot to check with rich ramen. Water is behind the chairs with coat hangers under your table or behind as well.

Ichiran is a must-visit for ramen lovers! As soon as you walk in, you place your order before even sitting down. Once you've ordered, they'll guide you to your own private booth, which is great for solo diners and groups alike. The staff are super respectful and welcoming, even though you don't actually see them--the booths have covers in front.

Now, let's get to the good stuff--the ramen. I went for the traditional bowl with some extra toppings, and the broth was a knockout. Rich, spicy, and you get to choose your spice level from 1-10. For those curious, 2-3 offers a good kick and 4 cranks it up a notch but is totally manageable.

Feeling extra hungry? No worries. You can easily order more by marking it down on a paper. This place gets a solid 5/5 from me--both the experience and the food are off the charts!

I was feeling cold and craved soup for lunch. Not just any soup. It had to be Ramen. On this day, it had to be Ichiran.
As a foodie, I have observed the following about certain businesses: 1. Some have a great marketing and promotion campaigns in place 2. Many people have FOMO  ( I can be guilty of this at times) 3. The above (along with the good food), results in being a "must visit" restaurant.

Arriving  just shy of 12 PM, there was a mini line in place. It moved rather quickly and the person in front passed a clipboard to the person behind him/her to place your customized food order. It was very systematic.

Luckily, an employee asked if it was my first time (it was) since I was actually completing the pork Ramen soup order.  I was quickly given the vegetarian. Phew. Anyway, you have the opportunity to review your order once seated.
The seating arrangement was a bit strange.

A little cubby hole with a backless stool served as the place to eat. A bamboo shade was in place and when the faceless server lifted it, you're able to ask questions and confirm the order. I really couldn't  see the person--i just heard him/her.

The veggie soup came inclusive of minced garlic, scallions and noodles ($22). It was recommended to order the sides (soft boiled egg, seaweed and mushroom) for an additional $7 to make the soup more filling. Okay, done.
Water was help yourself  at the several coolers situated against the wall. I ordered a Diet Coke ($3) instead.

Sides arrived first. Soup followed.
Opinion?
It was really very good.
The broth was rich without being salty. The noodles were thin and flavorful with a somewhat firm texture. The toppings (lightly salted soft boiled egg, scallions, slivered mushrooms and seaweed) were the perfect accompaniment.
The soup didn't weigh me down and was executed very well with different levels of a flavor explosion.

Million dollar question. Was it worth $31?
I'd have to say NO. I've had Ramen Soup across Manhattan that were also very good, equally good or better. Totto Ramen is one of my faves.

Ichiran has a hype surrounding it and yes, there was a New York Times write up. It was very, very delicious. I just think their prices were a bit elevated.
Come on--broth and noodles?!?

BTW this is a no tip establishment.

Such a cute and cool idea, I love the whole dining alone experience made comfortable. I had really really high hopes for this place, a chain from Japan! I expected to like it more than any other ramen place I have been to. I didn't. It was bland, I ordered the spicy ramen and it wasn't spicy at all. I didn't like how the toppings came on the side and you had to put it in yourself, they came cold and I enjoy how the flavours of the topping infuse with the ramen. I love the concept and really wish I liked this place, but definitely not the ramen for me.

Ramen more expensive than Ippudo? Yes, at $22/bowl, but there may also be a reason because these guys are definitely up to the challenge of rivalry. I went yesterday, on a Saturday afternoon around 4pm, because I was in the area and heard the line for this place can get crazy, but it was only 3 ppl deep (probs because it was an 80 degree May day, so most wouldn't go for a warm bowl of ramen). I understand the line though; you can only get in if there's an open seat inside. Each "seat" is a single-serve "booth", lined up like cubbies from grade school. If you're in a group, you can request to be sat adjacent to each other. Once you're allowed entry, you place your order on an ipad and you're shuttled to an available booth shortly after. There are 2 rows of them, on either side of the "kitchen" in the middle, and your ramen is slid to you right in the cubby.

This place ONLY serves tonkatsu ramen, the SOLE menu option (the only real side being a bowl of white rice), which is pretty unique. They are also a no-tip establishment, rare to find, but likely because there's no waiters. Knocking a star for the following:

-I specifically requested no scallions and they threw them in there anyway.
-The ramune soda is not the original Sangaria Ramune brand. Luckily, it still tasted fine.
-The seats are all small backless stools; it would be great if they were a little more comfy/ergonomic.

But the ramen IS delicious. It doesn't take long to come out, the broth is creamy, flavorful, and possibly the best ramen broth I've ever encountered. I rarely actually sip the broth, but I drank half the bowl, especially after reading the nutritious benefits of it (bone broth, collagen, etc...). The chashu looked a bit different than others, but it was tender and delicious. They don't rush you at all either; they encourage you to take your time, relax, and really soak in the flavor. When you're done, you just leave your bowl there and bounce.

I will definitely be adding this place to my rotation, especially since it's so single-seater-friendly. Even the ambient music that sounds like you're an adventurer in an RPG who's just stumbled upon a tavern in a quaint town.

Second time here! Couldn't find the picture of the first time but this place is inconsistent in my opinion. My first visit I felt like the broth was richer and flavorful. It also came in a closed box shaped bowl.

The second time, it felt so oily, especially with all the add ons, I thought it was going to be better but it felt like I was drinking straight butter.

The vibe inside is just like the usual ichiran places - single stall so great place for if you're eating alone.

I love coming here for lunch whenever I go into the city as it's a short walk from my office. For the best experience and no wait time, try to go during the off peak hours because the line outside can get really long!

The ramen here reminds me of Japan as it follows the classic look and taste. I've also had their matcha pudding and it's absolutely delicious! The only thing I have an issues with is that it's pretty pricey. Especially since I've only paid about $12 whenever I went in Japan as opposed to nearly $50 a meal here.  

The service is great and perfect for introverts haha it's also super clean! The wait time for your order once you're seated is almost nonexistent. It's a classic spot and I recommend if you would like to be reminded of the ichiran in Japan.

It was a rainy day and just opened. Didn't expect a line outside but everyone seemed to be craving some ramen. It wasn't a long wait, and when I got inside, they showed me to a tablet to order my food and only waited for a minute to be seated. It was my first time and they explained where everything was and how to order from the booth. When I got to my seat, I was greeted again by someone from the otherside of the booth, kindly explaining what to do with my recipe/order I had placed. It was a nice experience, hooks under the table on opposite sides. So I could place my umbrella and bag down.

The food came out and I placed my chosen toppings on top. Delicious broth and the noodles were really good. Egg was nicely cooked and yolk still gooey. I would definitely come back on a cold or rainy day.

No tipping here. You pay when you order something. After I finished my food I could just leave.

Let me start by having a disclaimer: I have been to Ichiran in Tokyo and the one in NYC. I have also been to countless ramen places in search of that authentic ramen place, and in the US, Ichiran is the CLOSEST thing to authentic Japanese Ramen. The NYC Ichiran experience is as close to the Tokyo Ichiran experience as I can remember.

What is Ichiran? Ichiran is a renowned ramen restaurant that has garnered a dedicated following around the world, and rightfully so. I recently had the pleasure of dining at Ichiran and the experience was nothing short of exceptional.

What sets Ichiran apart is its unique approach to ramen. Upon entering the restaurant, you are greeted by a calm and serene atmosphere. I felt like the NYC location transported me to Kyoto for a brief hour. My wife and I were placed in an individual booth, and we both knew we had work to do; we had to focus on the ramen.

The star of the show at Ichiran is their signature tonkotsu ramen. The broth is rich, creamy, and full of depth, created through a meticulous process of simmering pork bones for hours. There truly is NO other ramen place like that in the US. Let me say that again, there is NO other place like this in the US.  The noodles are perfectly cooked to your preference, whether you like them firm or soft. I always go for slightly firm. The toppings, such as tender slices of chashu (braised pork), spring onions, and their secret spicy red sauce, complement the ramen beautifully.

One unique aspect of Ichiran is their customizable ordering system. Before entering the booth, you can use a simple form to customize your ramen experience to your liking. They utilize a vending machine so you definitely get the full Japanese experience. Here at the vending machine you select your broth flavors, your add-ons, your noodle tenderness, etc.

The service at Ichiran is efficient and discreet. After placing your order, the ramen is served promptly, ensuring that it arrives piping hot. The staff is attentive, yet respectful of your privacy, providing you with a satisfying and seamless dining experience. The literally lift a curtain to hand you your bowl of ramen, bow out, and leave you in peace!

If you are in NYC, please check this place out. Is this the best ramen place in the whole world? No. Is it the best place in NYC that is walking distance from the subway system? Absolutely. For the price, it cannot be beat.

To Ichiran - Thank you for the wonderful experience.

Day and time : Friday 6:30pm

Found this online as a recommendation : tasting menus under $100 .  With inflation, it's becoming harder to justify paying for mediocre food.  My friend and I decided to try out this place as it looked cute from online photos .  It didn't disappoint- the place is cute , with high ceilings and open layout .  Given the name , I expected more floral arrangements and though nicely decorated , it could use more flowers.

We first sat at the bar to served by an attentive and helpful bar staff .  We made it to happy hour and availed of the specials .  

Restaurant wasn't very full when we got there but mid meal , more patrons came.  I'm not sure what it is but despite the friendly staffs , ambiance , I felt that this place need a little bit more .  

On the food - we opted for the tasting menu as this is what we came here for in the first place .  I wish they spent more time explaining the dishes but by memory we had ravioli stuffed with ricotta , burrata with tomatoes and another dish .  They were food but the texture of the burrata and ravioli were too similar ( perhaps another dish like a salad or another texture would be better ). Second dish was the tagliatelle hand made pasta ( with the pinch of salt, it was better).  Bread was served but due to the amount of food , we saved it for the short ribs served with mashed potatoes and corn ( this was our favorite ) .   Desserts consisted of gelato which was on the softer side and pannacotta with granita .  

We also decided to go for the wine pairing which in hindsight we should have just ordered a bottle of our choosing .  

I would give this is 3.5-4 rating because of the space , friendliness of the owners and with improvement on their dinner service ( explaining the meals better and just having a little bit more energy and putting more thought about the tasting menu : variety of texture that's complimentary , incorporating farm to table like ingredients or flowed into the food  and instead of purely pairing worth wine , include a cocktail ), this can easily be a 4.5 place .  

I might go back and check out the brunch menu.

This is a chic and large space, but the food didn't impress me, especially for the price point. Th fish burger lacked a lot of flavor. Our food also took a long time to come out. But, the side potatoes were crispy and delicious. Maybe worth going to try one of their pastas!
LOVED it here - amazing drinks, food, and ambiance. Would love to come during the day for the flower shop part!

If bland, overpriced food is your bag, this is your place. We started with meatballs as an appetizer. Not flavorful, sauce was thin and watery. We paid for bread - came out with a cup for I presume olive oil but only with some dry seasoning and spice at the bottom. Whoops. We had the rigatoni carbonara rosso and the chicken. Not sure how something is a carbonara without egg, pancetta or cheese. The sauce was akin to Campbell's tomato soup. The chicken was bland as if it was boiled then finished in an oven. Again, the theme of the night bland and flavorless. Osso bucco special at another table looked nice but hey they were sold out before 6 PM. I recommend the chef pursue employment as a hospital cafeteria.
Came here on a Saturday, not a long wait. The spring-like décor feels like stepping into a AD magazine cover. Food was deliciously unique, highly recommend

Lovely environment-we each had a couple of the signature cocktails. Not a heavy pour but lovely. Appetizers ( burrata and olives) were both lovely! Special call out about the peppers. We split a salad that had sliced fennel I believe-it was fine. The pasta was lovely with a meaty sauce snd we ended with the steak that was ok, nothing remarkable. But super toasted potatoes-very hot, then creamy. All in all a lovely, if pricey meal. Service was super attentive snd right there when needed.
Both my coffee cup and pasta plate were dirty. The pasta also had some hair or cloth string in it. Won't be coming back

We had SUCH an amazing time here before a birthday party we were going to across the street! We came for dinner and drinks but I think our hostess Ali was the highlight of our evening - she gave us all the best recs, and when it started raining she even walked us across the street to the party with the restaurant's huge out door patio umbrellas so that we wouldn't get wet - what hospitality!

We ordered the trout appetizer (incredible!), the potatoes, pappardelle and one more pasta. Surprisingly the trout app was my fave!

The tasting menu here is phenomenal! Even though it's 4 courses it's really several items. Unfortunately got too hungry and couldn't take photos of all the courses. Olives, bread, salad and burrata to start. Burrata and bread were both delicious!

For the pasta course they gave us this red sauce pasta that to us tasted way too fishy. We were disappointed because all the other reviews mentioned the lavender papardelle which we hoped to try. We mentioned this to our waiter and he added it on to our next course for free! Next course was the short rib - pretty good but not as good as the lavender pasta. Finally finished with dessert (but by now we were stuffed).

We also got the wine pairing - very nice pours! We will be coming back!

Came here for a birthday celebration. The service was great - they took really good care of our party of 10. The interior is also super cute - great for a girls' night out or brunch.

Now on to the not-so-good stuff... We ordered two pastry baskets, which we were enjoying until my friend found a small rock in the biscotti as she was eating it. The manager addressed the incident promptly and was extremely apologetic and offered to make things right.

I ordered the Shashuka for my main and didn't like that the eggs were overcooked. Not sure if this is indeed how they do it here, or the eggs just sat in the skillet for too long as they were getting the rest of our orders ready, but the egg yolk was too solid for me to enjoy. It also had way too little harissa sauce to be a proper Shakshuka and was more like baked eggs instead. The scallion fritters were good tho.

Il Florista has the right idea, because having a restaurant in a flower shop is genius. As such, I came with high expectations, expecting Il Florista to showcase the best of its flower offerings, but the flowers seem to be the afterthought.

My best friend and I arrived at Il Florista and were seated immediately for our reservation on a Friday
night (which we didn't need because the restaurant was far from full). We decided to order the chef's menu instead of the restaurant week menu in addition to the thorn in my side, suddenly last summer, butterfly kiss, and lavender pollinator cocktails.

We expected to be served 4 dishes but we were served 10 dishes (I'm not complaining!). We were served the stracciatella, trout tartare, satsuma mandarin + dandelion greens, off-menu fussili, squid ink cavatelli, bread, salmon with beans, hangar steak, semifreddo, and a coconut sorbet with strawberries.

Starting with drinks:

- The thorn in my side cocktail was a perfect mix of sweet, floral, and refreshing without masking the taste of the mezcal. 10/10

- Suddenly last summer was beautifully presented but tasted very watered down. My best friend informed the waiter and he immediately replaced it with the butterfly kiss cocktail.

- The butterfly kiss cocktail was really sweet, and when the cocktail gets warm the sweetness is unbearable.

- The lavender pollinator cocktail was strong and the floral notes from the lavender complimented the gin very well.

Food highlights:

Stracciatella - the sweet green tomatoes and creamy straciatella mixed with the summer squash is great! Very light and refreshing and served with several seeded crackers.

Trout tartare toast - very flavorful and seasoned well. Great way to start our meal.

Off-menu fussili - the fussilli was coated in a lemon sauce with basil and cheese. When you're not expecting it, the lemon can be overwhelming at first. But the more you eat it, the better it gets. I wish they gave us two servings of this pasta.

The average:

Satsuma mandarin + dandelion greens - the combination of flavors is great but the balance isn't there. I find that there are too many dandelion greens without enough toppings. Since the dandelion greens are very bitter, if you don't have a bite of the greens with a piece of orange, goat cheese, or raisin, you're gonna regret it.

Bread - it's warm and fresh. The taste is fine, nothing to complain about. They also give you a lot.

Salmon with beans - the salmon is tender and the skin is crispy. The beans are served on the side. This tasted average.

Hangar steak - cooked to medium rare topped with corn, mint, and some unidentified leaves. The dish came together well with the sweetness of the corn and the refreshing mint complementing the beef. Pretty good but not a standout.

Coconut sorbet with strawberries - a mildly sweet end with a fruity finish. The coconut sorbet is creamy and light and the strawberries and fresh. The dark chocolate shavings are a nice touch.

The duds:

Squid ink cavatelli - this tasted fine and I liked the touch of fennel and saffron but there were a few issues with this dish. The cavatelli was slightly undercooked making the pasta a little chewy in addition to the calamari being slightly overcooked which creates the same problem. It would also be nice if the sauce was cooked for longer to bring out the flavors more.

Semmifreddo - the texture is very off-putting. There's an unpleasant graininess that is consistent throughout the dish. Even though the dessert tasted fine, the texture could not be overlooked.

Despite the rollercoaster quality of the food and drink, the service and atmosphere is impeccable. Our waiter was friendly and professional (similar to how the michelin star waitstaff are). Our waiter periodically came to check on us throughout our meal but was not overbearing. The waiter made sure that the suddenly last summer cocktail was taken off our check (since it was barely touched). The backdrop is chic bohemian and the noise level is reasonable. The style definitely matches the flowershop restaurant.

I think I would rate Il Florista a 3.5 but closer to 4 stars than 3. Il Florista has the potential to nail the food and drink because the flavors are there. With minor tweaks here and there, I would be willing to come back and try more of the menu.

We booked this restaurant for dinner for my friends birthday
It was easy to get in a reservation for a group for 7 so that worked out well for us. We were promptly seated in a room which was well lit and decorated.
I must say the cocktails were delish and worth the price averaging around 20$ for a drink. I loved my drink - lavender pollinator which was tequila based with floral taste.
They had limited dinner options and ended up getting fusili. It was just okay and wanted to add in meat but we weren't allowed to customize it
Definitely more of a fine dining place.

It was quite busy for a mid week night and maybe that might be the reason the service was quite slow. Anyways might be good for a office dinner or a quite date !

We visited during a weekend for a brunch. The inside was bigger than I expected, bright and vibrant, fun and modern.

We started off with Coffee, made with a real-deal espresso machine at the end of the bar. We asked for milk on the side a the time of order, and the staff brought our coffee with milk that was heated up!!! How awesome is that! They do NOT offer free refill, but when the coffee is this good, and made fresh per cup, I can understand...

For food, we ordered Shakshuka and Il Fiorista BLT. The Shakshuka was kind of a let down. First of all, it was small... and I mean, tiny. The eggs were completely cooked, which was sad. Fritter were nice, but it did not wow me. It didn't have much of the sauce, making this dish to be more on the dry side. Overall, it was a disappointing dish.

The BLT was more like a burger, with bacon marmalade similar to ground meat texture. Like a fancy Sloppy Joe. Eggs was done perfectly here. It was very flavorful, each bite was a delight!

Since the food portion was rather small, we decided to get some desserts. We ordered Lemon Meringue Tart and Black Cardamom Semifredo. They were both amazing! They do excellent desserts (and coffee) here.

The staffs were very friendly and polite, and the food came out super fast! Although the Shakshuka was a bit of disappointment, everything else was great.

We had dinner with friends here last week and had a great time! The food was incredible and our favorite dishes were the burrata and the gnocchi. The gnocchi was so soft it just melted in your mouth!

We also loved all the floral touches to the dishes. We were expecting there to be more of a floral design to restaurant itself but that wasn't the case - it was still a really cute setup! The service was wonderful as well. Would definitely recommend this place for a date night or dinner with friends!

This is a cute, upscale restaurant that's also a floral boutique! You can get a hand-tied floral bouquet on your table for $35-$65 if you want. My friend and I were just there for the food so we didn't get one, but we saw some people who did and they looked lovely. We had a 6pm reservation for 2, and it wasn't busy when we first got there but almost every table was occupied around 7-8pm.
We liked the unique options they offered on their restaurant week menu. We chose the dandelion greens+castelfranco salad, trout tartare toast, wild craft farms polenta, marinated tilefish, almond torte and semifreddo. Almost everything was really good! Portion sizes were about what you'd expect - not enough to be truly filling, but still decent. I especially like the tilefish and the semifreddo. The tilefish was tasty and the potatoes with it were really nice as well. The semifreddo was a bit intense but in a good way. I have to admit I really did not like the dandelion greens salad though, and neither did my friend. It was pretty bland and the flavors in it didn't work together at all. That was the only dish that we didn't finish. However, we had a great time chatting and enjoying everything else there!
Come by if you're in the area, especially if you want to admire some pretty flowers.

Came here with friends for celebration and had high expectations but unfortunately we were disappointed. Cocktails were expensive $19-$21 and tasted very very average. I had the sweet potato pasta and was amazed how tiny the portions were. Finished in 2 bites and  when my friend wanted to try a piece there wasn't any left. Also because we waited a long time for our food (large party) but really long time too. Interior is cute and they had nice bathrooms. If you are here for a $$$$$ & little bites of food kind of first date / trying to stay on a super model diet, come here.

The food was very very salty, and the staff was great at first in checking in with our group but then after a while they stopped checking in when we needed the check it took such a long time to haul someone down.

TLDR: very pretty brunch place although selected brunch menu, with a great ambience, takes reservations, and good quality food!

Came here for weekend brunch, I love that this place took reservations for brunch - I no longer want to wait hours for brunch spots in nyc that are notorious for not taking reservations for brunches. Made a reservation on brunch and was seated pretty quickly.

Walking in, the ambience of the room was phenomenal, tall ceiling with a beautiful bar that takes up one side of the room and a centerpiece made of fresh flower bouquets.

The coffee here is made by a barista that is right by the bar so you can see that they grind coffee beans and everything is freshly made.

The food for brunch was a limited selection but quite a unique take. I got the shakshuka which is traditionally served with bread but they served it with chickpea fritters - I really liked this twist, something I haven't seen before.

Super happy with the experience here and definitely would come here again.

Came from a pulsd deal and thought we would try this place out given the positive reviews on Yelp and google. Super disappointed and underwhelmed with the interior, food, and service.

The chicken ($34) was beyond bland and unseasoned. Idk what that burrata dish was, it had some stale popcorn kernels on it paired with grapes and pears.

The pappardelle was also super bland ($26) not worth the price for some pasta with a bit of cheese on it.

Despite the pulsd deal, after tax and tip, it really wasn't that great of a value. Don't know how anyone would pay full price for this place, when we barely thought it was a good deal using a coupon ($89 for the pri fixe + $17 for tax/tip)

Service was beyond slow, took almost 30 mins after the app for the mains to come out

Dessert was the orange blossom fried donut item. Just ok as well

Drinks were strong and good which was the only upside

A restaurant in a flower shop. This is why I pay sky-high rates to live in NYC.

We started with the Seeded Cracker and a half portion of the mashed cauliflower. Believe the hype about the Seeded Cracker--it's like crack. Haha, get it? I mean, I'm spending time describing a cracker. It's a damn good cracker. A big, crispy, flavorful, healthy, gorgeous piece of crunch. Get it. Don't regret it.

The pastas weren't quite as impressive. The Pappardelle was a tad overcooked, though the lemon sauce was nice. The Campanelle had a similar flavor and was a bit more interesting. The special of the day pasta--something in a red wine osso buco sauce--was by far the best, but bizarrely served in a flat plate instead of a bowl and no bread, both of which would've been better for sopping.

But the cocktails are the real showstopper. Flowers in everrrrrthing! Try the Cheeky Damson (strong), Thorn in My Side, (less strong), Alpine Spritz (light), and Lavender Pollinator (light like a grandma). Flower Power, y'all!

Service was Michelin-level friendly without any of the awkward obsequiousness. Come here before more people discover it.

Really cute cafe with a floral theme and aesthetic presentation

Overall: 4.5/5
Food: 4.5/5
Decor: 5/5
Presentation: 5/5

Great indoor and outdoor seating with adorable decor and great food. Had a mandarin and dandelion salad ($19), also stinging nettle ricotta toast  ($18), and a floral latte ($5). Portions were fairly substantial and beautifully plated. Great setting for brunch with friends in the Flatiron area. Would recommend!

Not a fan.  At all.  My husband arrived first and ordered me a cocktail.  The rim of the glass was dipped in charcoal.  Who thought this was a good idea?  It was disgusting.  We had the trout tartare toast.  One bite convinced me I did not need any more of that in my life.  Maybe a good place to see and be seen?  To take pictures of yourself?  I don't know.

Enjoyed our visit to Il Florista.  This is an interesting establishment - a restaurant, bar, café, florist, boutique and community education space.  We enjoyed the Strocciatella,  apple and fennel spinach salad, chicken and grilled black maitake.   All were good as was the service.  Friendly service in a warm environment.  A good neighborhood restaurant worth a visit.

What a fantastic experience.

We found this place on Google while looking for spots with tasting menus that were reasonable, and this fit the bill perfectly. The interior is very cool (and floral), the atmosphere is cozy, and the staff great. We did the tasting menu (4 courses but 8 dishes) and had wine and the total was $300 before tip. They even brought us champagne because it was my wife's 30th birthday, which was unexpected and so nice. The hostess was very fun and spent time getting to know us.

The food is creative, floral, and delicious. Portions are nice also, which was appreciated. The trout tartar was one of the best dishes I've even had; the pappardelle was delicious; the deserts were excellent as well. All dishes incorporate flowers in some manner, which is fun and creative as well. 10 out of 10.

I got their fusilli and it was great! The pesto with the breadcrumbs gave the perfect texture and flavors. While the food was great, the service was not the best. We had to wait a while before the server came to take our order and it was rather difficult to get their attention to get the check after too. Ambiance wise, it was really cute, very florally and colorful.

Overall, solid 9/10.
Nice ambience, good food, good service.. but nothing really awesome that makes me want to come back.
Great food, great service! Super cute brunch spot to go with the girls. Everyone's meals were delicious.

Very cute and cozy spot. Very beautifully decorated with the flower theme of course. All the things we ordered were very delicious and presented very well.
Staff was extremely friendly and very quick with our orders. We hardly waited which is always a plus.
Ambience and experience were both great and I would highly recommend this place to anyone.

The interior of this place is beautiful and has really nice and calm vibes. The lighting was ambient and the floral decor fit the name of this place (as it should). The service was good and the servers were friendly.

A group of 4 of us ordered 4 drinks and 4 dishes. The drinks were good and had sprinkles of floral tastes to them. Pricing for these were pretty standard for Manhattan at around $18 each so it wasn't that big a turnoff. The entrees themselves tasted great but the portion sizes were pretty small and not all that filling for what we paid for them. A simple strip steak ended up costing around $40 with nothing else on the plate. The flavors were great though and each bite was enjoyable (like melt-in-your-mouth enjoyable) but we were still left wanting more. We did not stay for dessert and went elsewhere. This place is good for the experience and the ambiance and the food is delicious but don't expect to get too full for the amount you pay here.

A friend of mine and I decided to check this place out.
Such a cute spot.
It's light, airy, and relaxing.
Chill, not too busy.

You can hear yourself talk and enjoy beautiful, organic cocktails and food.

I even ended up buying a few candles from here that smell amazing.

I'd go back.

Adorable brunch spot! Approaching from Sixth Ave, a few mini greenhouse seating setups greet you curbside. Each clear-paneled structure appeared to accommodate 4-6 people. Walking in, a bright lofty space gives off a relaxed, artistic vibe, with an undulating contemporary mural wrapping around the left side and back walls. There are about two dozen tables with seating for two to four people as well as seating at the bar.
