Loved the concept of florist meets morning meal--from the floral arrangement centerpiece centered in the entry, to the planters lining the bookshelves and the use of lavender, hibiscus, etc in most brunch plates,--there was a botanical element running thru the decor and menu.

Ding'd one star for two reasons: like some other reviewers have mentioned the serving size for brunch is a bit on the smaller side, the shashouka was just about filling for one, while the smoked trout rilette was a bit less substantial for one person. Between two people of moderate appetites, we could have shared another item to be on the fuller side. Also while the floral theme was evoked, the floral/herb elements in the dishes weren't specifically highlighted. It would have been nice to have them incorporated more forwardly.

Appreciated the efficient and courteous service. They also have a fully stocked bar, so hope to come enjoy a drink here soon!

The food was great a little
Over priced in my opinion but still decent. It was very girly and floral everywhere which made it cute.

Very beautiful restaurant with all the natural light and flowers.

We had our baby's birthday at this spot. Event planner Alison was attentive and helpful. She helped us plan a perfect event with many kiddos.

The charge was very reasonable for a prefix menu. Food was creative, decorated with real flowers. They have a nice drink bar too. Would recommend anyone who is looking for a spot for large group gatherings.

Went for brunch on a weekend during prime time and we were able to be seated right away. Enjoyed the ambiance of this cafe/florist type of vibe restaurant. The menu is very unique, my boyfriend and I went for the french toast. It was also unique with the yogurt, oats, and jam to top off the french toast. Only negative point is that my coffee was lukewarm / not hot and maybe I should have sent it back. I had to flag down some service and ask for a drink menu for brunch.

I would say I would come back for the ambiance, perhaps would try more of their menu, as it isn't your typical brunch menu.

Even though it's on the small side for a restaurant the space is very relaxed and beautiful. The food and drinks were all very unique and tasty and I love that they use the natural essence of lavender and other plants in their dishes and cocktails.

Very healthy, creative and probably non -traditional food. We had a mushroom and seaweed stir fry that we found delicious but maybe other people wouldn't and a whole fish for two people that was delicious. I would definitely like to come back again to try their brunch. Restaurant has a long bar that seems to get really busy with young professionals who go there for drinks after work.

Restaurant aesthetics 5/5. Food 3/5.

Firstly, this spot is beautiful. It reminds me of a bridal shower. All of the menu items are inspired by different flora. It's open, airy and contemporary.

For food, I had the shakshuka - a safe choice for me as it's a dish I generally like and find can seldom go wrong. It was good taste-wise, although quite dry and I wish there had been more tomato / sauce in there.

Cocktails are strong and I liked how each cocktail incorporated flora very noticeably to some extent. I had the lavender pollinator which I enjoyed.

Overall, the standouts of this restaurant to me are its consistency and passion for flowers and sourcing locally, as well as the pure airiness and aesthetics of the interior design itself. Food-wise, it is just okay. I'd come here more for the ambiance.

I had a fantastic time at Il Fiorista! I enjoyed the food, drinks, ambience and service...nothing disappointed!

Drinks: Overall, the drinks were tasty and strong. I'd definitely recommend trying one!
- I started off with the Lavender Pollinator. It was exactly what I'd think of when I imagine a floral gin drink and I really enjoyed it.
- For my second drink I had the English Rose; it had a very strong cherry flavor. Although this is was expected from the description, it was a bit of a strong flavor for me.

Food: All of my food was delicious!  
- Tumeric sourdough with sunflower petal spice olive oil - HIGHLY recommend. This was probably the most delicious bread I have ever had. I would go back just for this bread alone. The outside of the bread was crispy but the inside was perfectly chewy and soft. The dipping oil was perfectly complementary as well; the flavors blended so nicely.
- Pappardelle with lemon and lavender: I really enjoyed the pasta. I was nervous after reading some of the reviews that it was tough, but I found it to be perfectly cooked. My only complaint was that I wish the portion size was bigger (particularly for the price). I found the flavors to be really unique; the cheese melted perfectly into the lemon sauce while the lavender added a fun twist. All of the flavors blended perfectly and didn't find any to be too overwelming.
- Bombolone: I had really been looking forward to the chocolate cake, but since they were out, I was convinced to try the bombolone. It was essentially a warm donut hole with apple compote inside and a creme dipping sauce. They weren't super unique but very tasty!

Service / Ambience: I sat at the bar and even though he was constantly making drinks, the bartender was attentive and quick. Also, even though the chair didn't have a back, it was actually really comfortable. Overall, it was a super cute restaurant - very trendy and chic.

Simple and elegant is how I would describe Il Fiorista.

Every dish also a floral note to it, which for someone who loves flowers, I think is a great motif. I had the pappardelle that is done with black pepper, lavender, lemon, and pecorino. The dish was bright, tasty and overall I enjoyed the dish.

Wouldn't recommend to other to visit and check out their other dishes.

The manager, Alysson Caine, is the WORST. She's an awful human being. We planned a bridal shower back in July, and Ian was very helpful and accommodating to host a simple party. However, the minute when we arrived, Alysson, gave us ATTITUDE. We initially ignored her as we didn't want any ill feelings on our dear friend's special day. She may have had a bad day but she was totally unprofessional! To add insult to injury, when we asked a male host to take a photo for our group, Alysson rolled her eyes and scoffed before our very eyes. We were nothing to polite to your staff. What did we do to deserve this terrible service from you on what should have been a beautiful day? You better check yourself before you wreck yourself.

I've been debating whether to leave this review since I don't want to affect local business. But I think it's worse to allow Alysson to continue mistreating innocent customers and being plain NASTY!

In summary, the food was 3/5 (mid) and the decor was 4/5. The space is very bright, airy, and has lots of flowers! If I can give the service negative stars, I would (even 1/5 is being too generous).

Cute. Floral. Veggie friendly.

Drink looked better than it tasted. Pesto pasta was delicious.

So my mom is on tik tok and found this restaurant while she was surfing on tik tok. When she told me that wanted to go the restaurant with the flowers on tik tok for her birthday,  I had no idea what she was talking about but I was glad that she found the restaurant. In preparation to bring my rather lively family to the restaurant, I had contacted the restaurant to make a reservation. They were of course very friendly and accommodating. On the day of, they contacted me again to confirm and were soo soo friendly abt it.

We arrive at the restaurant. My parents arrive there first. The manager on duty graciously gives my mom a small gift for her birthday. When I arrive, I fell in love. The vibe of it was cool and the front of restaurant has a real florist tending to flowers and plants.

Now on to the food. It was fresh and tasty with very good plating. I'm not going to lie the portion size was small but it was enough! I want highlight something else that i really appreciate the staff for doing. Soo my little 3 year old nephew was also with us and as you can imagine a 3 year old of looking to have fun. One of the patrons complained to the staff and i was just soo pleased and warmed at how the staff handled it. That's when i knew this restaurant was the real deal.

Thank you for hospitality!

I was so excited for this weekend, a rare escape from home and into the city. I got a great rate on a hotel room and was all set for a weekend full of museum visits and some outdoor meals with friends.

Two hours before tonight's meal, my friend texted to say his wife had potential Covid symptoms. Of course I had no problem with him cancelling (better to find out beforehand), but there went my dinner plans. So I checked into my room and headed to a place that looked good on Yelp. They told me all their tables were spoken for but I could check back in an hour. I told them I'd look around. A few other places didn't look inviting or have distanced outdoor dining. Then I came across Il Fiorista.  What a sight for someone who hasn't eaten at a restaurant since the fall! The inside was beautiful, spacious and so tastefully decorated. A wonderful touch is that it's also a flower shop, as it's name in Italian implies. You can even get some flowers and gifts for home. Floral ingredients are featured in each dish.

Thursday through Saturday they offer a chef's tasting menu ($75 for 4 courses or $59 for 3) or à la carte options. I choose the tasting menu. After 5 months, it was time to live it up!

I started with the salted cod brandade over Focaccia. The fish is whipped with potatoes, garlic, and olive oil and spread over the crusty bread. It's as delicious as it sounds and a welcome change from the usual starters. It was served with greens.

Up next was a house-made pasta with basil and sunflower cooked and seasoned to perfection and topped with sunflower petals. Another perfect dish. This really was like being on a trip to Italy yet I was only 90 minutes from home!!

The sea scallops were impeccably prepared and plated along with scallions, corn, and baby onions atop a green garlic sauce and lightly sprinkled with tiny saffron flowers. Just magical!!

I finished my magnificent meal with the tiramisu. The waiter, who was excellent, told me it was a must-try. Made with rhubarb, pistachio and elderflower, this is not your grandma's tiramisu. The flavors do come together wonderfully atop bits of lady fingers which retain much more texture than those soaked in the restaurant staple.

If you go with a party of two or more you can book one of their greenhouses, just the spot to enjoy wonderful dishes inflected with floral touches. The food was outstanding with service to match. I'm so, so glad I ate here, it was the balm I needed after a long winter. I highly recommend it for a much-needed night out.

On the way back to my hotel I noticed the table at the first place was still empty. No worries, I'm so happy I ended at Il Fiorista!

Came for a birthday dinner for a friend on Saturday night. Though it was dinner time during the weekend, we were the only customers for most of our dinner which I found a little strange but my friends who had a baby with them actually preferred. The service staff were extremely nice and attentive. I wasn't very hungry so I just had Stracciatella which was alright, while my friends had various starters and main entrees which they all enjoyed. The decorations were cute though nothing out of ordinary. Wasn't my favorite, but not a bad experience by any means.

*chef's kiss*

Amazing food. Beautifully decorated and designed inside. Cozy, cool ambiance. Awesome wine selection.

Some of my fave dishes were the Pappardelle (so lemony, but in the best way), the Berber Tea Sasso Chicken, and the Pumpkin Brioche (we ordered a second because 1 wasn't enough). We came with 6 people and ordered almost everything on the menu to share (it's a somewhat limited menu for dinner, however, each dish is exceptional, so that's okay!!) and it was a solid plan. Then, once we were nearing the end, we added a couple repeats that were our faves and that definitely helped.

As some have said, the portions are a little small for some of the dishes. I don't think the Pappardelle would be enough as a main for one person if you didn't add a couple apps as well. As long as you that know going in, and can order a couple other items, you won't regret it. The dish is incredible.

The entire restaurant concept is really so unique and well thought out. The idea of infusing floral aspects into the food, drinks, hands-on classes, etc. is awesome, and they pair this with a major focus on sustainability and eco-friendly practices. I also love that they source ingredients (produce & flowers) directly from greenmarkets in NYC. Love a local restaurant supporting local! Would definitely come back here and even try out a cooking or bouquet making class!

All I can is WOW. I went here on Saturday with my Mom, my sister, and my fiancé's mother after finding my dream wedding dress at Kleinfeld's. As I was signing the paperwork for the dress, I looked at my phone. It was 5:20. Our reservation was for 5. I was SO sad, because as we all know, basically every fun NYC spot has a 15 minute grace period, and they aren't sorry about it.

To my suprise, I called and the host said it was no problem at all, and he would see us whenever we got there. I was so excited to visit this spot and the host made me feel so reassured.

When we got there, the host was even more friendy in person! I wish very much I had asked his name, because he really was very kind. He asked us about the dress shopping, and my sister was very quick to show him a picture, haha! He was so involved in our conversation and found us the perfect little "greenhouse" which is their outdoor seating option. I didn't think he could be any kinder, but then he sent our table 4 glasses of sparkling rosé as a celebration on the house. It was such a special moment.

We only stayed here for drinks, but we tried the Alpine Spritz and the Lavender Pollinator. They were both really good, and it was hard to only have one before we had to head to dinner!  

To go with our drinks, we had the seeded cracker appetizer and the portion was large for something like this! It was SO good, I'm not sure if they handroll their seeded crackers, but the size and taste led me to believe they might.

I can't tell you how good of a time we had here! I will be back, and will start recommending this spot in the future!

Delicious! Great service and tasty food. We tried the tasting menu with the wine pairing and the presentation and food was fantastic. Would have like a little more explanation on the courses but overall great ambiance and experience, would definitely come back.

We were so happy we continued walking down 26th Street and came across this little jewel II Fiorista!  It was an early Sunday afternoon and we thought we would grab a Bloody Mary and keep walking. However, it's beautiful, serene ambiance would not let us leave!  We ended up staying for Brunch and thoroughly enjoying our well-crafted Bloody Mary's!  We bonded with the phenomenal Bartender, Annette and even had an opportunity to meet the Chef!  A great treat.  We enjoyed II Fiorista so much, we returned the next evening for cocktails! Wish we would have found earlier in our trip; it was like meeting new friends! Can't wait to return on our next trip to NYC.

There's a few words that summarize my experience at Il Fiorista ... amazing, refreshing & beautifully scented with bouquets all over the space. The host took care of us just as nicely as the Bartendar did !

My beautiful Tahirah loved it, I loved it ALL

Not very flavorful and filling brunch menu. And the prices are way overpriced for such a tasteless and small portion meal.
Also, we waited 20 minutes for a table even though we had a reservation.

It was a great experience with hospitable staffs, delicious dishes and beautiful presentation.
I highly recommend to everyone.
I would like to come back here again.

Customer service was great. Food was hit and misses depending on what you order.  The place was a bit dark if you wanted to take pictures but it was great to chat with your party.

Our server was really nice. She also let us know if we wanted to take any pictures before she cut things up. Awesome!

Now the real focus needs to be on the food: My party ordered a whole bunch for the table. My fav was the beef tataki, beef tongue, chicken gizzard, and the veg tempura. My party also said they enjoy the sashimi that comes with the Tuesday special and the godzilla roll. Beside those, everything else fell short - either too dry or could be more tasty. Definitely, a bunch could use extra seasoning or salt with the exception of the short rib entree. That was salty enough.

Bill came out to close to $500 for 6 people. I was left with a feeling of how much it could have been better in terms of food.

I wouldn't be back for the fact of food not being up to par if they charge those prices.

Great place for quick bites and drinks! But must note that the yakitori (which is roughly one serving) takes up to 25 minutes for the kitchen to prepare, so would recommend ordering other dishes while waiting.

Our sushi roll - Astro Boy - was the first dish to come out: pretty standard sushi roll, topped high with spicy tuna and doused with sauce. We were then served our Tuna Tartare - I was expecting more of a puréed/tartare texture but got cubed tuna. The avocado mash was perfectly seasoned to complement the tuna. Lastly, we were served our yakitori:
* Zabuton steak - really tender, juicy, and well marinated; paired really well with the wasabi from our sushi roll
* Chicken thigh with Yuzukosho - very soft and juicy too
* Chicken meatballs - juicy and mildly flavored with a crumbly texture

The food was authentic and tasted great. Short ribs were braised beautifully and the liver was excellent. The waiter was attentive, pleasant, and not hovering. The atmosphere was warm and inviting. Not overtly fancy but still classy enough for a date.  I will return.
Service is quick and the food is great. Good happy hour deals too. I got the salmon onigiri and octopus salads and both were great. Great appetizers too.

This place is a gem down an unexpected street! Incredible food, lovely staff and wonderful atmosphere.
I recommend visiting for a date night or for a night out with friends!

Great for hangouts, dates, or even company dinner. Service is top notch - super friendly and they know you need another drink even without you mentioning it. We got hamachi tataki, tuna avocado tartare, and some yakitories, all of them delicious We also got a bottle of sake (Kubota Manju) which was the best I've tried (and they give you the cutest sake glasses!!) Don't miss out

My first venture into Manhattan's NoMad district was this appropriately named place.  It's dark, tight, and loud in here but it's also a good, fun, and vibrant hipster place for a boys' night out on the town.  It's a bit too loud for what I would call a date night place, and I think it's louder than your typical Japanese izakayas.  But this is NYC isn't it, ha.   The food quality is also tip-top good here, and I'm in no position to judge prices as what I think may be a little pricey may actually be reasonable in Manhattan.  Anyway on to the food and drink.  My nephew and I had a foodies' izakaya dinner:

For drinks, nephew had a high ball and I had an old fashioned and an Orion draft beer.  It turned out to be the cheapest old fashioned of my 3 day trip at only $16, woot woot, and good too!  For food, it was an assortment to try out their menu:

- beef tataki
- assorted tempura vegetables
- chicken meat balls with egg yolk
- yakitori skewers of chicken thigh, chicken skin (kawa), and beef short rib
- salmon
- 2 uni rolls
- shishito peppers
- oyster mushrooms

It was all delicious and a fun dinner.

Decent izakaya with a fair selection of drink and food options. I liked the interior a lot, and the service was nice, but nothing that we ordered stood out as particularly tasty. It's a fine date spot or place to go out with friends, but not somewhere I'd be dying to go back to, if that makes sense.

Food was kinda average here, came here with a friend for dinner last week and wasn't that impressed... tried a bunch of dishes from tofu to grilled squid, beef tongue, chicken skewers, purple yam fries, mushrooms and nothing really stood out. I'd recommend finding other spots to check out over this place. Friendly staff though but they'll give you the bill when your time's up to prep for the next group, even though the place was pretty empty.

First time eating here and don't have good impression. I ordered Squid Teriyaki and it was very hard to chew and rubbery. The taste is bland too. Chicken Heart yakitori is ok too. Nothing mind blowing.

Tried this place and thought their skewers were the highlight! It's an izakaya with a lot of seating for different party sizes. If you sit near the bar/window type area you can see them grill the skewers!

The okonomiyaki was really good too but i thought the spare ribs glaze was too sweet and i have a personal preference for a savory sauce! The grilled veggies with this dish was amazing tho and were ate it all. It was perfect for snacking or eating when you're hungry bc of the various portion sizes.

My favorite skewers was the pork, enoki with bacon, and the drinks were really good!

My friend and I came here on a Wednesday night and we were able to get a reservation same day. The restaurant is very dimly lit, but I guess that added to the ambiance.

Service was friendly and quick enough - bathrooms were clean as well, so that is definitely a nice-to-have! Also, quick appreciation note on the wall hooks for our jackets! I know this is probably more common in NY, but when you are wearing a heavy coat, the last thing you want to do is drape it over your chair and pick it up off the floor 15 times over the course of dinner.

Food-wise, we ordered:

- Seaweed Salad - Pretty standard, so nothing to write home about. Satisfied my desire for something green and healthy-ish though!
- Pork Belly - Best skewer of the night imo! Can't go wrong with pork belly.
- Meatballs - Good, not great - I mean..it was a meatball.
- Okonomiyaki - Really good okonomiyaki! Just know that this is pretty filling, so after two pieces of this - I was pretty much done for dinner!

Overall a good experience here! Pro tip is that they also have really good sake here as well, though we did not partake since it was a school night and all!

Came here with a friend after work on a Thursday at around 630 without a reservation and was able to get seated right away! Lucky we got there when we did as the place was filling up quick!

What we got:
Tsukune - Chicken Meatball
Pork Belly
Thigh w/ Yuzukosho
Thigh w/ Scallion
Enoki Mushrooms wrapped in Smoked Bacon
Teriyaki Ika
Tuna Avocado Tartare with Ikura & Uni

Everything was seasoned very well! The chicken meatball specialty was tender and juicy and the sauce with the egg yolk that came with it was tasty as well. They presented you the grilled squid and cut it to bite size pieces and their tuna tartare was good
I liked the food, ambiance and service.   Since I am not a big fan of tiny portions and tapas style restaurants -  one star off.  It's not a bad place but I won't be bookmarking it.

My friend and I came here after shopping a sample sale, and we were pleasantly surprised by what we ordered!

I loved the karaage, it's a hefty portion cooked perfectly. It's juicy, crunchy, and flavorful, what more can you ask for?!

The salmon sashimi was buttery and delicious and seemed like great quality fish! It was pricey at $20, but you gotta treat yourself sometime.

The specialty roll we had was good, but the other two dishes we got were definitely more memorable.

We got one of their house cocktails featuring peach and yakult, and that was such a treat! It was so refreshing and not too sweet. These could be super dangerous if you're knocking them back since they don't taste of alcohol!

I'd honestly come back just for the karaage, but a good cocktail is always tempting too. Yum!

TLDR: Don't go here. It doesn't taste like Japanese food, the food ranges from "tastes like food poisoning" to "just ok", the uni had gone bad, the server never checked on how our food was, and most of the items were overpriced.

One of the worst dining experiences I've had. The food was awful, the uni (sea urchin) tasted old, and the service was unacceptable. After one bite of one piece, I was legitimately worried about food poisoning given how old and slightly sour it tasted.  We sent back 3/4 pieces since no one else wanted to try it after my reaction and informed the server that we did not want the rest.

I would have given maybe 2-3 stars for the food, but the fact the server did not offer to replace or reimburse an item we ate less than 75% of and sent back turned the dining experience even more sour than the uni. By the way, the 4 pieces of uni sushi were 28 dollars because uni is usually a luxury food.

We ordered the following and I'll give comments for each one.

Uni Sushi Onigiri - Tastes like food poisoning. Uni was not fresh, sent it back
Ebi (Shrimp) Mayo - The shrimp had minimal flavor, basically just oil and batter. Fried batter tastes good,but why even call it shrimp.
Okonomiyaki - Ok. Nothing special, but it was fine.
Karaage - Similar to the ebi mayo, it only tasted good because it was deep fried. If you like fried anything it's fine, but it does not taste anything like real karaage - mostly because of the lack of seasoning.
Grilled Squid - This was ok. Nothing special, but ok.
Tsukune Skewers - This tasted good. The main complaint is that it was $10 per skewer and most good yakitori places are $5 per skewer for the same or better quality. It's strange how being surrounded by other subpar dishes makes you more grateful.
Sweet Potato Fries - Exactly what you would expect for fries, greasy potatoes. No complaints on this one.

How have I overlooked this place so many times? Such delicate chicken karaage. Crispy, light tempura. Freaking delicious onigiri. Delightful skewers. My friends ordered a bunch of sushi rolls (not authentic but they seemed to be crowd pleasers). Boomer/Millennial group tip: if you want to have a dinner with 8-12 friends where you can all hear each other, book the front window area. It was perfect for our girls dinner.

The food and service were amazing! The sushi rolls were large and delicious. I recommend the astronomy roll. Also, I really enjoyed the enoki mushrooms wrapped in smoked bacon.

If you want a cocktail, I tried the peachy it was very sweet and tasted like candy.
This is a pretty nice and cute restaurant, we went here for a friend's birthday dinner. The food was okay but the service was great.

Phenomenal sushi and Japanese cuisine. We had the seaweed salad and fried chicken. Both were absolutely delicious. The chicken was fried to perfection and came with a spicy mayo dipping sauce. We ordered cocktails and they not only looked beautiful but were also strong. The sushi was beautifully plated and delicious. Nothing in this place was lacking. Ambience was on point, dimly lit with good separation between tables. This place is totally great for a quick date or with friends.

If you agree to sit "outside", you are actually in a very uncomfortable shed with not windows. Inside is very noisy but has a nice look. The food was okay. The dumplings are tiny and only 5. Service was spotty. It was all fine but not sure what the hype is all about.

I visited this place a while ago during my visit to NY, and I still remember the meal I had. Just well-prepared food and drinks, all at the perfect temperature and flavor. I'm back in my hometown, and still in search of a place that will match the experience.

Great drinks and even better sushi! Staff is very amicable and friendly. Ideal spot for after work drinks and dinner. We ordered a Golden roll, an Astro boy and seaweed salad. Everything tasted great.

I always enjoy yakitori. We had the chicken meatball which was interesting with the egg yolk sauce, the beef short ribs which were tasty, the enoki mushrooms wrapped in bacon which were also good and the pork belly which was my favorite.

We also had the mina roll, which I think was expensive for what it was. Typical sushi roll, nothing special. We also had the bbq squid, which was good (large amount for two people to split).

Food was fine, the low rating is for the service - there was no greetings, no check in, no refill of water nor soy sauce - which we depleted both. We had one bottle of water to start with, which we poured for ourselves, and never got a second bottle. My friend got sashimi and finished up all her soy sauce, and had to eat the leftover soy sauce from the rest of us. Server didn't bother to take away dishes we've clearly finished - with nothing on them. As another review mentioned, the server was very ready for us to leave and rushed to give us the check. I get that service rating is overall good for this restaurant, either New Yorkers have very low standard of so called 'good service', or we're being discriminated against for no reasons.

I absolutely loved this place prior to the pandemic and glad that the quality of the food and service was still maintained. Stopped by today for dinner and was sad to see how quiet it was even if it is a weekday. Ordered the grilled hokke, yakitori skewers (pork belly, short rib, chicken thigh with yuzukosho, chicken wings), lotus root salad, and hamachi tataki.

Hokke - 4.5/5 this was a huge portion and fish was grilled just right though there were some pieces that were a bit too burnt for my taste

Yakitori - 4/5 overall this was solid and enjoyed the short rib and the pork belly the most. The chicken skewers were solid but not memorable. Short rib was so tender and juicy.

Hamachi tataki 4.5/5 - hamachi was delicious and the salad it came on top of was refreshing though I would prefer if they didn't use iceberg lettuce

Lotus root salad 3.5/5 - this was OK, too much iceberg lettuce and salad dressing didn't have much flavor. Octopus was really good and wish they added more pieces of lotus root

Overall a solid experience and food was good. Service was fine and staff kept their masks on at all times.

We enjoyed the food here, but the service needed major improvement.

Here are some notable dishes:
- okonomiyaki: my favorite! And trust me when I say that because I DO NOT like okonomiyaki. I've had the best-rated okonomiyaki in Osaka, and I didn't enjoy that as much as the one here.
- teriyaki ika (squid): another delicious dish!
- pork belly yakitori: the perfect amount of fat.
- Dasai (sake): 720ml was a great bottle to share among four people.

Now comes the ugly part. We came here specifically for the yakitori. The server warned us that the wait time for yakitori was about 20 mins, which we acknowledged and proceeded to order other stuff while we waited.

The server came back 5 mins later to tell us that the wait time for the yakitori had increased to an hour due to a backlog in the grilling station since another party had placed a large order. So we asked the server if he could offer us anything for the inconvenience...he walked away to place our order (I am not sure why the order wasn't placed in the first place) and never returned again.

We flagged him down in passing to see if he had spoken to the manager, and that's when he finally realized what we were asking. I was trying to be smooth about our request, but I guess it didn't translate well. I get that it is not always possible for the restaurant to comp the customers for the extra wait time. Still, there is a better way to handle this than just being defensive towards the customers, especially after placing the order on large ticket items.

I understand that there is a labor shortage in the leisure & hospitality sector. Still, basic customer service training is a must in every job sector, despite the labor market today.
Wonderful service. Got to sit down right away at the bar on a Friday night. Food and drink was incredible. The ambiance is very nice -- it's dark and moody but very lively. Highly recommended.

I was inspired to write a review after having an awful experience here. Somehow, almost everything about this place is simultaneously terrible.

Service
* The waiters were pushy and started asking us if we were ready to order two minutes after sitting down. They would then come back every two minutes after that. When we went, the restaurant was not full.
* We sent a food item back because it was foul and still got charged for it

Food
Let's start with the yakitori. This place is apparently known for it, and I think this is your best bet. The chicken tsukune (meatball) is pretty good. I didn't try any of their other skewers (see section re: price/value below). However, for a place that prides themselves on yakitori the selection is painfully mediocre; I would've liked to see items more befitting a yakitori specialty shop like chicken oyster, heart/liver/gizzard, cartilage, and seafood (shrimp/scallops). If I somehow have the misfortune of eating here again, I'd stick to skewers only.

Besides the chicken tsukune, the Purple Sweet Potato Fries were the second best, followed by the Chicken Karaage and Ebi Mayo. Yes, the non-yakitori item I was most impressed by was fried potatoes. Still, their fried food could use a little less breading across the board.

Everything else ranged from "I might literally get food poisoning" to "Just okay". By rank order from worst to best we ordered
* Cured Salmon Rice Ball with Ikura & Uni. Uni looked discolored and mushy/watery. Tasted equivalently bad (bitter / funky). We sent this back because we didn't want to risk food poisoning.
* Hokke (Grilled mackerel). Tasted like salt and was super dry. If you're looking for a similar flavor profile at home, I'd recommend eating miso paste straight from the container.
* Okonomiyaki. Tasted fine. I couldn't really taste the seafood, but fried batter + kewpie mayo carried it to the mediocre tier.
* Teriyaki Ika. This was just okay. They get points for the chewy texture and the slight char. But they need to chill with the teriyaki sauce.

Price/Value
This is mainly knocking their yakitori menu. Per skewer, expect to spend $5-10. Calling out specifics, $10 for chicken tsukune and $5 for chicken thigh is highway robbery, even for NYC. Places that I've been to (in the same neighborhood and in the same week as the writing of this review) with far better yakitori in terms of taste and variety charge on average about 30% less for comparable skewers. I think the rest of their food is reasonably priced, with the caveat that it has to taste better than it does.

Came in here with a group of 4 on a Friday evening. What we got;
Purple sweet potato fries; 4/5; The fries were hot and crispy! It was actuallly a good price for the amount we got and I would get this again!

Moku roll; 4.5/5; The roll was so delicious. From top to bottom the avocado, rice, & eel was super soft and smooth! The only con was that we waited almost 20mins for our roll and we were starving which was not that great.

Chicken yakitori; 3.5;5 it was just alright... a bit too salty. However, the chicken was really good. If it didn't have that much sat it would've been better.

Service: 3.5/5; The service was just mediocre. But they were nice.

Overall; 3.5/5; I only recommend the purple sweet potato fries and the Moku. If we didn't wait that long for the sushi roll I would've rated higher.

Not very good, expensive and troubling services. We ate outside at a table for 6 (we were three couples) on a Wednesday night. We ultimately paid something like $200 each (including tip) which was outrageous for the poor food, small amount of food, and no alcohol included. My wife was sick about 6hours later, and I believe it was from the food we at here.

Do not go, we will not return. I can't believe the prices, and the poor poor quality.

Great service and an eclectic playlist make for a fun night out, but this Izakaya would probably work best for drinks and snacks at the end of the evening - not as the main event.  Short rib skewer was delectable, chicken skewers fine.  Standouts were the octopus salad and the hamachi tataki.  The sushi roll we ordered was nothing special and the rice was a little mushy.  Vegetable tempura was generously portioned, but the veggies were obscured by an overly crunchy crust.

Came here to grab dinner with a GF since we were in the area. Let me tell you everything on the menu was as good as we read it!

We had different skewers and the tuna avocado tartare with Ikura & Uni. Unfortunately, I do not have pictures but that wouldn't have done justice anyway. One of the ones I favored was the "tsukune - chicken meatball" b/c it was served w/ free-range egg yolk & uan dipping sauce

If you can't decide on wanting Sushi or Izakaya, this is the perfect option.

I'm a sushi lover while the person I came with likes non-sushi Japanese food and we were both satisfied.

The Izakaya does take a bit longer than the other items but we got a lot and we stuffed by the end of the meal. Reasonable prices and a great selection. All pictures matched up.
Great decor, service and kitchen were fast and efficient. Menu was not huge but very diverse so it was suitable for all tastes and levels of "I've been to Japan".
Absolutely amazing food. Great atmosphere and the food is fantastic. I had the Kakuni and she had the dragon roll, both were fantastic. Also the Red Rice Ale was great!

Came here on a Friday night with three friends and we sat outdoors in their COVID spaced outdoor dining huts. The staff was attentive and the inside of the hut was warm even on a cold night.

We did multiple yakitori - asparagus, chicken breast, tomato wrapped in bacon + short rib. the short rib and the sauce was AMAZING. Def the favorite of the yakitori. We continued with the sweet potato fries, okanomoyaki and the tuna tartare. The drinks were also really well done - although I would say the Japan Knees was just bit too sweet for me. Will def be back for more yakitori!

Hit and miss dishes. The grilled chicken skewers were excellent but took forever to cook. The tuna tartare composition was strange- giant chunks of tomato and slimy seaweed on top didn't do much for the texture and the tomatoes were overpowering the fish. The soft shell crab sushi/roll was the best thing we ordered. The salmon carpaccio wasn't amazing but the sauce had good flavor to it. Overall, maybe I'd come for the sushi again but skip some of the other dishes we tried

Unfortunately the sesame ice cream is no more (they no longer serve dessert), but otherwise Izakaya NoMad has come through the pandemic well and is still a great place to go. Particularly at the moment when you can't get to Tokyo. Skip the sautéed squid, but otherwise all good.

To those who are looking for an authentic izakaya experience, Izakaya NoMad is it. We couldn't have picked a better spot for a farewell dinner for one of my girlfriends. Between the ambience, the soul-nourishing food and the great company, Izakaya NoMad made one of our last gatherings an evening to remember.

The food and good vibes were flowing all night, but the yakitori definitely made it to the top of the list. Whether you opt for gizzards, chicken thighs, pork belly, beef tongue, oyster mushrooms or shishito peppers, your taste buds will be delighted. Each skewer was graced with the essence of binchotan and grilled to perfection. It was all extremely juicy and made the wait all the more worth it. You could taste the care and attention with each bite. It was hard not to order more than one of everything.

The other highlight of the evening had to be the hot pot. I was surprised by how much I enjoyed their oden and clam hot pots. There was so much flavor for something that looked very humble and came in what appeared to be a pot sized for 1-2. While the dashi base was common to both, the addition of the oden and the clam in each lent the broth extra complexity and nuance. I only wish we'd been able to get broth refills.

If it's your first time at an izakaya, I'd recommend sitting bar-side. Nothing quite beats watching the chef tend to your yakitori!
Great food and good service! Enjoyed the night with my friends after suggesting the place to them.

AWESOME drinks. they come out super fast and have been creatively designed and well executed. the chuhai was my favorite but peachy was also good if you want something a little sweeter. the yakitori was also very well seasoned- tastes just like in japan. the showstopper was absolutely the hamachi tataki. whatever the sauce was, it was mouthwatering!! a bit pricey but worth

Came here last minute with a friend a few weeks ago and was pleasantly surprised we didn't need a reservation on a Thursday night. They have a great happy hour Tues-Sun (5pm-7pm) which includes $5 draft beer, $6 sake, and $7 wines. Score!!

They have bar seating in addition to tables that can accommodate large groups. Service was warm and welcoming.

The menu is quite extensive and can be a little over whelming so I have listed my favorites down below.

FAVORITES:

-Grilled Prawns (super juicy)
-Grilled Shishito peppers (not too spicy)
-NoMad Glabi (flavor was incredible)
-Sesame Ice Cream
-Hot Pot with Mussels (mussels were fresh and was a generous amount)
Delish!! Would highly recommend the okonomiyaki! Definitely best for its grilled menu options

The best izakaya for everyone who loves skewers must try!! It's so tender and juicy, I tried most of them and all tasted great. And their uni (sea urchin) sooooo fresh can't eat anywhere else. Yesterday we tried bunch of different cocktails too but my favorite was the nomad's land. If you are fan of the ginger try the nomad highball delicious. All the staffs were so friendly and the lighting is perfectly dimmed so it's great for date night too. We'll be back definitely!

Overpriced, somewhat mediocre food, and a very noisy place. Service was fine, but the place was very tightly packed, and the music was intensely loud, but they turned it down a small amount on request. Just not a comfortable spot for expensive and inauthentic izakaya fare.

I am so saddened to say that this place used to be freaking amazing and now everything just tastes like sugar. I have brought countless people here, friends from london, italy, france and spain, i brought my family and relatives from out of town, i have celebrated birthdays and and many other occasions. And now i just cant go back anymore. The beef tataki was to die for, now it tasted like sugar, the sushi rolls were amazing, now just ok, the chicken meatballs used to be great, now those taste like sugar too. Since the pandemic ive been back three times. Each time the food wasnt good but I thought, hey they have just had a rough time thats all. But I am afraid this place has changed forever and not going back to what it used to be. and I am so sorry to say I wont be coming back.

Very racist and unwelcoming, especially once they saw my family and I with a child. Forced us to throw away our toddlers milk and refused to seat us until we mentioned the open seats that were available which "I guess you can sit there." Talked to the manager about the milk rule (which even airports allow milk for babies) and was met with defensive BS excuses. Would not ever recommend this terrible place!
Love this place. Although the outdoor dining can be a bit noisy especially when the cars are zipping by. The rolls are fresh, the beer on tap is fresh. The yakitori is amazing.

It has been a  long time since i came back. Was a staple for me when i worked in NYC. However the food was fantastic as per usual. Linguine n clams done right. The place had been solid for the 30 plus years i have gone.  Little Italys jewel.

This is 30 plus years of love for IL CORTILE

I went to a dinner for a diabetes product a while back. One of the representatives from the company told me that his family owns this restaurant and he occasionally helps out. He gave me his contact and said if you ever go there, let me know.
I finally tried it recently. I brought my brother-in-law (BIL) and his boyfriend (BIL's BF) here to celebrate their graduation from graduate school. A was there as well.
I made a reservation and told the guy that we were trying it. He asked me to send me what name I used for the reservation but he found it as I had made it on OpenTable or Resy. He marked it with his Initials I think.
When A and I got there as we were early, we couldn't find the host/hostess. We kind of stood there awkwardly waiting for someone to help us out. Eventually the hostess came and sat us in the back part of the restaurant, where it kind of feels like the outside but it's not. It's an open space area with a lot of light and it's a really beautiful area.

As an aside, the decoration is gorgeous and the ambience is that of any Italian restaurant in Little Italy - busy, but the staff are still attentive.

Back to the food, when my BIL and his BF arrived, they gave us bread and ordered glasses of wine. Food wise, A got the chicken parm, BIL's BF got the chicken fillet, BIL got the penne vodka (which is what we predicted he would get), and I got the pasta with their special made sauce that is only done on weekends. I didn't realize my BIL's BF didn't like mushrooms so he pushed all the mushrooms to the side and ate the chicken. I picked at his mushrooms here and there because I like mushrooms a lot. But my dish was amazing. It went well with whatever wine I had gotten and the sauce was amazing: it has meatballs, spare ribs, sausage, and braciola in it. It's difficult to tell in the picture because only the meatball shows but the other meats are buried under the sauce. I didn't think I would finish but I surprisingly did. I think we all finished our dish for the most part and we were all so stuffed. When the waiter came around to ask if we wanted dessert, we said no thanks.

However, one of the perks of knowing the owner is that they ignore you when you say no dessert. They brought us a dessert sampler that included cannoli, red velvet cake, and two cheesecakes. They were heavenly. I didn't eat the cannoli because I'm not a cannoli fan but the cheesecakes and red velvet cakes were so good. Even though we were all full, we managed to eat dessert.

To summarize: great food, good service, lovely interior and atmosphere. And they also do live music although it's like a musician here and there that plays a violin and goes to every table randomly and then later an accordion player that goes randomly to different tables. A bit strange but I guess it's part of the ambience. Give this place a shot if you can -  but make a reservation!

So I was in New York, more specifically Manhattan.
I was told the Italian Food in New York was delicious, which I found out by trial and error was incorrect in my opinion.
I Google searched best Italian restaurants and searched on Instagram for the best restaurants to eat Italian Food in Little Italy.
The restaurant was well reviewed, high ratings and on the top three of every list I saw.
I convinced my wife and two other friends to give it a try.
We were greeted by a wonderful, polite and amazing hostess. She was Turkish but seemed to know a lot about Italian food and recommended a few dishes.
Once she seated us we were being served by another amazing staff member he was Italian American, Sicilian to be specific and a true Native of Brooklyn. We had great time with him and he as well gave his recommendations for food.
I gave them the benefit of the doubt and ordered the suggested dishes.
We ordered cocktails but I think wine would have been better suited especially because the prices weren't bad at all. Cocktail were average at best.
We ordered some apps which were the Burrata and Pan Seared Pear. That actually wasn't bad at all. It worked well together.
The other app we ordered was the Mozzarella in Carozza which I personally didn't like but my friends liked the Pablo type of crust it had.
Next came our mains.
My wife and I decided to share dishes, she ordered Ravioli stuffed with crab and cognac crème sauce.
I ordered the stuffed Veal chop with the bone In.
The ravioli came out and there was 4 pieces of Ravioli.
The sauce looked watery but I dug in to give it a chance.
The ravioli were a disaster, they were way too soft and as soon as you cut the piece the pasta could hold the filling and broke apart. The sauce was heavily salted. I didn't not enjoy that dish at all.
The stuffed veal wasn't what I expected at all. When it came out it was this round ball that lucked like a giant meatball that they stuffed and inserted a bone.
The veal wasn't stuffed rather than rolled like an involtini and it actually did have the bone Inserted in.
The meat was cooked fine and heavily stuffed which was the only good thing.
It had this gravy sauce with mushrooms that was again overly salted and to the point I felt like my body was shutting down. There was no taste to the food but salt.
It was awful.
I tried my friends Penne alla Vodka which thank Gid was at least cooked somewhat Al Dente but the sauce wasn't tasty at all.
My other friend ordered Sunday Sugo which was Sausage, Braciole and Ribs cooked in Tomato Sauce the sauce wasn't bad at all. The sauce was very very sweet though, too sweet for my likings to ever order again but the meat was cooked in the sauce and very soft.
The ambiance was a very nice setting, clean, well arranged and decorated. The staff were amazing and made me feel comfortable and welcomed.
If you are looking to have good conversation with the staff and a welcoming, warm and beautiful environment then Il Cortile is the spot but if you're going to have a good authentic Italian meal or just an overall culinary experience the. Please don't waste your time!
We loved the food. The service was amazing and the ambiance as well!!! Will definitely be visiting soon. Summer time will definitely be sitting out in their courtyard.

Came here during restaurant week on a weekday. Place was pretty packed (indoor and outdoor seating). Loved the aura of this place and the staff was really nice. Had the standard drinks and an array of apps. Calamari was a hit as was the stuff calms. I got the mozzarella/tomato salad which was ok. My main was salmon with risotto which was a huge portion. Seasoned well. Dessert I got the Italian cheesecake and it was huge. Couldn't finish it all. After dinner we walked around Little Italy and it was gorgeous with all the lights and the atmosphere.

The waiters were very attentive and catered to our needs. The interior is also amazing and if you get a chance to sit towards the back, I would highly recommend.

In terms of the food, it was very mediocre. My party and I ordered several different pasta dishes and some were served under cooked and others just we're not that good. The appetizers were also okay.

We came here after we saw a video on TikTok and though we'd give it a try but I think it may have been overhyped.
Been coming here at least once a month for over a year. Food never disappoints, specials are always worth considering. Now featuring pizzas!

This place is beautiful and decorated very nicely. We came in with a big group and took long intervals of time to order, and our waiter was very accommodating to an almost impressive degree. Food was amazing, I still dream about that farfalle and fried mozz highly recommend!

Coming to NYC for the marathon weekend, I had to stop at this authentic Italian restaurant, where you still get treated like family with delicious food!

This restaurant has a combination of outdoor patio dining, indoor dining, and a beautiful garden room (indoor/outdoor area). Asides from the great setting for an Italian restaurant, the service is stellar, with making me want to come back next time I'm in Little Italy!

The scallops, veal, and fettuccine pasta is highly recommended and delicious. You won't be disappointed.
Celebrated by boyfriend's birthday here and I'm so glad I chose this place. Food was amazing and the staff went above and beyond. Place was picturesque and romantic. I can't wait to go back!

This place was recommended by someone from NY while I was traveling. I made reservations for a birthday dinner. Tables seemed like it could be loud when busy, but it was not.
Fresh bread was good. We tried the fried mozzarella, which was nothing like we'd ever had before.
One special was pumpkin gnocchi with mascarpone sauce. It was served in a pumpkin. This was delicious.
We also chose ravioli, which was good.
Had to get dessert, and chose lava cake and cheesecake. We were happy with our choices.
Other meals that passed us looked wonderful and smelled amazing.
Sucks. Made a reso for the dining room and got seated by the door. The food is not homemade and kinda gross. Perfect for a tourist.

Recently my parents came to visit. Naturally, being the good Yelp Elite I am, I wanted to take them to some of the best New York City has to offer, and in particular somewhere with Italian-American food. Il Cortile came recommended by my friend (who has excellent taste), so I went ahead and made a reservation for 7pm on Friday.

Upon arrival (about 15 minutes early), we were greeted and seated. Unfortunately, once we were seated, we were greeted by the dreaded QR code menu rather than an actual paper menu. While this isn't something that bothers me, it was very difficult for my parents to read the menu on the phone. Later in the evening, I noticed that paper menus were in fact available, but not presented to us (we did not realize it was an option). Frankly, I was ready to condemn this place right here: while QR codes made sense during Covid, there's simply no reason to use them for menus any longer, and certainly not at a restaurant with an ambience any nicer than McDonalds. While using QR codes may save money for the restaurant owner, so does removing toilet paper from the bathroom (which is a bad idea). Even worse is that the linked menu was a PDF that used a "fancy" font, and not optimized for mobile, making an already difficult to read menu even harder on my parents, particularly my father. While we were trying to figure out the menu, the tension was raised just a bit by the roving accordion player who seemed to want us to tip him to play (I'd rather tip him not to). We did not appreciate it, but any accordion fans will likely enjoy this touch of ambience.

Once we were able to figure out what the restaurant served, we made our orders and relaxed: the hard part was over. Our bottle of wine came out and was acceptable, and then it was time for food.

First, we had ordered the antipasto platter. It was pretty much what you would expect from an antipasto platter, with a collection of meats and cheeses and various accoutrement. Nothing special, but it started the meal off on the right foot. We skipped salad, but it looks like the Caesar is made table side (at least at other tables), which is always a good sign.

Our mains came out after a little while (not overly long of a wait, but not too soon either). I ordered the linguine cicale, which is basically a seafood pasta similar to dishes I've had in the past and a favorite of mine. The seafood was cooked well, with the always-tricky octopus coming in not over cooked, always an accomplishment. The sauce was also quite pleasant. My mother ordered the cheese ravioli, and quite enjoyed it, with the sauce again serving as a highlight (it was remarkably fresh tasting). Finally, my father had the Chicken Scarpariello. The dish was very generously portioned, and my father seemed to enjoy, with his primary complaint being that the dish was far too much for him to eat in one sitting (overall a good thing). It didn't seem particularly appealing to me but that is simply preference.

Finally, we had the bomba for dessert. The gelato was exceptionally good, and even my father (who was stuffed from his main course, see above) enjoyed it very much.

Shortly after we received the bill, which came out to a couple hundred dollars. Overall, the value for money was solid, but there are certainly ways they could have improved the experience (particularly the menu issue above). I wouldn't say that this is my new "go-to" for visitors, but you could certainly do worse, and it doesn't seem to be as much of a tourist trap as some other Little Italy Italian restaurants. I won't rush back, but I will not avoid this restaurant in the future.

We made a reservation using Open Table, but it took them about 20 minutes to sit us down. We weren't getting updates on times and the hostess walked past us a couple of times. We finally got sat in the (inside) outdoor covered area which had really nice vibes and views. Restaurant is pretty big as well so you don't feel too close to other tables.

They brought out some bread for the table which was good, but the sticks were really really hard to eat. I got the cheese ravioli and it was very very tasty, delicious, and just the perfect amount of food. Top it off with some parmesan and black pepper and it's good to go! *Mouth watering while typing this*

I would give it 5 stars if it wasn't for the wait time we had even with a reservation placed - however, I feel like they can redeem themselves next time around!

Loved eating in the garden room although it was a little warm. It is literally a greenhouse. My is sister and I arrived and were treated very nicely. We never were empty on water and the house sangria was very nice. I ordered the Cesar salad which was delicious. I got a red pasta and my sister had the ravioli. Both were delicious.
The food was incredible, the ambiance was outstanding and the service was excellent. If you love Italian you have to go!

Came here with 7:15 reservations with a total party of 5, but didn't get seated until 7:40. We were led to the back and ordered drinks while we waited. When we were seated, we ordered the fried calamari which was pretty good and the mozzarella. I opted for the Ragu del Macellaio and it was okay. I wished the dish came with more sauce since the cavatelli was so dense. The inside was really well decorated and the place was decently filled with people. Overall, I'd come back considering the size of the restaurant is very well accommodated to fit large parties.

As a 12 year resident of New York, I'm always hesitant to grab Italian food in little Italy. This restaurant is gem. Pasta is homemade. The house red wine was chef's kiss.   If visiting NY or shepherding your visitors to the city in Little Italy, stop by this place.

I'm torn between calling it a tourist trap or well decorated for the holiday season. One thing is for sure, the venue is well equipped to host large parties. It seemingly appeared to have never ending space.

On this note, given there was SO much empty space - my friends and I were waiting for 20 minutes with manager(s) and wait staff avoiding eye contact.

We ordered - very generous portions for all dishes:
1/ Linguine with garlic clams - appreciated the clams were still in shells but needed more garlic flavour; could use a bit more broth
2/ Fried cheese - definitely give it an order!
3/ Farfellete con Pollo - absolutely must order

During our dining service, the waiters were attentive, bubbly and energetic.

Would visit if in the neighborhood, but would not go out of my way to plan for!

Great, authentic Italian food! The ambience of this restaurant was great, and felt very authentic. The place was decorated beautifully, and the staff were all kind. The portions were very large. I had a large party, but we all got our food quickly and everyone loved what they got. Definitely would return here again.
Had a reservation and they kept saying that we hat to keep waiting. We waited over an hour and then we just left
Outstanding restaurant in the heart of Little Italy. We sample multiple appetizers (Polpette and Mussels) and had fantastic wine. Loved the service and the atmosphere. May be a new favorite in NYC.

We came here for a team event/dinner and it was very well received.  We had a choice of a few things to choose from and I chose the mushroom risotto and salmon...there were lots of appetizers...it was all very flavorful and wonderful.  

We had about 30+ people for dinner...and the restaurant thought we ere coming on Tuesday, instead of Monday.  And they were amazing in how they made it work...despite thinking we were coming the next day!  It worked!  Thank God!!!

We had a violinist play while we dined..and there was a couple that got engaged while we were there...it was a good evening. I took lots of pictures...will post them.

I took my boyfriend here for his birthday. I made reservations almost 3 weeks in advanced for 2 people at 8pm. We did not get seated until 9:15. We did not complain or make a fuss because we saw how busy the restaurant was. It was just very unfortunate that tables larger than 2 were getting seated before us.  The atmosphere of the restaurant for Christmas was beautiful. I would definitely consider this a tourist spot. The Caesar salad and burrata was amazing, definitely recomend ordering for start. For my main course I had the ragu del macellaio which the meat was delicious, but the pasta was a little too over cooked for me. I recommend coming earlier than prime time seating or later.

Borderline tourist trappy Italian spot in Little Italy. Our party of two was easily able to make a reservation on a Saturday night day of. Which tbh I thought was a bit of a red flag lol. We arrived early and the hostess ushered us to another empty part of the restaurant overlooking the garden room (which was gorgeous and where we had requested to sit). After several minutes past our reservation time were like wait did they forget about us lol. And we saw two people that came after us get seated before us in the garden room. Eventually we flagged someone down and we were immediately seated - but in another part of the restaurant, not the garden room. So that was a bit upsetting. We were given some bread and breadsticks with butter - which was subpar. The bread wasn't even the slightest bit toasted, breadsticks were dry and the butter was the kind in the yellow foil squares. We split an eggplant and cheese appetizer and it was delicious. Incredible and prompt service through and through. I really appreciated how our server split our appetizers for us on our plate, and the same thing with our main courses. Because my sister and I mentioned that we were going to split the lobster ravioli and the penne vodka, our waiter automatically had the two of those split for us on our plates. Which was so nice and something I honestly hadn't ever seen. We also got tiramisu on the house which was a nice gesture. Definitely a $$ type of spot. There were endearing moments but I don't think I'd necessarily return.

Fun fact - the late James Gandolfini (Sopranos) apparently used to come here; his photo is above the table he always used to sit at

Wonderful place with authentic Italian food.
Veal chop with mushrooms was out of this world!

Excellent food with above & beyond very PROFESSIONAL service!

Seriously, even if the food wasn't wonderful, (and it was truly top notch), the servers would have saved the day.  A really nice mixture of good service and having fun.

Loved it!  We'll be back soon.

I came across this cute spot on Yelp!
I came here yesterday for Valentine's Day dinner and this place did not disappoint. This was my first time dining at an Italian restaurant in Little Italy.  

Our server gave us some great recommendations for food.

Some dishes were not pictured but we started with the schiacciata di salsicce e carciofi and mussels fra diavolo. The schiaccata di salsicce was a pie consisted of sausage, artichoke and mozzarella. This dish was definitely underrated. From the first glance, it didn't look appealing but I was surprised that it was so good. We got the mussels fra diavolo with red sauce which was recommended by our server. I definitely recommend these two dishes.

For the main course we ordered the rigatoni speciale and the creamy penne vodka w/ shrimp. At this point we were stuffed from the bread, appetizers and drink.

For dessert we had the tiramisu and the cannoli. I usually don't prefer cannolis but they were delicious .

The decor and the ambiance was amazing. There was a cute table set up with 3 bears for the Valentine's Day theme. Although I wasn't seated in the garden room, I saw a quick glimpse. The garden room looked super scenic. I'd definitely recommend to reserve a spot in the garden room for a date.

Hmmm as for the service, I'd say that the service was just okay. From the busser to the server the service was alright. We had to ask multiple times for the check and our last round of drinks never came out. I understand that the service may have been mediocre since it was busy due to Valentine's Day. Nonetheless, the food was great!

Would I come back? For sure

Came here today for the restaurant week lunch special with a friend. The patio is really cute to sit so I was excited about that. I wasn't sure if it was outdoors, but it's Indoors extension of the restaurant with a sunroof.

Started off with the bread. I tried the one with the tomatoes on top. It was good, very thick, but good. We ordered the calamari and Cesar salad to start which were both really good. The Calamari was lightly fried and the Marinara sauce  was good.

I ordered the pork chop and my friend ordered the vodka penne w chicken. The sauce wasn't really vodka. It was def more marinara. It was just a regular pasta dish with chicken and sauce. I liked my pork, but wasn't what I expected. I knew it would be a breaded piece of pork but I didn't know it was a pounded flat piece that was served the way it was served. If I knew I would have just ordered chicken Parm. The dish def needed a vegetable or some pasta, sauce, or something on the side.

My friend got a dessert in a cup which was delicious. I don't remember the name but her dessert was really good, some kind of moose, My cheesecake I wasn't a fan of. It was dry, not creamy at all. Had a lemon taste..I didn't finish that.

Overall the service was good, but We were both slightly disappointed in main course.

Saw this place on Instagram and please do not believe the hype . The food is tasteless, didn't really get to experience the services. The server seem to be offend when asked to take it back . The ravioli yuck and the sausage linguine epic fall . Once again tasteless and undercook .

Now the drinks was awesome ! The Old fashion and the Lemon Drop get 5stars . They can keep the food though!!!

Il Cortile is the place to go for fresh, authentic Italian food! My friends and I ordered the gnocchi and ended up putting in additional orders as the night went on since it was so good. The servers were lovely and we enjoyed our time dining here. We'll be back soon!
Delicious! Best food we had on our trip to NYC. The atmosphere was exactly what I would hope for in a Little Italy restaurant. The waiters were wonderful and kind. Can't wait to go back someday!

The food was good but the service was exceptional. The waiters were extremely attentive and were constantly (but not too frequently) checking in on us and making sure we had everything we needed.

We got the gnocchi and the capellini piselli. The gnocchi was good but I have a preference for meat sauces. I was quite fond of the capellini and thought the sauce was particularly good. The generous portion sizes also ensured no one in the party finished their meal still feeling hungry.

Good food, spectacular service, 4/5.

Wait : we did rsvp
Place: a bit loud , and a bit crowded, it's good for group and won't plan to go there alone
Food: we ordered lobster ravioli, chicken parm some appetizers . They all come with big portions and really delicious. Chicken is very tender, juicy and delicious. Pasta is well cooked. We also ordered a side dish for spinach and I love it.
Service : very informative, super nice and attentive.
Drink: espresso martinis is ok, not very special
Price : worth the price
Overall: would love to come back
Love! Always a nice spot to eat at in little Italy. My dish was great the fettuccini di parma but the bolognese was not our favorite. Overall a yummy spot!
Food was very good, gnocchi was excellent. Waiter your knowledgeable about the food specialties. Would definitely go back.

I was blown away by the incredible service and kind staff... I was meeting a friend and some of her friends, who I had never met, who turned out to be rude and awful. The staff at Il Cortile let myself and my (service) dog sit in the waiting area the whole time while my friends were over and hour late... they held the table for us and were so incredibly sweet to my dog. This was during the San Gennaro festival so they were super busy, I couldn't believe how lovely they were to us. After ordering one drink at a time, my table then refused to order entrees and decided they wanted street food instead. If I were the server at that point, I probably would have cursed us out! Instead, the wonderful service continued, and they remained light-hearted and kind, even taking multiple pictures of us when asked (mortifying!)... I can't wait to come back here without these assholes to actually try the food, which looked AMAZING. But what a wonderful staff they have at this place!
This is one of the best spots in Little Italy among many pretenders, food, service and ambiance Ill Cortile hits all three bars for me.

*chefs kiss*

Maaaammaaamiaaa! Talk about delicious. I brought my bestie here for her birthday and we had a wonderful time.
We sat outside and enjoyed music from a local playing his accordion. It was so nice and added an extra touch to the experience. I ordered the prosciutto stuffed jumbo shrimp, which were mouth wateringly good. The sauce they laid on was creamy and cheesey. I'm a big fan of shrimp and when it's stuffed that's even better! The food tasted fresh and arrived rather quickly after being ordered.
We had passion fruit margaritas and watermelon martinis. The passion fruit margaritas were made with REAL passion fruit, there were small chunks in the drink which I really liked.
Totally recommend this spot for a lunch or a dinner date or celebration, or a laid back evening.
Food and service was OK. The risotto and the vegetables pasta with capers was our favorite. The restaurant was spacious enough for our large group.

Was recommended this place by a friend and it did NOT disappoint! It was a beautiful day so we sat outside, and their sidewalk set up was so cute! Great curb appeal. The staff was wonderful as well. We had at least 3 people stopping by to check on us, refill wine, clear the table, and make sure we were happy.

The food was delicious, every person in our party was raving! We started with the stuffed mushrooms and the calamari for appetizers, and both were amazing. I ordered the Ragu del Macellaio, which was their version of sunday sauce. This goes quick, limited amounts on saturday and sunday because it's that good so get there early! My wife had the Capellini Piselli e Prosciutto Speciali, and one of our friends had the Penne Creamy Vodka with Chicken. We each tried the others and all agreed that this place is a 10/10. Our other friend had the Fettuccine di Parma and refused to share because it was that good! Wasn't willing to part with any of it and cleared his plate completely, so the lesson is you really can't go wrong here!

We finished with the red velvet cake, which didn't have a ton of icing and that was a good thing! Icing sometimes gets put on so thick it overpowers the cake. My wife is VERY anti icing and she loved it and said it was a perfect ratio of icing to cake.  

Definitely stop by this place and give yourself enough time to sit back, relax and enjoy!

A lovely restaurant with GREAT food.  Everything I had was freshly prepared, I ordered several seafood items from the menu, and the service was excellent.  Say HELLO to The King and The Prince as they are usually near the door to greet patrons.  They add character to your dining experience if you are lucky enough to share conversations with them during your stay.  Highly Recommended

Came here with my boyfriend on a Friday night around 7:30 and right after coming in, there were so many parties joining the restaurant. It does get pretty pack as the night go on. The waiters are very friendly and attentive. We ordered Fettuccine di Parma and  Farfallette con Pollo. We told the waiter that we were going to share and he offered to help us divide the pasta. The pasta dishes were pretty good. I also ordered a strawberry mojito, it was warm even though there was ice but it was weak in alcohol.

Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5

The food is horrible. We paid 209 dollars for 3 dishes after waiting 1 hour. The dishes included two basic and regular tomato sauce pasta that you can cook at home.

The wine is simply disgusting. My girlfriend threw up. Please do not take into consideration the good reviews of this restaurant. Unbelievable

Best Italian restaurant on Mulberry Street & NYC. Atmosphere is great. The Garden room makes it feel like summer anytime of the year. Everything was delicious. The linguine Cicale I must have ordered over a dozen times from various Italian restaurants all over the country. This right here was best I ever had, hands down. The sauce was full of robust flavor. Chunks of garlic was a nice addition. And the seafood was fresh and cooked to perfection as was the pasta . Could eat this 3X a day, every day. The food was a crowd pleaser for all.
We were looking for a good Italian restaurant and we definitely found it , love the place food ,service and drinks.
Traditional Italian Restaurant in Little Italy.  We loved the evening. Food was delicious and our server had the right look and attitude.

Average pasta, but overall disappointed being that it is in Little Italy. My mom, sister, brother-in-law and I were visiting from across the country and wanted good Italian food/pasta one night. We found this place which had great reviews online and was a recommended restaurant on a popular foodie website. We all got a different pasta dish, chicken parm, a tomato based rigatoni, vodka cream rigatoni, and gnocchi. We came in expecting homemade fresh pasta, this did not seem homemade, and certainly wasn't fresh. As far as the taste of the sauces, I thought they were very good, however overall it just didn't live up to my standards and We left slightly disappointed. The staff was very friendly however which was nice. If you are looking for fresh pasta, I would recommend elsewhere.

Great ambiance inside the restaurant. We passed by this restaurant multiple times and decided to have dinner here. Wasn't all I thought it was. There was someone going around and playing music, which was nice. Someone came around taking pictures, which we thought was nice as well. Both occasions we had to pay or shall I say "mandatory payment". Again, we didn't mind because we were in good company. I had a few appetizers, and the meatball was delicious! I had the special for the night which was a steak topped with olives, peppers and capers. That was the most over salted piece of meat I have ever had in my life.

Customer service was decent, I expected better table service. When we sat down we had someone bring us water and bread, which not sure if the bread offered was suppose to be cold. From the time we waited to order appetizers and drinks it took 20 minutes, we tried multiple times to flag our waiter but was no where to be found. 40 mins later he comes and takes our order. Disappointed.

The restaurant was beautiful and the staff was very friendly. While the food was not the best the atmosphere was nice enough for me to want to return. We were initially seated outside, but due to the weather the waiter kindly moved us inside and even provided us with a free beverage.

We were looking for a good Italian place in Little Italy that could accomodate my allergies (gluten and black pepper - which is a hard one!).  As we were walking down the street, we were bombard one by one from each restaurant.   We stopped to look at Piccolo Bufalo's menu and at that moment, a paper flew out of a gentleman's hand that was sitting there.  My husband went to grab it and the man came over to talk to us.  We talked to him about my allergies and answered all our questions and did not pressure us to eat there like everyone else.  They were having a special also!  We decided to give it a try and boy were we not disappointed!  The gentleman was the owner (I am sorry we did not get your name!) and we chatted a little bit after we ate.  My husband got the chicken parm with alfredo sauce instead of red sauce and it looked like it could feed three people!  I debated between the vodka pasta and alfredo and asked our waitress what she recommended and she suggested the alfredo so that is what I went with.

We were in from Pittsburgh and will be coming back next time we are in town.   Thank you for making sure everything was great.  Everything was delicious and the hospitality was great!!

A very nice stop in the little Italy are of New York.  The ambiance is good just liker everything about this place.  You must know that this is one of many similar shops on the street that offer almost all the same.

We chose this above the rest as they offered authentic Naples pizza.  We spent time in Naples and ate pizza many times there.   This pizza was close but not the same.  The bruschetta was burned and drenched in oil.  Not how it should be.

Service was ok and timely, but everyone around us was very annoyed.   You have to know that this place is run like an old world Italian restaurant in Naples.  They let you sit there for hours if you want and really don't bother you.

Get the special chicken parm special.  Host was incredibly nice and welcoming when I cruised by.  Great music inside, amazing food, and decorated well for Halloween.  Would come by again when I'm back in Little Italy.

I always appreciate nice employee's it makes the experiences extremely enjoyable. The food was really good! The pizza was perfect, it was light and not heavy. It was crispy and held itself really well. The Fettuccine Alfredo wasn't greasy or heavy, it was really delicious.
I also am a huge salad eater and their arugula salad was perfect! Ugh, I could eat it all day everyday!

I was looking for a budget friendly meal for a late lunch, and finally decided on this spot. With a selection of five different specials today ranging from a meat lasagna, to manicotti for just $13.95. I asked my waitress, who was lovely, her favorite and she recommended the spaghetti and meatballs! The pasta was cooked perfectly and the sauce was great. They were not my favorite meatballs, but it is a good I am picky about because I cook them myself. Overall, a fantastic little spot with a great vibe, good music, and nice staff :-) (the more i ate the meatballs the better they got!)
I love this place. It's a quaint Italian restaurant in little Italy. It has great pizza, really good prices, and good soups!
Dave gave a good score and pizza was fine but no big deal. 6.7 imo but I'm not the Presidente.

Went back for a second try and we weren't disappointed. This time we had a pepperoni pizza and shrimp
parmigiana.
