We had churro-esque donuts for dessert. The caramel and dulce de leche ones were so good. We didn't enjoy the blueberry(?) one as much.

Overall, this place is a little expensive for what you get. Not sure that I'll be returning but maybe for a drink and a little photo op ;)! Rating: 3.5/5.

We hosted an event at IXTA in the city  yesterday and it was absolutely phenomenal.

We had about 50-60 guests.
IXTA team did a fantastic job with the food and drinks
They gave us so many delicious  and flavorful vegetarian options for our guests ! The appetizers were served so beautifully and once again so many options.

Great cocktails and wide selection of beers and wine and of course mezcal.

Would highly recommend the place for hosting big or small events .
The service is top notch

Excellent service, fun ambiance, and great food and drinks! We loved our experience and had a great time. The food was hot, tasty, and they had a good amount of vegetarian options. The drinks were fantastic and our server was very attentive and made sure we were well taken care of. Its giving Tulum vibes in the best way!

IXTA Cocina & Mezcal Bar is a true NYC gem in a city filled with good restaurants.  The large space is tastefully decorated with authentic hand carved artifacts from Mexico; the bar area is stunning with a very sexy vibe.  The cocktails are to die for with my personal favorite being the Santo Remidio which is mezcal based with basil and hoja santa (a South American herb from the peppercorn family).  The food in my opinion is the best Mexican cuisine in all of the United States.  The recipes are authentic and very unique and the quality of meats, seafood, and produce used comes shining through.   Must have appetizers on the menu are the Pulpo Zarandeado (charred octopus with almond pasilla adobo) and Char Grilled Mayan Prawns (served with chilis, garlic, and onions).  For the main course, we loved the NY Strip (served with guacamole, grilled spring onions, and pico de gallo) as well as the Whole Grilled Branzino (served with 2 salsas and furikake).  Our vegetarian friends loved the Enchiladas Diovorciadas which was served with house made mole rojo and mole negro.  For the sides, please don't miss the Esquites made with local corn, and the Zanahoria which is roasted baby carrots with a sherry piloncillo glaze.  For dessert the tres leches as well as churro balls with ice cream are both outstanding.  Bottom line is that we have been to IXTA twice this week already and cannot wait to go back again soon!

Always love trying new Mexican restaurants! Came on a Sunday night, it's a very large and well decorated space but was almost empty. Probably because it's still pretty new. Idk if their heater was broken that day but it was FREEZING. Even the staff was wearing jackets.

Temperate aside, the food was all very good. Standouts were the Elote and the birria tacos. First time trying goat meat tacos and they did not disappoint.

Extensive cocktail list, their spicy marg is actually spicy!

The portions are pretty tiny for the price though which less than ideal. But surprisingly all their cocktails are under $18 which seems to be a rarity in nyc.

Worth trying before this place becomes IG popular, just be warned you'll be spending a pretty penny!

My friend and I went on a weekday evening, and ah the ambiance is so romantic and sweet! Felt like lots of first dates there. My friend and I both opted for the Restaurant Week menu (3 courses for $60/person) and got:
1. Guacamole - very good!
2. Ixta Salad - surprisingly delicious and quite large!
3. Pollo Rostizado - half the dish had a mole sauce and the other half just tasted like bland grilled chicken. Not sure what this dish was supposed to accomplish.
4. Enchiladas Divorciadas - The food wasn't hot when it got to us and it was just warm. The tortilla was somewhat hard so it felt like eating day-old tacos or something. Flavors were meh.
5. Mango Ice Cream - this was alright, not as mango-y as I'd like and it just tasted like cream
6. Tres Leches - I love tres leches generally but this was just sponge cake with whipped cream and some berries. Idk where the milk was supposed to be because this didn't have it.

So yes, the appetizers were superb but then it all went downhill from there. I felt very disappointed given that it came out to $77/person post-tax and tip. The flavors just weren't there:( Portion sizes were good though, my friend and I were stuffed after everything. Our waiter, Christian, was kind and attentive.

Great food and ambiance.  The decor is really nice inside and the tables are well separated.   The mole in the enchiladas divorciadas is delicious.  The squash blossom tacos consist of a squash blossom stuffed with cheese then fried in a tempura-like batter and paired with a slaw. The Al pastor sauce in the Brussels sprouts was tasty.  Service was also on-point. They brought a clean set of plates, re-filled water and the waiter was quite courteous.

This place is physically beautiful, the staff are welcoming and accommodating, and the food is superb. Apps included the pulpo (octopus) which was perfectly cooked, the flavors were amazing and no, I don't have a pic because it looked good and we just dug in. The other app was the ceviche mixto (again no photo) and that was a treat, it came in leche de tigre, perfect blend of heat, citrus, and flavor. Entrees (pictured below) were the birria tacos and pollo rostizado were delicious. The goat and consume for the tacos were really good. The mole sauce with the roasted chicken was divine. I'll be back.

New spot! Came across their social media and decided to bring a group of friends. We started off with a round of margaritas and Paloma's (the spicy margarita is VERY spicy). We ordered a bunch of appetizers and main and shared everything. The stand out the only dish with rib (chef kiss). The staff was very welcoming and gave us two extra desserts. The prices are high $20+ for two birria tacos. Overall it was a great experience.

Went in to get a couple drinks before dinner at another bar. Randomly walked into this place and pleasantly surprised we did! The bar is aesthetically pleasing and the drinks we had were great. Definitely want to come back and try the food Next!

What a let down. The food was decent though the portions were small, but what really raised my hackles was that they charged $4 for a tablespoon of habanero sauce and another $4 for a few extra tortilla chips to go with the guacamole. All this on top of a very pricey menu. The $17 drinks (spicy margarita and Oaxacan Negroni) were also rather wimpy and evidently low on alcohol.
Overall, we left both disappointed and annoyed with their nickel and dime attitude. If you're looking for a classy Mexican restaurant try Maya on the UES or one of the Rosa Mexicano locations. Of course there are many more cheaper and way more satisfying options around, including our recent go to place, Nina's Burrito, on the UWS.

Just miserable. Honestly one of the worst meals I ever had and extremely overpriced.

If you ever want your night ruined, come here.

nothing memorable. good cocktails, fairly priced wine selection, unsurprising and uninspiring modern interpretation of Mexican food. chic atmosphere. funny belly dancer with fire tricks, don't know why she was there. you'll spend a good amount of money here, better spend somewhere else unless you need space and sitting time with a large group of friends.
Awesome atmosphere, music was awesome as well as the food. Would definitely come back. Highly recommend the short ribs and enchiladas

Came here for a friends birthday dinner and was overall disappointed because there was no music nor a fun atmosphere that we were expecting  (the manager did let us know the DJ cancelled last minute).

Service and management was very friendly -- 5 stars!

The food was pretty average, expected a lot more given the price tags.

The drinks were excellent.

Overall would recommend for a drink, not for a meal or dinner party based on our experience!

If you are looking for a classy but fun Mexican spot, look into IXTA. This place made me feel like I was in Tulum eating some amazing food. The portions were small, so it was the only downside. I did like the mezcal flights. Give it a try!

Great service and food! The host was a bit off putting but easily ignored and forgotten once we were seated.
Oysters, Branzino, corn, guacamole all were good and the Don Hemingway cocktail was amazing!

My girlfriend and I stumbled into this  place after a great sushi dinner, accompanied by a lot of saki. So take note, this was a "late night" stop-in (we're 40+ so "late" is usually 9PM ;) and we definitely didn't plan it. That said, from the ambiance to the bartenders, this place is awesome! We had a few specialty cocktails recommended to us by the bartender and were extremely happy. What did us in was the flight of Mezcal we had before leaving. As delicious as they all were, at 11PM, we were hammered! Regardless, if you like tequila and Mezcal, this is your spot!!

Former DBGB restaurant/bar, which has been unoccupied since 2017. Given the previous Boulud establishment, I had high hopes for IXTA. Service was lacking; it took over 20 minutes to receive drinks. The tables were too large for a group of 6; it felt spread out and awkward. Next time I would prefer a table instead of a booth. There are many Mexican options nearby; IXTA definitely has the highest price tag. The food was nothing special and small portions. They need to serve more than 3 large chips with the guac.

Top notch service and ambiance, but most of the food was fairly bland and incredibly expensive.  The ceviche was almost devoid of flavor.  That said,  the tacos, and cocktails were fantastic and so was the dessert.  Go for them!

We went to Ixta on a Thursday night and started off with a spicy marg by the bar - 10/10. The aesthetic is on point and both the drinks and food were beyond delicious. The Birria tacos are an absolute must, however, the steak, duck tacos,  guac, salsa trio and ceviche were close seconds!! I suggest sharing with friends so you can try it all. Will definitely be back!!

Ixta is a phenomenal new restaurant in town. The decor and ambiance gives Tulum x modern mexican and the drinks are delicious. To start we got the tuna tartare and the octopus. The tuna tartare is very good, a little creamy (exactly how I like it) and the octopus was one of the best dishes I've had in 2022. It melted in your mouth and was so flavorful. Next we got the "truffle tots" which was so good, perfect amount of truffle and cheese and then the full head branzino which was so refreshing. I highly recommend this place from their food and drinks to their vibes and artwork!

Ixta is one of the best new restaurants in NYC!  I went there this past weekend with my wife and we had an incredible experience.  You can tell right away when you walk in that every detail of the restaurant was well thought out, from the bar, artwork; the interiors were very refreshing and contemporary.

Everything we had on the menu, including the cocktails were excellent.  We would highly recommend the Guacamole, Ceviche,  Birria Tacos, and the Prawns El Diablo.

On top of the great food, the service was on point; with our server consistently checking in on us to see if we wanted anything else.

Overall I highly recommend Ixta; whether it's for a date night or a night out with friends!  The food, drinks, and service are all top-notch and we cannot wait to be back!
The guacamole was delicious! The only negative here are the portions are a bit small. I thought the veggie enchiladas were good, but probably would order something different next time.

They only have brunch menu on Saturday during the afternoon and there's NOTHING plant based on it. Also, they had no toilet paper in the bathrooms (all 3) and I told multiple people and they couldn't care less. Nobody have enough s*** to actually put TP in the bathrooms. Stay away.

We went on a weeknight, and were pretty much the only customers in a place that is cavernous by Manhattan standards. The food, the decor, the service were all really good.
Our friends immediately decided to order enough guacamole for the whole group. I usually don't get restaurant guacamole, since it's pretty easy to make at home, but am glad we got this, because it was unusually tasty. It had some vinegar-y flavor that was a nice contrast to the avocado.
Big selection of mezcals, if that's your thing.
The prices were on the high side, because the rent at such a prime location at Bowery and Houston must be insane. A mixed drink at $18 is just a sad fact of life in the big city. They have to get the money from somewhere, and nobody NEEDS alcohol to stay alive.
Anyway, my partner and I got around the high prices somewhat by ordering a whole grilled branzino for $40 and sharing it. The fish was delicious; in fact, all the food was. I wonder if the fact that the location is so prominent maybe deters Mexican food fans; if the place were a tiny hole-in-the-wall with the same chef, it would be a huge hit. Definitely worth a try, for a special occasion.

BEWARE OF PRICE GOUGING!!! I went there for my 50th birthday dinner, some friends and family. Total of 7 of us. The ambiance was nice. The food was decent. My husband and I do enjoy a good mezcal drink. He asked for mezcal with some simple Guave juice, nothing extraordinary. We did all order food and drinks. I completely understand that we are in a recession and that the prices went up. However, $43 per drink is insane and unheard of. I can buy a whole bottle of Mezcal for 50 bucks.  I've been to many restaurants in the city and the most I've ever paid for a drink is $20.  After spending all that money, they didn't even offer shots or anything on the house, especially for someone's birthday. I felt so bad for my family and friends who had to spend all that money for mediocre drinks. The manager and our Waitress did not even try to address our issue with the bill. So, disappointed
Usually sitting at the bar but the service everytime was amazing. Kiki is an expert at drinks and super attentive. The food is great especially the ceviche and branzino. Definitely a must!

One word: catfish. New to the city in 2023, after looking at Instagram I thought this place was going to be a fun brunch spot. Unfortunately, that is not the case. I was fooled by an Instagram promo video, lol. First of all, they play elevator music, I was there at noon on a Sunday, and it was totally empty, which is prime brunch time. The only reason I am giving a 2 star review is because of the way the place was decorated.
This place is absolutely amazing - from the food to the cocktails to the detailed decor and vibe, y'all have to check it out!  IXTA is my new go-to spot for sure!

The decor here is amazing. Great spot for date night...but...don't go there if you're super hungry lol. Service was decent and the dishes are delish but they're on the pricey side considering the portions you receive.

I went for a group dinner on a Friday night and was blown away by this restaurant. The ambiance serves to transport you to another place. I felt like I was on a tropical vacation in Tulum instead of in New York on a cold January day. I tried the Oaxacan Negroni & the El Carajito del Este and both cocktails were incredibly well balanced and paired beautifully with the Enchiladas Divorciadas. Overall, the vibes were immaculate and I definitely see myself going back very soon - 10/10, I would highly recommend.

My time here at Ixta was very nice. I came to celebrate my birthday with a few friends. The drinks were strong and the food was delicious. I got the Birria Tacos and a spicy margarita. We also got guac for the table with these delicious tostadas. For dessert we ended with these yummy little churro donut holes. There were many photo ops which definitely was a plus! The downside was honestly the service and my friends and I felt that the menu was a bit limited and lacked some Hispanic essentials such as rice and beans. We continuously had to flag our waiter down and during our 90 mins stay and voluntarily came by once. Overall 3.3/5.

I went for a birthday with a group of 7 and the service messed up the night, we waiter sat us and then just took the order and never came back to ask how we we're doing , we have to call him several times to order drinks and stuff, and it was pretty annoying, my friends order a "birthday dessert" and asked if a "little show " was going to be provided when they brought out the dessert, he said yes, but it never happened, on top of that , they order the dessert at 9:30 pm and apparently he forgot about it , and brought out at 10:40 pm , and on top of that, there was only 1 people at the table , so we had to run from the bathroom before the candle turn off.

When the bill came , it was 20% gratitude included , which came out to $100 for tip , (when someone provided a good service , you pay the tip happily ) but this was not it .... We kindly asked the manager that we wanted to lower the the tip amount, because the service just wasn't there. He didn't even bother to ask what did the waiter did wrong, and just left .

Overall food was good, menu does not have many options, portions are very small and pricey . Really nice romantic ambiance , but BIG changes need to be made, they need a better manager

Food was pretty good which makes it more unfortunate that the service is so horrendous. The abnormally long wait time for drinks vs. short time for food made dinner not enjoyable. Had wait staff literally tap their fingers impatiently on the table as we finished our food so they could clear the table and take plates that we were still eating from. Don't waste your time or money at this restaurant.

The waiter was incredibly rude and the food came two hours late (and not what we had ordered). On top of that, when the check came, they tried adding several items onto the bill and we had to "negotiate" the check with the manager.

The food itself was small portioned and low quality. Will not be returning.

The cocktail menu is almost exclusively mezcal and tequila which is so fun jf you're a fan. There was one gin drink which was good. The bar appeared to have a decent selection of vodka and other options. For food we split the tuna tostada, esquites and birria tacos. Everything was incredible. The decor and scene here are also great. Can't recommend this place enough.

If you love Tulum, IXTA is the place you want to go. When you walk in, you immediate feel tulum vibes with the beautiful tropical decor, paintings, and sculptures. My friends and I went for brunch and enjoy the ambiance and chill music. All of the food we ordered was also excellent, you get your monies worth as the portion are very generous. Food is an eclectic Mexican mix; full of rich flavor. If you like spicy, ask for the hot sauce! I absolutely love the space at IXTA, great restaurant for a team dinner or company outing. I can't wait to go back again!

Just left the restaurant now. The place was very cool and seated us fairly quickly. They had a live band and a woman who was dancing with fire sticks which was different and cool. The food was good. The salsa, guac, and tacos were good. The chicken was good and the papas bravas was good too. The cocktails were also good. The only thing I'll say is that the service was a tiny bit unorganized but they were super busy so that's probably why. Overall was a great service experience and would be back for sure!

food and ambience were great. But the service was of the worst kind....our waitress was pushy and miscommunicated menu items and quantity to us so we would order more. She came to our table once every 15 minutes asking us if we would like more time or to order more. we didn't understand why this was happening since we came to our reservation on time and the restaurant was supposed to be open for another 3 hours? We felt rushed and pushed to order and spend more than we wanted to. Left a bad taste in my mouth.

We went to Ixta last night for a birthday celebration and it was wonderful! The food was delicious and amazing and the drinks were creative. The atmosphere was fun and the space is big, yet cozy. But most of all, we were impressed with the service. After a server accidentally broke a glass of red wine which spilled all over my friend's white top, the servers and manager went above and beyond to make it right - including comping our entire meal. We assumed they would buy us a round of drinks, but we were blown away by their ownership of a simple accident. We will return and highly recommend Ixta!!

Dined there last evening with my husband and our friend. It took 30 minutes to get our drinks. Ultimately they were unenjoyable. Very watered down. Seemed to me the margaritas were batched (with ice) and then served over ice. We ordered four apps and one entree to start and let the server know we wanted to order the remainder of the entrees shortly following. Birria tacos were good. Ceviche good but overpriced and the flautas, super dry. Presentation is lovely but the service and food were no good. The music was also terrible and ridiculously loud. My entree never arrived nor did anyone come by the table to take the rest of our order. I did manage to track the gentleman down and place an order for a non watered down Margarita and a glass of wine for our friend. That Margarita was wonderful.
Sooooo good!!!! Guac was amongst best I've ever had.. tried the birria tacos-- goat is a first for me but i loved it!!!!

Don't go to Ixta.  The service is so bad and because we were a party of 6+ it was a mandatory 20% tip.  Drinks were forgotten, food came out extremely slowly, couldn't get the bill for 30 minutes.  I've rarely had experiences this bad in New York.  If you want a similar vibe, I'd recommend Tao, Catch, Budakkan

Went for Brunch with my girls to this new spot and I must say we were thinking it was going to be cool and great food and it was a mess. The menu was lack luster. Eggs were over done and my niece found a peace of glass in her drink. Its like they are trying to be this hip place but who has a belly dancer in a Mexican restaurant and the DJ was from NJ and didn't know the nyc vibes. The owner bought us shots that were just pinapple juice and we just wanted to get out and save our time and go to Beuty and Essexs. Will never come here again:(
Service was not good at all, food and drinks were not worth the visit. Will not be returning. It's like who's running this place, what a waste.

Ambiance and cocktails were  but they definitely have some kinks to work out. The staff did not seem to know the menu, couldn't speak to what was in the dishes or how they come prepared.  The menu itself is a bit misleading. $20 for a single short rib taco which wasn't actually a taco.  Food and drinks took a long time to come out and when they finally did I reminded our waitress that we were missing something we ordered and took so long to come out that the rest of our food got cold. Overall, has promise to be good but they need some fine tuning.
The food and cocktails were incredibly delicious and the staff was super friendly and helpful. Will definitely be coming back!

Stopped by around 11 on a friday night and the place was maybe a third-full.  Bartenders were cool and friendly.  Music selection good. Decided to give it a go.  Bartender's suggested beer was spot on.

Place picked up and was packed from 12 to close.  Music got considerably louder, though no less good and not loud enough to make us leave.  Crowd seemed to be mostly NYU kids and recent grads, really relaxed.

Cant speak to the food; the kitchen was closed (due to rennovation?)  And is supposed to be back in a couple days.  I'll definitely be back to check it out.

This place had only been open a few weeks apparently when Eric and I stopped by on Christmas Day. I got to try a winter beer that I had been wanting to try for only $3 (they have a nightly special where one beer is $3/pint). The walls have record covers on them and they had a nice collection of records and eight tracks(!). The bartender was really friendly. I would definitely return here, especially for the $3 beers.
CASH ONLY!

Nice change of pace in an area full of busy bars. The beers they had on limited tap were pretty good and they have a $3 crappy beer special. The bartender goes out for a smoke occasionally but I like the laid back chill feel of the place.

Leave Max Fish, walk across the street, and enjoy Imperial Tavern.  We were able to walk in, sit at the bar, enjoy a friendly bartender, get a great beer, and listen to some fine tunes.  The walls are covered with LP jackets and there's a great record collection behind the bar.  The kitchen was closed, looked like it was closed for more than the night, so I'm not sure what's going on there.  Definitely give this spot a go, good space that wasn't crowded with all the things you'd want in a bar.

Inconsistent and go there, don't get delivery.  They recently changed hot sauce and tahini (for no reason as both were good) and now terrible.   The falafel balls and pita bread are amazing in the falafel sandwich - truly best I've ever had.  And the other ingredients (red cabbage, pickles) are great.  But depending on the person, they sometimes shove all the salad at the bottom so you get only falafel at first then nothing but cabbage and pickles on the bottom.  The tahini and hot sauce used to be great - but I went tonight and they changed the hot sauce to some weird chipotle smoky sauce that tasted more Mexican.   I've gone there and they're super friendly.  If you watch them make it and ask them to spread ingredients throughout sandwich or ask for something different or extra, they're nice and accommodating.    I've had delivery and it was soggy, falafel balls side dish were dry vs with garnish, tahini, salad on bottom.  I'll go back as the falafel balls/sandwich can be delicious. But will watch and instruct them (and leave out horrible red pepper sauce).

Doesnt look like much from the outside and was pretty pathetic of an excuse for Indian/Middle Eastern food. The so called chicken tikka was just boiled chicken. Got a katti roll and the paratha was uncooked! I almost never write Yelp reviews but this one was so bad that I had to spend 3 minutes of my time writing up this place. Definitely not worth it!

I was part of a 20 person party in the downstairs wine room for a big birthday celebration dinner.  Every course was tasty and well prepared and flavorful.  Course timing was appropriate and we started out with cheese and varied charcuterie and plenty of wine. You knew early on that you were in a high quality establishment. Excellent bread, wide selection of apps (Calimari, a nice salad, fancy grill cheese type of item).  The entrees (pasta, Beef, Pesce for me) were all top notch.  A nice selection of Italian desserts were served- lemon pound cake was especially good.
The ambiance of being in a private room with 5,000 wine bottles made the event even more special and enjoyable. The staff did not allow guests to take pictures while standing on the ladders used to reach wines on the top shelf- probably a really good idea. Restrooms are only on the main level.....
Service was highly professional. I can't speak to prices and value but from an attendee perspective it was a great evening. I highly recommend.

It's a miracle we got same day reservation at this gem of a place. Highly recommend this place :)

So it's very vibey and the decor is extremely nice. Somehow it works for both date night and friend gatherings.

They have a great wine selection so pls get advice from their sommelier unless you know what you want and what goes  with what!

Started with their pumpkin flower ricotta cheese fritters (yup that's what I'm calling it because believe it or not my culture also has a similar dish :)) nicely fried well flavored and beautiful appetizer

I ordered the tagliatelle that had truffle shavings all over. It went just right with my Sangiovese

The other pastas my friends ordered were also delicious. The rigatoncini comes highly recommended as well.

Listen to their specials as we ordered from that list and were extremely pleased. One was a version of the bolognese and the other was a good ol carbonara variation

They also have olive oil tasting btw if you are interested :)

Overall, extremely nice dinner place

From start to finish, every moment of our experience was impeccable. The vibe inside is so cozy and inviting, with a warm and rustic feel. We started with the Croquetas and the Olive Oil Tasting, which was such an interesting and enjoyable experience. We both had the Halibut, which has a citrus salad on top and was served on a bed of olive oil mashed potatoes (incredible). We could not say no to dessert and went with the flourless chocolate cake and the most amazing, fluffy light "donuts" in a berry sauce.
Our server was so kind and attentive. It truly was such an enjoyable evening. I look forward to the opportunity to come back!

An extremely authentic Italian dining experience. I felt I had teleported to a family run restaurant in the heart of Firenze or Bologna.

Came here with mom as she was in town for the week. The only res was for outdoor and I was a bit skeptical, but it was a great overall experience.

We both got a glass of Chianti and started with the Salumi platter and the Kale salad.

Eating with mom is the best because she eats like a mouse, so I essentially get my entree and 93% of hers. I ordered the Bistecca and she got the Torchio. A perfect steak-pasta pairing like Kobe-Shaq, Bonnie and Clyde, Shrek and Donkey, Kobe-Pau, etc...

Everything was fantastic and Il Buco has become a goto Italian spot in the city for me.

Very cozy ambience inside and almost always crowded. They also have an awesome wine cell downstairs that would be perfect for small events like an engagement party.

Food is consistently good even though their menu is always changing. Some things are definitely better than others though so definitely worth asking your server what they recommend.

Our server was great - attentive and knowledgeable and not overbearing.

Il Buco has been my favorite restaurant in NYC for over a decade and a remains one of my top 5 world wide. It is the place I go for the farm to table rustic Italian food I grew up on in a setting that feels like home. The food is more like you would find in Tuscany than Mulberry street (not that there is anything wrong with a good red sauce joint). As a fixture of the neighborhood, they even host an annual pig roast that feels like a NYC block party.

NB: the menu constantly changes to feature what is in season, but the kale Caesar is always on the menu and a well earned claim to fame. Many plates are small-medium size portions so it is best to get a few things from across the menu and share. The Somms are great, as is the rest of the staff if it is your first time or you have questions.

I came here for an early dinner after work on a Tuesday night.  After reading the reviews posted on Yelp, I was really excited to try their dishes, especially the pasta with truffles.

When I arrived, I learned very quickly that the menu changed daily, so they didn't have the taglatelle with truffles. However, my server highly recommended that I still order the taglatelle because it's made in-house. This pasta dish was made with figs and pancetta.
Service was great overall. My server was knowledgeable and an upseller. My server was trying to persuade me to pair my pasta meal with a very strong wine.

The highlights of this dining experience were the Bikini sandwich and the Panna cotta. I absolutely agree with the other reviewers who posted they these two dishes are a must get.

The bikini sandwich is to die for especially paired with the red wine (r. Grosjean Gamay), which was really good. I'd definitely would order this again.

The Panna Cotta was also amazing. The way this dish was served was the Panna cotta was presented plain, and the server pours the right amount of aged balsamic vinegar to create that perfect balance flavor. It's definitely a science, and it's worth trying.

I want to go back to try their pasta with truffle dish that people are raving about.

Ambiance and food is great - definitely a romantic restaurant good for a date with the dark environment and candlelit tables. Our server was really patient while we fumbled with the wine and food menu. We thought it was a bit strange that we had to order everything upfront (appetizers, salads, pastas, meat), instead of ordering it course by course. However, he made some helpful recommendations and we went with the burrata with cherries, truffle pasta, and some kind of mini sandwich appetizer. The burrata was interesting mixed with the cherries, and the appetizer was fine. The truffle pasta was definitely full of truffle flakes (not just truffle oil and salt), and the pasta was extremely al dente. You won't find you italian american menu here, but be prepared to be transported to a restaurant in italy.

A solid option. Reservations are difficult for dinner.

I came with some friends to taste several menu items. We tried the ricotta appetizer, the octopus, the ribs, and the gamberi.

Of these, I would recommend the fresh ricotta and the gamberi. There's nothing like a fresh ricotta and this one has a good balance of flavors and textures with the fresh grapes and radish shavings. The Gamberi were perfectly cooked and not over-seasoned, so that you could really appreciate their freshness.

The ribs and octopus, however, left much to be desired. I have high expectations at this price point for a grilled octopus dish to be cooked well. Everyone knows overcooking octopus gives it an unpleasant, rubbery texture, so why serve overcooked octopus at the three-dollar sign price point? Should be as easy as removing it from the grill, no? Same critique for the ribs - overcooked. They also come over a sauce that I believe adds nothing to the dish.

Onto the main courses - I tasted all the pastas on the menu that night - truffle linguine, the torchio with pork shoulder, and the spaghetti with gamberi. Each was decent. You can tell the pasta is fresh and perfectly al dente. My torchio was the best in my opinion. I love an al dente pasta and the pork shoulder pieces were plentiful and perfectly cooked, with a very good flavor.

The truffle pasta was a bit disappointing. For almost $50 I expected the strong flavor and aroma of truffles that normally fills the restaurant when ordered. The pasta came with a generous amount of truffles but they taste like normal mushrooms. Not sure if it's me not knowing good truffles or if it's more that these are cheaper mushrooms. IMO not worth $50.

The shrimp spaghetti is a solid choice. Not much to critique or complement for that.

The desserts are good. I had the panna cotta which comes topped with a balsamic reduction. This is a new flavor combination for me. I am not sure I enjoyed it but I could see someone else enjoying that combination. For me, the balsamic reduction flavor is too robust and overshadowed the delicate vanilla of the panna cotta.

The other desserts are good.

The service is excellent. I have to point this out because our servers never made us wait to order and the food came out at a reasonable time always. This is a rarity nowadays!

It starts with the setting. You walk in off of Bond street and are immediately made comfortable by the country restaurant vibe. It's not very big inside, and as a result is comfortable and the noise volume moderate.

The next thing you notice is the attentive nature of the staff. Everyone is friendly, helpful and prompt, without being pushy at all.

There were four of us 3 meat eaters and one vegetarian.

We started with bread, EVOO and some chunks of aged parmesan. As I always say, the bread (chips in the case of Mexican food) are key indicators of what your experience is likely to be, in this case, the bread was excellent and the EVOO was very good, of course it's really hard to go wrong with aged (king of cheese) parmesan.

We ordered the burrata and the rigatoni with sausage for starters and both were fantastic. The burrata was so creamy, the tomatoes sweet and fresh and the balsamic so good you might be tempted to drink it.

We ordered the truffle linguine for the vegetarian, the pasta was cooked perfectly and the sauce was excellent. The price is very reasonable, so don't assume you're getting slices of fresh truffle on the pasta. The black truffle is very subtle in the dish.

For the 3 meat eaters we ordered the bone in ribeye (enough for 4 easily) and it was fantastic. It was cooked to perfection (medium rare) seasoned beautifully, had a great sear, and was topped with an arugula salad for some freshness and peppery bite.

I'm not sure how Il Buco is only rated as a four, maybe they went through a rough patch? In fact, even with a switch in waiters halfway through the meal, there wasn't a hiccup and both our servers were true professionals.

if you can get a reservation, i highly recommend you go.

The italian fare here is a rustic, yet refined taste. Albeit the portion sizes are nothing incredible, the quality makes up for it. I came here with a group for Mother's Day Brunch. And we pretty much ordered everything in the menu. The lamb was a star of the show, really glad that we had ordered two.

Overall, I would recommend checking this place out especially when there's a tasting menu, that way you're not just ordering a basic plate of pasta (there are other places that do a far superior job of that).

First time coming to il buco. The service was good and the restaurant was very aesthetic. For our main entrees got the salman and a pasta dish with pees and lobster. The salman was more on the medium rare side. I thought it was really good when it came out hot. After talking and enjoying the meal for a minute and the salman cooled down, i thought it had more of mild/bland flavor profile. The pasta with lobster dish- we thought the lobster was dry and not super flavorful.

We got the panna cotta for dessert and thought it had a great texture. However they went a little heavy on the balsamic toppings.

Overall, I think the food was pretty good and the service was great. If I was to come back, I would probably try a different dish.

Probably a more of a 3.5 than 4. But still decent place, though very expensive.

Had an amazing lunch here! Made a reservation for Thursday but didn't need it since not many tables were full. I loved the decor and smell of wood inside. There's also a cute outdoor seating area with fans, but it was too sunny for us so we moved to a table under the restaurant awning.

The bread basket and olive oil/salt pairing was delicious. I loved my lasagnette dish which came with pancetta and asparagus. My friend got a black truffle tagliatelle which she loved. Service was also great--my water glass was never empty. I would love to come back for dinner!

Came here for a team holiday dinner. Very cozy atmosphere and great service. Wait staff was very helpful in recommending dishes for the table to share as well as individual choices. Great drinks as well.  For my main, I've ordered skirt stead that came out perfectly cooked. I can't wait to come back.

Standouts from the menu (attended private event from my company):

Ceviche (Wild Spanish branzino, jalapeño, strawberry-citrus juice, cilantro): citrus flavors combined with the fresh, raw fish was very good!

Fave (fava beans, Windfall Farms greens, Espelette, formaggio Mitica Pantaleo)

Pesce (seared filet of Atlantic wild king salmon, avocado, citrus, rhubarb pickles, black garlic): the seared fish was seared to perfection, juicy and fatty.

Because it was a private event, we were seated in the basement in their wine cellar. Great ambiance and cozy seating.
Great food and service. Il Buco's burrata is clutch. Their bread and olive oil is also strangely addicting. Their pastas are decent as well.
Excellent food service and cocktails. Will return. Really enjoyed dinner there! Panna cotta A+++++

I stumbled into il Buco with friends a week ago. The ambience was warm and cozy. Smell was great inside here, nice italian cuisine. We ordered wine, and cacio e pepe pasta. We ordered insalata the kale caesar is so absolutely tasty, pulpo (seared octopus), and the black truffle tagliatelle was bomb. Will be back for more dinner and dessert.

This is a very cute restaurant. It's got a cute rustic interior and I understand they have a pretty wine cellar downstairs for private dining. Service was great in terms of constant refills of our water but I otherwise found our server not particularly friendly or attentive (it was other staff refilling our waters). I also didn't love the communal table seating - we sat at the same table as another couple, separated only by a plant and two chairs. We could hear everything they were saying and it was a little weird.

As for the food, it was pretty good. Thoughts on specific items below:
- Homemade bread basket with olive oil (6/10): The olive oil was incredible but I didn't love the bread. It came with two kinds - a white and wheat - but I didn't like either. My husband thought they were okay. You can buy the olive oil at their sister restaurant around the corner (Il Buco Alimento). I was very tempted to buy some.
- Bikini (9/10): These were amazing mini sandwiches with homemade mozzarella, truffle, and iberico. This was one of my favorite dishes of the night - a little greasy but so tasty - highly recommend.
- Kale salad (7/10): The black Tuscan kale was good and I loved the taste of the Parmesan but the croutons were so hard that they were inedible.
- Truffle Tagliatelle (10/10): it is a little buttery as some reviews suggest but I didn't find it off putting. We loved the texture of the pasta and there was a great amount of truffle.
- Orecchiette (8/10): I found the pasta texture was a little tough and difficult to chew but my husband (who says I like mushy pasta and that I probably just don't like al dente) thought it was good. I also wasn't a huge fan of the meat with it but I did enjoy the brightness of the peppers, which was a nice touch. Not sure I would order it again though.
- Flourless chocolate cake (6/10). I would skip this. It was fine but nothing special. I have definitely had better. Something about the texture was just a little off.

Cute, cozy spot with a fantastic wine list. Went with a friend on a Friday night at 6pm and it was already packed, and stayed that way for as long as we were there.

Service was professional and knowledgeable, and the food was very good! We did the olive oil sampler to start which was very fun, followed by the ricotta, and for my entree I had the risotto. Fun fact, the olive oils are for sale at their sister location down the street.

Overall, it was a solid Italian spot and if you're in the area, definitely worth checking out.

The ambiance here was the best aspect of the visit for us, really nice and cozy without being crowded. We were sat at the end of a communal table that luckily wasn't fully booked, so we didn't have to sit right next to others. The food was all amazing, perfect. The white Negroni was really delicious. The aspide spritz was quite sweet. Service was incredibly attentive and never intrusive or overbearing. Would love to return.

Note the ricotta dish contains meat and cannot be altered.

Great food, ambiance, and service. Also got the chance to dine in their private wine cellar downstairs, which I highly recommend for a larger private party. The ceilings were very high and it felt like we were in an authentic Italian wine cellar. Servers were polite and attentive. Highly recommend this spot in Noho instead of the tourist spots at Don Angie, I Sodi, or Via Carota in West Village. Make sure to make a res!

Dinner spot with a couple of others.  Quiet and unassuming Spot but great food and ambiance.  Service was great and sommelier attentive and thoughtful.  Very knowledgeable.

Dinner was shared starters-
Kale salad - good size. Nice fresh salad.  Good acid on dressing.  Lovely start.
Prawns.  Real ones.  Large 'meaty' and tasty in a nice sauce.
Octopus - a little small but with some accompaniments and pickles which worked well

Dinner entrees .  
Lamb on black rice - perfectly cooked.  Loved the tenderness and med rare style.
Pasta with cod - was delicious.  Size was great with ample cod.  
Pasta with truffles. Need I say more.  Aromatic and tasty. Deep earth flavors.  

Great wine list. We sampled some Sicilian wine from Mt Etna.  Loved it and worked well with the food.

I recommend this place!

Good portion sizes, great flavor, and everything was cooked incredibly.

The staff was kind and accommodating. They answered all of our questions about wine and preferred menu items. We were seated in the back of the restaurant which was so cute! The decor is homey and comforting.

We got a bread basket ($6) and started with the octopus  appetizer. It was well portioned and paired insanely with the side greens and cherries. Really good flavor. The octopus was a bit fatty but still fab.

The spaghetti was delicious. It had really great flavor and the texture was amazing. There were a lot of little shrimps and the meal was so substantial I had to take half of it home.

The ragu was very flavorful as well. The meat was tender and the pasta was cutely shaped.

Overall a bit pricey but would come back!

Amazing ambiance and great for a good date spot. The menu changes all the time but the appetizers pretty much stay the same. Right when I walk in I was greeted really nicely by the host and waiter- definitely didn't feel like they were judgmental like other reviewers have said as my date and I are queer and interracial.

I totally would recommend the olive oil tasting if you fancy your taste buds being pleasured. I'm huge on tastings so this was an amazing experience for me and my date as for 18 dollars you get really unique olive oils throughout different regions of Italy and a whole two baskets of bread! I would say this is more worth it than just getting the bread basket for 6 dollars. I ordered the crudo and it was really delightful as it's super flavorful and lemony. I love a tart appetizer. We both had the lobster spaghetti and it tasted really fresh and flavorful but not too forward with any crazy palettes so I really thought this was great if it was a sunny day (however I went on a rainy dark night haha)

I have to shout out my waiter Michael as he made our night really worthwhile and sweet!

Recent reviews have been negative. I was apprehensive but kept my lunch reservation. Upon arrival I was asked for vax proof and ID. I did not get an attitude as other reviewers did, but I am yt.

The hostess seated me and asked whether I preferred sparking or flat water. I got the impression she was amused when people did not understand what "flat" meant as I watched her ask other diners.

Sun was streaming though the windows and around 1:00 things got sexy and they turned down the lights and partially closed the drapes. Seemed excessive for the lunch group.

Ordered the cavolonero and burrata, polishing off each dish. The dressing on the cavolonero was bright and lemony and the highlight. The burrata was fine and the standout of the dish was the persimmon underneath the cheese. Took the waiter's recommendation on white wine and had two glasses. Also ordered the olive oil cake which I would not get again. it was heavy and did not strike the right notes.

I was asked if I wanted and a bread basket and I did. it was brought to the table with olive oil and flaky salt. It's not clear there is a separate charge for this. Sneaky sneaky. However the olive oil that they brought with it was divine so I would not skip this part of the meal.

Just me for lunch was $100 including tip. My server was great so no heartburn there, but it is pricey. Be prepared to treat yourself. If you don't enjoy the meal you'll definitely be pissed about the bill.

Really, really good service. I got the risotto, which I really liked and found to be a great vegetarian option. A fantastic place for a date, or a special celebration. We had a group of 8 and they were very accommodating to our big group. 100% recommend!

Here we are solo at il Buco on Bond Street.
I walked in off the street and was asked if I would like to sit at the bar I declined. Instead I opt to sit outside on a beautiful summer night
This is described as an "upside Italian restaurant."
For those of you who have seen my previous Yelp reviews, I am an Italian food fanatic.  I have been to dozens of Italian restaurants in Brooklyn. So I'm pretty opinionated on good and "authentic" food.  
I order a familiar wine, Antonelli Montefalco Rosso   It is vey very good
My waitress, is gracious and when I was seated, she said gee it's my lucky night.
I order the assorted salami plate. And it is mouth watering.
For the entree I order the Miale pork chop, and it is juicy and spicy.  With tiger figs and green and yellow string beans  
This is a very classy place.  The clientele is manhattan sophisticates.  The people in the next table are friends of Hillary Clinton, one of whom met with her this afternoon. They are yapping away and are absolutely obnoxious. But screw them!
I'm happy sitting here watching the world go by!

Amazing food and atmosphere. The area is spacious and the decor is thoughtfully picked out. The restaurant also sells sandwiches and bakery items near the front, in addition to pasta and cheese. We started off the a charcuterie board with some bread (would recommend). I loved the garganelli pasta with forest mushrooms and arugula. The flavours all worked so well together and I really enjoyed the pasta itself. The service was also pretty fast. Would definitely come again!

While the food and wait staff here was excellent the hostess was completely rude and going extra on vaccinations cards for people eating outdoors even, but what really struck a nerve was that she singly only asked me if I had state id with my excelsior pass.

I was the only tanned person here and the hostess asked for a state ID on top of my excelsior pass but didn't ask any of the Caucasian/white patrons for a state id on top of their vaccine cards. That's why the one star.

I had the tagliatelle (which is made in house) which was really tasty I could eat it all day! I also had the Uovo wince I saw this on MasterChef recently and was curious to try it out! I didn't like the bread basket was an extra charge for six dollars which in Europe you know it will cost extra but in the states that has always been free so that was sneaky addition.

The music was a bit confusing because they were plying French music in an Italian restaurant but I enjoyed it regardless.

I wish I could recommend this place to others but the hostess rudeness here just left a horrible taste in my mouth.

We stopped in for a snack since we wandering in the hood.  Il Buco is an institution on the NYC culinary scene; our drop in reinforced that notion.  We sat at the bar and ordered the fluke ceviche, fried artichokes and cavatelli to share and the hostess, Jada (?sp) made us feel like we were in her kitchen, offering details on the onerous preparation of the mini artichokes (we asked) and the other dishes.  Grazie mille, Jada!!

You will never be disappointed at Il Buco with the food and hospitality.

I had the skirt steak with vegetables and every bite I was in heaven. Some of the best steak I've ever had! Wow! And the vegetables were so well cooked. I could have happily eaten a whole plate of the veggies alone. Great ambiance, service, and vibe. Cannot wait to return!

The service was bad. It was terrible and expensive. The food was gross. The manager might be from out of town and so they don't understand the NYC restaurant scene. We were asked to move to another seating area and our water and other items were not moved by the wait staff. We moved it ourselves and we tipped well... It discouraged us from ordering any more food. The food was terrible. The drinks were OK. It is hard times for everyone and all people want to do is support local businesses but the service here was garbage.
It's a perfect Italian traditional restaurant! The food is amazing! The service is great! And the environment is fantastic, l really love the classical and home style decorations!

Solid food, good brunch option. Also good wine selection. A classic New York stop! The wine cellar is also really lovely to dine in. Constant new updates to the menu are great and they know how to handle allergies well.

Burrata was fire. Cherries and pine nuts were a thoroughly flavorful yet delicate compliment to the creamy spherical cheese. Would definitely order again, might be my favorite burrata ever.

The truffle tagliatelle was disappointing.
-- essentially buttered noodles that costs $40 dollars. I would've preferred Kraft Mac n Cheese for more satisfying flavor. I couldn't taste the truffle at all. You're better off ordering a pasta with meat.

Ambience outside was nice, but the wooden desk as a table felt awkward and my legs didn't fit underneath it.

I have been to Il Buco more times that I can count on my two hands at this point. It's always been a mainstay and a cozy knook of a spot to enjoy a delicious meal. I still enjoy it's rustic energy and its toned down "sceney" vibe, but as of late I've found the food to be less than exciting and falling flat.

This all being said, the waiters are fantastic and they have a pretty fantastic wine list. If you're in the neighborhood, you can't really go wrong with having a delicious meal here.

Super cute and delicious spot! We came here for my sister's wedding and sat in the wine cellar for the evening. It was a set menu, but the food was fantastic! We started off with charcuterie, then moved on to the apps, pasta, a protein and then dessert. I can't even remember everything that was served, but the stand outs to me were the bisteca, the charcuterie, tagliatelle, and the panna cotta! The service was just fantastic. Nobody ever had an empty wine glass, and employees were just so friendly. Loved this restaurant and we are so glad we could celebrate my sister here!

Everything was great! We ended up sitting outside which was nice since this is a quieter cobble stone street. The sommelier was very helpful in selecting A nice white wine that would go well with our meal. We ordered the crudo scallop, fresh bread, bisteca, tagliatelle with lamb, torchio and cavolonero(kale caesar).

My top dishes would be the torchio if it's on the menu, and the cavolonero. It was a simple kale salad but there was so much flavor and the Parmesan was so fresh there was nothing left on the plate (I didn't even have a chance to take a picture!). You should definitely make a reservation in advance (and try to get inside if you want a nice romantic vibe) Will be back!

We absolutely loved every food at Il Buco! We were intially concerned about being seated next to the kitchen, but they were honestly super quiet and it ended up being a cool experience! We still had great ambiance in the back room and loved seeing the new menu for the day. Wines recommended were tasty as well. Will be back!
Amazing food, ambiance and the servers are so accommodating! I've been here twice now and that rarely happens in nyc. I feel like I'm transported straight to Italy the moment I step in. Must try!!

We hosted a very elegant graduation party for 9 at Il Buco. The food was unique and fantastic. The service was so professional--we felt like the guests instead of the hosts! They made planning from out of town so easy. Everything was perfect when we arrived--from the custom menus at each place setting to the arrangements from the flower shop they'd recommended. What a memorable event--highly recommended!

Amazing service, wine selection and Michael the sommelier on the night we dined was fabulous. Food was great, and the atmosphere is warm, friendly and elegant.
It doesn't feel like a trendy spot, but a place more focused on their product and customer experience than being "cool". We will return. Reservations are available 2 weeks in advance on Resy and require some dedication.

Last night I had the best food ever at Il buco. I go there regularly as it is super high quality, lovely ambiance and kind staff. The calamari  was off the charts! So soft and flavorful and the fish for my main incredible. I also tried their new desserts ; fresh peaches on a pastry with blueberries. Divine. See you next week!
Great country farm house feel . Service was great. Truffle pasta a standout. Wines were also good.
Cozy and delicious.  All the food was delicious and fresh (the menu is always changing). The ambiance was warm and subtle. The staff was amazing (the bartender, the hostess and the sommelier).

Pros- intimate atmosphere, flavorful food, unique dishes
Cons- menu font too small for old people, little noisy
Just a lovely meal- Kale salad, Risotto and something tasty and sweet. And the right wine.

This Italian restaurant has a wonderful ambiance, the food is delicious and the staff is friendly and resourceful! I recommend and will be back. I ordered the mushroom tagliatelle, which was creamy and not heavy. I ordered a glass of red wine from côté du Rhône region for $17 which was ok. Not exceptional. The Cestino di Pane (olive oil and bread) was very good, especially the darker bread, which was fluffy, fresh and delicious. I recommend sitting at the bar if alone, it's fun. The bar tender knows what he's doing and has good recommendations. I like that they change the menu daily with fresh seasonal ingredients and dishes. Will be back!

I had my birthday dinner here and everyone made it so incredibly special. The food was fantastic. The waiter was so kind. Everything was seamless and perfect. The kale salad was one of everyone's favorites dishes!

Food was incredible, highly recommend the Short Rib and Roasted Artichoke.
Service was a bit slow -- but overall the ambiance was incredible and I will be back!
Great wine too.

Came here off the back of a friend's suggestion and was so pleased with the food & service. Had artichokes & prawns for appetizers and these were excellent. The prawns were cooked in some delish butter sauce & would recommend that you especially get bread to dip in the sauce to savor every flavor.

For the mains we had bucatini cacio e pepe (which was neither too saucy nor was it heavy), crab mixed wild rice & whole branzino. I think these were delish and not too heavy though I personally wished they used a softer rice/actual grain. I've had very similar dishes in proper Chinese cuisine and I think my palate is conditioned for a softer grain with it. It's an interesting dish nonetheless. The whole fish was also flavorful without being too heavy (though be warned that it does have a hefty price tag).

The meal felt rather light and so we had ample of room for desserts. The flourless cake and olive oil cake we equally light, with the olive oil cake tethering on very Angel food cake consistency. My favorite was the panna cotta which was interestingly drizzled in balsamic. Lastly we had some ice cream and enjoyed the coconut and fennel flavored ones. Will pass on lemon sorbet for next time as it was too  tart for me.

Also had some spritzes which were truthfully not memorable. Would stick to wines next time.

Overall a fun evening. We were seated upstairs which felt quieter but was happy that the service was still attentive. I appreciate how well-staffed they are. The vibe certainly leans younger here though there's were handful of families on our floor. It's very chill though and not at all pretentious.

This restaurant used to be one of my favorite Italian food in NYC.  My recent visit, we sat at bar counter and ordered glasses of wines.  Bartender was measuring the pour of wine with his eyes lowered to the counter level.....we ordered Riso Selvatico (risotto with crabs and $42) among other dishes which was served within 2 to 3 minutes after we ordered.
It was very dry and one of worst risotto I ever tasted.
I had to assume it was pre cooked.  
Same was true with pizza we ordered.

Overall, this restaurant feels as if it is run by pre-set manual with under trained staffs.

Our server was so funny, friendly, and nice. This definitely made the experience better. The food took a bit too long to come out but the portion sizes of each entree were huge! The chicken was a bit undercooked and very red on the inside so we took it home to put it in the airfry to cook it a bit more and it was delicious. Very cute ambiance inside! The pizzas were also all so good (:

The food was good, but not a ton of bang for your buck.

This is a cute restaurant inside.  We were seated upstairs and it was adorable.  Service was ok; our server warmed up to us over time but originally told us that we needed to hurry up and order because we only had the table for two hours (meanwhile, we were nearly a half hour early- she said this at, for example, 6:45 when our reservation wasn't even set to start until 7:00)

We started with some cocktails which were alright and a little on the pricier side.  We split several appetizers and entrees:

GRILLED PRAWNS - probably our favorite of the appetizers.  Really nice sauce on these guys.

CRISPY ARTICHOKES - nice as well, exactly what you'd expect.  Small portion.  

RAZOR CLAM CRUDO - totally fine, also exactly what you'd expect.  Small portion.  

SPAGHETTI BOTTARGA - this is what I got for my entree and honestly for $25 it was extremely basic.  Spaghetti bottarga is pretty basic to begin with so I'm not sure what I expected, but this was recommended to me instead of the cavatelli and the garganelli so I was hoping for something interesting here.

CHOCOLATE CAKE - very standard

PANNA COTTA - delicious.  Balsamic on top added a nice touch.

Nothing about this meal was bad by any means, but I think if I was going to drop $350 on a three person dinner again, I'd consider going somewhere else- but I wouldn't be mad if I ended up here again, either!

I've been to Il Buco several times but this was my first time at Alimentari.   I loved it!   The ambience was great and the service was exceptional.   I sat at the bar, had a beer, and ordered a few things to nosh on.   The baby friend artichokes were some of the best i've ever had.  
The chicory salad looked and tasted great.   and the pizza was perfect!!!    can't wait to go back.

The other day my wife and I had dinner at Il Buco. The dishes I would most recommend are pepperoni pizza, little gem salad, and bread (which is not free and must be ordered). A prawns appetizer was not that good. They were overcooked and swimming in too much sauce. For wine I would recommend L'Erta di Radda "Due & Due." I had a few bites of the olive oil cake and wouldn't recommend that.  

Service was OK, it was friendly but a little lackadaisical. The proceedings could have taken less time without any loss.  Sometimes our waiter appeared to be hanging out by the bar.

The atmosphere was pretty lively on a Thursday night. A mostly young crowd.
Food was great. Cocktails excellent. Service was outstanding.   Will definitely return

Honestly I was hesitant to come get due to the negative reviews, however my daughter already made reservations so I decided to give this place the benefit of the doubt and glad I did. The Bucatini Cacio de pepe was excellent, the pasta was cooked nice fresh and aldente'with really flavorful lightly coated sauce, spectacular!. The pepperoni pizza oh wow also great!! Nice chewy crust, and bursting with flavors!! The house bread was nice and fresh and the Olive oil was very fragrant and bright with flavor. Service and ambiance was great as well. A little higher than normal pricing but WELL worth it, we will be back for sure.

If you're a pasta lover, you definitely need to made a stop at Il Buco. The pastas are lovely, as are the salads, and the portions are great. Not too big not too small.

A definite go-to spot for dinner with friends and you won't be disappointed eating inside or outside. Definitely take advantage of the little market too, if you need some really yummy treats to bring home (or gift).

** amazing Italian food & ambiance ** we were here for my brother's rehearsal dinner private party upstairs. Charcuterie and drinks, followed by curated dishes with local ingredients! They have and espresso counter and a dinner counter as well as tables. Loved the Italian grocery that makes this place a must stop!

Dimly lit and intimate restaurant. For the space, it accommodated a few larger parties. We had a party of 6, and we decided to order for the table to share family style.
The food was good overall. Main highlights were the Roasted Beets, Prawns, Crispy Artichokes, and pastas. Cavatelli was my personal favorite of the three. We even ended the night with dessert.
However, I must say, the server we had was quite snobby and pushy... He demanded we order everything at once upfront, but no one had dined here before, so we weren't sure of the portion size. We felt pressured and he suggested we order more, trying to upsell. We didn't and said we preferred to order more later if needed.
Fortunately, we did not give in because there was plenty of food without overindulging, especially because we were also drinking wine/cocktails. We finished just about everything, except a couple bites and pieces of bread.
My go to for weekend brunch. Solid staple menu and ambiance m. Good service and amazing coffee. My standard order is the Uova Al Forno- best in the city

I had a reservation for Il Buco for Saturday lunch and enjoyed my experience. Initially, my friend and I had planned to go for restaurant week but didn't realize their lunch restaurant week menu didn't apply to weekends because they had brunch instead. This is something that I wish they had clarified on their restaurant week menu, but either way, I had a decent experience. The restaurant is definitely more casual than the original location but was fun and felt like an upscale deli.

The waiters were pretty friendly, and unlike some of the other reviews I've seen, I thought the service was pretty good.  My friend and I split the fried artichoke appetizer, the spicy green olive pizza, and the bucatini cacio e pepe. The pasta and artichoke came before the pizza and were both great; however, my favorite dish had to be the pizza- for both value and taste. The artichoke was great but was a little small in portion for a $17 dollar appetizer. I also thought the bucatini was great and would order it again, but it was a pretty standard bucatini cacio e pepe. The one dish I was 100% recommend trying (if you enjoy olives on pizza) is the spicy green pizza. It was really unique and the flavors melded together really well.

Overall, I enjoyed my experience at Il Buco. It is a little bit on the pricer side, but I do think it is generally worth it and would come back. There are interesting choices on the menu as well as some classics, and I enjoyed the three dishes that I got.

Pretty good Italian food!

I came here for a weekday dinner and it was fairly busy. I shared the crispy artichoke, burrata, branzino and olive oil cake.  The artichoke was soooo good! Really delicious but a very small portion. Burrata was so so, nothing special. The branzino also wasn't special, but the veggies that accompanied it were really good! The olive oil cake was really solid as well.

It was good overall - not sure if I'd go out of my way to dine here but maybe for the artichokes it would be worth it!

Delicious as expected.

Charcuterie Board - great variety and selections!

Steak Tartar - okay, not my fav.

Octopus - pretty good but not as memorable.

Fried Mini Artichoke - interesting and very addicting.

Margherita Pizza - more like a flatbread we think. Thin crust very crispy, in my liking though.

Short Rib Pasta - very goooood!

Duck entree - delicious but a bit much in the fatty part. The grape and oatmeal side is weird.

Branzino - good as expected.

Service is a bit slow but it's a a big space. Overall is great!

Good to see this place up and running .
One of the most underrated Italian cuisine in NYC.
Cavatelli was fantastic , rustic and real and made right.
The sea bass was fine , nothing to write home about just fine , though next time I will try the branzino for 2 with a hope that it is as it was when they first open .
Good food with solid wine options (variety of wine by the glass). Small market where you can get quality ingredients and aesthetic kitchen/resturant area.

We were having a pleasant dinner, but at the end as we were signing the check the "service" manager came up to us and told us that they needed the table and we had to leave, but take our time!!! Really? A nice kick, as we were on the way out the door. I doubt that we will return, and I will not recommend it to a friend.

Sadly the days of Donna making you feel like the center of the world are gone.  Apparently COVID took that Il BUco.  They still have prosciutto but I'm not sure it's actually Italian anymore.  They don't welcome children.  I made efforts to bring my fanily here for Thanksgiving after what's been a tough year.  We are the only reservation that is seated outside. They insisted they overbooked and had many tables coming.  We were alone outside on thanksgiving.  So disappointing.  After an hour and half we are the only people.  Never once did anyone form the restaurant check in.  In fact each time I needed a drink (often) I went inside.   I'm thankful that I got to go to the real Il buco back when the food and the people mattered.   My wife just reminded me maybe this place is still Italian because clearly that don't give a shiz about anyones Thanksgiving

Stay away! I had high hopes considering it was a part of the Il buco family. I went for my 30th birthday with my sister who is gluten free, and when asked if we had allergies, we made it abundantly clear she had a severe gluten allergy. I specifically asked them weeks before if they could accommodate, and I was assured they could.

Well, let's just say the server did not follow through with their commitment. He wasn't knowledgeable, reassuring or informed.

We ordered and asked specifically if it had gluten and he said, "no". After she ate it, she knew it had gluten and we asked our server and he said,  "no, it's just in the fryer for a second". He was careless and casual about it.  I'd expect that he would understand the severity of intake of food and him to escalate our concern. I'm guessing he knew he messed up. We were clearly pissed.

Needless to say, my sister couldn't enjoy the rest of my birthday night, felt terrible and had to go home. Thanks a lot... my birthday was definitely memorable in the worst possible way. AVOID.

That server was disingenuous and pretentious.

We were visiting NYC because we wanted to browse and do some shopping. After a while of shopping we wanted to have a late lunch and settled on this place. So glad we chose to do so. We started with a charcuterie board made up of for different types of Italian meats. The meats were excellent and a great way to start our lunch. I chose the Margherita pizza while my girlfriend had the Spanish torta. We both enjoyed our meals. The pizza had a thin, crunchy crust with sausage, mozzarella and fresh tomato.
The restaurant also has all types of specialty food items. They has all
Types of cured Italian meats. As well as various types of cheeses. They sell other specialty food items like sea sat, canned anchovies, jams and other things. This is a neat little place with good food and other specialty items. The food and service is also very good.

As soon as we walked in, the aroma of the cured meats, fresh-out-of-the-oven pizza, and traditional Italian pastries hit our nostrils. We loved the pepperoni pizza; the cheese was melty and they were very generous with the pepperoni. The carbonara was very good; the pasta was quite Al Dente and chewy which I liked, but definitely something to keep in mind if you prefer the softer fresh pasta. I liked the ceviche but wish it was a bigger portion size. Overall a great restaurant and amazing service, but definitely a bit on the pricier side.

Accidentally made a reservation to the wrong location. The original is located on the cobble stone st, and I still want to go back to get the octopus there but this location was very rustic feeling and it was nice to see the cheese/wine/ meat selections as it also functions as a store.

We got the bread basket which was nice to start, additionally we got the riso negra (black rice with squid and chorizo), the pizza with bacon and the short rib pasta . We also got the panna cotta for dessert which was nice, they add balsamic vinegar to the top (which we could have done with a bit less of) but still enjoyed the dessert. I would definitly get the pizza again if I came back here- it was cooked perfectly and not soggy on the bottom as sometimes this happens with brick ovens. The wait staff was very helpful but it was hard to tell who our waiter was because various people stopped to check in, take our order, and bring out the food.

Absolutely horrendous experience. Took 3.5hrs for my order to show up with no way of contacting them to get even a courtesy update as to if it was ever even coming or not. If you want to eat your lunch within 4hrs of when you order please save yourself the ridiculously bad experience and order somewhere else. Unbelievable.

This restaurant is incredibly charming inside. It really captures a special ambience/experience. I will say that the food was not incredible... The best part was the bread they served us at the start (which was actually quite good). The egg dish that I had was very oily. My friend got the Cacio e Pepe which she said was very dry. I would be interested to come back here for dinner at some point rather than brown
The best Carbonara  in town. Good vibes great ambience. If you think about Italian lunch meet up with your friends or family lunch dinner. It's great for all. Just love the space and food there.

This review is specific to their new staff.

I've been a loyal customer here since I moved to NoHo a couple of years back and order from here 3-4x a month. I have only dined in a few times, as I prefer to carry out a panino or bread and other items from their bakery.

I asked for my normal weekend order of the filone sliced & the staff member at the counter who I have never seen once before tells me we don't slice the bread here. I said I've been coming here for 2 years, since when has that changed?

Apparently my response triggered the staff's short man energy asking me what's with the attitude. I left without getting a response and went to Lafayette down the street.

Since they added new seating up front where the market used to be, there have been a few new faces working in the bakery who have had an attitude towards myself and other customers while I've been waiting in line.

It feels like they view bakery customers as an inconvenience to everything else going on. If that's the case, then don't have a bakery!

Literally so delicious. The aperol spritz i had was amazing. Whoever decided beets and mango would taste delicious together was a GENIUS because it was SO GOOD. The pasta was just an added bonus as i was already having the best meal.

Food was very good, short rib was cooked to perfection. Pasta was a little stale though

Service was super slow, it took a half hour to get our drinks
Went for a work party and they had the best food and service and want to go back as soon as I can.

It's definitely not Il Buco, but the Alimentari is useful in its own right.  We have been here several times for sandwiches, and they are uniformly satisfying.  A recent meal in the loft was good for what it was - a casual Monday night dinner.  Service was excellent, but the farmhouse table we sat at was all aesthetics. It was so wide across, we practically had to shout to carry on a conversation and we couldn't reach to hold hands.  

A salad of large, sprightly lettuce leaves and radishes in a balanced vinaigrette tasted like it came right from the greenmarket.  But the steak tartar was overly salty and almost half wild rice (why?) - definitely a dud.  The pizza had a wonderful sweet sauce and great basil flavor, with a crust that was chewy and a little leaden.  The budino with crunchy cocoa nibs was a sweet finish.
Superb my first time to NYC. The Al dente pasta was my favorite. The service was excellent very attentive and always kept my wine glass full. Beautiful restaurant feels like you stepped into Tuscany

Lovely server, super noisy but they graciously  let me change tables.  Those factors aren't driving this review.  It's the claw.  I always order the same thing there (cacio e Pepe, delish) and this time I decided to branch out. Big mistake. They serve their one chicken dish with the chicken claw.  My friend and I were both kind of repulsed, but we didn't want to be weenies so we didn't say anything... We figured perhaps it was an Italian tradition we didn't know about.  (Note:  it isn't, and also the owner is American).  The $38.00 chicken was undercooked and gamey  anyway, but the claw kind of put it over the edge.  I'm guessing this was an attempt to be different or exotic, but all I'm saying is, it should be stated clearly on the menu.  So those who are thinking to themselves, "Boy, wouldn't it be great to have a giant chicken foot tonight" will be happy, and the rest of us won't have PTSD the next day.  

Really hoping this isn't the beginning of some trend. Not looking forward to a steak served with a giant hoof.

If I could give this place zero stars I would. There's a reason they haven't claimed this business on Yelp. It deserves to be shut down.

The manager of this dump deserves to be barred from this industry. His arrogance and absolute disrespect of his patrons is disgusting. The owners of this restaurant should know they've selected a clown to run their establishment.

Horrid experience. Do not waste your time or money here especially in a city where we are spoiled for choice!
I have loved this place for years but are here last night and it sucked. The menu has changed, the staff are so full of it & the vibe is bridge & tunnel. Really disappointed - never again

Came here to celebrate a birthday. Had a lovely time. We sat at the bar, but the bar tender was very attentive and friendly. Our wine, appetizers and entrees were great. Would come back for a casual dinner with friends.

went there on the advertised hours only to find that it was closed. there was no indication that it would be closed on their website. When i went, the rude hostess said "it's only for today," and didn't even apologize. the restaurants were going down during the pandemic and a lot of people felt sorry for their demise, trying to save them. i always thought of their attitudes before, how they treated customers bad. after two years, the attitude is back. look lady, if you think a restaurant job is beneath you make it in your desired career first because you give service industry a bad name and wish your place gets shut down asap.
Came here for a birthday dinner a friend was having for about 12 people, They had a prefixed menu, the food was delicious and the service was great.
