Came here for an anniversary dinner. The service was exceptional - they threw in some extra items on the house for our special occasion, which was a nice surprise and the gesture went a long way. Food was great and loved the rustic atmosphere.

Il Buco Alimentari has FAR EXCEEDED our expectations. Everything about our meals and our experience at dinner or brunch have been world class, original, and memorable. This is among our favorite restaurants in Manhattan.

Highlights:

House-made ricotta with figs.

The Tagliolini Neri with crab, leeks, and chives: creative perfection, and unlike any pasta preparation I've had before.

A nightly special of a whole Spanish mackerel grilled with herbs, sprouts and figs: OUTSTANDING (it was also easily enough for 2 to share, but I managed).

Baked items including rustic loaves for dinner and crostatas for brunch are world class.

Porchetta is at least the equal of any I've had in Tuscany and Umbria.

The menu is small, but there are quite a few specials -- enough to make the choices still rather difficult.

Il Buco was delicious! Tucked in the Bowery it's easy to find on the East Side of the city. We had a 6:15 reservation and were seated right away. To start a Peroni and a cocktail along with the olive oil tasting. 3 types of olive oils, light to dark served with focaccia bread for dipping. All 3 were amazing. One of my favorite dishes, cacio e pepi was on the menu and it was one of the best versions I have had. My friend loved the pizza she had as well. Very good service and overall very pleasant dining experience. We loved it!

Came here on a Saturday night when a reservation miraculously opened up for 2 at 9pm. I heard this place was good, but I had no expectations whatsoever and I'm glad because this meal was fantastic.

For appetizers we got the crispy artichoke and the prosciutto. The artichoke was SO GOOD. The prosciutto was so fresh and it came with a lot served in a wooden board. For the meal we got the bucatini cacio e Pepe pasta and the pappardelle with meat and WOW. Both pastas were so fresh and so good. The pappardelle was a little spicy but other than that it was incredible. For dessert the olive oil cake is a must- it was so good and the perfect way to end the meal.

My one critique was that we were seated upstairs at a counter and not at a table. The counter was a little small and tucked into the corner so we didn't have much room for the food and our seats. I look forward to coming back and trying more items off the menu.

I had lunch here the other day and enjoyed the atmosphere of nice food in a gourmet food store environment.  The staff was friendly and the striped bass main course was cooked well with crispy sweet potatoes.  We also tried the beets which were a good contorni.  Overall, worth a trip

I went in a peculiar day, because it was thanksgiving. They had a four course fixed menu with three options per course.
The place is so Italian looking that I loved it. Very simple, all wooden floors and furniture. Because it was thanksgiving, the place was packed. However, service was impecable: fast, friendly and on top
of every detail.
The entree I chose was pasta with mushrooms and cheese. Then the turkey with sides (family style serving) for the main course and caramelized pears for dessert. You could chose pumpkin or Nutella pie too. They had a long menu with wines and 'aperitivo' too.
Also, the place has a market. So, after you have your meal, you can take home some pasta, sauces, bread or wine.
Please, do yourself a favor and visit this amazing place in SOHO.

Had a brunch with friends and we were amazed with ambiance and service. Ally was an amazing server and her team were very attentive to our needs and requests. Everyone enjoyed their meal and experience. I would highly recommend!
Watch out for the host stand. They don't honor resy reservations and try to sit you in tables that don't reflect what you booked. Plus they are rude.

Ok service, and good wine selection. Don't order the pizza. It's not freshly made. Every time I've ordered one here it's come out room temperature, with the sauce cold or cheese congealed. Would be delicious otherwise.
First date night in a while - ordered a glass of wine, and some pasta. Amazing. Felt good to be out again! Vibes were healthy and the environment was clean with a TON of indoor seating.

Teetering on average - formerly consistently strong meal was average to underwhelming. Service was poor, maybe understaffed - sommelier rambled but not informatively or passionately. Cavatelli and in-house sausage  was a micro-portion and barely warm. Bottarga and spaghetti was unlovingly plated, noodles dragging over the side. Uneventful tartare. Gone are the days of their amazing porchetta (or at least on my recent night out).... Restaurant feels old and losing its special seasoning...

This was the best food I have ever eaten in my life. I got the Chicken Paitan ramen and Yuzu lemonade and it was an emotional experience, seriously I teared up for a moment. You have to try it.
Great service and a cool private patio in the back with an awesome mosaic mural.

Stopped into Ivan Ramen on a Thursday evening for dinner with a reservation. They require your whole party to be present before seating you, but we were seated immediately when everyone was there. They seemed to have plenty of availability for walk ins at the time as well.

As a big fan of spicy food, I decided to go with the spicy ramen. In addition to a warning on the menu, the waitress cautioned me that it would be extremely spicy. The food came out very quickly. However, to my disappointment, it was not very spicy at all. It still had a very good flavor though and the toppings were fresh.

We also decided to try their made in-house yuzu lemonade. The flavor packed a punch with strong sweet notes and a sour aftertaste. The two paired together really well making it quite tasty. I would recommend giving it a try.

All in all, this is a pretty good ramen spot, but I probably would only come back if I was already in the area.

Three stars? Really? Yes, really.

The service is what gives it the extra oomph. I found all of the servers genuine, attractive, and intelligent, especially the one who helped me out at the bar. I expected less out of her and instead got more, which is why I gave her more when my meal was over (I sadly could not get her name, oh dear).

As for the rest of the meal, it is pretty par for the course. Like really par. Not mediocre, but not outstanding. The prices are eye popping for such a small bowl and plate of food. Two pastrami bao for $13 is killer. Thankfully they are tasty, and it feels like I am getting a vintage Lower East Side twist with a modern take on the neighborhood. Only reason I will not judge these too harshly.

The ramen is tasty too, albeit the portion is on the smaller side. Not a lot of noodle, one piece of chashu pork, but a lot of soft boiled eggs. Never turn down extra eggs. Everybody could use more protein.

You will need kadima, or a noodle refill. Otherwise you will still be hungry. For some reason I almost always need it at every ramen restaurant I have been to. Thankfully I got the lighter ramen compared to my usual Tonkotsu one. The latter ramen you should only order when it is 30 degrees outside and blustery.

The pretty staff will have you seeing double and ordering more, but the high prices and small portions will have you seeing stars and ordering less.

Think about all of that before you make your move.

Made a reservation for two at 1:30pm on a Sunday and it was packed. Service was friendly and quick.

I got the Shoyu Ramen and we had the Picked Cucumbers to share. While it doesn't look like a lot, the bowl ended up being super filling and tasty.

I'm glad I tried out Ivan Ramen while visiting the city, but I don't think I'd go out of my way to come back.

Came here at 12pm for lunch. There was a short line outside before they opened but they still had many tables available.

We ordered the eggplant to share. I'm not usually a fan of eggplant but this one was cooked really well and very tasty! I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and enjoyed it as well. The broth chashu was very tender but the star was definitely the noodles. They were very thin and had a unique texture.

I wasn't sure about what to expect from this place given the middling reviews, but I actually quite enjoyed the meal I got takeout.

I typically favour pork-based ramens, but when I saw how popular the chicken paitan is here, I opted for that instead. My friend got the tonkotsu. While it was good, it wasn't stand-out, and I'm very glad I tried the chicken paitan. I would highly recommend it, with its rich and flavourful chicken broth (a tad on the salty side) and minced chicken. It might be because I ordered takeout, but it's worth mentioning that I got a regular ramen egg instead of egg yolk, as is listed on the menu. The ramen egg was strangely cold compared to the rest of the soup (it had probably come right out of the fridge) but the flavour was great.

Overall, this is a decent spot to order from and I'd order/visit again for the chicken paitan!

A favorite once in Japan and now seated in the East Village, Ivan Ramen is the spot for authentic ramen. I have visited twice now and was impressed both times with the food, service, and overall vibe of the restaurant.

I have tried the karaage, shoyu ramen, and chicken ramen. My favorite is the chicken ramen but I opted for the shoyu at this visit because I thought the broth would be more fitting for a hot summer day than the richer broth of the chicken ramen.

Although Ivan Ramen is a slightly higher price point than other ramen joints in the city, I think it is a great spot for a chilly night. Note that they have a fairly spacious patio for when you want to dine outdoors.

My friend and I decided to try Ivan Ramen after seeing that it was featured on Chef's Table and is also super close to her apartment. We didn't have any issues getting a reservation for dinner on a Thursday, but we thought the food was overhyped.

Our favorite thing we ordered was the yuzu lemonade; very refreshing and not too sweet. I would definitely skip the Japanese fried chicken next time. I was expecting it to be more of a traditional karaage style fried chicken, but it didn't have much crisp to it as it was essentially drenched in a very strong soy glaze. The ramen was ok, maybe slightly above average, but nothing to write home about.

Service was very quick which was nice, but it didn't really make up for the mediocre food. The restaurant itself was kind of loud and dim but there was a cool wall with a bunch of pop art.

Overall, definitely overhyped

Amazing, amazing, amazing experience. We took a guest here that was visiting us from out of town, and needless to say it lived up to the hype. Our server went above and beyond to explain items on their interactive virtual menu to us, gave us great suggestions, and even modified the ramen to fit our exact needs. Since I was between two, she somehow found a way to combine the both of them into one, and I was extremely satisfied.

The place is always busy, on any given night there is a line out the door -- BUT this is the perfect excuse to put your name in and head around the corner to have a drink at Donnybrook (which we did) or the cute wine bar two doors down. We were seated in less than 20 minutes. Overall, I'd recommend this restaurant to anyone who loves great ramen.... This will not disappoint. I live in the area and will be returning ASAP.

Ordered delivery from this place and it was one of the best delivery meals we've had since living in NYC. Ordered the fried chicken, pork buns and spicy ramen. Chicken was very tender and the glaze was delicious - probably my favorite of the three. Buns and ramen were wonderful as well, the chicken is just something I've been craving ever since. This place was recommended to us by a friend and I'm glad we listened!

I came here after seeing the Chef's Table episode about Ivan, the restaurant's founder. He has a really interesting story, and his restaurant makes really delicious food. Unfortunately, he wasn't in the kitchen on the day I went.

I had a reservation for 1pm on a Sunday, but arrived early. They were able to seat me where I wanted on the counter, even though the restaurant was quite busy. And it was busy for a good reason.

The ambience is Japanese-style comic book (not Manga, the western-style comic book). It's a fun and unpretentious vibe, but with a lot of thought behind the decor, and the flatware/silverware.

I started my meal with the Kyuri (cucumber pickles). They were well-made, but beware, they're quite spicy. Consider yourself warned.

My friend had the pork buns. He really liked them, but s not as good at describing food as I am. The buns were not spicy, but he said one of the garnishes inside it was. He did not consider the dish itself to be spicy, and he said he thought it tasted really good.

The crispy eggplant was incredible - probably my favorite dish of the meal. The coating on the eggplant was crispy, but the eggplant itself was tender - perfectly cooked. It came on top of a delicious sesame sauce. It felt reminiscent of the Japanese "goma nasubi" dish, but with a New York twist. I loved the dish and would order it again. That said, (suggestion based on personal preference - not a criticism) it would be cool if the sauce came inside the eggplant instead of underneath. Cutting the eggplant would let it cool down faster, and the sauce being on the inside would make eating it a different experience.

The ramen itself is not your traditional Japanese ramen - but I really enjoyed it nonetheless. The chef mixes rye flour into the noodles, giving it an interesting texture. The noodles come firm at first, but soften up as they sit in the broth. They don't feel particularly springy, but are still a delight to eat. The broth itself was probably the best ramen broth I have tasted in my life - the umami was strong, but the broth did not leave you dying of thirst after having it. I also really appreciated the grilled tomato - it was something different - it tasted almost Italian.

It's apparent that although this restaurant is a ramen spot, and celebrates the 20 years Ivan spent living in Japan, the restaurant does not purport to be 100% traditionally Japanese. Instead, while being firmly rooted in proper Japanese cuisine, I appreciate how each dish also brings in an element of Ivan's New York heritage. For example, while the Kyuri is a traditional Japanese appetizer, the pickles were more akin to NY deli pickles, and while the ramen looks traditional to the ye, the noodles contain rye flour - a testament to Ivan's background (I learned the rye part from the Chef's table episode).

The food is delicious, and each dish tells a story. It's creative and delicious, and I plan on coming back.

I docked a star because although the service was good, it did feel a bit rushed at times. That said, the restaurant was quite busy on the day I went.

Come here to get the appetizers and ramen. Skip the dessert. MAKE A RESERVATION ONLINE!

The Japanese chicken appetizer is a great option if you want crispy, tangy fried chicken. These chicken thighs are in small pieces and served with ranch.

The tonkatsu ramen is awesome. The best part is the broth, which is super rich and creamy and perfect for cold, rainy days. The noodles are bouncy and chewy, perfectly cooked. The egg is right between soft and medium boiled. And the pork is super tender and soft.

The yuzu cheesecake is a bit disappointing, just a normal cheesecake without much of a yuzu flavor. I would have preferred a pretty tart yuzu flavor to make this a unique dessert. The burnt top of the cheesecake a little too burnt as well.

In the end, if you skip the dessert, this is a great option for an excellent ramen experience.

Very rich, depth broth flavor, definitely exceeded my expectations. I loved the chicken paitan the most as it was the least salty, the other broth were good but it is salty after a couple sips. I also enjoyed the crispy eggplant.

This place is a known quantity, so it's probably silly to add yet another review. But, I wanted to at least mention that while my most recent visit was delicious this place can be a little uneven. I think that may always be the case when the owner is, more or less, the reason a place exists; the restaurant will sort of ebb and flow with their influence and participation as the "energy source" of the place--as opposed to some restaurant group monolith that changes very little from season to season. Knowing that going in may be useful.

This place is smaaaalll (read: "cozy"), and I encourage a reservation regardless of the day or time. In the summer, you're going to be warm. It's LES, it's an old building, and AC can't always do miracles.

On our previous trip, I just did not care for what I ordered at all. On this trip, the wagyu brisket buns were delicious and sort of whimsical, like the Coney Island Tofu used to be. (Alas, RIP.) The ramen I ordered was equally tasty and essentially textbook perfection. I added nothing and nothing was needed.

The servers here are really good, by the way. Our most recent was so pleasant, and ready to answer questions and make recommendations--but not in an obnoxious way. She kept the meal rolling along without making it feel hurried. I mention this because it's getting harder and harder to find this, even at places where it shouldn't be.

You should go if you're in Manhattan, bearing in mind that it's a bit of an adventure. Part of the charm is the variances from visit to visit. It's as close as most of us will get to meeting Ivan Orkin himself.

To be fair, I didn't eat ramen here, so I definitely need to return and update my review based on that.

Ivan Ramen is a really cute restaurant between LES and EV that serves ramen and a few appetizers. The menu is small, but everything I tasted was delicious. We started with the cauliflower appetizer, which included fried cauliflower, a delicious curry sauce, and shaved (maybe fried?) ginger on the top. Everything came together beautifully, and I thought the curry sauce was absolutely delicious. The cauliflower also did not get soggy throughout our meal and tasted as crisp as when it came out. I ordered some of the pickles, which were spicy and salty and delicious. My friend ordered the chicken ramen and added spicy sauce to it. It was definitely spicy, but the broth had a  really deep and tasty flavor.

Overall, I really liked this place. The staff and service was amazing, and the food was stellar. Now to return and actually try the ramen!

I came here with my son who lives in the neighborhood.
It's a minimalist lower east side ramen joint.

We started with the crispy eggplant which was new to me. Very good. Crispy outside, moist inside. Great sauce.

I had the gound chicken ramen (it has a better name but I forgot it) and my son and the tonkonsu (pork).
The broth was very nice. The noodles were good. They were thin and dark like soba but did not taste like soba. The toppings were interesting. Ground chicken with a little crunch.
Prices are very reasonable. The server was very nice and helpful.
Verdict: minimalist, high quality, tasty.
Go for it.

My friends and I enjoyed our ramen dinner after a looong day. After the reviews, I was a bit worried, but without reservations we were immediately seated (at the bar). I enjoyed the bar because we were given excellent service!  The bartender/server was really friendly. My boyfriend and I tried the shochu cocktails (grape or plum flavored). The grape one was tasty but the plum didn't have a strong taste. Both of them were pretty mild in terms of tasting the alcohol!

For ramen, I ordered the Tokyo Shio which hit the spot. I enjoyed the signature roasted tomato. The dinner wasn't anything mind blowing, but it was an enjoyable experience with great service.

Came here around 6PM on a Friday and it got pretty busy but never was completely full. It was rainy, humid, and hot so having cold noodles on the menu really made me happy since I was slightly dreading hot ramen. There were larger tables in the back and small parties at the front which was unfortunate since the air conditioning was running more in the back so I was slightly uncomfortably warm. I got the hiyashi chuka and it wasn't bad but the two shrimp was over cooked and the ham was way too salty. I also added bok choy ($3 extra) and it was literally 4 small pieces which was not worth it at all. I also tried the lemon-miso Brussel sprouts which were the highlight of my meal. They were crispy and refreshing. Overall I don't think off of my one dish this place was worth the price but maybe their warm ramen would've wine me over.

Argh, almost 5 stars for the savory umami broth and quick service. Fun vibes with the waitstaff both taking their jobs seriously and not taking themselves too seriously while selecting different Christmas songs and dancing along. The wall art was unique resembling graffiti/comic book art. We sat at the bar and had a direct view of where the magic happens.

Would recommend getting a beer to go with your ramen. We got the tonkatsu (garlic, umami, rich) and chicken paitan (Ivan's favorite, clean, homey) ramen. Definitely hit the spot given the paucity of thoughtfully created ramen dishes in our area (please feel free to prove me wrong).

Love the story behind this place, watch the Chef's Table episode! Not your traditional ramen place, if you're looking for the classics this isn't it. Was able to book a resy a few days out.

Nomz: Shared a couple of starters before having a bowl of ramen.
Lemon Brussels sprouts: really tasty in terms of flavor, felt healthy, unlike most of the times I order it at restaurants
Japanese fried chicken: came out a bit cold, a little sticky but good flavor, probably wouldn't order again
Steamed pork buns: my favorite starter, delicious and flavorful
Tokyo Shio Ramen: I'm a tonkotsu girl at heart but tried something different this time. For me lacked flavor, the tomato bites made it better but I only had one piece so couldn't make it last for the entire bowl. I did try the tonkotsu from someone's bowl, a lot lighter in flavor and density than your average, not for me.

Drinks: Had two sakes bottles, didn't have much price spectrum, on the more expensive side. Unfiltered was my fav, on the sweeter side of sake but not overly sweet generally speaking.

Service: Waitress was prompt and helpful.

Ambiance: Small/cozy long setup of the place, hip art and outdoor back area.

Nope or Dope: Nope, the pork buns were winners in my book but the ramen should be stealing the show and it didn't for me.

There were some parts of this restaurant that I loved and other parts that were okay. This place isn't bad at all, but I wouldn't put it at my top recommendations for ramen in NYC.  If you do like ramen that packs a punch, then I think this place would be good for you.

My loves for the restaurant:
- Great service and attentive staff. They explain the menu very well and provide excellent recommendations based on your preferences. They don't hover too much and they're there when you need them
- The buckwheat noodle style. I preferred this with the punchy flavors of the ramen because it's not as thick and heavy as the other noodle styles

The part that left me hanging might just have been the broth itself. Does it taste different from other restaurants? Absolutely. But, it just felt like too much for me. It's a very stimulating experience, so if you're wanting a homier style of ramen, I would try another place.

We had a lovely dinner at Ivan Ramen yesterday. The bartender (brunette with bleached eyebrows) at the counter was a delight, she gave us recommendations and provided great service.

We ordered:
* Crispy Eggplant ($13)
* Yuzu Lemonade ($4)
* Ivan Palmer ($4)
* Tonkotsu Ramen ($19)
* Tokyo Shio Ramen (18)

We spent a total of $63.16 - a little pricy but the food was delicious. The fried eggplants had a delicate crispy breading on the outside and had a silk like consistency on the inside. The drinks were tart and refreshing -- some might say they're not sweet at all compared to traditional lemonade and Arnold Palmers. The unsweetened barley tea is very prominent in the Ivan Palmer even when you mix it together but it was very good. It was a nice palate cleanser to cut through the richness of the ramen.

I LOVED the broth of the Tonkotsu ramen. It is jam packed flavorful with tender pork and bits of mushroom. Tokyo Shio ramen had a very deep yet "clean" tasting broth. The tomato was a nice umami bomb which is an unusual topping but totally worked. Both bowls didn't look like a lot of food but we left feeling stuffed. The only thing we weren't too crazy about was their noodles. They were a bit lackluster and wished they were wavier for texture. Also they only have one dessert on their menu which is their Yuzu Cheesecake. But overall we had satisfying dinner.

If you find yourself in the LES craving ramen, head on over Ivan Ramen for a special treat. Although, don't be too spontaneous because you'll need an online reservation!

I very much enjoyed the chicken paitan ramen. I added a soft boiled egg and bok choy to add to the fun! The crispy togarashi chicken skins added an extra something-something to the dish. I also enjoyed the Ivan Palmer - half-tea and half-yuzu lemonade. We also liked the yuzu cheesecake.

Last, but not least; our server was attentive and lovely.
Holy hell. If you don't go, you missed some serious enjoyment of life. Just be sure to make reservations, and have some of the best treats in the country. Try everything.

We had to sample Ivan's famous ramen after seeing him on Netflix's Chef's Table, and we're definitely glad we got to try it! Ivan incorporates rye into his noodles, and they are noticeably chewier than others I've had before. It gives a bit more of a "glutinous" feel to your bowl.

We got the tonkotsu ramen, and the broth was rich, flavorful, and the other ingredients were super fresh.

We shared the kyuri pickles - which seemed like northern chinese pickles with a spicy kick, the fried chicken, and the crispy eggplant. All 3 were a hit. The fried chicken was cooked well - wouldn't be surprised if it was twice fried, and had some spice to it. The crispy eggplant was in a bed of miso based sauce, and while very crispy, I was slightly disappointed that there still didn't seem to be much flavor unless you loaded them with sauce. This was a surprise because other reviewers loved the dish. The pickles were more of a bar food item - not something to fill you up, whereas the chicken was a fairly large portion.

While the ramen was great, we're on a mission to find new places to try and the food wasn't memorable enough to try twice.

Overall,
Food 4.5/5
Ambiance 4/5
Service 4/5

Ivan ramen is an incredibly cool spot in the Lower East Side. They have a great front and back patio and the inside is very hip as well! The staff were super helpful in providing recommendations for our first time there and we were not disappointed.

We got the cold noodles and the chicken ramen and both were awesome. The chicken ramen almost tasted like thanksgiving dinner with an asian flare but was a 10/10. The cold noodles were super refreshing for a summer night but if you have a low spicy tolerance definitely asks!

Damn this place is so fire. I had heard this place was gas, and it definitely did not disappoint. Started with the Ebi Lemon Mayo, per our server's recommendation, and it was seriously so good. Lots of great spicy lemon flavor. For ramen, I went with the Spicy Red Chili and DAMN SO FIRE. Our server said it was a 7/10 on the spicy scale which was pretty accurate. Incredible flavor.

Service was 10/10 and the vibe was 11/10. I also think this would be a great solo dining spot. A bit pricy, but absolutely worth it.

When you step into Ivan Ramen, you're transported into a new continent full of fun and exciting flavors.

Comic-lined walls and invite you into a cozy, quick-to-serve slurp shop, where, spoiler alert, the best thing on the menu isn't the ramen but the fried chicken.

Service is quick as staff tries to keep up with the demand Netflix created with their hit show Chef's Table.

If I were more of a ramen fan, I might give this 5 stars, but my ceiling for ramen just isn't high enough!

Ivan Ramen's QR code menu was SUPER pretentious, all but forcing you to watch a video on each dish's origins before it gave you any information on, I don't know, what was in it. This level of self-importance would have been easily forgiven if the bowl had been great, but it was barely edible, and the reason why is...

... salt. I don't know what happened in the kitchen that day, whether this was an aberration, or whether every Ivan-celebrator just reallllly likes salt. But I reallllly like salt most of the time, and it was about a thousand times too much for me. When they pickled the mustard greens and the wood ear mushrooms, is it possible they just poured the pickling water into my soup? It was medicinally salty, chemically so. I could smell it when they put the bowl down - I picked the bowl up to sniff it curiously before I even lifted a spoon to my mouth.

If ratings were an average of how well each ingredient was prepared, Ivan would have done okay, actually. The pork was a perfect melt-in-your-mouth ring, the noodles firm and chewy, the egg delightfully orange and runny. But none of those things mattered because they all sat in the Great Salt Lake of Ramen.

Excellent ramen with a reputation that speaks for itself. I love the creative spin on traditional dishes. Deviations like this polarize many, but I found this take to favor my palate. I can never choose between the chicken paitan and the tonkotsu. It's always a pleasure when there's a specialty tsukemen on the menu. The karage and eggplant appetizers are always good. I've been many times and will continue to return.

Very tasty food; atmosphere - okay; overall I enjoyed my dinner but think that this place is overrated.

If you ask me, it's hard to mess up ramen. By default - it's delicious, and sure, I greatly enjoyed my bowl of Chicken Paitan, but did it blow my mind? No. I also found the ramen portion a little smaller than I'm used to - not necessarily a bad thing, but FYI.

Was also unimpressed by the appetizers: Japanese Fried Chicken, Tobanjan Green Beans, Spicy Kyuri Pickles.

So why 4 stars for what reads like such an underwhelming experience? Well, if you're looking for a yummy meal in the area - definitely go, you'll have some good food. BUT if you are on a mission to find NYC's best ramen - don't go out of your way to eat at Ivan's: I think there are plenty of similar or better options throughout the city.

Tip: definitely make a reservation and get a table in the room in the back if you can. And for those who prefer outdoor seating - that option is available as well!

Yo.  The hype is real! Excellent service, mouth watering ramen (OG chicken) but the kicker was the pastrami/sauerkraut steamed buns. WTF.  I had to hold onto the back of my head to keep it from blowing off.  Will be back, Ivan.  Love your story and love this food!

I came here on Monday for my birthday brunch this past week. We came with a group of 7 and were seated in the backyard patio. We made a reservation ahead of time and I'm glad we did because the place filled up even on a Monday afternoon.

We came here on a suggestion of my friend who saw this place from Chef's Table and from strong recommendations from other friends.

Here is what we ordered:
For the table
- Crispy Eggplant
- Coney Island Tofu
- Pork Buns
- Spicy Kyuri Pickles
- XO Daikon
Myself
- Tokyo Shio

All the appetizers were really savory and delicious. I must admit I did not have high expectations but they well exceeded what I'd expected. The Crispy Eggplant had such a good crisp and the spices to it meshed so well. The Coney Island Tofu was soft but packed a good punch. I was surprised at how good the XO Daikon was. XO sauce usually gives a strong savory front, and it worked well with the daikon neutral flavoring. Pork Buns and the Spicy Pickles were both very tasty. I must say this was quite a lineup of good tasting appetizers. I got the Tokyo Shio which is their signature dish. The broth and noodle were on point and not too salty. The roasted tomato they add in gives it that well placed umami taste in every bite. My friends who got their Chicken paitan really enjoyed it as well.

Our service was attentive and on point. Our server Zack was knowledgable and courteous. He gave us a thorough rundown of the differences between the different types of ramen, which I am sure is a common query. Definite big props to him for making our experience that much better!

In summary: great food and service; I would be returning here!

Ok this place for some reason gets a very hard shake that it doesn't deserve. 3.5 stars????!! What are we doing here Yelp family. This is a five star establishment. The ramen isn't super traditional but it is super delicious. I love the tonkotsu ramen. The apps are also money specifically pork buns and fried chicken. They have a great beer menu, wonderful sake selection, and lots of other good looking drinks. The vibe inside is really cool, lots of playful comics above the bar that I love. Also there is solid outdoor seating in the garden. My one qualm is that the service is a bit too fast. I like a well timed service that gives you ample time for apps, chit chat, and dinner. They rushed through everything a bit too quickly for my liking.

I haven't tasted a better ramen. Kogane's broth on 14th come close on the umami meter, but their noodles are like rubber bands. Here, everything from texture to taste is perfectly balanced, making every bite or slurp orgasmic. I have to take a star off for how expensive it is. Yes the prices are comparable to others, but the portion is noticeably smaller. Also, most of their seating is on stools which I find extremely uncomfortable for my back, and would've had to leave. Luckily I got there at noon so they let me move to a table!

Pros
Outside seating
Inexpensive
Excellent service
Vegetarian option
Soft serve yogurt
Decent food
Good music

Cons
Closes early
Icy soft serve
Only beer for alcohol

This is a delayed review: I came here in April and had reservations for 4. To be honest the ramen wasn't too memorable now that three months has passed, but that means that the noodles and soup were of good quality since bad noodles are the worst when you eat at a ramen joint!

THE BEST HOWEVER was the CRISPY EGGPLANT.
Oh my lord.
I smelled it from the bathroom. The texture is excellent. I would 1000% come back for this plus a beer on the regular.

Definitely worth a try!

I traveled all the way to New York just to try Ivan's ramen, and I was not disappointed. The noodles were incredible, and the broth was even more so. I had the pork belly buns, which were fantastic! I wish Florida had a ramen business as good as this one. If you ever visit New York, this is a must-visit.

New York City has no shortage of amazing ramen restaurants, and Ivan Ramen is no exception. Every dish is absolutely gorgeous, and the flavors definitely live up to the Instagram-worthy presentation. For my plant-based friends, they have an absolutely amazing vegan shoyu ramen, or you can always go for one of their vegetarian starters.

I'm, personally, a huge fan of crispy eggplant, which has a delightful breadcrumb layer that is fried to golden perfection and offers the best contrast against the soft, succulent eggplant. This goes beautifully with the rich, nutty sesame paste and the smoky, fragrant charred garlic. If you're a fan of eggplant, I definitely recommend giving this dish a shot...and, honestly, I'd still give it a try if you aren't a huge fan of eggplant -- this dish might be the one to convert you!

They also have a lovely yuzu cheesecake with a burnt top; while the cake was rich and lovely, I didn't find it particularly special. The yuzu flavor wasn't particularly strong, and it honestly just tasted like a slightly lemon-y, vanilla-y New York slice. The burnt topping was a nice contrast, but I think that there was a bit too much of it for my taste. All in all, though, I loved my experience at Ivan Ramen. The service was phenomenal, the prices were reasonable, and the outdoor patio was wonderful. I can't wait to visit again!

One of my new favorite spots. The Chicken Paitan was truly one of the best things I've eaten, and the Tokyo Shyo was really excellent as well. One of the best things there was the service, though. We sat at the bar, and the bartender/server was incredibly friendly, and informative with helping us pick the items that matched our style. He also was kind enough to let us taste various sakes, and was overall a blast to have as part of our experience.

Will for sure be back!

Ivan is a decent Ramen place but what helps it greatly is how friendly and welcoming the entire staff is. I'm not influenced by Netflix so the ramen options were not mind blowing but still very good. The atmosphere is one of casual and nothing exceptionally ground breaking. Expect a good Ramen and great service, recommend if you're down in this area.

My fiancé and I came to try out Ivan Ramen by recommendation of my sister during our recent visit to New York.  

First let's start with how awesome and hip the interior was. I loved the wall pattern covered in what looked like images that were classic to Japanese pop culture. So cool!

Now the food: On first bite, wow we were speechless.  The egg plant and chicken karate appetizers were so bomb. The ramen, wow. And the yuzu cheesecake, chef's kiss!!!  This was the best ramen that we had on our trip, and we went to four places total. Just written this review is making my mouth water lol!

Lastly, the service was amazing. Our waitress was so attentive and friendly!!

I definitely plan to go back the next time we visit NYC! Thank you Ivan Ramen for a memorable dining experience!!

Easy weeknight reservation. Good place for a comforting meal after work. I came with my partner but the bar tables make it solo dining friendly. There's an outdoor dining area that would be great for warm days. The inside looks a lot like an elevated diner with fun murals covering the walls. I loved how our server started with recommendations and popular dishes. We took her advice and ordered the Chicken Paitan, Tonkotsu Ramen and Crispy Eggplant. They were all some of the best food we've had. You can ask for chili oil if you'd like added spice. Portion is generous and filling. Had to try the yuzu cheesecake. On the surface it looks pretty ordinary- no toppings. But it is a rich and solid slice of a classic desert with an understated taste of citrus.

THE BEST RAMEN AND FRIED CHICKEN.

I've heard about Ivan for years but finally made reservations. I got the Japanese fried chicken for an appetizer and it was perfectly juicy with a light and crunchy batter. I couldn't stop eating them and almost ordered another portion to take to go lol! It came with a garlic aoili mixed with herbs and the balance between the two made it one of the best things I've eaten.

For ramen, I got the pork ramen and the broth had a depth of flavor that was unmatched. The umami and creaminess of the broth mixed with all of the toppings made me eat every last drop.

DO NOT SKIP THIS PLACE!

Stopped by this spot after a comedy show next door and my experience was... alright! Nothing crazy, neither good or bad.

If you're an avid ramen eater, I don't think you would like this place. First off when a ramen place is owned by a non-asian person it's already heavily discredited in my opinion. I can appreciate it and their love for ramen but I guess I'm biased.

The restaurant itself looks like any other ramen restaurant. Super long. (Anyone else notice this? Why are so many ramen restaurants long?) There's a bar section and also dining tables. We sat at the high top section. The decor is cute, not too obnoxious but definitely Asian-centered which again, a little weird since it's owned by a non-Asian person... lol.

We ordered off the online menu that everyone seems to be so entertained by but when you're in the city with slow service due to high traffic/crowds, it's just annoying lol.

We got the Tokyo Shoyu, Tokyo Shio, pork buns, curry flower, tofu Coney Island.

The ramens were good but not great. Nothing special or out of the ordinary. Broth was subpar and not deep and rich. Also the portion was pretty small... The pork buns were great. Super soft and delicious buns and the pork was cooked and seasoned well. The curry flower was delicious! Such an interesting flavor and texture combo and it just worked. The tofu was also pretty good but a little salty.

Overall, I would say the apps stole the show. It was good to finally try this spot but prob won't be craving this spot by any means.

Came here on a Friday night and the interior was really chic, especially for being in an outdoors area. I really liked the broth and the texture of the noodles.

Service was good. The ramen was great but didn't blow me away.

The ramen was so salty. I came here on a recommendation, but really I wouldn't come back again. Had me wanting to chug water after the meal. I'd recommend looking for other options unless you like your food pretty salty!

About a 1-1.5: I made reservations in advance to try Ivan Ramen out, and the super friendly host made sure we had great center seats at the counter, in front of the kitchen. That was so nice!

The menu included various starters, ramen, mazemn, tsukemen, rich dishes, desserts, and beverages.

We came here for an early lunch, and ordered:
+a Chicken Paitan - chicken broth with minced chicken, egg yolk, and chicken skin
+a Seafood Tsukemen - this came with a bowl of lobster & shrimp dipping broth, roasted cabbage, and slices of shrimp toast
+a glass of Housemade Yuzu Lemonade

At first, we wanted to try the Shio, but we got suckered in in ordering the Paitan, as that was stated to be the most favorite out of the ramen choices.  Unfortunately, both bowls were just not good.  The ramen noodles were slightly overcooked for our taste, and there were several noodles that were clumped together.  Both of the broths in the Paitan and the Tsukemen had an unpleasant taste to them.  

I thought I liked the shrimp toast, but after the 2nd bite, it just tasted super greasy.  The tuskemen broth was on the thicker end, which I appreciated, but it had a fishy taste to it.

The housemade yuzu lemonade was fizzy, but could have been more chilled or served with more ice.

Service was welcoming and friendly, but our server enjoyed rambling on and on about the menu, and without sporting a mask, I noticed that the counter was continuously sprayed. Eeks.

The place definitely became packed with both those who had reservations and those who were walk-ins.

I'm glad I was able to try this place out, but wouldn't return.

+fishy tsukemen
+clumpy noodles
+reservations accepted

There's 2 places I frequent in NYC. Ivan Ramen happens to be one of them. I typically eat here for a pre race meal before running the NYC Marathon or NYC Half. This time around I decided to just go for the heck of it. I love the idea of a little hole in the wall ramen shop. It's very reminiscent of my short short time in Tokyo. I like the idea that everything is made in house. The flavors of cold sesame noodle dish, I can close my eyes and still taste it. I learned how to make these noodles however nothing will ever compare. The ramen was well balanced and not overly salty. The pork buns were just so so but still 5 stars to me.

Had great ramen here (and also spotted some celebrities!). We shared the cripsy eggplant appetizer on recommendation from other Yelp reviews and you really can't miss it! The food came out quickly. I had the chicken paitan ramen and loved the touch of crispy chicken skin. The food was solid and our server was incredibly friendly and happy to offer her suggestions.

Food: 5/5
Service: 5/5

Really enjoyed our dinner. The ambiance is relaxed and cozy. The waiter did a great job and took special care to pace the tasting menu so that we were never waiting for the next course, but we were never rushed either.

I'd recommend that people get the full course menu over the light menu because we really liked the sashimi and dessert.

My other favorite dishes were the oden, marinated pumpkin and okra skewers. But everything was great.
The service is very good, the owner offered us free drinks. The environment is very clean and calm. I recommend for dinner!

Amazing food, professional service, everything was fantastic!!
Great ambiance, I love the Japanese decor too!

The restaurant is small but service is excellent! It specializes mostly in skewers...chicken. There's only 2 options to choose from the menu. A nice place to hang out and talk for 2 hours. The staff takes his time to explain each skewer to us, recommending what spices to dip it with. Very nice experience.

I eat yakitori around the world; often I travel to Japan just for yakitori. This place has it nailed! Ambiance, sake selection (and price!), and love of yakitori were all on point. It's people who care about yakitori, and if you don't know yet, you SHOULD care about yakitori too; sushi is the celebration of fish, yakitori is the celebration of (grilled) chicken. It takes time, it takes skill, and it pays off. I let them know well in advance, but they had all the chicken parts I love, and all expertly grilled. You owe yourself a night out here; get the 3 year aged in snow sake: Hakkaisan Yokimuro. So good, just the optimal pairing.
Simple but high end, chicken-focused yakitori in a typical hideaway izakaya setting. Attentive, informative service, lovely atmosphere.

Cute little spot from the same group behind Azasu and Yopporai.

Cute outdoor seating during Covid.

We came here for second dinner of the night so more like drinks and bites.

Tsukune skewer was tasty.
Grilled Salmon was fresh but little overcooked.
Grilled Squid was my fav. Super simple just fresh ingredient not overly done.

Would recommend!

I had very high expectation for this place so I booked this place for my friend who are visiting me today from DC. We ordered agedashi tofu, scallops, octopus, wagyu beef over ice and chirashi. All appetizers are okay, scallops were better than okay. The chirashi had many different fish in it and generous amount of uni, but it had cooked shrimps. I've never seen a chirashi had cooked shrimps. But it was okay. The wagyu beef over rice is really sub-par. Beef were over cooked and hard to chew. I didn't even finish. I started to doubt if these were wagyu or just regular beef.

Good food, good service.  Duck and beef were fresh and soft.  Good choice of drinks.  It's a very small (intimate?) place, so if you are seeking a large crowd, this isn't the place.  Also, there's only about ten seats in the whole restaurant, if you have a loud table, you wont be able to communicate with your group.

Would not recommend this place. The omakase is subpar and there are many other places that serve higher quality items at their price point. The soba is VERY underwhelming and pretty much soggy. I mentioned this to the staff and their response was "this is what we expect the soba texture to be". I have eaten at many other Japanese restaurants and I've never been served COOKED salmon as a form of "chirashi". An absolute disgrace to Japanese cuisine - STAY AWAY

Excellent kitchy, whimisical, retro 80s speakeasy that that only be pulled off in a Japanese neighborhood bar! The yakitori is top notch as well as the drinks! I really felt like I was in Japan again but with American salary men having drinks and skewers after a long week.

I suggest the beef tongue, pork belly, gizzard and skirt steak skewers!

My partner and I were on our way to another restaurant when we passed by Ronin Stones (obviously a play on the Rolling Stones). We decided to try this place out because it's new, it's closer than our first intended restaurant, and we like supporting small businesses.

We walk in, and it's not very big inside, but it's EXTREMELY clean and cozy. And as if it wasn't already cozy enough, they also have a heater on the ceiling and an open grill that you can feel heat being emitted from. There isn't much seating at the front, and the seats are close to one another, but that wasn't a problem for just the two of us.

The chef/staff were very friendly and nice. Usually restaurant staff don't make me feel comfortable because they seem like they're always on your , but I was really comfortable with them.

We ordered the edamame, potato salad, grilled vegetables, chicken gizzards skews, chicken thigh skews, and beef tongue stew with demi glace over rice. THEY WERE ALL FANTASTIC. THEY WERE ALL ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS  we've had really tough gizzards before because they've been overcooked, but the ones here are tender, juicy, and flavorful! And no potato salad compares to Japanese potato salad. It was rich, filled with assorted vegetables, and fresh. I was a big fan of the rice dish. The beef was cooked until tender and once you bite into it, it just melts in your mouth  the sauce also pairs well with the beef and rice. The sauce may be overwhelming for some people (like it was for my partner), but I definitely loved it.

I will absolutely, positively be returning soon!

Small intimate space. The menu isn't creative or different; it's just the typical izakaya menu. I felt many dishes were heavy handed with the seasoning. That's probably because the food is supposed to encourage you to take sips of your drink. Everything is just OK, but the vibe  makes things work at this place. I would stop by again if I'm in the area but won't go out of my way to go there.

If it weren't for the owner of Azasu handing me and my boyfriend guitar pick business cards for Ronin Stones, we may have never found the place for years. For an intimate date, take a friend or two to the back room, which is decorated with rock and roll memorabilia, Polaroids of guests, and the lilt of music from old tour videos playing in the background. Danny and I split a few skewers--my favorite being the beef tongue--grilled vegetables and Sapporo. Will return soon to enjoy more of the ambiance and later a larger entree.

Wasn't as impressed food wise as I was hoping to be, considering how much I loved Yopparai. But it's an awesome concept (with the live music + small plates + sake) and I imagine a fun LES spot in pre-covid times.

We tried:

Beef tripe stew - Probably my favorite item, soft savory beef tripe.

Chicken skewer -  The chicken tasted a bit undercooked and under-salted. Not my favorite.

Tsukune - My favorite out of the skewers we tried, but unfortunately I kept comparing it in my mind to the most incredible tsukune I had at a neighborhood izakaya in Japan, and this just wasn't that. Good but not exceptional.

Skirt steak skewer - Better than the chicken but also nothing standout to me (found it a bit chewy).

Oden - Nice warming dish for the winter but again fairly standard.

At the end of the day, I think the issue was that I had the wrong expectations going in. Rather than another Yopparai, which is a more refined izakaya experience, Ronin Stones is just a solid neigborhood spot with an excellent sake list paired with some great drinking food - nothing that's meant to blow you away or be particularly innovative, but a failsafe when you're just looking to have a casual drink and unwind after a long week.

The food was underwhelming. Standard Izakaya with no standout dishes, though the sauces were good. The scallops and duck were overcooked and they quickly fixed us another plate, but the meat itself was neither as tasty nor tender as French duck.

Such a cool new addition to the LES! Rock n roll themed Japanese skewer/sake bar. Came here with the boyfriend for dinner and loved the experience/food! Storefront is super tiny and easy to miss so be careful or you might pass it.

When you walk in there is a front room with a small counter seating area along the grill. I thought it was really cool that you could watch the grill master cook your skewers. However, caught a glimpse of the back room bar when I went to use the bathroom and it looked awesome! Walls are lined with records, cassettes, a little mini guitar, etc.

Some great deals for happy hour, any kind of chicken skewer (meatball, thigh, gizzard, liver) was $5 for 2 and $5 beer/sake. We tried a little bit of everything. I thought the livers were super flavorful albeit very rich, 2 was almost too much. Beef tongue & skirt steak were delicious. Thighs were very tender. My favorite might have been the meatballs - very interesting color (green) but really yummy. Definitely get them.

They have an amazing outdoor dining setup, which keeps you sufficiently warm in frigid temps. Highly recommend coming here for that reason alone, but also the prix fixe menu was great and the food/sake was delicious. I called and made an outdoor dining reservation for 2 people at 8pm. When we showed up, it was 28 degrees outside... but they have booths with a heater INSIDE the table, which was extremely effective. The outdoor dining setup is incredibly cute and even comes with fresh blankets and robes that you can wear while eating. Despite below-freezing temperatures, we were completely warm and cozy.

Ever since indoor dining got shut down in NYC, I have tried a lot of restaurants with heat lamps and nearly froze to death at most. This was the most comfortable experience I've had yet! Only downside is you cannot fit more than 3-4ppl in a booth, so doesn't work for big groups.
Outstanding food and service. There is brief intro for each course and the flavor in each course is balanced perfectly. I'd definitely recommend the place, especially who want to try the omakase.

Wow this place is amazing. It is amazing that it's so hidden and it's like a speakeasy that serves food. It's literally LES's new secret.

Even though we came when they recently opened, there were already people waiting at 730pm!!!!!

Ok anyway - the service is AMAZING. The service and the people are AMAZING. Shawn and Pamela are incredibly nice and the food is amazing as well.

This restaurant is by the same owner as yopparai and azasu which are Japanese restaurants that you have to make reservations weeks in advance so imSO happy ronin exists.

Pam and Shawn are amazing and the food is delicious. HIGHLY recommend but just don't come when I come because i hate waiting haha :)

Cute little place, themed after the passion the owner has for rock and roll and music. Fairly new and offers Japanese style skewers and rice bowls.
We stumbled on it while strolling through LES, and a couple sitting at the window gave us the nod and a thumbs up, which was enough for us to be sold to eating there.
The place has a small eating area at the front and all the cooking happens behind the counter. There is however a private room in the back, which is open to the public o. Regular days unless there is a private party going on. That place is like walking into a man cave of a music lover. Very well aid out, posters, lps, CD's and even cassettes on display.
Food was good, looked fresh and tasted fresh, though we only tried skewers this time around, it warrants a return trip for the rice bowl.
My vating is more for the overall concept, the friendliness of the people who work there and that Man Cave!!!

What a wonderful little bar.  Having lived in Japan for a couple of years, it was a reminder of home in a way - just like what you'd find there, but through a NYC prism.  The bar itself was Tiny, and everyone was more or less chatting with each other, while enjoying tasty food and drink.  Also, the night I was there, there was a really, really good DJ.  I can't wait to go back here.  Cannot recommend enough.
Just a perfect, creative omakase menu served in a tiny, romantic space. You'll love it.

Lovely outdoor seating area with heavy blankets for extra warmth on a cool April eve. We had maguro tuna chirashi and sake steamed Hudson Valley trout. Each dish was delicious and elegantly presented. Washed it down with a nice crisp sake. The ambiance was comfortable exotic Japanese.

Let me tell you, Yopparai Ronin was simply mind-blowing. This place is awesome at what it does. The menu is really terrific, so many really good choices, I had to go with Beef Tongue, and it was terrific. Staff are really helpful and service is very quick. Yopparai Ronin is definitely a special place.

You will be AMAZED, everything cook to perfection when you order. It's a little more pricey than bigger restaurant but this place is very neat and clean reminds me of the time when I  went to Japan. The food was spot on and I don't think I can get that anywhere else. I love the beef tongue  and the sauce it came with. The oden was delicious and cook perfectly. Can't wait to go back.

My favorite neighborhood bar. Where else but the lower east would you find a rolling stones themed Japanese bar with great sake and yakitori!! Love this place. Once you make it though the secret door, you feel like a true ronin (a rōnin was a samurai without a lord or master during the feudal period). The other ronins - Pam, Shane and kazumi are incredible people who make you feel like home. You can even pick your cds and they'll gladly play it for you. thank you guys!

Beautiful and unique outdoor dining experience. We did the prix fixe menu and everything was delicious. Service was exceptional and we stayed cozy and warm with the Japanese winter style seating with heat lamps.  Make sure you make a reservation and support this amazing local business

Heading back tonite after being introduced to RS a couple of weeks ago.  To say the place is "chill" is about the most appropriate adjective to use.  The vibe, the food, the drinks, the music...ALL CAPS, ALL VERY GREAT!
Go and have a relaxing time.  Oh, and the bathroom, yes, the bathroom is 2nd to none in the history of bathrooms.  It's almost worth going just for that! :)
Amazing bbq skewers and cocktails. Food is fresh. The green-tea cocktail was delicious!!! Highly recommend for a late night evening!

I was downtown and decided to take advantage and find some good authentic Italian food.  My wife found this place on Yelp so we decided to try it out.  Street parking was pretty easy to find in the area too which was a plus.  

From the moment I entered I realized I was in for a treat.  The place had a vibe about it that took me back to my time in Trastevere a city right outside of Rome.  I would eat in the same place almost everyday the last time I went there.  The food was authentic we ordered CALAMARI ALLA GRIGLIA and it was incredible, full of flavor and so tasty.  The service was extremely efficient and impressive, attentive without being overbearing.

For the main dish I ordered TAGLIOLINI SAPORE DI MARE because it reminded me of a dish I ordered in Rome.  It was home made Tagliolini with seafood in a red sauce.  When it came out and I watched the food runner place it in front of me with anticipation.  It was steaming hot and looked outstanding.  I finally got to try it and Wow!  This dish is an absolutely delightful.  I very rarely take home
what I don't finish but this time I had to take the rest home.  The next day I ate it for lunch and it was just as good as when it was first served.  

For dessert, we had a special that was suggested I can't remember the name but it was a cake made with olive oil and fruits served with ice cream and it too, was incredibly delicious.  This is a place I would highly recommend, authenticity means everything to me and to make matters even better the prices were very reasonable.  I will be back to this place for sure.

Il Posto Accanto is an absolute gem in the world of Italian cuisine! From the moment I stepped through the door, I was enchanted by the warm and inviting ambiance. The charming rustic decor and soft, dim lighting created the perfect setting for an unforgettable dining experience.

The food, oh, the food! It was nothing short of a culinary masterpiece. Each dish was a symphony of flavors and textures that transported my taste buds straight to Italy. The pasta dishes were cooked to perfection, and the homemade sauces were bursting with authentic Italian flavors. I can't recommend their signature lasagna enough - it's a true work of art.

The wine list was extensive and expertly curated, offering a wide selection of Italian wines that paired beautifully with our meal. The knowledgeable staff helped us choose the perfect wine to complement our dishes, and their service was impeccable throughout the evening.

What truly sets Il Posto Accanto apart, though, is the warmth and genuine hospitality of the staff. The owners and the entire team take pride in making every guest feel like family. They were attentive, friendly, and eager to share their passion for Italian cuisine, enhancing our overall experience.

Whether you're celebrating a special occasion, enjoying a romantic date night, or simply craving an authentic Italian meal, Il Posto Accanto is the place to go. I can't wait to return to this culinary haven for more delicious adventures and memorable moments. Grazie mille for an incredible dining experience!

Stay away! Too many people know about this place now. It's ALWAYS incredible. Get the specials. Get a bottle. Even if you indulge, it won't break the bank. Bea and Julio are awesome but-  if you don't like NYers- don't go.
If you want an authentic NYC experience - this is the place to be.
But like I said, STAY AWAY - I need a table when I need it, damnit. I can't wait for your tourist ass to finish the SPECTACULAR Panna Cotta.

II Posto Accanto small quaint restaurant-we went with no reservations being it was a Tuesday night didn't think it would be a problem-as we walk in the man behind the bar asked if we had reservations I said no and he said well you can sit at the bar, I looked around and said to myself there's  plenty of empty tables now -but I think with the look on my face he said you can sit overthere-two person table great. I felt he was not nice lol -but felt lucky we got to sit . As I looked at the menu I was noticing this is an authentic Italian restaurant. I order as an appetizer CALAMARI ALLA GRIGLIA mind you thought this was the regular fried calamari lol-but it was fresh calamari whole marinated in extra virgin olive oil it was deliciously amazing-then I was looking for entrée so I choose LINGUINE VONGOLE -vongole clams sautéed with garlic, olive oil and a touch of peperoncino-I Am someone that rarely finishes her plate, but this was so fantastic savory linguine cooked to perfection-eat the whole thing. My husband ordered Tagliolini Al Sapore Di Mare again a perfect choice delicious. Moving on to desert it was in the special menu -their apple tart, it was a cake like stuffed with cinnamon apples and drunken raisins soooo good. Overall I will be going back with reservations-the service was wondering soo attentive and classy. Ended the night with a delicious expreso -sooo good

This restaurant has some of the best food I've had in my life. It is owned by a very sweet Italian couple with of course, authentic Italian food. I came here with my father and sister. The outside of the shop is easy to miss, but once you go inside you will be amazed by all the gorgeous Chinese lantern lights and other decorations. There is a bar on the right side, but you can order drinks at your table if you don't want to sit there.

We ordered a variety of food, but the one thing that stuck with me was the Calamari Alla Griglia. It wasn't fried like it usually is at other place, it was marinated and grilled. It was very soft and tender and SO FLAVORFUL. This was also the best calamari or squid I have ever had. I highly recommend coming here, and trying this is a must. We also ordered Cavatelli di Ricotta Fatti in Casa, Tortellini with Ox Tail, Polpo Alla Griglia, Crudo di Tonno Con Avocado E Agrumi, Crocchette di Baccala' al Curry, and for dessert we got the Tiramisu. It is pricey, but very much worth it! I will definitely be coming back soon.

NYTimes put it best. Beatrice is "The Empress of East Second Street" and her trattoria is an unparalleled gem.

In addition to its already generous menu, Il Posto offers a lovely selection of daily specials - always seasonal and often sourced from local farmers' markets.

This is one of the few places that serves fried squash blossoms, which are only available for a short time, stuffed with cheese with a perfectly crisp batter.

The seafood pasta is also worthwhile. With a light red sauce clinging to each strand of linguine and teeming with muscles, squid, shrimp, clams, and scallops.

But the real star of the show, in my opinion, is the Sunday lasagna. I don't even usually like lasagna but this dish is perfection. Unapologetically rich and never soggy. It has an ideal ratio of meat, sauce, and bubbling cheese.

If I lived closer, I'm afraid that I would need a 12-step program because this place is addictive.

Had the meatballs, fondue, creamy shrimp pasta, oxtail tortellini , and frito misti

The meatballs were the best dish but only came with 3 pieces. The fondue was thin and watery. The creamy pasta is good but it was small and probably only 4 bites. The oxtail was very doughy and stodgy but the sauce was good. The fried seafood was ok but needed a sauce  not just lemon.

Overall the dishes are very small for the price and the service was slow.

Love this place so so much! I've been a few times now and usually sit at the bar. The bar tenders are so nice and friendly. They got their liquor license a few months ago and the cocktails look amazing however I usually stick to wine. It's such a cozy, neighborhood spot and great to grab a drink and some small plates when in the area or for a a date. Definitely check it out

Came for a lunch with family and sat outdoors. Everything we had tasted great.

Appetizers & salad:

Calamari - grilled, not fried. Some of the best squid I've ever had!

Spring market salad - this was great, all the different ingredients worked really well and the dressing was refreshing, not too heavy.

Rughetta e fungi - this was the simplest dish so i liked the spring market salad more, but it was still solid. Just arugula and sliced mushrooms but the parm was really good!

Mozzarella with prosciutto - the mozzarella was really good! Came on top of some bread, which got a little soggy but was fine

Pastas: all cooked to al dente, serving sizes were good. I was actually too full to finish mine!

Spaghetti Bottarga - first time trying this and really liked it. A little salty, but super flavorful

Cacio e pepe special with squash blossoms - this was a thick pasta, a little too firm on the cook for me but possibly perfect al dente for others. The squash blossoms were a nice addition. Would recommend not adding on extra grated cheese - made it a little too rich for me!

Squid ink special with uni - this was great, the uni was rich and creamy and the sauce had a nice spicy kick.

Spaghetti with tomato and basil sauce - solid dish!

Desserts:

Lemon sorbetti with sage - loved this, the sage made a great addition to the flavor

Affogatto special - first time not having it with vanilla ice cream and it didn't disappoint!

Also got an olive oil cake from the specials menu (forgot the flavors) that was good too, maybe a bit sweet on its own to ear the whole thing but was perfect for sharing

Service : was good, everyone was really friendly. Cleared dishes promptly and cleaned up the table a bit before dessert. I think the manager / owner made sure to check in on us, thanked us after our meal and made sure we enjoyed everything. She also gave some tips while we were ordering (like including grilled veggies to balance out the salads)

This is my second time here and it was an extraordinary experience the first time and it was even better the second time around. The food is simply the BEST! Every dish --there were 5 of us and we each had something different. All were delicious and beyond excellent! The lasagna is a show stopper as are all the fresh pastas! The neighborhood is wonderful! The DJ spun dope tunes all night! This place is not to be missed! Go there! You will be happy you did!

Came here for a late dinner on Sunday night. The reason that's relevant is that lasagna is the Sunday special, but because we came late they ran out so we didn't get to try . Instead I went with the burrata to start and the oxtail tortellini.

Burrata was one of the better ones I've tried around the city. Cherry tomatoes were fresh, well seasoned, and had so much flavor.

Oxtail tortellini was flavorful but a bit one dimensional so don't think I would get again.

This place has a very laid back neighborhood vibe which was ultimately my favorite aspect about it. Would definitely come back for the reasonably priced wine and an appetizer.

I really wanted to like Il Postó Accanto more than I did. I made a reservation for 4 on a Saturday night. We were seated immediately.

What I ordered: my partner got the FETTUCCINE FATTE IN CASA CON POMODORINI E SHITAKE. It was good, but there was nothing special about it. I ordered the VERDURE ALLA GRIGLIA (pictured). The sauce was delicious and the veggies were cooked very well.

Overall the pasta was just okay and the portion was just okay as well. We saw our server maybe twice. I would be down to give them another shot, but my first experience here was average.

Great patio to people watch. Pasta may have been the best I've ever had. I'm still thinking about it! Service was friendly but spotty towards the end as they got busy, but not reason enough to not recommend or return.
My neighborhood Italian go to spot, especially for Sunday lasagna. I love it here, it's your typical hole in a wall Italian spot with traditional Italian dishes, a killer wine menu and great service

Loved this spot! Some of the best Italian food I've had in the city! I called the day before to make a reservation and I'm thankful I did because on a Sunday at 7pm, the place was packed. They have outdoor and indoor seating; we opted for outdoors. We started with the zucchini flowers which were so good! We got two entrees and shared (see pics because I forget the names). Both were a good portion for one person. And for dessert we did the tiramisu. I was a little disappointed that it wasn't traditional tiramisu; it came out in a glass instead of on a plate but the taste was still delicious. Service was good and the manager came around to make sure we were happy. I'd highly recommend coming here for great Italian food!

This was so delicious! The summer salad was beautiful, the lasagna is so savory and decadent with super flavorful tomato sauce, and the pan fried chicken was moist and crispy. Yummy!! Also great attentive service today (7/23/23) will be back
Awful customer service.  I do not recommend this place at all.  They were super rude.

COVID Report: Il Piccolo Acanto has both indoor and outdoor seating.

My boyfriend and I had a great dinner here in early November. Definitely make a reservation, as they're super popular these days. We tried:

+ Fab fall market salad (special)
+ Cavatelli di ricotta fatti in casa
+ Tortelloni di coda
+ Fritto misto All'Italiana
+ Lemon tart

My favorite dishes were the fritto misto and lemon tart, though everything was great. Definitely recommended!

Food, service and ambience  5/5
The food was delicious I'll be back for sure!!
We had lasagna, fried sea food and the the desert was the cherry on top!

Il Posto Accanto is a neighborhood gem! Can't say enough about the food, wine, team, regulars. It's a special place and is one of the best spots to come for dinner alone and not feel alone. The menu has some constant hits but adjusts with the seasonality of fresh ingredients from the Union Square Market, Arthur Avenue and beyond. Care and love find their way into everything at Il Posto Accanto. Enjoy!

Had lunch here this past Sunday and really enjoyed it.

Service is friendly and food comes our pretty quickly.

Ambiance is nice and rustic and the place is really busy so next time we'll make a reservation. Outside seating was completely full so we sat inside.

Food is quite good...we had pasta, salmon, and a grilled vegetables as a side. It was all delicious but I had to send my salmon back to be cooked more as it came out pretty raw (I'd asked for it to be well done).

Prices are pretty reasonable but note that quantities aren't very large.

We'll definitely return!

NYC is an awful place because you can grow up around the East Village, but only as a South Brooklyn adult do you come upon a gem like Il Posto (BECAUSE YOU SAW IT ON THE INTERNET-- on instagram). I was amazed that someone (Bea) treks to 14th street, selects the freshest picks, and   was able to make me howl with laughter while calling me a petunia (just watch the reels). Anyway, I planned for months to come here and actually try one of their delicacies. One night, after waking for miles around Manhattan, I was able to round up my grand total two friends to walk with me all the way to East 2nd from south st sea port. The dishes were phenomenal, the wine list great, and the people were real New York.

This place met all of our needs. We originally selected this particular restaurant because it stayed open later than other places. When we got there we were delighted by the ambiance and quick service. The food is so good you can hardly stand to put your fork down. Perfect portion sizes and authentic taste that keep your mouth watering for more more more! We will be back soon!

Petuuuuuuuniiiiiassssss! This is the best Italian spot in New York City - there, I said it! An absolute gem with unbelievably down to earth staff, soft/homemade pasta, and a welcoming and family atmosphere. The front of the house is expertly managed by Julio, while Bea runs the kitchen with ease. You may also get some expert wine suggestions from Vinny the sommelier.

This little hidden gem in the east village has consistently fresh/local ingredients and a seasonally rotating menu straight from the farmer's market to your plate. I usually order off of the specials menu, but consistent delectables include anything with fresh burrata, their fettuccine with mushrooms, the basic "tomato sauce" aka scialatiella or the classic (but not so classic) meatballs. Their main dishes are slightly smaller plates, made to share in my opinion, so be sure to order a few for the table. If you end up with enough room, their wheat olive oil cake is fantastic too. Wherever you live, make the trek here - it is worth it.
Sublime. Locally sourced, devinely produced Italian. I mean old school, rustic Italian, with combinations of ingredients and pastas that ring all the bells. Drop whatever you had planed and GO!

It's easy to walk past this neighborhood joint but do yourself a favor, don't. The food is really quite good. I absolutely love the anchovies and the fondue. These are probably two of my favorite dishes here.

The polenta and mushroom is also a great choice. The pastas change pretty often but I had the cavatelli tonight and thoroughly enjoyed it.

My only two comments is that they make you wait for your entire party before they seat you which is a bit annoying. And their heating lamp kept sitting off for some reason.

Other than that we'll be back.

Uninspiring food and rude owner. Pastas aren't a matter of mixing pasta and some vegetables. A good sauce makes all the difference. As does the absence of one. And, not sure why the owner decided to watch us use a condiment and then later come and admonish us for ruining his dish.

Unpleasant experience, overall.

something has changed poorly in quality and attitude. No longer a friendly local place to relax, dine, chill.
foods once great for the high price tag, now mediocre with attitude.

breaks my heart

Best Italian restaurant in NYC; all produce  is organic and the food is prepared with love! Try their carbonara, amatriciana, lasagna (but only on Sunday!), any special of the day with seasonal vegetable! Excellent wine selection and great cocktails too: Negroni or Sbagliato are a must!

Another great visit. This time, we got the burrata/prosciutto, grilled calamari, fried eggplant balls, meatballs, paccheri with sausage ragu and ricotta, cavatelli, and their porchetta special. The repeats were all excellent (I had forgotten how great the meatballs are), and we loved the paccheri as well. I loved the porchetta, but it wasn't really my wife's thing as much.

Will get back to you ... have to go back to Il Posto Accanto four or five times more. Maybe an even ten more visits before choosing my words carefully. So the only word that comes to mind now concerning Il Posto Accanto is ... Mangia!

Truly one of the best Italian meals I've had in NYC. Looking forward to bringing my friends to this GEM!

Il Posto had been on my Restaurant List for a little while and I finally got the opportunity to test it out on a Sunday night around 9:30pm.

SPACE: Lovely indoor/outdoor space on a quiet street. I sat inside close to the street

FOOD: Every dish I ordered was truly spectacular. I started with their calamari ("Calamari alla Griglia") - possibly some of the best calamari I've ever had. It was absolute perfection. The "Buffalo Mozzarella Caprese" was excellent. For pasta, I ordered the "Fettuconi con Pomodorini e Shitake" and it was fabulous! I had been craving pasta just like that for a long time! I could have eaten an entire pot!  I also ordered the "meatballs" which were fantastic! The sauce was to die for. Finally, I agreed to get dessert even though I was ridiculously full. I am so happy I did! I was served one of the best Panna Cottas I've ever had! So light!

SERVICE: Everyone was very nice! I believe the manager or owner made sure I was enjoying my meal. My server was patient and gave me wonderful recommendations.

FINALE: I cannot wait to go back and bring friends! What a wonderful Italian restaurant - culinary magic. DELICIOSO!

This was a quaint restaurant in alphabet city/east village. It is on the same block as Supper, which is another Italian restaurant that I have not tried yet.

The interior was nice and dimly lit. I thought it was interesting that they had paper lamps like Chinese lanterns on the ceiling. It was definitely unique.

We were given complimentary basket of bread which contained all sorts of bread and breadsticks! It came with olive oil I believe... Hard to keep track as it was one of three Italian restaurants I went to this week alone....

We shared the meatballs and the eggplant croquettes. They were both phenomenal! I opted to get the mushroom fettuccine with the different mushrooms. It was very unique and definitely very fresh. It felt like a very healthy pasta option, which caused an internal dilemma as I've always craved creamier, much less healthy pasta dishes.

We skipped dessert. I also really liked how welcoming the owner was! He was there greeting all the customers and making recommendations.

It's always a delight when a familiar restaurant surpasses expectations and delivers an exceptional meal. Grilled calamari, buttery salmon, and well balanced salad dressing, perfect combination, thank you

The owner of the restaurant yelled at us until all three of us girls were reduced to tears. Because my friend asked for Parmesan on a dish that traditionally shouldn't have Parmesan.
