He told us to get the f*ck out because he doesn't want us as customers - over Parmesan. Other diners and even the staff were shocked and apologetic. I wish I could give zero stars.
Incredible find in the East Village!  Impeccable food, authentic Italian made with fresh ingredients and lots of love.

UPDATE: GET THE PANNA COTTA !!!!!!!!!
This time we got dessert, and I really cannot stress enough how VITAL it is that you order the panna cotta.

Very disappointing experience. Food is OK. But the owner/manager has THE WORST attitude. Overall the experience was bad - it's obvious the staff is pushed to move people quickly. I have never been so rushed to order, eat and have my plates removed. Miserable vibe and won't go again.

Used to come here every other weekend for brunch 10+ years ago....  Finally revisited again and IT IS ***STILL*** EVERY BIT AS GOOD AS I REMEMBERED IT TO BE and then some.  This is a really special restaurant,  the food is ALWAYS GREAT and the owners are wonderful people.  

Make sure to order something from the specials menu with your meal for a taste of the best stuff the season has to offer, along with the mainstays that you will find yourself coming back, over and over again for.

Honest, unpretentious, Italian cuisine at its best.

I gave "chef's choice" to allow the chef to pick for me!  Best
Choice EVER!  Small, quaint, personal bistro with amazing food.  So glad a local recommended it.
Have been coming here since 2006 and it has always been AMAZING !!! The food the service the ambiance the everything is amazing.   I highly recommend il Posto Accanto and all of its dishes.

What a hole in the wall! Great atomsphere, great staff, amazing food. Everything we had was great.. not to mention the bread that they give you to start. I would recommend this east village Italian spot to anyone I know!

Damned--I liked this restaurant as Il Bagato, but this was exquisite food at reasonable prices.  Amazing squash flours stuffed with cheese and anchovies--fried to perfection, not greasy at all--so flavorful.  Fresh greens--clean and very fresh and the pasta, a sausage mushroom in a cream sauce which sounds ho-hum but absolutely rich, creamy, delight.    Thank you for an amazing meal to bring out of town guests to.

Nothing less than Superb!
My wife & I came Sunday for the first time for lunch, and everything we had was truly Delicious!
Unfortunately, we didn't have enough time for dessert. That only ensures, that we will be back sooner than later.
Thanks for a great meal
a great girlfriend of mine gigi. we used to eat at il bagatto just next door. ( the same owners) the food is to die for

Came here due to the amazing reviews I saw on Yelp. My husband and I came early on a Friday evening, and wete seated immediately at the bar. The restaurant had several diners inside, and was about half full.
The service was appropriately efficient, not outstanding.
We ordered quickly, and the food came out not too long after ordering. The food was not bad, but was not amazing.

wow, what a perfect meal! went with my sister and mom on a Friday night, was crowded but well worth the wait! the staff was friendly and attentive. we ordered the market salad, the fettuccini with shiitake mushrooms, the oxtail tortellini, and the john dory fish with lentils - every dish was delicious! highly recommend if you're looking for a truly yummy meal and cozy vibes

atrocious. my birthday was ruined. the only redeeming quality was the focaccia bread but they didn't even refill the oil so i choked on it. 1 tbs of olive oil is enough to feed a small cat. not 6 human beings. food was not that good. no flavor in my fettuccine NO SALT NO SALT NO SALT. my breaking point was when the waiter kept running away from us like he was being chased. couldn't even get a word out but we did. my friend asked for a birthday candle for my apple tart. the waiter didn't bring it and i cried. and then we asked a second server and they still didn't bring it. a candle is the least they could've done. i'm ruined and feel no joy joy joy. wish me a happy birthday if you care.

This is a lovely neighborhood spot. We stopped in right before closing, and the staff treated us so well. It's a wonderland inside and of course great wine and dessert...It was pointed out to me that I did eat the lion-share of what we intended to split.
I wish I lived down here so I could make it my Cheers! spot. Say hi to Lana for me. She's a gem!
The WORST experience eating out, in absolute shock. The owner is a rude jerk, insults and yells and his customers. Do not go here, food is mediocre.

Food is amazing, music is good. Perfect place for the  late night omakese!! Very authentic and beautiful presentations. Service is amazing, Roka the manger was so nice and we are going to visit them again!!! OMG

Nothing fancy, just amazingly flavorful food. This simple East Village spot delivers excellent Japanese izakaya dishes. The service is friendly and good. The wine, beer and sake selections are basic. All and all it worthwhile going out of your way to eat there.

BAD BAD BUSINESS!!!
We were supposed to go to Sushi Izakaya on June 7th, the day that there was a health hazard due to the wildfires coming from Canada.
The wording from all media outlets as well as the governor of NY said that people should not go out of their homes.
So we proceeded to call Izakaya to cancel our reservation.
They proceeded to charge us a cancellation fee of $150 per person.
We tried to explain the situation and say that we felt this was very unfair.
To make a long story short, they charged us the fee and Amex had to pick up the cost..
My thoughts, short sighted and very bad business.
We will not be going to Izakaya, there are many options of sushi restaurants especially in NYC and we will go where people are empathetic to situations such as a health hazard.
Just some food for thought.

A cute small modern izakaya with just a few tables. I got lucky and got in quite quickly on a Friday night for a table for 2, but recommend reservation otherwise. Most of the things in the menu are small plates that go well with sake or beer.

Well prepared agedashi tofu, the mentaiko omelette is full of mentaiko fillings and the egg is fluffy and flavorful. The nanban chicken is extremely juicy with just the right amount of sauce. The vongole is made using ramen noodles, which I think have a slightly strange alkali-ish flavor.

Overall most of the dishes are really delicious and the atmosphere is very cozy and comfy. Relatively pricey (with the food mentioned and a carafe of sake it was around $60 each) but a nice place to treat yourself a chill Japanese evening.

My friend and I had a reservation at 6:15 on a Wednesday night, and we were very glad to have made a reservation beforehand. While it was a weekday dinner, the restaurant was full and walking-in customers unfortunately were told to come back at a future time.
We each got a cocktail. I got Yuzu-tini, which tasted exactly how I imagined it to be and finished in a blink of an eye.

For food, we got More Addictive Cabbage, Yellowtail Sashimi, and Sake Clams Vongole "Ramen" Spaghetti to start, and later added Seaweed Tempura. My personal favorite is More Addictive Cabbage. It was so so so good! I would order again for sure. I feel Yellowtail Sashimi was overpriced, and Sake Clams Vongole "Ramen" Spaghetti was good but would want to try the other one in the future. Seaweed tempura was also good. I liked their small tapas more than the main ones. Overall experience was great, but even considering the neighborhood average, it is a bit on the expensive end.

I love izakayas and this one did not disappoint!

Was walking by looking for something to fulfill our drunchie needs when we came across the neon sign. We didn't come with any expectations, but we ended up really enjoying our meal. I really liked the mentaiko dishes in particular.

A small hole in the wall izakaya in the east village. Wide selection of japanese home cooked food, which is pretty unique to find in nyc. Lots of selections from tapas to sashimi to rice/noodles. We started off with the addictive cabbage and fried eggplant for tapas, got the yellowtail for sashimi, the singature nanban for our entree, and the mentai cream ramen spaghetti to finish. The addictive cabbage was truly addictive, and quite possible the dish I was most surprised by! The eggplant was a bit too sweet, but otherwise o-kay. The yellowtail was good but not mindblowing, and really thick-cut and filling. The nanban came with a creamy sauce that we really liked. The mentai cream ramen was also good, but a lot bigger than we expected. Overall good service and great atmosphere.
Wow!! One of the best sandwiches I have ever had, very tender; juicy, and flavorful. Highly recommended

Came here on a whim but actually had it bookmarked in Yelp for quite some time. This hole in the wall spot is easily missed and shares the same street address as a neighboring restaurant. That said, once you find it, our waitress/hostess was super friendly and engaging.

The mapo tofu was definitely one of the better ones I've had. Which says a lot considering I've had a lot of mapo tofu in my life. Both the cucumber and cabbage was exactly what I expected, flavorful and refreshing. The fried rice complemented the mapo tofu. The fried chicken was cooked to perfection. Crunchy on the outside, juicy and tender in the inside. And the agedashi tofu was exactly the soul warming dish that you would want on a snowy wintery night.

I wanted a dry but fruit forward sake and that was exactly what was served to me. Everything about this place was great, even the price at the end of the night. I'll definitely be back.

Really solid japanese tapas spot with delicious small plates and a cool intimate vibe. Loved the agedashi tofu, chicken nanban, salmon sashimi, and addictive cabbage! Will definitely be back since there was more on the menu I would try.

The Izakaya NYC was a disappointing experience overall. We sought some clarification on the portion sizes of appetizers and tapas, but they just recommended that we order 9 dishes to be "full" for a table of 2.

This seemed a little bit too much food, so we ordered 4 dishes: the more addictive cabbage, signature chicken nanban, beef sukiyaki, mushroom garlic butter fried rice along with a sake flight (pre-fixed, we don't have a choice) and a beer. This was more than enough food for 2.

The food was okay with most dishes being average and some being very bad. The Beef Sukiyaki was the most disappointing as it was wayyyyyy too sweet, had 3 pieces of cabbage, and the meat they used was mostly fat. Chicken Nanban was okay but it was oily and not crispy. The Mushroom garlic butter fried rice was the best dish. The addictive cabbage was good, but definitely not worth the price tag.

The most frustrating thing about our dining experience was the service. We arrived here at 7PM and received our last dish around 8:20PM. There were very long gaps between each dish when we were the only table in the store. The server was not knowledgeable about the menu and had to inquire with the manager each time we had a question. We were not checked on once for the near 2 hours we were there. We had to flag them down each time we needed anything.

We left unimpressed and with no reason to be back!

I got here knowing I had to wait and they were so busy on Sunday night about 45 to 1 hour wait. The host was friendly and extremely welcoming :) the staff in general was super friendly and I bet they were busting their butts working. And they're on resy..

As we're still in a pandemic, dining out has been such a different experience, tables are separated with barriers and the menu is via scanning a QR code.

I can't say the food was 5/5 that day, but if I'm scoring it based on past experiences too it's for sure a 5/5. They have so much on their menu and constantly adding and taking things off their menu. I thought I would try some new things; the scallops had a sweet dressing on top that completely took away from the natural sweetness of the scallops. If you want to try the goma ae - just know the sesame dressing is strong! I would ask for a little less dressing. The grilled tako - delicious. Their sushi and rolls are good but nothing special. I think they're most known for their kimchi udon, for a cream based udon it's not heavy at all. Kimchi flavor isn't as pronounced but we enjoyed this dish the most! This does come with shrimp! Super bouncy udon.

For my light drinkers out there.... their cocktails are great. Super tasty and you won't taste the alcohol. This could be a bad thing for some people. They also have Kirin frozen beer, it's just so pretty.

I've definitely enjoyed my other experiences more in terms of things I ordered (omu soba, garlic rice, croquettes, chicken nanban, beef tongue, kalbi, salmon tacos), but I was exploring new dishes on the menu this time around and will continue to try.

Please go as a party of 3 or 4, these small dishes are definitely meant to share and it'll be great to have more bodies to feed so you can try even more dishes.
The food was amazing and the staff was very attentive and kind. Went earlier around 6 and we got the restaurant to ourselves, its a really nice atmosphere that's relaxing and inviting.

I came here for quick drinks, and some appetizers but holy shitalki everything was delicious. We got seated right away, and offered sweet potato snack. It was yummy, and we couldn't stop eating. The sushi rolls were fantastic, drink was just right amount of alcohol, and ambience was very cute. I gotta come back for a full dinner.

This is an excellent tapas place. If you're looking for small plates, come here vs Boqueria (yes, different cuisines but this one is much more flavorful). My favs/would order again: cucumber, cabbage, sake steamed clams, cream ramen, signature chicken, omelette. Would not order again: salmon and mushroom with miso in foil, eggplant, garlic butter fried rice, the regular fried chicken. Love the small portion size - can try lots of different dishes. Inside is ok, a bit small. Would recommend.

My friend and I came for a quick dinner. We only got two things to share because we already had some food beforehand. We got one appetizer (the clam) and one entree (mentaiko noodles). Both were soooooo good. The clam was better than I thought and the mentaiko noodles were very interesting. At first I wasn't sure if I liked it but I kept going back for more. Definitely will come back and order more things next time for a full dinner

Recently got back into outdoor dining and The Izakaya did not disappoint. There is ample seating outside as they have a tent area goes into the street. Still a bit less than compared to other neighborhoods, but it's East Village so that's expected.

We started off with the Relax Sake as I was looking for a Junmai Gingo type Sake. As for food, my boyfriend and I got the addictive cabbage, chicken nanban, agedashi tofu, fried smelt, and clam vongole ramen spaghetti. The addictive cabbage and chicken nanban were the absolute favorites. The cabbage had a spicier kick than anticipated, but that's what made it so good. The chicken nanban was so juicy and had an amazing sauce that paired with it! Clam vongole ramen spaghetti was a very interesting dish. Was good and happy we tried it, but wouldn't go out of my way to get again. Overall, the food hit the spot for all our izakaya cravings!

This is a super small/tiny/cozy restaurant, with maybe 5 or so tables inside? But they also have an outdoor area. I'd recommend making reservations just in case.

It looks like they have some rotating items on their menu, with a few popular ones that have stayed consistent.
We ended up ordering  a little too much for the two of us, so we left very stuffed and could've done without one dish

- addictive cabbage: a must try!! fresh and crunchy with an amazing savory sauce. I think sesame oil based? but also had a bit of a tang to it.. maybe wasabi?
- yakiniku: super flavorful. meat isnt that tender, but the pieces are small enough that you can eat one piece whole
- mushroom fried rice: bombbb! you can definitely taste the butter and garlic. it seems like a simple dish, but delicious flavors
- grilled mackerel: I'm always a fan of a mackerel, and there wasn't anything special about it but you can't go wrong with a simple grilled mack
- chicken nanban: this is one of their most popular dishes, but I think one of my least fave of the night. the tartar sauce threw me off, but that's their special take on it. the fried chicken is REALLY juicy. but it's not really like karaage chicken, which is what I was expecting. good to try but it comes with 4 really big pieces and it was too much for the two of us.

Overall, a great place to try! I'd recommend if you can snag a table.

Been coming here for a few years and as the restaurant got busier things have changed. The food isn't quite as good as I remember it being even the staples like the sake clams and mushroom garlic fried rice.

The real killer for this experience was how fast the meal went by we were quickly rushed out the door in 35 minutes after ordering 6 dishes. Props to the kitchen for being hyper efficient, but definitely pace your meal yourself as the kitchen won't. The overattentive servers will also snag your plate away the second they see or think it's empty. I was left holding half a piece of fried smelt as one of the over eager servers pulled my plate away as I was trying to dip it into spicy mayo.
Great food, great for casual date or a quick late night bite. Highly recommend the sake clam, nanban chicken, and fried smelt.

A friend of mine and I stopped for a drink here on our NYC food tour. I loved the food and the people that worked here were mostly Japanese which was awesome! Our waitress was very knowledgeable about Sake and you can tell she was on top of everything. The Shishito's were very lightly seasoned and the fried smelt was perfectly fried.

My friend and I were food hopping around NYC and we stopped by Izakaya. We ordered two small dishes and they were quite tasty. The Shishito Peppers had a good fry and lightly seasoned with salt. The Smelt Fish had good amount of roe inside and a nice crispness. Izakaya also has Orion beer (Okinawa) on draft. Izakaya is Japanese owned, so they know what they're doing. I'd come back again for their dinner course set.

We thought it would be too trendy and overrated, but we were pleasantly surprised! Izakaya's food was quite good and it didn't break the bank--would recommend for a quick weekday lunch with friends. Ordered 3" tapas" and 3 "appetizers" for two people and it was perfect.

The addictive cabbage was indeed addictive. Great to start out the meal. Something about the seasoning just made the cabbage really transcend its humble origins. It was sweet and salty and slightly sour and a bit spicy.

The agedashi tofu was alright. Definitely have had better elsewhere--it was just a little too soggy (wished the batter was a bit lighter). The eggplant was good but fairly standard. It was grilled well and the sauce and toppings went well, but not super memorable.

We were huge fans of the mentaiko omelette. Surprisingly so delicious. It was very light but flavorful. The omelette was soft and curd-y on the inside, a perfect french omelette. The filling was awesome--we weren't totally sure what it was (it involved roe and dashi), but it was deliciously umami, fishy and sweet all at the same time and paired so well with the egg.

The chicken nanban was also pretty good. The chicken was perfectly tender, since they left it in large pieces. It wasn't as crispy anymore, sadly, because of the tartar sauce, but the tartar sauce was tasty and did seem to be homemade.

The grilled mackerel was not our favorite. It was a bit overcooked (not as tender anymore) and had a really fishy flavor that made it taste not fresh.

Fantastic Japanese restaurant. This was my last restaurant outing with friends pre-Covid. Crazy to think how much time it's been. The dishes are thoroughly well prepared and everything was excellent. Washed down with good quality sake and it's a fantastic meal!

This is a long overdue review. We discovered this place 3 years ago and haven't been back until yesterday. They changed the whole staffs and they are very accommodating. The thing we learned from this Izakaya is GET THE CABBAGE! Yes it is addictive and yes you will want to order more than one!! The point of this tiny tiny hole in a wall restaurant is to drink. They offer a variety of sakes and beers. Their food is supposed to be tapas like and small dishes. It's more like they serve snacks to go with your huge bottle of sakes. This place is definitely a fun place to visit.

We ordered the cabbage, agedashi tofu, croquettes, and fried chicken nanban to start. The cabbage is marinated in salt, sesame oil, seaweed, and sesame seeds. It was just so delicious that you're willing to pay 6 dollars for some pieces of cabbage! The croquettes are made of potatoes and corn served with spicy mayo. The agedashi tofu was perfectly made. The chicken omg the chicken!!! It's probably one of the best fried chicken very juicy and delicious!

For the main course we had the clams ramen, the curry and the sukiyaki. The curry used to be way better with rice served separately but now they put the curry on top of rice in a clay pot and added cheese to it. We didn't like it as much. The clams ramen is amazing. It reminded me of spaghetti vongole but with a twist of saffron and chili peppers in it. It was delicious! The sukiyaki was also amazing. We really enjoyed the food here!!

My friend made a reservation at Izakaya for dinner. As a disclaimer, she mentioned that Izakaya is slightly hidden and hard to find. It was true, I walked past it and had to circle back around. The restaurant is quite small with limited seating. Everyone who walked in had a reservation.

Since it was my first time, my friend ordered food for us to share. We got the original addictive cabbage, agedashi tofu, chicken nanban, and beef sukiyaki.

Appetizers were both small portioned, flavorful, and somewhat healthy. I thoroughly enjoyed them. Chicken nanban was absolutely delicious! I usually don't like mayo-based tartar sauce, but wow, it went so well with the crispy and juicy fried chicken. Sukiyaki, I didn't like as much. The beef was overcooked and hard to chew, while the concentrated soy sauce simmered and made everything extra salty. Don't get me wrong, the sukiyaki was still good, but not something I would order again.

Overall, I was glad I got to share multiple small plates with my friend. Everything we ordered was solid in terms of taste and reasonably priced (no tips needed either).

My only complaint would be the fact that my friend and I literally could not hear one another due to the loudness in the restaurant. Not a place for first date or catchup session.

Came here on a prior trip to the city, before the recent unpleasantness.

The thick cut salmon is some of the very best I've had. It was so fatty and was beautifully presented.

The steak was savory and delicious.

The fried chicken was the standout of the evening, tender and moist on the inside, crispy outside.

We were taken unawares by the eggplant and tofu dish: the peppers are hot. Steel yourself, before you try this one.

The service was excellent.

Worse place for a first date! But good for friends, coworker, & casual hangouts.

Cons:
The restaurant is cramped and super loud.

Pros:
The food were so delicious and prices are fair.

We ordered:
More Addictive Cabbage $7 - Just a little spicy. It's crunchy. Dont worry, it's not that addictive.
Agedashi Tofu $9 - Four big pieces of soft tofu. The skin is a little bit fried. Soaked in dashi sauce/soup and covered with my favorite Katsuobushi (bonito flakes).
Chicken Nanban $12 - Four pieces of tender and very juicy fried chicken
Sake Steamed Clams $16 - Steamed clam cooked with sake. The sauce actually tastes very alcoholy.
Sashimi Trio $38 - 4 pcs salmon, 4 pcs fluke, 4 pieces of scallop. They offer soy sauce and yuzu with the fish.
Ume Soda Cocktail $10 - It's plum cocktail. It's sweet and tastes just like Japanese sodas.

I'm planning to revisit soon and better the experience.

aww man. I LOVEEEE this place. it's actually very hard to find at first, you really have to open ur eyes wide and look for this place. their sign outside is barely noticeable.
limited seating so definitely had to make reservation ahead of time. everything here is just small plates so order away. the whole menu is yummy, so u can't go wrong with whatever u order.

a little surprise at the end after u get the check, if u don't want me to ruined it, then u should stop reading now.
-
--
---
still reading? ok. they don't want you to tip. in japan, no tipping is required so this place like to carry on the tradition. just give them a big smile before you leave =) the service is AMAZINGGGG.

Cozy, friendly, and delicious.  "Addictive Cabbage" is no joke, and the salmon tartare with guacamole is exquisitely subtle.  The salmon sashimi is also pretty amazing: you really got to know every seam of muscle and fat in that poor, doomed, splendid-tasting fish.  The portions are on the small side, but that's a consequence of wanting more of everything.
Excellent all round. Charming, delicious food (get the salmon mushroom miso and yellowtail sashimi) and great drinks. Will come again soon.

*takes reservations*
*no tipping restaurant*

Small hole in the walls rarely ever disappoint, and Izakaya is just another great example of that.

Chicken Nanban - very juicy
Addictive Cabbage - indeed addictive, and refreshing
Addictive Cucumber - refreshing and yummy
Thick Salmon Sashimi - good sized pieces and fresh
Yakitori skewer - yummy
Izakaya Pudding - kind of like flan
Matcha Brulee - personally I wish this was a bit more bitter

Solid place. Somehow, I've never thought to come here because of the plethora of places available in EV. My friends and I had put our names down at another restaurants that had a 2.5 hour wait. We called Izakaya and while they had initially told us there was a wait, they called us back about 10-15 minutes later to tell us that they had a table for us.

Ambiance: cozy, small interior. Would not recommend this for big groups.

Food: chicken nanban was delicious. Piping hot, juicy, and came with a good sauce. Would definitely order this again.

Mentaiko spaghetti: I'm always a fan of mentaiko noodle dishes. They sprinkled a generous serving of Parmesan cheese on top. Had we not planned to hop to another restaurant after this, we could have easily done another plate of this.

Salmon sashimi: it was alright. Not the worst that I've ever had, but it's not a sushi restaurant and definitely wasn't the freshest cut of salmon sashimi. I could pass on this next time, but wouldn't be opposed to getting it if someone else wanted it.

Service was good; they were quick and friendly, and filled our water glasses consistently.

I don't think I would come all the way to EV from the west side just to eat here, but it's a good option.

Very interesting name, simply Izakaya. Make sure you book at least a day ahead for a weekend night. The place a good variety of a-la-carte and appetizer with reasonable pricing.

For the two of us, we had the grilled mackerel, beef tongue, mushroom fried rice, cabbage appetizer, and sake steamed clams. The two obvious goods were mushroom fried rice and beef tongue. The fried rice was very flavorful with butter and cheese, highly recommend it. The beef tongue was thick and tender, well grilled.  Tasted a little like pork, also highly recommended it.

Steamed clam was good but on the salty end. Went really well with the garlic and butter flavor, but don't drink the very salty soup. On the other hand, addictive cabbage was not very addictive. The appetizer was on the salty side with way too much sesame oil, I wouldn't recommend it. Wouldn't recommend the mackerel, would rather get something else like the fried scallops instead,

The yuzu beer is a signature at the place, but it tasted very flat, not a lot of flavours (but try it if you haven't.)

Our waitresses were three nice Japanese ladies, treated us well. Suggested tips included tax in the calculation, something I opposed a long time.

ambience 3.5/5
service 3.5/5
food 4/5
value 4/5

Tiny place, but authentic Japanese food.
Staff is friendly and helpful with the menu however everything is a bit on the pricier side in correlation with the amount of food you'll be getting with each dish. Super nice ambience though; good to come for the experience. Also no tipping is needed at this restaurant!

This was a tiny, but nice and warm restaurant in NYC.  When I walked in we were seated with reservation.  I came here with my girlfriend and some friends to try out some Japanese cuisine.  I was told the dishes were best to be shared in a group, so my girlfriend and I shared three dishes together, but in my opinion the dishes are very small portion so it was gone in about 30 minutes.

Food: We ordered Mushroom Garlic Butter Fried Rice for $13.5, Sukiyaki for $17, and the Izakaya's signature Chicken Nanban for $15.  

The Garlic Butter Fried Rice: The flavor was very strong and delicious, but it only takes me a few spoonful to end up finishing the whole thing.

Sukiyaki: This was probably the best to get for sharing, but it won't last long because of the small porition.

Chicken Nanban: There are only 4 pieces, it tasted very fresh and its definitely the best  nanban I had in a while.

Service: The only thing that I did not like was how they messed up our bill, but they fixed it immediately.  The space is very cramp in my opinion, but very cozy. I love the no tipping policy also.

Overall: I will come back and give it another try in the summer!

Overall okay here. Small cozy place. No tipping policy.

I had high expectation for the "addicted cabbage", we thought it was just okay, just cabbage with sesame oil and sesame..

Sukiyaki was out for the night :( much needed for a winter night.

Japanese fries was disappointing, 8 slice of potato with a butter cube on top.....

Miso beef tongue was pretty good.

Mentaiko omelette was way tiny than expected, and it could be made better in a Japanese restaurant...

Nanban chicken was a bit heavy on the sauce side.

Oolong something drink was too sweet.
Yuzutini was good.

I came here earlier this year in January with my boyfriend, who had been here before, and left happy and full! This is a small spot but service was quick and the food was excellent. We ordered the chicken nanban, agedashi tofu, addictive cabbage, and salmon truffle flavor with egg. Everything was on point. I had high expectations for this place and it definitely exceeded them. Will definitely come back again!

I visited Izakaya on a Friday night with my boyfriend. We made reservations ahead of time because this place is super busy, especially on weekends.

We started off our meal with the Addictive cabbage, the addictive cucumbers, and the corn fritters. We LOVED the cabbage and cucumbers. They are a must try. The corn fritters were a bit of a miss for us, but the rest of the meal made up for their mediocrity.  

My boyfriend really enjoyed his salmon onigiri and salmon sashimi. The absolute star of the show, however, was the chicken and cheese curry dish we shared. It was honestly one of the best things I've ever eaten. I finished the meal with the chicken nanban which was super yummy too. I highly recommend it. For drinks throughout the evening, I had the lemon fizz (soju, lemon, and seltzer) and the boyf had their ube plum wine cocktail. We both loved our drinks.

This is some of the best Japanese in all of NYC! Five stars are well deserved.

It's so hard to find good Japanese food in the US. Mediocre sushi and ramen are usually the best you can get, everything else is either completely unavailable or if immensely low quality.

Luckily for anyone in New York City, Izakaya offers a menu with plenty of Japanese dishes such as nanban chicken or Tonkatsu that are hard to find well made in the US. They do these dishes justice, barely deviating from the Japanese origins of their menu even as they offer tapas style appetizers. Their sake list is expansive, and their mixed drinks are a steal for the location.

As a side note, we had ordered their sashimi trio, and while the fish served was definitely Edomae-style (yellowtail was fatty and melted in your mouth), the quality control was low. The scallops tasted as if they had not been freshly shucked and all the fish were served warmer than I'd expect. Also, one of the pieces of yellowtail was served with some amount of skin/connective tissue still attached that could not be bitten through. I will not order the sashimi here again.

Love the minimalist decor. Cute little hallway of a restaurant where they serve small dishes to share. Got the sake flight, which I enjoyed tremendously. The chicken nanban was good, and the thick salmon sashimi was actually thick. The corn croquette like some other reviewer said, had very little corn, but it was fried to perfect little balls, so I did like it. The only disappointment was the garlic mushroom butter fried rice, which was just okay. I would come back to try all the other little dishes!

Really big fan of this place - it's a subtle, traditional style Japanese izakaya serving up higher quality izakaya food. Reservations are generally a must given how tiny the place is (probably sits sub 20 people). They used to be really hard to get when they were on Opentable, but since switching over to Yelp, it's been a bit easier.

I typically go for the addictive cabbage, chicken karaage, salmon, and mushroom rice. All in all - everything is cooked simply with dashi broth and seasoned with delicious yuzu flavors. Really tasty home cooking Japanese food. Am a fan!

Went for dinner on a Saturday night and really enjoyed it! 3 stars because when it's busy, service really lacks.

I really liked the small plates and small restaurant vibe! Run down of the dishes:

Original Addictive Cabbage ($6) : cabbage with sesame oil. You can pass. Wish I tried the hot version.
Fried Smelt ($8) : 5 fried fish with Japanese mayo and Japanese hot pepper! Really good!
Chicken Nanban ($12) : 4 pieces of extremely juicy chicken. Served with cabbage and a lot of mayo sauce
Grilled Mackerel ($12) : my favorite dish. Perfectly simple.

I would go back- maybe just not on a Saturday night...

How much confidence it requires to name an Izakaya category of restaurant "Izakaya"? (Izakaya means: informal Japanese gastropub). I visited izakaya with that question on a Saturday night and izakaya didn't disappoint. Food is solid, and the ambiance is nice and talk-easy.

We ordered sake in glasses since they ran out of the small bottles. There are many choices - dry, smooth, and sweet tastes; light, medium or thick texture etc. Food wise, I highly recommend the signature chicken nanban, fluke sashimi, addictive cabbage, stir-fried noodle with egg, and beef tongue. Everything is solid. My favorites are chicken nanban and beef tongue. The chicken meat is super juicy and tender. The tasty meat juice ooze out when you bite. Unlike other places, izakaya serve thick BBQ beef tongue that is a bit more chewy but still well seasoned.

Overall, izakaya food is on the lighter calorie end among bar food choices. Highly recommend this place! Plates are in small portion. Slightly pricy - 40pp for us (no tips in izakaya).

This is one of those places where the description "quaint hole in the wall" best fits. For a casual Japanese-hipster lunch inside, away from the weather with your little circle of friends in the village, it's a good something to try.

The tonkatsu-sando (Pork Cutlet Sandwich), while definitely unique, is one of only a handful of items offered within the very spartan menu here. Now, a sandwich is just a sandwich, but it's incredibly tender, easy to cut into, and the sauce that accompanies makes this unique dish something you won't soon forget. The wasabi sauce and the fried sweet potatoes are a great compliment, and the presentation is for sure, instagrammable for all of your friends to see.

The big challenges here are the fact that the hours are extremely limited; lunch hours only. I suspect all of the items on offer are based on quality, not quantity, and the lunch hours make the limitations an exercise in the quality of the dishes on offer here.

Sapporo Beer on draft, (no Asahi-boo) but I can't wait to be back for lunch again.

Small and cozy restaurant with a very Japanese feel to it. Our servers were great and friendly, always stopping by to fill our waters. For an izakaya, the dishes are reasonably priced. For two people, we ordered the toro (generous portion), curry rice, fried smelt, addictive cabbage, and grilled mackerel. The sake was a bit pricey in my opinion. Nice place, make a reservation!

Location: east village. Place is extremely tiny so be prepared with sharing space with others.  Because of the limited space, you have to reserve to secure your spot especially on a Friday night. The dining atmosphere is bad if you decide to come in the winter time. I was cold AF while seating there waiting for the food and the owner/waitresses seems to give 0 fuck about how customers felt. I mean, if you see lots of customers start to rewear their coat in your restaurant, you should know that something is wrong with your air conditioner?!

Food: addictive cabbage is too salty to keep eating. Agexxxtofu is okay but not the best from my Japanese dining history at NYC. Japanese styles fries is just a joke that I would rather buy McDonald'ss fries. And the best we had was the nanbang chicken. Well, to be honest with eveyone, still not the best fried chicken.

Service: horrible. We were there very early and probably was the first/second order. But they kept us waiting for our food while people who were behind us got their dishes.
You may argue: it's because we ordered the different dishes. But the truth is that's exactly the same dishes we order and somehow they decide to give out to others and kept us waiting.
I barely encountered things like this in NYC. This is bit unprofessional.

I had many good Japanese dining experience here in NYC. I never complained. I seldom gave 1 star for restaurant because I know this can impact lots of peoples lives.
But being cheap doesn't allow you to give bad service to customers.

This is for sure a 1 star experience
I
Incredible meal, we ate and drank and lost track of time. Loved it and can't wait to go back.

This place is small and intimate. Minimalist and clean looking. We ordered:

The More Addictive Cabbage- which is the spicy version of the original. It seems like just cabbage but there are layers of flavor including what seems to be sesame and a fishy spice. This was seriously addicting.

Agedashi Tofu- the tofu was silky with a stretchy fried coating which soaked up the tart broth nicely. I could have had two orders of this to myself.

Corn Croquette- it was what is expected of a corn croquette. It came with shredded cabbage and a spicy mayo-like dipping sauce. Solid dish.

Grilled Mackerel- this was a filet grilled nice and crispy with almost no bones. Very reasonably priced I think at $12.50.

Curry Doria- it came in a little ceramic pot and was topped with oodles of melted cheese. The rice at the bottom was a little crispy or al dente. Idk if that was intentional or not, but loved ending the meal with this dish.

They also do not take tip there. Is nice to order multiple dishes tapas-style. Everything was good or solid, and reasonably pr

This was a tiny izakaya and can seat about 24 people.  We came here on a Friday night and because the weather was so cold, we were able to score a table with no wait and no reservation.  

We started with the corn croquet.  This was perhaps the weakest dish of the night.  It was not a true corn croquet, but rather a potato croquet with some corn mixed in.  Next came the mushroom garlic butter rice.  This popular dish was fantastic.  The rice had a good texture, not too mushy, and fragrant with wok hei.  The garlic butter made it more decadent than typical fried rice.  Next was the salmon with soft egg and truffle oil.  We mixed the fish and egg with the aforementioned garlic butter rice and it was a delicious combination.  The salmon was cooked medium rare.  I hate how so many restaurants overcook their fish in the pursuit of crispy fish skin.  Izakaya was able to cook the fish perfectly.  The salmon skin was crisp, but the flesh was silky and rare.  We also sampled the yakitori set.  Don't let it freak you out, but chicken thigh was also slightly undercooked.  I am talking medium well, not cooked to oblivion to satisfy American's irrational fear of all chickens harbor salmonella.  Lastly, we had the chicken nanban, juicy fried chicken topped with a sweet mayo based sauce.  Personally, I would only order this dish for table of 4 or larger.  This dish for some reason was huge compare to the portion size of the other dishes as we received 4 pieces of substantially sized fried chicken thighs and couldn't finish all of it.  Overall, I love izakaya and wish I had stomach realestate to explore the menu.  Lastly, authentic to Japanese culture, there is a no tipping policy.

Large group on a Wednesday night in October (sat in the large back room).  Beautiful space with great food and wine (I didn't get to try any of the cocktails), conveniently located a couple blocks from Bryant Park.  It's connected to a hotel and Daintree Rooftop is in the same building.

It was a mild night so there were a lot of people sitting outside in front of the doors.  When you walk in you are in the bar area in front of the elevators, and the host stand is at the end of the bar.  I was not expecting such a large space once I turned the corner... and then was even more surprised to see the large, bright private back room.

Our group shared a few things including Crispy Halloumi, Kangaroo skewers, Blistered Brussels Sprouts, and Charred Octopus.  (A few people ordered other things that I didn't try.) We ended up ordering extra of the Halloumi and the Brussels because we enjoyed them so much. I love Halloumi and it really hit the spot.

I was craving white wine and decided on the orange wine that someone in our group highly recommended.  Delicious, not too sweet, not too orangey.  According to the menu the alcohol selection is local and sometimes changes.

A few tables in the main dining area were enjoying the new espresso martini flights and they looked amazing.  (I need to come back to try the espresso martinis, but decided against having something caffeinated so late on a weeknight.)

We went up the elevator to check out Daintree Rooftop after, but as it was a Wednesday night (sigh) we didn't stay for drinks.

Apparently there are happy hour specials, hopefully I am able to get here in time to try them.  Someone mentioned the restaurant participated in NYC Restaurant Week, I'd love to try more food items the next time!

Came for the espresso martini flight and also added the regular espresso martini which wasn't included in the flight. Enjoyed them especially the one with olive oil and the 43 ingredient

At first we were wondering why the service was so slow but once the drinks arrive, we understood why

The location itself was nice but didn't like that there is only 1 shared bathroom. The service was good but wish they would have checked in on us a little more or had some something to get a server to come by

Aussie chicken parm - not the highest quality but not soggy. Not really flavorful

Spicy rigatoni - the prawns have good texture and wasn't over cooked. The rigatoni was a bit over cooked with a kick of spicy.

Hallumi fries - tangy sauce with pesto on the bottom. Was a little salty for my preference.

Fries with truffle - was like a cafeteria French fries with truffle mayo sauce? Wouldn't recommend

Pineapple basil cocktail - so refreshing and didn't taste the alcohol but very good and alcohol def kicks in after the drink

Service was very nice! Friendly hosts and servers.

Ambiance is also very clean and earthy with plants as deco.

The only problem was the food getting way too cold and wasn't that warm when served.

6.5/10!

Went here for a friend's bridal dinner. It's ok. The food was good. The ambiance was ok. It was pretty empty. The service was amazing. The waitress and waiter were very sweet and accommodating. They were probably the best part. I don't know if I would go back. It's nothing bad, It just didn't give me the wow factor. But I guess you can try it for yourself.. we also went upstairs to the rooftop after dinner, the views were nice. Again, nothing I haven't already experienced. Overall it was a good time.

I had a chance to grab drinks with a friend here on a Wednesday evening. I made a reservation before but given how open it was it doesn't seem like you need to do that if you're walking in. I checked in with the desk and they sealed aside a table in the back. You should know, that they have a huge dining area in the back, it's not only the bar and outside area seating. After we were seated, we were given menus to look over. We were just doing drinks so I went with a House martini that was around $18. Strong into the point which is what I like! Service here was also efficient and everyone was very friendly. I definitely come here again for dinner or drinks with a group of friends after the workday!

Came here on a Sunday morning with reservations and it was relatively quiet. It's located in the lobby of a hotel but still easy to find. We ordered the sambal scramble eggs, sausage rolls, and a salad. Compared to other Australian cafes in the area, it wasn't anything to write home about. But if you're looki Ng for a quiet place to catch up with friends and not be rushed out this is the place to go!

I heard about this place from an IG reel months ago. The reel had mentioned $12 for 12 oysters during their happy hour. I'm not a huge oyster person but enjoy them on occasion and will definitely have them if they're on the HH menu.

This place is on the first floor of a hotel. I came in with two friends. They gave us the regular menus even though it was still HH. I asked for the HH menu then they brought it over to us. No oysters were listed!! I asked about it and they told me it had been taken off the menu some time ago :(

Other HH items were good. We ordered fries, brussel sprouts and wings. They used the same sauce for all 3 items but it was an amazing sauce so we didnt mind. Very affordable for 3 people sharing items especially for a restaurant inside of a hotel.

My friend wants to come back and try their drinks next time. Would definitely get their brussel sprouts again! Its just not the same making them at home haha

This restaurant is an absolute hidden gem! It's filled with beautiful and vibey decor, almost like a Tulum-esque restaurant. The music is great, the cocktails are unique, and the service is attentive and polite.

Marianna was our waitress and she patiently accepted all of our requests based on allergens.

We got the Toasted Coconut Negroni, and WOW- fresh, vibrant flavors, and delicious.
The fries are also a must- the perfect combination of freshness, crispness, and flavor.

Don't miss out on the rooftop of the same hotel as well!

SO good!!! pricey but worth it. the black garlic caesar salad with chicken is unbelievable, the espresso martinis are amazing, service was excellent! it was my friend's birthday and they comped 2 orders of sticky pudding for us! overall great experience, would recommend if you're willing to spend.

Solid 4-4.5. Definitely great for a quick catch-up or business meeting if you're in Midtown.

Happy Hour is until 6 and has $5-$10 bar snacks (fries, burrata, etc.), discounted beer/wine and $10 cocktails.

Espresso martini is excellent. Kudos to the bartender.

Space is beautiful and uses the awkward shape well. The bar doubles as a cafe, and there's bar seating, small group seating, larger lunch/dinner seating towards the back and two outdoor spaces (front & back).

Pro-tip: Daintree Rooftop is in the same building and a quick elevator ride away. Whisk away your evening date upstairs for great views and cocktails that it offers.

Heard they have a solid Australian brunch as well... not sure what that means, but will update again once we do that.

Solid Australian brunch spot in Midtown connected to a hotel lobby. I ordered the Isla Benedict with salmon lox, pickled onion, and hollandaise ($22), which was great. The toast was a bit too hard but the salmon lox was tasty and it was nice that it had some salmon roe on there too. The poached eggs on top were also good, and the hollandaise sauce was delicious/creamy and completed the dish well. The benedict came with lots of fries (average quality).

I also tried the Brekkie Roll with fries ($15), which was good as well (more like a burger for us Americans). I especially liked the bacon in there, as it was a thick cut and not too salty.

The place itself is actually connected to a hotel, with a bar area and a narrow main seating area that opens up to a larger seating area in the back. There was only bar seating available when I went on a Sunday for brunch (didn't have a reservation). The bar seating area is a bit uncomfortable since there isn't enough leg room under the bar counter so you have to somehow arrange your legs in a sort of sideways position. The place has modern clean decor. The service speed is fine, and the staff are average friendliness/attentiveness.

Overall, Isla & Co is a good choice for brunch if you are interested in some Australian food and happen to be in the Midtown area.

This is a nice spot for Australian-style brunch. It's located inside Hotel Hendricks.

The decor is cute and inviting with lots of plants and warm light. The staff were very friendly.

To eat, I had the mushroom toast and loved it. The buttery, crusty toast was loaded with savory mushrooms and a poached egg. The dish was also quite garlicky so beware if you order it on a date.

My friend got the brekkie roll and enjoyed it. She said the batch coffee was not the best.

Sort of a mediocre place, unfortunately. We got the sausage rolls to share and although the pastry was delicious and buttery, the sausage tasted like nothing. The sauce that it came with drowned out the flavor of the meat inside the pastry. I tried a roll without the sauce and still couldn't really taste much.

I got the fish and chips, and it was quite alright. Nothing to rave about. The chips/fries were pretty good (but I was also craving fries that night), and the fish was mediocre. Nice fry on the fish, but it came clean off when I tried to cut it. I think there was so much oil on the dish that I got a little sick when I got home.

My date got the lamb, and he enjoyed it, but thought it was also a little heavy so he didn't get to finish it. I also tried a bit and came to the same conclusion... just eh.

Service was fine, maybe we waited a bit longer than usual, but I'd give that a pass since we went on Superbowl Sunday. People were friendly and helpful. Sad that the food was just shmeh.

This was also located inside a hotel so vibes were a little fancy, but not like suit and tie fancy. Nice spot for date night. Maybe will come back when they have kangaroo on the menu :)

It was a little bit off that the hostess didn't greet me and sit me at the table. She saw me and just passed so I thought she wasn't an employee there for a second.

The ambiance, food, and service were okay, but not impressive when considering it's a hotel restaurant.
Bloody Mary was terrible. It tasted like tomato sauce for pasta.

I tried to call the restaurant for my lost item but they never picked it up and realized there was no way to contact them
The expresso martini flight and spicy chicken wings were amazing. Karson was an amazing bartender! Will be back.

4.5 stars - Came here with a party of 6 for dinner around 6:30 on a thursday night. It was really easy to make a reservation and also the restaurant wasn't too full so you could probably walk in as well. Everything was delicious and the staff was very nice. We had one hiccup, 2 people ordered fish and chips and one order only came with one fish filet while the other one came with 2. Not sure how they portioned it but we pointed it out to the waiter and he added another filet asap which was nice.

We started off with the Crispy Halloumi and the Blistered Brussel Sprouts as appetizers for the table. The Crispy Halloumi was so yummy, especially if you are a cheese/halloumi lover I would recommend! The brussel sprouts weren't super crispy but the sauce was delicious.
I got the Spicy Shrimp Vodka Rigatoni for my entree and it was delicious- no complaints!

Come again? I'm not dying to come again but I would be down to. It's a good place that's not too overhyped so reservations are easy and no long wait!

Shoutout to jarmine for the fire service and recommendations. Went for happy hour a few times and the drinks and food were delicious. My favorite are the Cajun balls and the brussel sprouts. Wings were good and sweet but I was too full to enjoy them lol.

I have never really tried Australian food before and this spot was such a lovely surprise! Really cute seating area and the staff was very attentive. We ordered the quinoa bowl, brekkie roll, and kangaroo tucker. Everything was truly so delicious and well balanced. Would definitely come back again!

To be honest, I don't want people to know about this place! Amazing food, excellent service, and such a nice classy ambiance. This place is perfect for special occasions.

My friend and I found this place during the restaurant week and decided to give it a try. We had the following dishes:

1. Crispy Halloumi - 5/5
It was my first time trying Halloumi and they were so tasty. Highly recommended if you haven't tried. Portion was perfect as a starter.

2. Shishito Peppers - 5/5
Not a big fan of peppers, but I could not stop eating them! Crumbs on top were crispy and it had both sweet and salty tastes, not spicy at all. Paired well with our drinks.

3. Risotto - 5/5
It was a different type of risotto - creamy and fresh! If you want a satisfying dish but don't want a salad or heavy food, this is it.

4. Striped Bass - 4/5
Fish was well cooked, but nothing too special. I would pick risotto over this.

Their regular menu seems to be different from the restaurant week menu. I will absolutely come back to try their brunch and other regular dinner menus (octopus and oysters)!!

Joined Isla for a slice of Australia without the 20-hour flight! It was such a cute hidden gem behind a hotel (you would have never guessed), and drinks/food were incredible. I felt like there was only one server working and not as attentive as I would've liked, but it was fine since we weren't in a rush. Espresso martini was perfectly made. I asked for the chicken sando without the bread  but they were super nice about it and made it to my liking. It was still extremely delicious and I'm sure it would have been even better with the sourdough.

10/10 This place was super cute, with delicious food, and great staff/service!

We wandered over to this place on a Saturday morning for a early brunch. They weren't too busy and since it was a beautiful day, all of the outside tables were full. Therefore we opted to sit at the bar.

We started with the oysters and cocktail. They were yum paired with a tasty cocktail sauce.

Boyfriend's meal: Shrimp Rigatoni is in a spicy vodka sauce that both my boyfriend and I could not resist! And I've been to Carbone. It was a 10/10 highly recommended dish for sure!

My meal: Mushroom toast - this was good, and I liked it more than I thought I would. Lots of mushrooms so if you don't mushrooms stay away! Next time I'll opt to try another dish.

Service: Amazing ! The staff were friendly and welcoming! Not something you always experience in NYC. Made the experience even better.

Solid place, but definitely not something I would crave or seek out. I got the eggplant panini and thought it would come with actual bread not burger bread, but still good. It was definitely on the smaller size portion wise. They let us stay for 4 hours since it was pretty empty, so a great spot for what we needed. The waiter was super nice and the food was quick to come out. It's part of a hotel so the inside was really nice as well :)

We had an early Sunday dinner seated outside. The location was convenient and the service was very good, friendly amicable and timely.
Drinks were nice. Food was above expectation they really earned the five stars with regard to their attentiveness and the way they managed things.  
They are part of a hotel, but still offered convenient, decent food
I would recommend because of the staff

I am a huge fan of the city and I'm always looking for new places to explore and experience. While visiting the Empire State Building, a friend and I were looking for a nearby place that we could grab some dinner that also had some pescatarian options available. We came across this place, and it was definitely a great choice. I think my only issue with the entire experience was the confusion with checking in or being seated. This restaurant is found within a hotel, and they have outdoor seating, but there is no clear indication of where or to whom you're supposed to speak to about that. Once we figured that part out, we were told to choose a table that made us comfortable, and we were given menus and left to look. The menu had plenty of options without being overwhelming, and we were able to pick out options that made us happy within no time. The servers we had were attentive without being overbearing, which is always a plus in my book, and they always made sure we had what we needed without making us feel like we were being circled by hawks. The food was delicious. I ordered the Charred Octopus, and the temperature and flavor were perfect. It was charred just enough to give a crisp to the outside while maintaining a tenderness within. I did order the Smoke Show (drink) with my dinner, and it was made very well. Overall, this wasn't a planned location, but was a great experience. I can absolutely see how it can be coined a 'hidden gem'. I hope to make it back soon!

The restaurant is very cute especially their garden lounge. There's a one restroom on the lobby for bar and restaurant it can be a very long wait. The food taste good but they are pricy. Couple things are let down.
1. The reservation, I have party of 9 Resy only let me book max of 8 so I was trying to call for a long time no one answers for about 30mins try, had to message through Yelp page to have someone to call me back.
2. When we arrived, we were a line standing outside no hostess at the door, I could see her chatting at the bar with bar tender and other people for 5 mins laughing.
3. Out service was very slow, it took a long time to get a drink order, then took a long time for him to return to get food order, same have to find him to get the check. Also he can't remember who orders what, placing orders on the wrong person.

I had the little gem is very little basically a small bowl of salad, not worth the $16, recommend to skip. Chicken liver mousse is really nice, wish they had more bread instead of only one piece. The scallops comes in four piece. So if you are hungry I will recommend to offer a small plate(small app size) and a big plate. It will prob cost you at least $50/ person without drink or tip. Definitely a pricy side. But for this service I would try elsewhere

This place is fantastic--after you figure out how to get in! Make sure you enter through the hotel entrance. Once you do make it inside though, you've found a beautifully decorated brunch place. Usually I'm not particularly impressed by pasta, but the spicy shrimp rigatoni was delightfully spicy and creamy with a nice crunch from the toasted bread crumbs. Our waitress was super nice and accommodating as well.

Overall, this was the perfect brunch spot to bring friends or a date--not overly crowded or loud, and delicious food.

Super cute and cozy date night spot! Also really sweet, chill acoustic live music. What a cool funky twist on classic dishes and a few things I've never heard of! We had the spicy PRAWNS rigatoni and burger with the kimchi aioli. They even threw an affogato on the house since we are celebrating our anniversary! So sweet!!! Great for larger groups and business meals too.

The nyc bar experience you dream of. This staff is so attentive and kind. High class ambiance at an affordable price. I didn't have any food but the drinks were exceptional. This is a place to go for good talks. A place where you start inside with food, then head upstairs for drinks. You could send a long time here. Alejandra took care of me and she was fantastic.

Went with a friend without reservation on a Wednesday night. We were seated right away. Loved the ambience of the restaurant - it's trendy yet cozy at the same time. We ordered fries with black truffle aioli, green curry, and spicy shrimp rigatoni. The food was surprisingly delicious! We enjoyed our night here. In NYC sometimes it's hard to find a restaurant quiet enough to have a nice conversation. But we had the perfect corner seat to enjoy the night and catch up. Would definitely recommend to friends and family!

I got excited when I heard about their oyster with a cocktail special, so decided to book this restaurant as my mom's birthday lunch. The oysters were fresh while small in size, but probably due to their origin. The complimentary sauce is too citrusy for us, so we just slurped the bivalve creatures in their natural juice. The brekkie burger was delicious wit the egg slightly runny but still holding up to the grilled bacon. Fries remind me of mcD version, but of course, better quality. We chose the King's cocktail as it's one of their specialties. Sadly, the alcohol content is too strong and got sick from this drink. Don't want to get into the detail, but the aftermath isn't a pretty sight. While it was a pleasant meal, the meal after sickness turned this into a not so great time. Never knew high alcohol content could do that to the body.

I came to Isla & Co for a dinner date with my boyfriend. It was around half full when we arrived on a Friday night. We ordered the pork sausage rolls to start and a burger and spicy shrimp rigatoni as the main. The pork sausage rolls were crispy and delicious although some of the rolls were only halfway filled with sausage. The spicy shrimp rigatoni was super yummy, not too spicy. My only complaint was that I wish the portion was a bit bigger (but I came from a workout so maybe I was feeling extra hungry). My boyfriend enjoyed his burger as well. Overall, very yummy! The staff were also super friendly.

A scary moment: recommending a place to good friends only to revisit it months later, and realize they overhauled their menu for the worse  

Isla used to have a fantastic menu - a vermouth selection, a massive tomahawk steak. The last time we went was so disappointing; they replaced most of their menu with standard hotel bistro fare. I had the worst Caesar salad in my life.

The vibes and staff are still great,  but imo for food there are much more solid options in midtown.

I was excited to try Isla since I saw that it was a new restaurant near Bryant Park, and I know there's typically not a lot of restaurants near Bryant Park. However, the food at Isla was just a disappointment.

We went in with a group of 16 for an engagement dinner, so Isla offered us a pre-fixed menu. The options were Sea Bass, Chicken, and Vegetarian Risotto. The Sea Bass had a really weird sauce paired with it, the chicken seemed roasted and nothing else was done to it, and vegetarian risotto was just ... ok. It was probably the best of the night but nothing crazy good about the risotto. We also paid extra for some starters like tuna tartare, octopus, oysters, and halloumi salad- all were just ok. We also got desserts like the panna cotta + chocolate cake, both were overwhelmingly sweet, so it was disappointing as well.

The servers were nice and attentive which is why I'm giving them some credit, and the atmosphere is great to dine in. I am hoping Isla can improve their menu and hopefully grow as a restaurant in the future.

In terms of vibe, this is a very aesthetic and quiet dinner place if this is something you are looking for. Service was good too. However, the food are average. My friend got the charred octopus, and it was a little bit salty. It had a very soft texture, which was different from my previous experience being chewy. Also tried the kangaroo meat skewers for the first time! It was really chewy but bland. The pasta was al dante. Heard that brunch is better, so might be coming back to try that

Isla is a new restaurant in the Bryant Park neighborhood in the Hotel Hendricks. Not the greatest location for what could be a terrific standalone restaurant. The food is very good. All very creative. The only disappointment was the focaccia (which was not great) with salted butter (which was not salted butter). Nothing to comment on, but it is a menu item and when bread is on the menu it should be terrific, here it is far from it. Also, the house cocktails are not great either. So you have terrific food, but it lacks the rest of the package to make it a destination restaurant.

This place is very nice! It was quiet when we arrived, only one other customer seated across the room in the evening. The food was great. Not too much of variety on the menu but nonetheless delicious. I'm surprised it wasn't busier from the quality of food and service!

I came here for drinks and appetizers but we ended up staying for dinner. The space is really small I would say there's maybe about five or six tables mostly meant for a couple of people to sit at each. They would push tables together for a slightly larger groups. It is in the lobby of the Hendrix hotel and you have to walk into the lobby and turn to the left to enter the seating area. They do have some smaller tables in front of people who just want drinks.

The wait staff is really attentive and very quick to give you menus and your food and make sure that the service is to your liking. I also find them really helpful and good with recommendations.

We started with drinks I had a version of the hot toddy and my friend had the three kings. Both were really well prepared and they also would give you drinks to take away to your room if you're staying in the hotel.  

For dinner We tried the oysters, the beef tartare the little gem salad the toffee pudding and the focaccia bread. The ice was really interesting they were really fresh and they come with a little bit of sushi roe on them. I did like the beef tartare as well it comes with a quail egg on top and toffee putting was totally the best dish of them all. It is like all of winter season in a dessert and is served warm. It has crumbles of crunchy toffee on top of a warm spiced cake. I would totally comme back for this alone but I assume its seasonal.

Docking a star simply because of the price. Everything else was phenomenal.

Food (5/5) - We shared the octopus which was really tender, and the jalapeno  / garlic puree sauce was a really good pairing. Portion was a little small for the price but was really well prepared.

The drinks are small but strong and don't taste like alcohol at all - would highly recommend the cocktails. The basil gimlet was my choice and it was really beautifully prepared, nice and refreshing.

Ambiance (5/5) - there are three seating areas - 1) the bar / small shaded outdoor area: not too loud, looked very classy but not overly blitzy, decently well-lit. 2) the lounge area which is nice and private, a little darker but pretty romantic. 3) the shaded back tent area which is also pretty private, more rustic and romantic. Think boho hangings and summer sofas, cream colored everything.

Price (3/5) - cocktails were $16+ apiece and food was around $20 per plate, sides were around $10. Definitely on the pricier end but everything was really nicely prepared.

Very limited menu but food was tasty. ULTRA slow service as they are understaffed. The barista, bartender and server are one person. She was really sweet and working hard--but it's also hard to manage running a front bar and coffee orders and run up and down stairs to get food. Bad scheduling on the managements part. My husband's food came and mine didn't come for another 10 mins after his--these are eggs on toast, so not sure what was happening. He had to eat without me so his food didn't get cold. Coffee is hella bitter. This sits inside the Hendricks hotel. Pictures are a bit deceiving as it looks like real restaurant--but the bar is the lobby of the hotel and the restaurant is kind of off to the side of the lobby as well. Would suggest you try an actual brunch spot if in NY. We stayed at the hotel, so we though it was convenient, albeit pricey.

We stopped by for dinner yesterday at isla on w 38 th st on a warm winter nite after finding Isla on Yelp. The online menu caught our eyes and thought we'd try it. Was a great decision. Nice quaint clean restaurant with friendly attentive staff.
We started off w the focaccia bread, grilled octopus with a grilled smashed eggplant purée, fried Brussels sprouts, endives and arugula with dates. Generous portions n It was all yummy.
For entrees we ordered the NY strip steak and whole roasted Bronzino for 2. Good portions. They were both yum yum. Not a morsel of leftovers. It was insanely delicious.
To top off our dinner we shared  the pavlova w stewed apples. Oh my god. It was heavenly.
Thank you Isla for a great evening w good food and ambience.

An overlooked gem in Midtown East. Australian food with a flair. The staff was extremely hospitable and knowledgeable about the dishes and drinks. Come enjoy a custom cocktail. Indoor and outdoor dining.

So glad that Isla in Midtown is open again (in Hotel Hendricks), because it is your perfect place for every occasion, dinner with friends, family, date, birthday, etc. the space is stunning but what matters is the menu. Favorite dish, scallops. Do. Not. Sleep. On. This. Dish.  The addition of the pasta and vegetables to a course that is usually not substantial really makes a difference. Other highlights include the super smooth cold brew martini, crispy halloumi, which is perfectly balanced and the asparagus dish with duck eye on top. What's even better is Daintree is right upstairs for a nightcap if you're not ready to go home!

This restaurant was located inside a hotel.
But, no server was available to take the order after being seated at the table? Felt like a ghost here. Left after sitting here for almost 30minutes. What an unpleasant/weird experience...

I stopped by during a week night for two and the service was impeccable. There's something noticeable about the servers, they are really enjoying their job and let out welcoming energy.

I didn't hesistate to chat with them or ask questions about the menu, 100 thanks to the staff for creating that environment for guests becuase it goes a long way in this city.

Now, for the food. YUM.

I had the 1/2 Beau Soliel OYSTERS with Trout Roe & Cucumber Shallot Mignonette. They were unbelievably fresh and simple - not dragged down with too many heavy sauces or heavy oils dressing. I was able to appreciate the tenderness of the oyster.  

The Ahi Tuna Tartare + Calabrian Chiles + Avocado Yuzu Puree + Squid Ink Croquant was memorable. The croquant was the perfect vessel for the tartare with enough stability to support the heftiness of the tuna but enough give to provide a satisfying snap when you bit into it.

My favorite dish of the night (to my surprise) was the Roasted Salmon served with Grilled Escarole, Lemon, and Ikura. The fish was absolutely tender and had an umami quality that just hit every mark in terms of salt, fat, and flavor.  

The star of the show was the 14oz NY Strip Steak with Grilled Rapini and Coriander Peppercorn Jus - visually stunning and perfectly cooked. The grilled rapini was gorgeous and very meaty.  

Lastly, I had the Medjool Date Cake with crème Fraiche, English toffee, and dulce de leche. It is a must-have if you only have one dessert during your visit. It is decadent and plays with textures like crunch, springy cake, and melted cream. BUT- If you can have them all (have them all)! There is no way to order the wrong thing.

It's not the easiest task to find a place that pleases all the coworkers for a midtown post-work outing, but this cute restaurant did it! First the restaurant was accommodating - we showed up with more people than I had made a reservation for. They reconfigured the tables and had us seated immediately. They didn't even mind the round-Robin of people at our table. We started with six, some people drank, left and others came in and took their place. The cocktails are inventive and delicious (get the Basil Gimlet) and the food is good! Really good! A couple of us got fish and chips - bonus is that it's made with a rice flour coating- good for gluten-free concerns and really good if you like a seriously crunchy shell! We truly liked all the food we got- crispy halloumi, blistered Brussels sprouts, grain bowl, grilled chicken sandwich...I work with these people, they complain all the time! Not a single complaint last night! :) This place is a small, chill hidden gem with nice ambiance and great food - a true find in midtown!

Went for me and a friend's birthday and the service was terrible considering no one was in the building on a rainy day. Went because a friend recommended the brunch and French toast, but we couldn't even get brunch. WARNING: They allow you to book for brunch on resy until 3:45PM, but you can only order brunch until 3PM. Our server wasn't very attentive either, so we had to go to the bar to order drinks in the middle of eating, and he LEFT without saying a word to us, so we didn't even know we had a whole new server for a period of time. The food was good though. Just not the experience I would've expected for my bday brunch. Disappointed.

Enjoy floor-to-ceiling sunlight, warm interior accents, vibrant greenery at here, serving up Australian-style cafe service for brunch and hearty dinner-time chow like this fish & chips + Isla beef burger option! Check their website out for more info about their menu!

Really cute decor and dainty menu with lots of small attention to details. Got the spicy vodka shrimp rigatoni and the flavor was super rich and creamy. Really delicious and would definitely come back to try their brunch!

I'm shocked to see this place has 4.5 stars. Must have hit it on a bad day. I went on Tuesday to get an amazing oyster special ($12 for a dozen oysters and a cocktail). Weirdly the special wasn't posted so I had to ask about it.

The service was 3/10 at best. The bar was littered with empty drinks even though the place was basically empty.

There was also a lot of fine print with the special. I guess they can do that when it's not written down. My party of two was limited to one dozen oysters. Was told "we'd go out of business if we allowed more." Yeah, probably. You should probably write the special down to avoid the confusion.

Also the bartender was apathetic bordering on rude.

Awesome time here!! We came for dinner, the restaurant is gorgeous, the service is very friendly and easy going. Our server, Andres, was perfect, attentive without being overbearing and after we paid still got water refills. The food was really great! The amount of shrimp in my dish was great (which is often an issue) and the risotto was super cheesy and delicious. Had a few drinks as well and they were all great!

Fresh and delicious food! They have a great selection of sandwiches and other necessities. Perfect location in the heart of everything. No seating, but there are ample places around to sit in the surrounding parks.
Great place for a quick sandwich and drink.  The personnel are not the most friendly but they are fast and efficient.
In & Out Deli is the perfect NYC bodega! The people are really great and they make the best deli sandwiches!

I work around the corner from this place and whenever I don't want Moe's or Pret for lunch I would come here. Mainly for the sandwiches.

I would recommend the cold cuts because it's quick and easy to make and you can't mess it up while making it. Sadly, that can't be said about the hot sandwiches. I ordered a hot chicken parm with bacon and I was highly disappointed. The cheese was still somewhat cold, the bacon was too hard and the worst part of all, the chicken was microwaved.

This is a hit or miss place. Would I come back? Maybe.
I go here every morning to get my breakfast. They are nice, fast and always remember my order before I even sat it. Their prices are very reasonable.

Me and my boyfriend enjoyed a delicious italian sub after walking around all day and not feeling like getting dressed up for dinner.  Very friendly people and there was a ton of meat on the subs and just the right amount of tasty italian dressing.  Would return!

Wage Theft !!!!! Owes my family $300.000 + dollars Ran and open a new store under new name.
Mojali Family Goverment not doing
nothing about it Allowing them to flee in and out of the country.

I'm giving them 1 star only because i cant give them zero the only thing going right for them is the breakfast sandwiches they're on point with them and price wise too but do not order one for lunch they'll charge you an extra dollar without notice verbally or posted anywhere in the store and yes that chicken cutlet sandwich is one of the worst I've ever had not crispy at all.microwaved and soggy horrible and the other day I ordered a turkey and munster cheese with mayo and a bit of mustard well guess what they couldn't manage to get that right something so simple . I got my sandwich overloaded with mayo and mustard that I couldn't even take a bite without it dripping off my sandwich I just don't get it.I do recommend from anyone  to stay away from this place there's plenty more around the neighborhood that will get everything right for you just the way you ordered it

Theyre a solid 3.5 stars so I rounded up to 4. Hard to give a bodega 4 stars but they get bonus points for being so nice. Even though its in the center of midtown, the guys remember me like I'm part of the neighborhood, and it makes for a pleasant visit. Its always crowded but I don't mind the wait, because its so close to where I work. Its strictly take-out. They have everything you need for breakfast or lunch at the grill and the typical refrigerated beer and drink selection. Its a good menu, for such a tiny place, if you read the sign posted above the grill. Its a typical dive, bodega-style, but the food is just right. It's made to order, and the price is fair for midtown. What more do you want? Place your order and then step aside toward the back, or wait outside in good weather. It's that cramped when there's a crowd. Am I the only person disgusted chick fil a had over 50 health violations. Never again. No thanks.

HORRIBLE STORE, they charge you according to how you look and how they feel. There are no prices on anything. Picked up a bottle of water and he charged me $3.50. That is highway robbery, I could have went to duane reade and got the same water for under $2.50 easily.
