Came here with a party of 6 at 5pm and we were seated immediately! Loved the ambiance, lighting and decor was a pleasure. Service was great, they provided many recommendations and brought out our meal quickly.

I ordered their lychee martini which I loved. Also got the shiromaru motoaji and thought it was great, added a perfectly cooked egg to it. My friends got the vegetable buns and aburi chashu rice, which they enjoyed as well. A little pricier than other ramen places I've visited, but service and the restaurant were clean and well decorated.

I really wish I would have taken more pictures of the food but quite frankly we ate it all so fast because it was that good! Located in a younger demographic neighborhood in Manhattan, this place is alive with vibrant energy. The staff all radiate an energy of being happy to work there and all very collaborative with eachother. Wonderful cohesion with all and gives a feeling of eating with family. We ordered the pork buns, the takoyaki, the chicken rice bowl and the pork ramen. Each dish more amazing than the next. Service was quick, music was fun and people watching was epic! Will absolutely come back next time I'm in town and try other options

Ippudo, famous for the ramen (And the long wait! ;))

However, I lucked out on a Friday evening and my party of two was able to get in after a 15 min wait. During your wait, make sure to check out the cocktail menu, they've got some interesting stuff!

Once seated, you can check out their menu via a QR code- they also have a special menu (with seasonal appetizers) that your server will show you. We ordered Akamaru Modern ramen and Karaka Spicy ramen, a special appetizer (a norimaki with iburigakko or smoked pickled daikon radish and maguro), and a draft Orion beer.
The norimaki was delicious- I've never had smoked takuan (the yellow picked radish) before, and I liked the combination with the maguro.

My Akamaru Modern features a rich (but not dense) tonkotsu broth, miso paste, and black garlic oil- blend together to make a well balanced broth, which is not an easy feat since tonkotsu broth can be so heavy handed sometimes. I really liked the chashu as well (nice, meaty and not overly fatty.) My only gripe is that the noodles were no longer al dente and were soft.

My husband really enjoyed his Karaka Spicy ramen, saying that it had a great kick without overpowering the tonkotsu broth.

While delicious, the rushed/slightly pushy service (servers kept asking if I was done when I wasn't finished with my meal) and soggy noodles makes me knock off a little- definitely a solid 4.5 experience.

Ippudo has always been one of my favorite ramen restaurants. I've been to a couple of their other locations in New York. We had a reservation for two at 6:15pm on a Wednesday. They seated us at a communal table with a handful of other parties. This seating was a bit surprising. The table is decently wide so you can still have a conversation without having to shout over others near you, but I would choose a different place if you're hoping for an intimate evening. They also seat solo diners in this section.

To start, I had the veggie bun. It was delicious. The sauce was rich and savory and the tempura-fried veggies made for a nice, crispy bite.

For my main, I got the Nirvana Karaka ramen. It was served with a spicy mushroom bolognese sauce on the side which was very tasty and added a nice kick to the dish. The ramen also featured artfully splayed fried mushrooms. These got soggy quickly in the broth, but I enjoyed the flavor. The broth was very hearty and rich and paired well with the buttery noodles. Highly recommended.

To drink, I had the lychee martini. It was sweet and juicy.

Service was very fast.

Service:  9/10 Noah was great, but I kept feeling rushed with the bussers. They kept asking if I was done and I wasn't. I wished they waited a bit more but overall very attentive so can't dock them too much.

Appetizers:
Pork bun
Friend #1 10/10
Friend #2 10/10

Cucumber:
Me: 7/10 not as spicy as I usually get them at other locations and some were more salty than others. Not consistent.
Friend #1: (7/10) - salty cucumber
Friend #2: she didn't enjoy & want to rate it :( sorry.

Ramen
Nirvana Karaka spicy:
Me: 7.5/10
The broth was goood and if you like spicy get the badunkan paste !'!!! WORTH IT. However, If it's a veggie ramen, it should have more veggies, but that's just me. My veggie ramens usually come with either bok Choy, cabbage, spinach, corn or bean sprouts and this ramen had NONE OF THOSE.  It had bamboo, noodles, green onions, noodles and tofu. If it's veggie ramen, I usually expect veggies but had to pay extra to get corn. Additionally, I asked Noah if the spicy paste was oniony and he didn't really know. I risked it and it had onions. I don't really like onions so I was able to scrape it off (thank god).

AKAMURO Shinaji
Friend #1 (9/10) Ramen and pork was delicious ! However, docked it because soft boiled egg was cooked a tad bit too much and the quantity of ramen could've a bit tad bit more.  It looked like it was missing food - missing noodles and broth. It  got me full but I could've used a bit more.

Friend #2:  9.5/10 everything was great but lacking in  pork

Ambience: LOUD and edm music. waiter kept with the Japanese theme so it was nice.

Having not had ramen in a minute, this hit the spot!

The place was quite roomy, with bathrooms a long trek downstairs. The service was cool, with waiters welcoming every party in. I do wish it was better when we needed to flag someone to order and pay though.

The Akamaru Shinaji ($20) was like your typical tonkatsu broth, but the flavor quality is apparent here. The thin noodle texture was perfect, and the juicy soft pork pieces was everything I could ask for in a tonkatsu. The smokey garlic sauce and the spicy kick also gave this bowl so much umami. Although, if the broth is going to be salty, the extreme saltiness from the bamboo shoots do not balance out. For this reason, I recommend the light creamy Shiromaru Motoaji ($18) more, which was essentially the same thing but without the extra salty condiments so you can truly enjoy every ingredient.

My friend's Potaru Miso Ramen ($22) was what I imagine ramen should be for a more balanced meal. It came with veggies like spinach and corn. I personally wasn't a fan of the beadiness of the spiced ball that transferred into the broth.

Ramen, to me, is noodles dunked in overly salty broth with 2 pieces of meat, take it or leave it. But, the broth is key, and Ippudo really nailed that in the head here. The high sodium intake never sits well with me, so I'm good with ramen for another year. If you're looking for a quick ramen fix, Ippudo seems authentic enough with a great selection of options to choose from.

Pretty good ramen, service was eh, maybe would come back for more ramen

Arriving around 3:30 on Saturday afternoon, no hassle or long wait to get a table for 3 without reservation. It's a bit dark in here, not really my kind of ambiance for a ramen spot.

First time having Ippudo ramen but I deviated from the classics and got the Potara Miso ramen. All the ramen looks visually great, would be nice for more toppings but unfortunately that all comes with a price.

The potara miso ramen is strong in flavor with the hearty pork miso broth and spiced minced meat. The wide thick noodles went well with the dish. The chasu wasn't fatty but not the worst I've ever had. Wouldn't recommend for non-spicy eaters as the spice does build a bit.

Tasting a bit of the classics Shiromaru Motoaji and Akamaru Shinaji, old is gold. They were cleaner in taste and lighter in flavor in comparison to potara but were solid on their own. I would pick them over mines on a normal day.

Service could be more attentive.

Overall, Ippudo is better than Ichiran

This was definitely the spot for a rainy NYC day!

The place is intimate. Service was pretty fast too. We didn't wait too long for our ramen which was a plus. I had the Kuraka spicy ramen and it was good. Price range was a little expensive -- you have to pay extra for toppings (e.g. egg, seaweed, naruto).

I also had the takoyaki balls which was pretty standard and lychee soda (which I liked a lot!)

Overall, if you're craving for ramen in NYC, check this place out for a speedy meal. Prolly a very expensive one too.

The best fried chicken I have ever had in my life.
We went for dinner on a Saturday night. The wait was about 45 minutes. They sat us in a oval table share by a party of 3 other people, but the table was wide enough that it wasn't uncomfortable. The ambiance was very good. Service was ok. We came for the ramen, which was very good. I never ever order chicken in a restaurant but a relative recommended the fried chicken and it was incredible. The best I have ever tasted in my life.

Surprised it wasn't busy for Sunday lunch. I was worried there would be a wait for a party of 7. But once we got there, we were seated immediately.

Staff was friendly and checked on us frequently. But I did feel kinda rushed with the bussers despite it not being super busy with lots of seats open. I finished my ramen earlier than most at my table and the busser noticed so he immediately took my bowl away. I felt that was kinda rude to those at my table and pressured them to finish quickly.

My go-to is the Akamaru Modern. It's got a rich, flavorful broth. Highly recommend: pork bun and karaage rice (the chicken is so crispy and juicy).
The takoyaki was pretty decent but there wasn't much filling in proportion to the batter.

What a great experience! Resy finally allows you to make reservations and you can choose between the main floor and counter. I ordered the Daizu No Chikara Miso veggie ramen and my friend got the Nirvana Karaka. The Daizu was absolutely delicious and very satisfying. The staff was very attentive and the ambiance was upbeat yet intimate. Would definitely come back!

Came here on a Friday evening at around 6:45. Was told it would be an 45-minute wait to an hour wait. We said, "sure, that's fine" since I was so excited to come here on our anniversary. It was not fine. We got sat at around 8:30. And by the time we were sat, it took an additional 15 minutes for the server to actually take our order. We were tucked away near the back of the house, off in a corner. Mind you, the place was virtually empty at this point besides a party of 10 who was near us so not sure why they would seat us far from everyone else and from the action. At least the decor where we were sitting was beautiful and nice to take pictures around.

We ordered the Karaka Spicy and the Shiromaru Classic. Mine (karaka) was mid at best, but my fiancé loved the classic.

Probably wouldn't come back here again as there are better options for ramen in Manhattan. If you want to try this ramen place, I'd recommend the midtown locations.

Ippudo has always been my go to for ramen in nyc since it never disappoints.

I always try to go during off hours to avoid any wait. I think the prices definitely increased from the last time I went (I've been going since my college days) but I am happy to spend that for that delicious akamaru ramen. I always pay extra for the egg hut wish it was included.

You may share a table with other people! Which I think adds to the experience. The atmosphere is great - while there are thousands of great ramen places in nyc, you still cannot go wrong with ippudo :)

This is my second time back after quite a while! I remember fondly how much I enjoyed my experience years ago and had a lot of excitement to go have some ramen from here. The noodles and flavor of the soup are still as amazing as it was but it was too oily for me and my friends. We were a party of three and shared a big round table with another party of three that came after us. I did see some private tables so not all the space is shared. This was overall a decent experience with the food and service but one thing that did bother me was we felt rushed even though the restaurant was not busy. Also, the amount of oil in the ramen was way too much

Used to be obsessed with this place because it had the best vegan ramen in the city!

No idea why they stopped making the vegan akamaru because every vegan/vegetarian I know loved it.

This new soy milk based soup is just average. I still like the mushroom/eggplant buns, but I just won't order ramen if I'm ever there again.

Such a shame =(

Best ramen I ever had. Great flavor. I was surprised by the cola I ordered. It was sweet and crisp. Usually I never enjoy the cola soda in the US but this one was great. If you are a soda fan, you will not be disappointed. The tonkotsu ramen had a nice balance. The egg was not cold which it usually is whenever I get ramen. The service was amazing. They are professional and friendly. The space was peaceful. I was seated at a table with others but I didn't mind. I overall enjoyed the experience and will be back to try more items.

I came in based off of a recommendation from a friend. They were pretty packed for a Thursday night which is great for business. Get there early! The ambiance was very intimate and unique. We were seated in an aisle island which was very interesting. Started off with the Brooklyn Kira Saki and the Summer Renaissance? Drink. Both were very good and tasty. As an appetizer we tried the Broccolini and the Takoyaki. The Broccolini was amazing! Especially with the bread crumbs and eggs. It was very flavorful, *chefs kiss*. The Takoyaki was not my favorite. It tasted a little weird to me but that's ok. For ramen, I got the Nirvana classic. It's a vegetarian ramen and I topped it with a tamago (soft boiled egg), Nori (seaweed), and Bakudan (super spicy ball). The ramen was the best
Ramen I've ever had. I was a little skeptical becoming of the soy milk in the ramen but it was perfect! The seaweed had an amazing crunch to it and it made me really excited. Aside from the food, the server was also attentive and helpful. He recommended the ramen I had, as well as the toppings. 10/10

I will be back!

If possible 4.8, but 5 stars felt better than 4.

Maybe top 3 ramen. I really liked the broth. Ordered pork bun & Yokohama Tonkotsu. Also drank a delicious mango cocktail.

Not sure where the 1 stars are coming from, I loved the ambiance. The ladies bathroom was a great experience. Arrived around 5 and got seated right away.

I loveee bao buns. The dough was beautiful, but mayo in a bao bun. Eh. Not a fan. 3.5

The drink was fire. It came with a dried mango which was soo good. Felt a bit tipsy after one tbh.

Spicy tuna roll was sooo good omg!

Ramen was good. I really liked the broth because it wasn't very salty. Wish the egg was a bit more runny but the combination of flavors was on point. I've never had pork pastrami before and it was a unique taste for me. I should have gotten the pork belly instead, but overall good ramen. Would definitely come again & recommend.

We went to the Japan Fes and it's a madhouse. Every booth has a massive lines. We only managed to get a boba drinks which is mediocre.  After 30 mins, we have given up and start to look for Japanese restaurants nearby and this fits the bill.

We also have Ippudo in San Francisco, so I know it's going to be good. We got to the restaurant around 11:30am and we were seated immediately.  Since the kids are not too hungry, we ordered two ramens and an order of chicken karage to share. The server is super nice and got us sharing bowls immediately. She said please feel free to let her know if we want more noodles or broth. How nice is that?!?!

I LOVE the miso ramen. It's so satisfying!!  Chicken karage is very flavorful and juicy as well.

Overall, it's 5/5 quick snack/lunch.  The restaurant is chic and servers are all very friendly.

We left around 12:45pm and the front lobby is packed!  Glad we got there early and didn't need to wait at all. You should absolutely go and have some miso ramen!!

This is how you operate a ramen shop.

Judgement-free, exceptional portion sizes, fair prices ($20 for a bowl is perfectly reasonable here), and friendly service to boot. What more can you ask for?

Oh yeah. Amazing food. That they have.

For the amateur ramen connoisseur, to the veteran, they have a ramen for every palate. It all tastes fresh, delicious, and if you want another bowl, get the extra noodles. You will not be sorry you did that.

I also ordered two pork buns which were also spectacular. The bao is cooked beautifully, silky and melty, and you get a mouthful of pork in every bite. It is enough to take the edge off before your ramen arrives, but if you want to turn it into an entree, have at it. They run at only $6 a pop, quite reasonable for a trendy East Village restaurant.

While researching this restaurant, I discovered that they have a location in San Francisco. I visited San Francisco this past May, how did I miss this?

Whether you are a solo diner, or going with a group, you are bound for a special experience from the moment you are greeted. They truly make you feel welcomed and appreciate your business, no matter what you order, and how you order it.

Since in the end, being true to the customer, and to yourself, is honestly how you end up with a successful restaurant, or in this case, a ramen shop.

Great ramen spot, especially if you're looking for more types of ramen than Tonkotsu ramen. This place also has amazing vegetarian ramen options.

For this location specifically, the interior is a bit packed. If you're coming in pairs or small groups, you may be seated at the same table as other parties. Interestingly, the tables are also very wide, so if you come in a pair, they actually seat you side-by-side. Overall though, the ambiance is quite nice and the service is fast, even with how busy they get.

I've tried their Tonkotsu ramen in other locations (it's also great), so I opted for the seasonal special - the sukiyaki spicy ver. The noodles are top quality, although they are lacking in terms of customization of thickness. The dish itself was quite sweet, but still holds a lot of the hearty savoryness that you'd expect from a ramen dish. Will definitely back to have it again, before they discontinue this.

I really wanted to love Ippudo, but I can't say I was impressed. I ordered two apps and two ramens. The first app was a veggie bun, which was incredibly salty. The second was a lotus sandwich, which had a good flavor profile, but it was not cooked enough. For ramen, I ordered the Shiromaru classic. The broth was good, light and flavorful, but the noodles were slightly under cooked and too thin for my liking. I also got only two small salty pieces of pork. My partner ordered a fish broth ramen, which they enjoyed but was oily.

The service was great, and they replenished our water often. The food took a while but it was a Friday night. The ambiance was nice though a little crowded. I would go back to try something different but I can't say I understand the hype.

Wow! Ippudo had amazing ramen. The nirvana classic (vegetarian) was great and definitely flavorful and filling enough so you didn't feel like you were missing the meat. I really enjoyed the broth and the noodle helping was very generous. We also tried the pork and veggie buns and really loved them- the bun was super soft and the pork was tasty. Overall the vibe in the restaurant was fun, with dark lighting and good music. I would love to come back with friends or on a weekend!

Very great place! Our waiter had a fun and upbeat personality. The food was delicious. We were a party of five and got seated right away at our own table. I was very impressed! I got the Nirvana Akamaru with spinach, chicken, and egg. It was delicious. The next time I go I plan to use about half of the spicy sauce to mix into the dish. I think that's the sweet spot.

Excellent customer service. Very friendly staff as well and I love their tattoos!!
Our waiter came and made sure we were aware of their QR only menu they had set up. Although, I hate QR menus Ippudo's wasn't too hard to manage.
The place was a bit full but wait time was only 10 mins for a table of two. I came during lunch time so many people were seated alone so it's not just great for groups.
The bathroom is downstairs and they do not sit you down until everyone has arrived in your group. Which I find very useful so everyone can be seated together.
The lychee martinis are my favorite

The only ramen I'll eat. It took awhile for my wife to get me on the ramen train since it never really fills me up and always seem to be left unsatisfied...

Buddy of mine introduced me to Ippudo in NYC and I haven't never been disappointed. The place is a vibe and very convenient drive in for me from NJ. Much prefer to travel for food rather than compromise quality. I usually get the Karaka spicy, extra noodle and add a boiled egg.

Oh and their lychee martini, UGH. Could live off of them!

I had such a great time at Ippudo! Unfortunately they do not take reservations or call aheads, so when went on a Wednesday night I was told it would be a 45-50 minute wait. Thankfully I only had to wait for 20 minutes or so and got a table! We were seated at a group kind of table but the service was still good. As a vegetarian, there are three main options for the ramen, and many appetizers too.

For the appetizer, I ordered the Nasu Dengaku, which was basically eggplant tempura on top of an eggplant hummus. It was delicious!!! I have been to Ippudo previously and also tried the Veggie Buns which are a good choice too. I ordered the Niravana Akamaru ramen as my main, and I loved it! The flavors were great and I also added an egg to mine which was soft boiled. If you finish your noodles and still have broth left, you can tell the staff "Kaedama" and they can bring you another noodle serving! There are two types of noodles you can choose from, so that's definitely a good option if you are looking to use up your remaining broth. Overall I highly recommend Ippudo!

Less sodium please!! I could tell the flavor profiles were complex and the ramen we shared had an amazing silky texture. But the sodium levels are too high. If you lower the salt context the ingredients will shine even brighter. Even the hummus for our vegetable starter was over salted. Sodium preference aside this place was great.

Ippudo is a great ramen place! I love that they use thin noodles for their tonkotsu as that is my preferred noodle. The broth is rich and satisfyingly salty. The chashu is tender and the noodles have a good bite! My friend also enjoyed the miso. It took a while for servers to come take our order, but other than that everything was very attentive. Love the ambiance of the place too, we were seated at the bar table and i loved the idea of it.
We only went for the yummy Takoyaki and didn't try anything else but it was so good! Also had a very refreshing lychee martini and Sake flight

The experience at Ippudo NY is great, service was great and very attentive to us. The ramen dishes are delicious and tasty. We ordered: Miso Ramen, Pork Belly and Fried Chicken. For those that like spicy they have a bowl that is not on their menu but it is amazing called Spicy Miso Ramen which is not for the faint of heart.
What an absolute rip-off! $27 for a tiny bowl of bland broth and noodles.. see the photo

TL;DR: Rich porky ramen in a communal setting if you can brave the aggressive wait (though the food is out in ~10min). Otherwise, E.A.K is a close second option.

Coming on a Sunday night, I was struck by the long line and this one Japanese phrase the waiter would say every time they seated a customer. Every time! When the host seated a new party, he would never fail to yell this phrase. It was an interesting touch.

We got the Potara and Original ramen; the Potara is heavy--very rich and fatty--while the original is spicier and lighter. Both broths were creamy, not too thick, and delicious. Impeccable and fast service.

Highly recommend Ippudo as a strong choice, though I will say, I wasn't blown by the flavor combinations. It is certainly top 10 but I generally like spicier, bolder combos so that's my personal slant.

Had to give Ippudo a try and it did not disappoint!

Gets pretty busy there so be prepared to wait. There's a little waiting area inside with some seats. There's a bathroom downstairs. Nice and good service.

If you come with a small party be prepared to sit across the table from strangers or with them. Not my fave thing but that's how it is.

Started off with the lychee martini which is absolutely delish. Not too sweet and perfect balance of flavors

For an appetizer got the chicken karaage and it was so good. Crispy, hot, and juicy with their delicious mayo! Enough to share with 2-3 people.

For the main course we had the Karaka spicy and the Akamaru shinaji. Both came with the thin noodles, green onion and marinated bamboo shoots (so good). The broth on both were soooo rich and tasty; the karaka spicy has a little kick to it but it isn't too bad when you mix it all together. it a more food than it looks like, very filling with a small appetizer. The charsu  was so flavorful and not dry at all

Added a marinated soft boil egg for $3 and I could go without it. Was a little more over cooked than I would like and didn't really taste as marinated compared to various other ramen spots.

I would come again for a nice treat. The broth is so flavorful and rich. Is about $22-25 a bowl which is pricy but it is good broth. Don't like sitting with strangers, but it's all good a few lychee martinis in and you start to tune them out

Decided to go here for dinner a few weeks ago. The place is cute and cozy. We went on a Sunday so there wasn't any wait

We got the veggie pizza as an appetizer. This was REALLY GOOD. the veggies were perfectly cooked and the tomato sauce was delicious.

For our main dishes, we got the penne pomodoro and rigatoni alla norma. The sauce was really good, but the portions weren't huge.

I'd go back!!

As soon as we walked in, my partner and I were seated by a lively and friendly host, but problems arose as soon as we sat down.

Service:
The waitress helping us gave my partner and I attitude when we needed a little more time deciding what to order (this was the very first time she asked if we were ready to order) and to have a bottle of sparkling water instead of tap. She visibly rolled her eyes. When she brought the bottle of Pellegrino and glasses out, she placed my glass right on the middle of the menu (the very menu I was looking at in order to decide what to order). I thought she wanted us to order quicker?

We ultimately laughed both instances off, thinking it was an off day for her, but then noticed she was very polite and smiley to a couple that was leaving (she smiled and joked with them because they almost left their leftovers behind).

I'm guessing it wasn't an off day after all. She was just off for us.

All the other gentlemen that we interacted with were pleasant and friendly, so it's not a restaurant thing; it's definitely a person thing.

Ambiance:
Their outdoor setting is quite cozy and romantic looking. We didn't get to enjoy it, though, because we walked in too late. But the inside is equally as cozy and romantic. The brick stone walls and dim lighting adds to the coziness of it all.

Food:
The carbonara wasn't bad, but flavor wise, it was lacking. Definitely not cheesy enough. But most importantly, it was lacking a 'wow' factor because the dish tasted dead.

The chicken and sausage with roasted potatoes and green beans (blanking on the Italian name): the chicken was breaded and the sauce it was coated in made me think I was actually having Chinese food. The only things that reminded me that I was having an Italian dish were the sausages, potatoes, and location I was in.

Overall, I cannot picture myself coming back nor can I imagine myself recommending this place to anyone I know.

I booked my daughter's 18th birthday a day before her birthday celebration and I am thankful that they allowed me to have a reservation for 22 people without having to pick prefix dinner. Other restaurants I had called demanded prefix menu, which was too pricey and impractical.

The place was cozy and the ambience was great in a little street in the South Street Seaport. The food was excellent and everyone enjoyed his/her meal.
I loved that they didn't charge us for the cake's slicing fee (we brought our own birthday cake).

The staff members were also helpful in figuring out what to do in terms of appetizers for a group of 22, most of these are teenagers. They were all great (from the servers to the kitchen staff) and did not rush us in finishing.

Ivan, who I had spoken to the day before, and making the reservation, was exceptional in answering all my questions albeit I called so many times with them.

Huge menu selection!

I highly recommend this place, and will definitely come back!

This place is very good. I happened to walk by it while walking in the seaport and the ambience is great! Extensive indoor and outdoor seating I really like it! Reasonably priced and very good portions size make this place easy to enjoy! The pastas were both excellent and the service was fast! Definitely recommend! Get the carbonara and seafood pasta!

About 45 minutes into apps and dinner, mid-bite, plates of food in front of us, we were asked by Navid, the manager, to move to another, smaller table or finish dinner quickly to make room for another, larger party.
    Sooooo, super-disrupted, my wife and I and 5 plates of food moved. The food turned cold. Nobody cared. The server shrugged. Still we left a tip since a busboy helped us move our plates.
   We won't return. Ever. We don't recommend Il Brigante because we had a terribly disappointing experience there.

We were looking for a spot for dinner and found this great place on a whim. We started off with the bruschetta, which was incredible. You could tell that the tomatoes and onions were very fresh and the bread was delicious. We had a glass of wine, and I had rigatoni with Bolognese. It was one of the best Bolognese I've ever had... The pasta was cooked perfectly I would not have changed a thing. My boyfriend got the prosciutto and cheese stuffed veal and he Ate The whole thing! He said it was phenomenal. Our waiter, was very kind and sat us even though they were going to close in 20 minutes.. in the staff was very attentive. We are so glad that we found a spot and I look forward to coming back. I also loved the decor. It felt very homey and very comfortable.... I felt like I was at my Italian grandmothers house. It was so fantastic.
At Il Brigante you can find good Italian food served in a cute spot featuring exposed brick. Enjoyed a late lunch here after a long bike ride.

Solid Italian restaurant for a cozy and casual Italian meal. My group was seated in the outdoors structure, which was heated and nicely decorated. We actually ended up preferring eating outdoors since the indoors area seemed more crowded with a tighter table space.

Food-wise, we all unanimously enjoyed the Brigante pizza, which had a nice balance from the prosciutto and arugula topping. We'd skip the Funghi e Tartufo next time - it was more of a regular mushroom pizza that barely had any truffle flavor or aroma to it. We also tried the Fusilli Silani, and it was a simple but tasty baked pasta with sausage and cheese.

Overall, a decent Italian meal but also pricey for what it was. It started getting pretty busy later in the evening, so make reservations if you want to come by during peak dinner hours.

Great find. Right off the Fulton st. We stopped in after the movies. Amazing pasta n pizza. The drinks a are refreshing. Love NY there's no smoking in or outside the restaurant. Service is very friendly. The tables are nicely decorated.

Solid Italian spot in the cutest of neighborhoods. Stopped by for lunch on a Monday and there was plenty of available seating.

There is no lunch specific menu - we ordered burrata as a starter and two pasta dishes to share. The bolognese was hearty and the fettuccine was delicious. The raviolis had a buttery sage sauce which was a nice lighter contrast to the heavier bolognese. The bread was fresh and tasty and came with some olive oil-balsamic mix.

Overall the meal was very pleasant but I wouldn't say that anything really stood out. Solid spot to get some go to Italian dishes. Service was also attentive and on point.
I love this place. I've never been to Italy but I feel like I'm there when I dine hear. Rustic and charming with top notch service.
Came for a late dessert and it was really good and the staff was also nice and did not mind that we were only doing dessert!

I've been twice now - once with some coworkers and once with friends. First time, I wasn't that impressed with my dish (linguini w/ shrimp and zucchini) but was thoroughly impressed with the wine selection. Second time was much better food-wise (maybe first time was just an unlucky miss?) I got the fusilli silani, which was QUITE good, and our table got bruschetta and burrata for apps, both of which were perfect.

Given that, it's probably one of the better Italian places around Fidi, and I would go back for the food. One downside is that my party of 7 waited close to an hour between apps and our main courses, so the service was pretty slow on a weekend night.

On a Friday night, I met up with two of my friends (one came all the way from Australia and my bestie from Long Island) in south street seaport for the Santa Clauses interactive experience at Watermark and decide to have dinner around the area afterwards.  Originally was gonna go eat at Fishmarket but it was packed full. So went and looked elsewhere and stumble upon this restaurant. Also had a slice of pizza as a snack earlier at the new location of Di Fara Pizza around the area. (Read that review later if interested).  

So glad we decided on this restaurant. The food was delicious, hands down. Don't think I remember a more mouth watery seafood pasta. Tasted so fresh and savory. The Branzino my friend got was well seasoned too. The grill chicken my other friend got was also grilled well. Wasn't too dry. I can't stay anything bad about the food except it was pricey. But on pare with Manhattan prices. I haven't given a place 5 stars review in a long time but this place deserves it.

The restaurant was packed full too. So we actually didn't get to dine inside. Instead they had an outdoor area they made that was enclosed, we sat in there which was also well packed but not to capacity. The host came over at the end and asked us how was the food. The waiter came by from time to time at appropriate intervals.

The last thing I want to comment on was the LED table lights that looks like candles on the table. It was so cute and well designed, I took a pic because I wanted to buy one or a few depending on the price. I found two companies online that sell it. It's not cheap. It's Italian design. And cost $149 a pop at retail price. I ended up buying one because I really like it. But at a slight discount price. Only one, cause it's too expensive to get more. It's rechargeable and portable which I like.

We went here for my sisters birthday after having stumbled upon this place a few months earlier. Everything was absolutely delicious from the wine and cocktails to the pizza and pasta. Everyone was so sweet and attentive and my sister had a lovely time!

Make reservations. Homey, warm, relaxed atmosphere. Calming, classy music playing in the background. Great for a date or a family/friends gathering.

Staff were courteous and did not bother us too much, which we preferred and appreciated.

The menu is pretty extensive, which can accommodate picky eaters like me. They also do daily specials. Prices are very reasonable for the popular location by the water.

Tons of people were ordering pizza, which smelled so invitingly. Will need to try that next time I'm back.

$22 Rigattoni were tasty, drowning in delicious sauce. For anyone who loves a lot of sauce--this is a place for you! There's nothing worse than restaurants that are stingy with their sauce.

$26 veal cutlet stuffed with prosciutto and mozzarella was a winner. The portion was a medium size, enough to fill you up, but not too big to stuff you till the brim. The cutlet is best devoured while hot, so the mozzarella oooozes out of the meat. Delicious white wine sauce reduction for the meat. Side of roasted potato wedges and carrots & asparagus were surprisingly delicious. I am not a fan of such simple veggies [because most of the time they are not cooked properly], but I thoroughly enjoyed these flavorful veggies!

The only downside was that the food was a bit too salty. Prepare to get dehydrated and drink tons of water after your meal.

The only inconvenient aspect worth noticing is that there is only one bathroom stall for the entire restaurant. The bathroom is clean and atmospheric, with fragrant candles and live orchids. But the fact that you have to wait in line to use it, is very inconvenient, especially when the restaurant is full.

Will be back to try more on their menu!
Came here with a friend. Not a bad place. The appetizer was the best part. The pizza was great. But the pasta was the disappointing part. Will try to come back and give it another go.

3 stars for food and wine and 1 additional star for service. We came here around 8:30ish on a Saturday night half expecting to be turned away as we had no reservations. But these guys have done such a good job of the outdoor seating and were able to find us a table right away even though the restaurant was bustling. We got a fish dish and mushroom pizza - while the quality of the food was good, there just was no seasoning at all. We had to salt everything we ate. It's a good spot if you are in the seaport area and are in the mood for Italian - be prepared to season though!

This place is perfect! My new favorite italian spot in new york. We got two delicious pastas and a bottle of wine. Service was great, atmosphere is nice, and overall a great place to catch up with friends or go on a date.
Delicious, best calamari ever.  Price is great and the service is wonderful.   Cool spot for outdoor dining.

I truly know nothing about this restaurant, it just showed up one day on caviar and didn't even have a Yelp review. I decided to give it a shot and really enjoyed my meal. The first time I ordered, I had the Carbonara pizza, which I barely remember devouring. I know I liked it and I'd say that the pizza is a good size for two reasonably hungry individuals. If you are only going to get one pizza, perhaps you both get a Caesar salad too. It has shreds of sun dried tomatoes, which are a very nice touch. Also the salad has crunchy and airy croutons and the dressing tastes homemade. It has that great Caesar anchovy punch to it. Tonight I ordered from them a second time and this time got the pepperoni pizza. The pizza was slightly over sauced for me (especially as I prefer white pizzas), but still really delicious. I would order both pizzas again and the Caesar is definitely worth the repeat order.

Located inside Pranzo in Eataly that will be open from 11/2 to 12/31, Il Tartufo is a pop-up that showcases Pranzo's pasta dishes with the amazing Urbani Tartufi's d'Alma white truffles!  I was able to come here for lunch on Eataly's famous Truffle Day (was only on 2 specific Sundays), so I was pretty excited that it happened to be on one of the days we were in town for!  The menu is limited and offers some appetizers, pastas, and a dessert.  In addition, any of the dishes can include a 4oz shaving of the white truffles, with a $38 supplement.  We tried Gnocchi alla Romana with the white truffles, which were two baked Semolina and Parmigiano Reggiano dumplings (which were more like square polenta cakes) with a poached egg and sautéed spinach - the hubs wasn't much of a fan, but I thought it was a very light and clean dish.  The 'dumplings' were soft and seasoned well, and the combination of the egg, spinach, and the truffle was yummy!  We also had the Fazzoletti al Ragù di Pollo e Porcini with the truffle supplement, which was housemade fazzoletti pasta with Parmigiano Reggiano - usually, this is tossed with a chicken ragù and porcini mushrooms, but our server, Miguel, suggested us opting for a butter sauce to enhance the flavor of the truffles (as the ragu would mask it) - he was right!  The butter sauce was light and flavorful, and the combination of the Parm and the truffle shavings was tasty! Service was super friendly and attentive, and Mr. Maurice, who was one of the main hosts, was very welcoming and made sure we got a special seating on a busy morning!  The restaurant is very open and bright, but is still intimate - I love that there is an open kitchen where you see the chefs preparing your dishes.  The cool thing is that there is a TV monitor that shows a live feed of a bird's eye view of the preparation of the dishes!  Just make sure you have reservations as this place is solidly booked!

+pop-up restaurant in Pranzo, inside Eataly
+runs from 11/2 to 12/31
+ask for Mr. Maurice!!! :D
+ask for Miguel :D
+friendly service!
Solid pasta, service in a pleasant atmosphere. Love it! Saddle up to the bar and grab some plates to sample with your crew. Let us full and happy.

Pleasantly surprised by this place!

It's a seat-yourself counter inside Eataly near Madison Square park with set pasta + sauce combos and a rotating monthly pasta!

We got the tagliatelle and bigoli. Wouldn't get the tagliatelle again because it was too thin for my liking, broke apart while eating and was too soft, no chew. Bolognese was just meh too.

BUT THE BIGOLI omg it was SO good. A little spicy, a little creamy, and SO flavorful. Clams are chopped and incorporated into pasta already, no shells involved.

I am def going back for the bigoli
Food is great. Serving size is okay. The water, they charge $8 for. They have these amazing Cole cole which is 5$, worth the price.

Slightly pricey for the portion sizes, but a popular and delicious spot! It'll definitely be a wait to get a seat on the weekends, but we came for dinner on a Tuesday and there was plenty of space. We started with the tigelle ($9), two small prosciutto and cheese sandwiches. The tonnarelli cacio e pepe ($21) was super flavorful. The agnolotti del plin ($28) came with an amazing sauce. Of course, the pasta was perfectly textured and chewy. For drinks, the il mulo dal sud ($16) was strong and refreshing. The only downside was that we were still hungry at the end, but we still had an enjoyable meal here!

If you want to impress your out of towners, a trip to Eataly is an easy ticket to do so. And, if you are fortunate to grab a seat at the counter at il Pastaio, you and your friend will be invited to a carb induced heaven. I was feeling cacio e pepe on my most recent trip, especially knowing it would be made properly and not with any unnecessary ingredients. Fresh pasta, properly executed... you'll be seeing stars. The price point, for a quick counter setting is a bit higher than you'd expect, but at least you won't be sitting there for hours racking up a higher bill. It's really just a good spot to grab a quick, delicious bite, washed down with a nice glass of wine. You'll have to save your aspirations for dolce fa niente at another spot (perhaps La Birreria is you can grab a rez)

Came here for a quick lunch while in NYC for a girls trip. We were sold when we saw them hand shaping the pasta right in front of the seating area/bar. My friends and I each ordered something different so we could try multiple things. We had the Con Tortufu Triangoli, Con Ragu Di Salsiccia, and Agnolotti Del Plin. All were delicious and the perfect serving size. Definitely recommend!

My favorite spot to stop buy after shopping. Fresh made pasta.

Alex, our server, was super friendly, courteous n knowledgeable. All his suggestions were perfect n delicious!

It's a treat! A piece of Italy n NY. Cone browse Eataly, n then rest yr feet n have a sip n bite of Italy's finest.

We came here on a Friday night and grabbed the last two seats by the bar (it gets busy!) We ordered two pasta and a glass of wine but according to other reviews they supposed to give out bread and olive oil? We never got that. The pasta took a long time to prepare and not the best pasta I've had.. seems to be overpriced for the portion as well. There wasn't any service provided throughout our dinner, staff just chatting with each other or on their phone.

Bar table wasn't cleaned as i saw a couple beef crumbs that's left from previous customers.

The vibe is 4 star- unique and best for tourists and friends catching up. Not sure I would come back for the food, maybe for the grocery in the store.
Attaching picture to my original post. Still one of my favorite spots and can't wait to come back!

The food is Five Stars, the service is 3. If the tables are full, just wait a second for someone to finish.

You need to order the fresh mozzarella appetizer. It was the perfect way to start the meal.

Don't worry, when you order and mispronounce the Italian words the server will quickly and quite annoyingly correct you.

The price is okay. The portions are perfect. You will leave full, not stuffed like other places.

Crowded surroundings? Yes! BUT you get the feel that you're in your own little bubble sitting at the pasta bar - in some cozy quaint Italian grandma recipes only restaurant while dressed casual sipping a fine glass of wine or a delicious imported Italian beer. F'ng NYC can get away with this. I love This place.

The pasta is fresh and delicious - the bread and olive oil also yummy 1 Bring good company & enjoy the good vibes!
Amazing homemade pastas!!! You can watch them make the pasta I. Front of you- and the wine flight's are amazing! I go there alone and my girls live it sooo much too
Pasta was great - nice bite to it but was a bit overcooked, past the point of al denté. Clams were nicely prepared and seasoned.

Delicious pasta dishes. First come first serve place, so there is sometimes a wait, but it's worth it. Pasta is always fresh and al dente. I had a braised rabbit ragu with Mafaldine pasta and it was great. Some nice appetizers too. But if you don't want pasta, they don't serve anything else for an entree.

This place is definitely open, not sure why it says it's closed. I came here for an early dinner one evening for a date. Place was super packed so most of the restaurants and counters were full. We picked this one because it looked cute, had a pair of open seats on the bar table. Honestly, you could toss a rock and where ever it lands will be a good pick.

Were greeted right away with fast and friendly service.

Ordered a bottle of red wine, carbernet franc, and honestly, the price was decent for both quality and the fact that it's in a restaurant. It wasn't too terribly marked up. All regions of Italy are represented here.

Got the Porri E Pistacchi to start. Fantastic. Goat cheese balanced out the leeks. The pistachios were a nice added crunch and nutty flavor.

Date and I had the Cacio e Pepe. Delizioso! Romano and pecorino cheese blends a nice salty and creamy flavor to the perfectly cooked pasta. Also got the tagliatelle. Beef was tender and aged well. The prosciutto added a nice saltiness to complement the beef's juiciness.

They accidentally brought us out the trenette, which we didn't order. I ate it anyways, and they caught their mistake and decided not to charge us for it. That's grade A service. It was also pretty good, although I'd say it was my least favorite of the bunch, even though I loved them all! I'm not a big pesto fan, as I found it overwhelming my palate. Also there was too much of it, making the texture feel like I was eating a basil smoothie.

Overall, spent $135 before tip, so not bad for a big dinner for 2. I was completely satisfied and the experience was amazing. Check out my review on Eataly as well!
Popped in for lunch and was blown away by caramelle con suga di zucco - pasta with ricotta in squash sauce with pumpkin seeds!!! 5 stars!!!

So we came here ( downstairs ) because the rooftop did not open on the time even though we had a reservation because they supposing were changing from fall to winter . That day was October 31st. Yes I know what you are thinking.... plus no one called me to inform me of the reservation cancellation... I know I know what you are think

So to calm down ... we found this place not far from the rooftop entrance.

Casual - bored with bar stool seating

Immediately I could tell that this place was gonna be awesome

Staff was super awesome

Wine was excellent

Watching staff make homemade pasta in front of our eyes was cool!

We opted to try to appetizers since we thought we were gonna eat upstairs . Very good!

I wished we stayed here .... honestly since the rooftop was disappointing except for the decorations

I will be back to try the pasta  and have more yummy wine here

I came for the eataly restaurant event (separate from restaurant week but same idea) and I ordered the bruschetta and agnolotti. The food was fine and prices are pretty reasonable (with the event discount which I believe was $25 for both dishes) and I was full by end. I'm not very familiar with Italian food so I cannot comment on authenticity but everything taste OK but not amazing. The service was OK although the waiter was noticeably busy and it took longer than expected to get water, bread, food, etc.

First time heading into NYC since the pandemic started. I just thought we'd walk around to see where we can eat. Everywhere you look there are many options for outdoor dining and they are all set up nicely.

Having never been to Eatery Flatiron, we decided to dine at il Pastaio. The host was nice enough to seat us 10 minutes early.

Here is what we ordered:
- Prosciutto di Parma - the housemade Stracciatella cheese, prosciutto and pizza bread (so buttery) is what made this one of the best pizzas I ever had. This is what I would expect to eat in Italy. Every bite had me wanting another taste. Order this.

- Fried zucchini flowers are filled with cheese (Caciocavallo) and was a lovely surprise. My son loved it. It was lightly fried and delicate.

- Linguine Con Aragosta with Maine lobster fell short for us. The noodles were way too al dente. I know it must've been an oversight on their part to serve it this way. But the sauce and everything else in this dish worked.

A waiter took noticed that the sun was shining onto us and asked if we would like more shade. He moved the sandbags and a huge umbrella stand to have it closer to us. That was awfully sweet and much appreciated. Service throughout was stellar and super friendly.

Make sure to stop by the market afterwards. There are tons of imported Italian goods.

Seats are first come first serve.  People often like to leave gaps between parties and the establishment won't do much to make people move over so more people can sit and eat. You have to say something yourself.  Also, if the "maitre d" asks around and tries to find someone who is about to finish their meal, do not rely on them either.  Had we not gone out of our way to put together two separated, but empty seats at one section, we would have waited easily another 30 minutes for a couple who had already paid their bill and said they were gonna get up, but didn't. Don't be those jerks, when you're sitting in a desirable, limited seating area, already paid your bill, and are just wasting time on your phone. YMMV with seating; goodl uck.

In any case, we chose this particular part of Eataly because of the larger pasta selection that could not be had elsewhere on site. I was going to get the Agnolotti del plin for $19, since its not everyday I eat veal, but the guy next to me got it and it didn't look appealing. Even with the picture of the pasta in the menu, its hard to know what it'll look like until its in front of you. I ended up getting the Tagliatelle. It came with Beef and Prosciutto di Parma DOP for $18. I only tasted beef, but it was a good dish. Not the fanciest noodle, but the meats sounded good. Perhaps I'll do the veal next time anyway.

Oh and the casrecca has a nice sauce on it. If only it had meat.

This is another restaurant within Eataly. All of the seats in this restaurant are at a bar. There are no reservations and no apparent organized list or control on customer seating. We were fortunate to find seats with only a short wait. Larry R was our server, and he helped us understand the menu and gave recommendations. We shared two small plates and an entree. The small plates were Melanzane In Agrodolce and Carote Pastaio. The Melanzane was eggplant, tomatoes, pine nuts, and onion. The Carote was roasted carrots, over whipped Calabro Ricotta with sunflower seed. Both the small plates were unique and very good. The entree was Tagliatelle. It came with beef and Prosciutto di Parma DOP Aged 18 Months. All were delicious. While waiting for our meal to be prepared, we were entertained watching a staff member make Cappellacci Di Zucca. These are "little hats" made from an egg pasta ravioli filled with butternut squash. This was the best of my meals at Eataly restaurants this visit.

Holy delicious!

My friends and I wanted to grab a glass of wine before starting our day so I suggested Eataly. We weren't planning on eating as we had plans to go have bagels right after, but the pasta just looked so damn good we ordered an entree and shared.

We ordered the beets along with the casarecce pasta dish. The beets were great and a refreshing addition to our carb-heavy weekend. The Casarecce was AMAZING!!! I thought it would be too heavy, but the sauce was perfectly portioned. The pasta was truly al dente and was the best pasta I've ever had!!!

The best part of this meal was sitting at the bar watching the chefs make fresh pasta. It made our food taste that much better knowing where it came from :) Highly recommend this place!

I had an excellent asparagus salad.  I think the green and white asparagus are cooked perfectly with probably blanched long thin strips or maybe raw strips of asparagus on top.  The dressing is lemon based with lots of medium shaved Parmesan cheese on top.

The noodles I had were like ribbon noodles with a prosciutto sauce minced into bits.  There is no tomato sauce in it.  There are some bitter greens in it.

The prettiest pasta I ever did eat. Pricey but delicious. I ordered the ravioli and the waiter recommended a perfect glass of Fiano white wine. The cacio e pepe was also great! It's a nice, quick meal, but I would probably go somewhere less expensive with bigger portions next time.

Great dining experience in the city. I've had Eataly on my "to try" list for years. Stopped in for lunch over the weekend and we didn't need to wait too long for a seat. Seats are close together which gave it that cute cafe feel. We ordered the specialty calzone for an appetizer; it was huge! More doughy if anything else but not bad. I had cacio e pepe as my entree. It was my first time ordering that anywhere so I don't have much to base it off of but it reached my expectations. Very cheesy and definitely peppery! I really enjoyed. My friend enjoyed her entree or choice as well. Everything tasted really fresh. I'd definitely return!

Sure...the ambiance is nice and the views are awesome. The service sucks (we waited 20 mins to get water when everyone else had water already on their table), the food was so-so and when we discovered an eyelash in one of the pastas they didn't even take it off the bill. 1/10 would not recommend.

Italian restaurant does not have any garlic??? What??? Yes it's true.
We ordered a ragu pasta & the pepper pasta. When my bf's pepper pasta arrived we right away noticed a hair!! I politely pointed it out to our server, he took the dish & there was a heated discussion in the kitchen. We received a fresh one shortly after. No apology, no free drink or anything! I thought it was kinda rude!

Fresh mozzarella was amazing, $6.

Agnolotti del plin-$19 Saffron veal ravioli was so good. The best I ever had. It was so tender and taste so good.

Tonnarelli cacio e pepe $16 was very basic. I was not a fan of this. But the agnolotti was just so good. I would come back just for agnolotti.

Service was good. You have to wait for the bar to open up and you get the watch the chef prepare the dishes in an open kitchen.

Food is delicious!

Definitely a good choice if you enjoy a nice seat at the bar.

Grab a glass or a bottle of wine. Service is efficient. I like the open kitchen.

Appetizers are well priced - get the fresh mozzarella!

Pasta dishes were delicious. Definitely get the tagliatelle!

Presentation is nice and portions a not huge but filling.

I would recommend grabbing a seat closer to the pasta making counter - sometimes you'll see them making pasta in front of you which is awesome.

My favorite Eataly restaurant for sure!

Great dining experience! Watch pasta being made and shaped in front of your eyes as you eat lots of delicious fresh food.

No reservations, only eating at the bar first come first served.

We went on Friday at 6pm and grabbed some stools straight away, I think we were lucky, but it's not impossible!

Worst lunch -- if you could even call it that. Tiny portions, pizza cold, and the rest of the meal never came although others around us were happily eating what we ordered. You're paying for the Eataly name but Lidia, you should be embarrassed.  Save your money and find a real restaurant to have lunch.

I am drooling still thinking about their pasta. My coworker and I were exploring the city during a work trip and stopped in here for lunch. We decided to try this place on a whim since a couple of seats conveniently opened up as we walked by. I ordered the Agnolotti Del Plin which has veal meat and my coworker ordered the Tagliatelle which has beef and prosciutto. The pastas were so good that we practically inhaled our meals after taking the first bite. The texture of the pasta was perfect - not too soft and not too hard - and also provided great tenderness and flavor.

My only complaint is that although the staff was very friend, the service was a bit slow and it was difficult to flag someone down to ask for something. Overall, still a fantastic place and I would come back.

Pasta Pasta Pasta

As I was waiting (patiently) for my shopping wife and daughter and seats I watched one of their pasta chefs put a large pizza sized lump of dough into a pasta press and after each adjustment and many passes it was like tissue paper and about five feet long...mesmerizing.

Across the street from the famous Flat Iron Building inside of Eataly (world's largest Italian market) we find Il Pastaio their brand new pasta wine and beer bar.

Turns out it's their "soft opening" featuring their many handmade fabulous pasta dishes a few beers and one red and one white wine all offered a an opening 20% discount...nice touch.

They feature many different sizes and shapes of pastas handmade from old country recipes (some from the 1500's) and flours.  You can even watch the preparation on their over head mirror over the pasta prep table angled so the bar peeps can see.

They have a nice menu offering groupings each of traditional pastas from the North Central South regions of Italy.

Their new granite topped bar with comfortable soft stools is nice and complete with purse hooks under...nice touch.  Held my girls jettisoned shopping bags easily and safe.

I noticed a small man that looked like an Italian chef as he personally checked and sometimes tasted (clean spoon) every dish that came off the line...cudos.

Our warm freindly server Rianna provided experienced descriptions along with fabulous service...a keeper.

Here's the thing I'll Pastaio is right in the middle of a very busy scene yet it somehow felt very personal.  

That's good hiring training skill and team work.  

I'll Pastaio is off too a great start and a bright future.

A very distinguished well dressed older gentleman (managed) stopped us as we were leaving and asked how our experience had been.  Great we assured him and related that we were regulars at Eataly even from Seattle.

He then confided that they were opening an Eataly in Las Vegas and LA but he would put a good word in for the Pacifuc Northwest.

Ciao,
Ricardo y Julia

Some of the worse serving staff I've experienced in years. Two hosts and four servers at their patio dining area. I was sat with no menu nor direction to scan a QR code. After about a solid ten minutes of watching the servers walk past me without saying a word. I finally stopped one to say I would like a menu and water. Once those were given, I sat for another ten minutes before someone came to take my order. At this point I stayed to see how they could continue to tank my experience. The food came about 15 min after I ordered and the pasta was really good (thankfully). Midway through my meal I asked for the check because I just knew it would take a while to get it to me, and I was right. I finished my meal and still was waiting for the check. It's pretty crazy how they had maybe 8/14 tables sat and most people had been there before me. So in my mind I didn't understand why the service was so slow and lack luster. They only get two stars because of the food. I say order ahead, take it Togo and find a nice sitting area around the restaurant.

Authentic Italian pasta. Incredible options in the the menu. We tried 3 pastas the cacho e Pepe tortelini and the veal egg ravioli and the smoked onion and pecorino with potato puree ravioli type. Please note that I'm calling these ravioli but that's not the real names lol. Everything was delicious the veal stuffed ravioli type was my favorite. The servers are nice and the wine selection is great. The prices are a bit steep for the portion sizes but I guess that's to be expected.
Came here on a cold rainy night for some warm pasta and red wine. The Cacio e pepe was absolutely rich and delicious and definitely warmed me up!

Really cool place, simple food simple menu you sit at the bar with your group and, have your own little world. in the mood for a quick bite of food made from scratch? this is the place to go.

They also offer pasta/mozzarella making classes which is awesome!!!

Cutest pasta bar in the middle of the Eataly market. I love the open kitchen set up, it allows you to get a view of the chefs making your meal. I got the Bigoli pasta and a glass of white wine that the server recommended. The pasta portion was pretty small, especially for the price of $18, so you will definitely need antipasti or salad to eat with it. Also be wary of drinking wine then going grocery shopping in an Italian market. I made some serious purchases following the meal haha.

Gladly frequent the pasta restaurant in Eataly several times a month.  It's sometimes a challenge to get a seat as it is self seating, but it's absolutely worth it.  I always start with the Mozzarella appetizer and frequently get the caserecce dish-- a lovely light tomato sauce with basil and almonds.

This restaurant was by far the worst Eataly restaurant I have been to. As we were seated, the manager actually told us to move to make room for other potential customers. After, they barely filled my glass of wine and they took over a half hour to bring us our food. The cauliflower was soggy and the bread was ok. Will not be eating here again.

Awesome food! My second visit here - no complaints. However, I'm very surprised that off-duty employees are allowed to sit at the bar and eat/drink. It really ruins the experience for neighboring diners when the on-duty employees are spending so much time joking/fawning over off-duty employees - the rest of us suffer from a service standpoint. I've worked in many fine restaurants and this was never allowed.

horrible, I ask for a table the girl told me it would be a 10 min wait, I say okay and walk towards the park, she texted saying the table was available, I return to the restaurant only to find out they have given my table away, Horrible service, horrible hostesses, never going back...

Recently we returned to one of our favorite spots in NYC for a quick bite & pre-evening apperitivo. Now as it has been a few years since dining at Il Pesce/Eataly there were some noticeable changes like the removal of the blackboard displaying an array of delicious specials & the venue itself no longer having that warm welcoming feeling/buzz floating in the air we still were able to enjoy some delightful cocktails & appetizers. It is clear with time comes change & although food & beverage remained firm some things like the amazing  "extra umph" feeling we always got when we visited the venue were missed.

While the service was great and the ambience was unique, I had to give this place 2 stars because the food was just ok and extremely expensive. I love Al dente pasta, but my pasta was way undercooked. There were a couple of noodles that were still hard and doughy, and the flavor of the sauce was just not there. I got the clam pasta, but the clams were so finely chopped that you honestly start to doubt if they even added it. We also got the fish plate sampler which was decent but extremely expensive. Overall, with the price and the taste of the food, I would much rather go for other Italian pasta options in Manhattan.

If you want a casual sit down dinner after work, it's a good place to grab a dinner. Food was okay my cod was a little salty for my liking but the flavours are great. We also ordered pasta with pesto and mixed fried seafoods (not in photos) they were both delicious. A bit slow for the service , we have to call them a few times for the bread and condiments because we we're waiting for while. Also we already placed our order at the time. Will come back to try the resto upstairs as you need to book a table in advance, especially on Friday nights. The price was a bit pricey but you guys can come and try it.

A nice experience, although overpriced. It's usually the only place in Eataly where you can easily find a table. The food was tasty but super small portions for the size. The di Mare seafood salad ($19) is pre-made so not really worth the steep price for a salad, but the Linguine al Pesto Genovese ($20) had a great texture. We came during the summer cocktail fest and had $10 drinks, which were great! The servers were friendly as well.

Il Pesce located near the fish section at Eataly in Flatiron is Italian seafood focused restaurant serving fresh fish and pasta. For appetizers we ordered a spicy shrimp skewer, incredibly tender calamari and arancini. For mains we ordered orecchiette with broccoli rabe, chili and crispy breadcrumbs for texture. The quality of the seafood really shines through here but the pasta was also perfectly Al dente and balanced. Il Pesce is a lively spot to enjoy some great seafood, wine and pasta

Visited on weekday afternoon. It was pretty empty. I was excited to try this place as I walked by it so many times!! The only part that I did not like was service part... it's definitely a tourist place.. the restaurant was pretty empty....

Fried calamari and veggie platter was pretty fresh. I liked how this was seasoned. Great texture and fried just right. Herbs tasted fresh. Veggies were mediocre. I wish it was little less fried, but that's my preference. Hope you can try this one day.

Linguine alle Vongole tasted pretty good. I liked it overally but salty, sea flavor was too much.. i wanted to ask for anything that could lessen the flavor, but I couldn't find the server for a while.. I just ate it..

Overall, I think it was okay but I would want to try other places too

Usually we eat at Serra when in Italy but today after a long say sightseeing and shopping - just wanted a quick bite in a casual setting and this was the perfect place.

We were able to grab a table amongst the chaos that is Eataly during the holidays and service is fast, and easy! We enjoyed local beers and some Prosecco and three good dishes : oysters - perfectly shucked, delicious and fresh, only thing I would have changed was the mignonette which was slightly overwhelmed by white pepper. We also had crudo and a lovely steaming dish of mussels.

Food was great, as was service and prices are definitely great for fresh seafood in the heart of NYC!

Serve fresh veggies, soup is good,a bit on salty side, seafood risotto tastes great. They allow to order half salad, lunch special has many choices, good value for money.waitress is courteous. Highly recommended. Meet my expectations.

Nice Italian seafood, walk in and friendly staff. I loved its fried calamari, the squid ink pasta with shrimps was had much ink and was too fishy, I had to change it and the staff were very accommodating. I would love to stop by for a quick calamari bite.

My waiter was fantastic and always on point and made excellent recommendations to me in everything. As a former fine dinner waiter with Sommelier certifications I do really appreciate Tony Juan G tonight. Hostesses we're excellent and let me leave all my bags up front. I found out my apartment has brown sewer water  coming out of the taps too. AsI am going home now to a nightmare I really appreciate it and big thanks  to all the staff at La Pizza and La Pasta.

Thanks again for everything

Sincerely

Patricia Conway

Was in the area, knew of Eataly, and wanted some Italian food!

This place was definitely pricy, but was interesting for a first time experience.

Upon entering, you sit down first and then the server will serve you. Not sure if it's because we looked like/are students, but the staff seemed to disregard us a bit since we didn't look the most upscale in the room. We did have to wait a little while for service while others seemed to be attended to faster, but could just be the impact of COVID or other matters.

The waiter we had though was kind and helped us choose between dishes. We ordered the oysters and the spaghetto pasta. Both were yummy with the spaghetto being our favorite. For being around $22, the pasta was definitely overpriced, but nonetheless also very yummy.

I'd say our experience was good for a first-time Eataly experience, but for the amount we paid, we could definitely get more at another place.
A little pricey. Ambiance was nice for a late dinner. Recommended wine was excellent.  Overall good experience.

RIP Sad! But I suppose all good things must come to an end.

This used to be one of the best , reasonably priced fish restaurants in NY..
Monday was full of the cities chefs , testament to its inside, in-the-know status.  

Firstly, they got rid of seasonal & local fresh catches  SPECIALS  .. best thing about the place.

Prices have doubled & even the Fritto Misto (now $35!) is a pale imitation of its former glory .. on my recent visit I got three shrimp @ the rest was salmon! & Veggies ( See photo)
I mean, deep fried Salmon YUCK!

False advertising .. used to be just Shrimp, Calamai & lemon .. no mention of Verdura / veggies  on menu but I guess no one is gonna sue.

It used to be ALL FISH & REALLY great

I'm so sad.  I will miss it.

RIP
No accommodations for allergies.  If you have nut allergy or shellfish allergy, do not come.  Service is poor.  Seems like customers bother them.  Ambiance is great due to being part of Eataly.

This is another restaurant within Eataly that features seafood. We were fortunate to find a table since they do not take reservations. It took a while for our server to attend to our table. The restaurant was very busy. For starters we shared a Rucola e Finocchio salad. It had arugula, fennel, with a vinaigrette dressing. Our entrees were Cozze di Limone  and Linguine alle Vongole. The cozze was mussels with lemon, onion, parsley, white wine, grilled homemade bread. The mussels were good and plentiful.  The linguini included clams poached in olive oil with lemon and parsley. All were good.

The food is pretty good but their instructions are really confusing. Their signs say to seat yourself but they really mean to get online and wait for someone to seat you. We sat down, as the sign in the picture says but then they made us get up and get on line just so they could put us in the same seats as before ... but I did like my squid ink chitarra though and the wine recommendation by the waiter was great. So if you're going to come here, make sure you don't seat yourself...

We had a bad experience Serra and we left hungry . One of the persons working there head that we want to eat there but we thought they were close and he said we can seat and he found us a table . We order two glasses of wine and the muscles and  we got to  enjoy it . We wish we have gone there since the beginning instead of the other place . Everyone was working hard and they actually care about their clients

There's one good thing to say about this place: The mussels are excellent. If that's what you're in the mood for, make it clear to them up front that you're on an unwavering mission. Otherwise they will try to upsell you at every opportunity. The alla Vongole had but a few little clam bits in a heavily over-salted sauce (had to spoon in the broth from the mussels to make it edible). Two of us were sitting over the last of our upsold large (never given a choice) carbonated water while our third used the rest room and this jerk of a waiter comes over to tell us we've got to get going because he needs the table for others customers. Then he tries to scoop up our third's half-full glass. Made sure she took time to savor it on her return and we won't be back. Plenty of other choices in Eataly.

Located in the middle of Eataly. Its bar seating n It's great place and very welcoming if you are dining alone. Service is attentive n friendly n efficient.  I had Aperol spritz n arugula fennel salad. Perfect for summer. I would  definitely come back.

We wanted to eat at another spot but the wait time was really long so we came to Il Pesce. We sat at the bar and had to wait so long for someone to bring us menus or take our order when there were only two other people there. I got the swordfish I believe and my friend got a pesto pasta dish. The fish was very dry and chewy, the worst part was how salty it was. I couldn't finish it, the olives on top just made it even saltier. The pasta was alright, nothing to write home about. I wouldnt suggest this spot, there are so many better places at Eataly.

Came here because the menu at the rooftop was not exciting.

Staff was friendly and efficient

I had the tagliatelle- which was good  . Friend had the swordfish and loved it .

We also shared a dozen oysters which were good

Food is decent. Is it outstanding? No. Portion? Ridiculously small for the price, but fine with me. Not a big portion eater anyway but my fitness were complaining. One of our party ordered steak. Although taste was decent you ought to see the size of strake. How dare you call that a steak  it's more one small strip. Size about 4" width .75" height and -1" depth. It's pathetic. We all laughed once we saw the size of steak. Although she said taste was good but too small. And she's a petite lady, Iif she says small portion for most of us it will barely be an appetizer size. Lol. Service was okay once we sat down. Although waiting online not a great experience. Most of them tossing their duty to each other it was actually disarrayed performant! Ambience as you can imagine noisy food market. Lol. What do you expect. Everyone passing by looking at the food you order, some makes comments some ignore. Open market food view. We are fine with it but just in case if you want to be a bit more private this is not a place for you. Overall good is okay, service can deal with price ridiculous!

The meal I had here was very good, but the chaotic environment and high prices make this a restaurant I feel most can skip.

Eataly is a wonderful place, full of both hard to find and common items, many of exceptional quality. In a lot of ways it's a one stop shop even with the Italian focus (on certain days, for example, the bakery makes challah bread). But eating there was an experience that felt overwhelming. Even with the restaurants strategically placed away from much of the grocery crowds, it's a constantly moving, loud environment. I had a seat at the edge of the bar and felt the servers  and patrons fast pace and energy at all times, and had to really try and focus on the food without allowing myself to adopt the same speed with my fork.

The oysters were fresh and delicious, but thought the mignonette was overpowered by vinegar. The buttery salmon tartar was dressed with amazing olive oil and a subtle sweetness from incorporated pieces of diced pears (they don't give you enough toast points though, and asking for more proved to be difficult). The vegetarian lasagna was interesting, in a good way. Richer than you would expect for being so green, and the haricot verts inside worked well- they were small, and tender but not mushy. Just don't let the vegetables fool you, this is still a heavy dish.

Unobtrusive  generally upbeat music played at a reasonable volume, some pop rock was thrown in. If the restaurant was elsewhere, I would be back, but I think this will likely be my only visit.

I have to give a shout out to the staff at il Pesce for saving an awful experience at Serra. We left Serra still hungry and thirsty, but couldn't find a table anywhere downstairs. One of the workers overheard us and they made a table just for us. It was super nice since they were closing in less than 15 minutes.

We had two glasses of Pinot Grigio and their dinner serving of their mussels. Overall the food was very good and much better than upstairs. The serving team was solid and did a nice job attending to us. We only wish we had started here and skipped Serra!  Thanks to their team for saving our night!!!!

I've been to Eataly in the Century City location, but I've never actually dined inside before. My coworker wanted me to experience the food, so we picked Il Pesce for some seafood.

To be quite honest, Eataly is slightly overwhelming if it's your first visit. I can see how it's organized, but with massive crowds everywhere, I lost my sense of direction. We managed to find the host for Il Pesce and were instantly seated.

I ordered the appetizer mussells and an aperol spritz. The meal came with a piece of buttered, hearty rustic bread, which I really enjoyed. Mussells were just okay because a couple of them tasted quite fishy. Kind of bummed that mussells were not that fresh. The broth settling at the bottom was also not that flavorful. I was hoping for more seafood or tomato essence. Aperol spritz was bitter, so I gave half to my coworker.

Overall, I didn't think Il Pesce was worth the time or money. Dishes and drinks were definitely overpriced with mediocre flavors. The only thing I liked throughout my entire meal was the piece of rustic bread.
Definitely not the best. Could do far better. Waiter threw cups and plates all over our table. Food was very mediocre. Cheap oysters though! Would I come again? Nope, don't think so.

Went for Daily Prix Fixe Lunch

Food - 5/5. The bread had great chew and the dip had the slight burning sensation you get from quality olive oil. Pesce crudo was flounder of which the flavor was really brought out by the salt and oil. Pesce azzuro was roasted well with crispy skin and firm meat. The blue fish by itself is very strong but the sweetness of the eggplant caponata matches well with it.

Service - 3/5. The staff seemed a little inattentive as service was fairly slow.
