Another rather odd thing was that the brunch menu's "seasonal" features from the summer carried over into the autumn (like gazpacho, pea shoots and so on). The dish we had (a battered mushroom, in a veggie take on chicken and waffles) was tasty but quite dry, and we would have loved to be able to get a side of cooked greens.
If they roll out a fresh spring brunch menu when it is warm enough for outdoor dining, and if there are vegetarian options, I will definitely give them another chance. In the meantime, I will enjoy the pastries.

This place is truly a great warm and  homie place to experience and the food has never disappointed I came here to try the salmon eggs Benedict and I was shocked how fresh and delicious it was. I had to come back to give the lunch menu a try and again it was delicious I tried the shrimp wrap (which I have no doubt would be great the way it comes) but I added chicken to it which they said would be  no problem and it turned out a 10/10 the shrimp was perfectly cooked and tasted extremely fresh the chipotle Mayo was the perfect amount and the chicken complemented it really well. my husband had the chicken sandwich and he was very happy with it the chicken was a thick crispy piece and was very juicy We also ordered the Mac and cheese and added bacon in it anddddd man oh man it was a home run!  I definitely recommend inwood farm. I wish they would get on Uber eats for those who unfortunately can't come in themselves it's a must try for everyone in the neighborhood

Best burger Uptown!  Absolutely love this place for dinner and breakfast. My family and I have been coming here for 5 years. Greatly appreciate the much much improved food quality. The only reason I did not mentioned 5 stars is due to the (somewhat) bad attitude staff behind the counter.  That is certainly not always the case, but does happen occasionally.

I'm not entirely sure how this place is rated 3.9 stars?!?!   That is a crashing shame, because it is amazing!!

First of all, it's in the West Village (which is a cool vibe all the way around), has a really cool vibe and the service...off the hook.

Fantastic food, good wine selection and come prepared to leave full, satisfied and ready for bed!!

5 star all the way...don't skip this place!!!
Great food, ambiance and service. Authentic Italian food and a great place for a large group.  It's always crowded because the restaurant is just that good- make a reservation in advance.

We were accommodated for a late reservation but very much were made to feel like they were doing us a favor and we honestly would have preferred they turned us away and not looked to take our money. Food was uneven and good but not memorable and for the prices, would have expected better. We were given a dirty plate and courses removed before we could finish.  Sadly we live nearby and have wanted to dine here for years and cannot see us returning. The restaurant also accommodated a large table of Kendall Roy bros adjacent to our tiny table of three who were doing shots and whooping it up which was surprising and not the vibe we thought it would be. Plenty of other lovely Italian places in NYC who treat their customers with amore and graciousness which we'll patronize and send friends to

Very nice ambiance.  Quiet, not rushed, candlelit.
Good service, making solid recommendations.
Pappardelle was great.  Veal was very salty and overcooked.  
Shell ice cream dessert was okay.

Probably my favorite Italian restaurant in Manhattan, especially if you love amazing pasta. From the moment you walk in you are greeted by the friendly and charming Maitre D who makes you feel welcome immediately, and are in a dark and moody environment which created the perfect dinner vibe.

The food was amazing, and the service spectacular. Even the bread basket was delicious, as well as the amuse bouche our waiter brought us. I got the "Pappardelle Alla Buttera" but subbed the pappardelle with a rigatoni noodle. This pasta dish was 5 stars, cooked perfectly with a creamy pink sauce w sausage and peas. We also got the pistachio tartufo dessert which was divine, and the perfect way to end the meal.

Next time I'm in Manhattan I'll definitely be heading back to Il Cantinori for another 5 star dining experience.

Excellent food and service. The ambiance is only fair. Loud noisy no great charm.
Overall highly recommended for foodies!
The food was amazzzzing. Great vibe and cozy restaurant. We will be back. Thank you again.

This place was amazing!!! The service was fantastic and welcoming. The espresso martini was so great. The charred artichoke appetizer was really flavorful. But the lobster pasta special they had that evening was the most amazing dish ive ever had. Every single bite was heavenly and perfectly balanced. They even offered complimentary prosecco for us which was so sweet. Will most definitely come back.

We were visiting from houston and wanted to try a quaint spot for dinner! We were pleasantly surprised with how delicious the food, cocktails, and service was!! The lobster specialty pasta was EVERYTHING! So good. I recommend this place to any and everyone. Can't wait to come back!

Soooo great-the restaurant is fairly crowded up front in terms of spacing but the service was great! Had a great server who was attentive to our needs and it was two peoples' birthdays at dinner too. The Pappardelle was exquisite! I initially thought it was a small serving when it came out and it didn't seem like it would fill me or taste so good but it was delightful. The sauce, the pasta, even the peas were a nice addition which I generally dislike. The dessert was great as well, with pistachio ice cream to really bring in a nice mix of flavors. This is definitely a more romantic/expensive restaurant so I'd advise a good reason to celebrate or date night if you were to come.

Really cute, romantic spot that seemed to be populated by local regulars. There was a buzz in the air that made the ambiance feel electric and comfortable at the same time. Very fast service with excellent quality food. Hearty Italian dishes that, instead of being ground-breaking, are familiar and homey in the best way possible. They also had ENORMOUS floral arrangements that smelled so good. Definitely a spot to return to.
food is very good, very little to choose from on the menu. service is great very attentive. ambiance is perfect.

I never write reviews and have never written a bad review, ever. Even for not great experiences, you want to give the benefit of the doubt it was just a bad day etc but this was next level.

We had a reservation, but were waiting for 5+ min in the restaurant for someone to greet / seat us. When someone finally acknowledges us, we didn't get a welcome etc nothing and we get seated outside when there were a bunch of options inside. Already off to a weird start, it being such a well known restaurant with 4 dollar signs, you usually expect a hospitable greeting. We asked really nicely if we could possibly sit inside, and were ignored. All this stuff usually not a big deal but when you're paying so much money, you expect a different experience.

Our waiter was odd but maybe just busy? Took another 10 minutes to be asked what we even wanted to drink, and we were just drinking waters, it took another 10 to receive those or menus. Waiter sped through the specials, didn't explain the menu at all and overall acted like he wanted to be somewhere else. Our waters tasted like dish soap and then when we actually got our food, he was lingering by our table. Just odd vibes

Food: We order the burrata to start, Cacio Pepe and lambchops. Burrata was pretty good, nothing special but hard to mess up. Cacio Pepe was AWFUL, pasta over cooked / under salted, super watery sauce. It was actually gnarly and they charge $35 for it? Insane even for amazing cacio Pepe but you expect it to be some of the best you've had. Lamb chops were actually the only good part of the meal but served with cold green beans and old potatoes.

Overall - this was probably the worst dining experience my partner and I have ever had. We love to go out to eat and try new restaurants (we were super excited about this one) and it was actually the worst experience on every level. Service, food, and coupled with the absurd prices? Highway robbery.

Don't waste your time, go anywhere else in New York you'll have a better time and better food.

Old school charm and wonderful service is the hallmark of this restaurant.  I have dined at this establishment on numerous occasions and it is always good, without exception.  I have had a selection of their pastas which are always sauced just right.  Recently, I have also had the veal scaloppine which is a enormous hit, the salmone alla mostrada, which is moist and well seasoned, and the pollo arrosto, excellent.

Service is old world and charming; they actually care about their guests without being overly fussy.  Always a treat to dine at this restaurant.

I had really high hopes for Il Cantinori, but unfortunately it fell a bit short of my expectations.

My party of six had a late dinner seating here on a Saturday night. It was easy to make a reservation and our table was ready upon arrival, however, once seated it took quite awhile for us to even get any menus to look at. Once we finally got the menus, our server came over to tell us the "specials", & there ended up being more dishes there than was even offered on the menu. It was a bit frustrating to not be able to see the details of the dishes or how much they cost.

We ended up blind ordering the calamari and trio pasta dishes. The food was mediocre -- calamari was a bit chewy & pasta was room temperature. It's not bad by any means, but definitely not at all worth the price you're paying. You're better off dining somewhere cheaper & getting the same (or even better food).

Nonetheless, our server was great & ambiance was nice with complimentary bread & salami/cheese offerings at the start of the meal & biscottis at the end.

My girlfriend has been raving about this place forever and we finally went there on a Sunday night during Labor Day weekend. It was a bit less busy than usual, but the service was great and food was phenomenal. To start we had the bread with the tomato based bread sauce they offer complimentary. For the appetizer we had the buratta and prosciutto. This was great. For our entrees I had the rabbit and my girlfriend had the pappardelle. Both were great but the pasta was better. After dinner they offered a few cookies / brownies complimentary

I was pleasantly surprised by my visit to Il Cantinori. Right away they hit you with a plate of red sauce, off to a fantastic start and shows they're a real old school joint (Silvio from the sopranos sitting next to us didn't hurt either). We then started with the salad which was great. I don't know what they do to those mushrooms but I wish I could make em like that. Up next was the pasta course which was by far the best part of the meal. The pappardelle alla buttera was one of the best pastas I've had in the city. I personally say it beats the vodka sauce at Carbone and is well worth the expensive price tag. The ravioli was nothing special compared to the other pasta. For mains we had the branzino and the chicken, they were good but nothing noteworthy. Overall the food and service were great and I plan on coming back

This a beautiful restaurant with very attentive service. You can tell the people who work here not only enjoy what they do, but enjoy bringing joy to the people they serve!

The atmosphere is very low light, soft music so if you're looking for a party go elsewhere-- and I mean this is good way. This is the kind of restaurant that you hold hands in and stare into the eyes of your significant other lol.

While you're staring, ORDER THE PASTA! Some of the best pasta I've ever tasted. Which pasta, you ask? Any of it. I sincerely mean that. The chef definitely knows what he's doing. Flavorful, light, delicious. Amazing wine selection as well.

Fellas if you're in the doghouse, this is the way out. Will certainly recommend to our friends!

The sauce is amazing, red sauce but much creamier than the traditional style, a generous amount too. I was only offered main course menu, but they have a good amount of alcohol selection. They provide a basket of bread before order and desserts after meal, very cute desserts!

Il Cantinori is an excellent Italian restaurant off of University Place. Unlike many other Italian places the menu is not huge, which is fine since everything is delicious. The stars thought are the pastas and the risotto.

Timeless spot. Food is so incredible and genuine portions that I could not finish. Experienced immaculate service - our water was always full and there was always food on the table. Come here for a downtown pre-show dinner or on a date.

I wanted to love Il Cantorini because I've heard such great things, but I was disappointed. I found the food to be hit or miss... For example, the Pappardelle was absolutely delicious but the Lemon Ricotta pasta was rock hard and sickly sweet (I could not even get through half of it). I don't know if they were having an off night or if I just ordered the wrong things. I would totally come back and order just the Pappardelle!

The service was more disappointing than the food. Our waiter had a dismissive attitude to the point of being a little rude and we had to ask someone if they could please ask our waiter to come over every single time we needed something, not once did he come over on his own accord. And when I arrived the host asked if I wanted them to store my umbrella since it was pouring rain and my umbrella was dripping. When I left they could not find my umbrella and I went home in the rain sans umbrella. Everyone has bad nights and no one is to blame, I just personally didn't see the hype from my experience at Il Cantorini.
We enjoyed a delicious dinner and the service was incredible!  Aldo was a delight!  We look forward to visiting from Seattle again soon!

A lovely evening from start to finish!
We started with the Zucchini salad which was fresh and bright, perfect on a warm evening.  
  The tomato and bread served as we enjoyed our Montepulciano  was fantastic. I enjoyed the Farfalle, and the Husband had the veal which he said was wonderfully prepared. The Profiteroles were the perfect finale to a wonderful meal. the ambiance and service is old world in the best possible way. We look forward to our next visit.

What's there to say that hasn't already been said? This old school restaurant serves up exquisitely hearty pasta and a rotating delicious variety of appetizers. The last time I came with my boyfriend, we ordered three appetizers and two pasta dishes for just the two of us. We couldn't decide and we had no regrets. I dream of Il Cantinori's pasta!
The best Italian in the city. Old school New York style. The waitstaff are all incredible - particularly Giuseppe! Il cantinori is the best.

Our sunday evening outdoor dining experience was amazing.
Makes you feel like you are in Italy. World class everything! Good for dinner date or group dinner. We love it and will be back soon for sure.

Went there for restaurant week.

I have been to 5 restaurants in restaurant week.

This is the only one that I didn't finish any course.

My friend only ordered salmon (medium) but what he got was a well done salmon.

My sea bass is too sour for me. It's just too ordinary compared to its price tag.

I love the flower arrangement more than the food.

Besides, I went there with a very causal outfit. The manager seated me ( I came to restaurant earlier than my friend) to the worst table location in the restaurant.... narrow... when I saw plenty of table for 4 persons available and also plenty of party of 2 were having dinner in a 4 persons table.

Never wanna go back again.

We just moved to the neighborhood and were excited to check out this restaurant. The food and ambiance were great, and we really loved that part of the experience. However our server was so checked out and rude, seemingly only to us? He was much friendlier with another large table. It definitely soured our dinner despite everything else being great. We'd like to go back and give it another shot, but only when he isn't working.

Lived across the street for years. Off menu shrimp fra diavolo best in city. Staff knows the locals. Celebs are there but only because food is bomb.
Ambiance is classic. Better for parents than first date. Tends to be quiet in the back. Outdoor is nice too.

Loved everything about it. My friend Erika is "the happiest customer" they've ever had. So cheerful and full of joy, so the Manager made sure we got a couple rounds of Prosecco on the house. We had so much food and such great service. Carlos was fantastic and we loved him! My favorite thing was the brown butter asparagus, and then scooping up the remaining brown butter with the bread. Oh yum.  This was my former boss's favorite restaurant when I lived in the city, and I never got to dine here until now. Man, I missed out. I haven't laughed so hard and eaten so well in a long time. What a wonderful evening with girlfriends at a beautiful venue in the village. Thanks to Il Cantinori, I am now missing New York more than ever before.
A nice imitate restaurant. Quiet and romantic. Food was special and delicious. A great neighborhood restaurant but on the pricey side.

Wonderful, old school Italian joint. The food and service are phenomenal. I've eaten there many times, but today I called to buy a bottle of wine for a friend's anniversary and had the pleasure of speaking with Eric. Eric was insanely helpful and super cool. He helped me pick a bottle and made sure the happy couple got it. Did I mention the service is amazing???? Cause it is. Thanks, Eric!!!

Extremely average at best. Waiter seemed annoyed with our presence. We ordered their burrata and it was bland and way too firm. How do you mess that up? I can only assume it's their supplier because Trader Joe's has burrata prepackaged that's 10x better than this. High price restaurant for sub-par quality and experience.

I finally had the chance to eat dinner at Il Cantinori. This place is always, always booked. The food earns 3 stars: it's good but I've had better pasta here in the city ie Marea, Via Carota, Fiaschetteria Pistoia and L'Artusi. Before starting our appetizers, we ate their delicious bread with red sauce and their small charcuterie and cheese plate. We split the sausage broccolini appetizer and the caprese salad, followed by the pappardelle and bolognese pasta. Both pasta dishes are huge, next time we will split a pasta. The service at this place is very good which is why I'm giving them 4 stars.

Really good!

Highly recommend:
1. Buttera pasta
Obviously it has a longer name but I don't remember it... this was really good! The sauce, crumbled sausage, peas, and pasta were so tasty. Really, everything about this dish was fantastic. It's a good portion for one person.

2. Clams
Our table shared the clams in wine sauce and garlic and they were so fresh! Couldn't get enough of these.

3. Dessert
Don't remember the name but it has pistachio gelato and a hazelnut cake. So so so so tasty.

The service was good and the food was great. The place is on the quiet side and has a more mature feel. I probably will bring my parents back here but not come back with friends.
I have been to this place for a long time. The manager Frank is fantastic person and his staff is fantastic. we all had the best time and the food is amazing . thank you frank for a great night

Came at suggestion of a friend during Restaurant Week 2018.
Food, Impression: Formulaic, old school Italian cuisine. Ambiance: Very pretty dining room with beautiful flower arrangement.
Service: Efficient, but not very personable (no one smiles).
Value: Regular menu items seemed high given the pedestrian cuisine.
Summary: No major negatives but nothing special either.

This is a strange review for me. I went here actually with pretty low expectations. This place has been around forever and quite frankly it is like stepping into a bit of a time machine. This is Italian food from a specific era. I'd say 90's Italian food. And the vibe the presentation the staff even make it feel that way. Yes it's a bit snooty and yes it's a bit of a scene and they lose a star because the food is overpriced. But it is in the village at what I'm sure is a costly lease. But why do I give it four stars? The food is surprisingly really good! I had the grilled artichokes and they were balanced and light and lovely. The bruschetta was fresh and refreshing. The gnocchi was seasonal and tasted of early winter but not too heavy. The steak was tasty and well cooked. The presentation is not what you expect these days but the flavor is there. Most places like this lose their touch over time and the food suffers. Not here. I was in fact surprised by the young people who were eating here. A nice retro experience. If you know what to expect o think you will enjoy it.

It's an incredible experience.  When I sat down to order my regular Pinot Grigio - the waiter suggested a tasting of 3 different white wines. "Try something new!" Why not.  I am no wine enthusiast - and appreciated the description and volunteered effort.  This really set the tone for the remainder of our lunch.  No need to mention how fresh and amazing the food is- you just can't go wrong with anything on the menu. And the tables are spacious, so you're not eating and listening to the conversation at the next table.
So delicious. I will never not go here when I'm in NYC!! Was so accommodating to my severe gluten allergy. Best pasta in the city and the staff is so sweet.

Came to Il Cantinori on a Friday night and immediately fell in love due to the phenomenal flower arrangements they have. They add an amazingly fresh scent as you walk through the room before you are hit with an aroma of amazing italian dishes.

Before you even order, the staff at Il Cantinori will place bread, a salami and parmigiano reggiano platter, and individual servings of their homemade tomato sauce on your table. I was practically full by the time the waiter took our order, but nevertheless, it was all amazing. The tomato sauce was pretty good, but it was the long salami (not the round) pieces that blew me away. The parmigiano reggiano was also delicious.

As for the entrees, we ordered the pappardelle, the risotto, and the farfalle. The pappardelle was pretty good--I absolutely loved the texture of their homemade pasta, and the sausage was delicious as well. Overall, the entire dish was ok, but I wasn't a fan of how the peas sweetened the dish. The risotto was my favorite dish since it was so strongly flavored--especially with onions, but the flavor of the mushroom wasn't as strong as I was expecting. As for the farfalle dish, it was light and had their homemade pasta which I am a sucker for, but the dish as a whole was nothing to write home about.

The restaurant also had a great staff, wine selection, and play list. The food was pretty good and their homemade pasta was delicious, but the dishes as a whole could've been better.

A miscommunication and horrible battery life landed me at il Cantinori alone and I'm not mad about it. My cousin told me she had a reservation between our shows. Saturday. 5pm. Then my phone died. 0% battery. I roll out of Sunday in the Park with George at 5pm and flag the nearest taxi. Pedal to the metal to il Cantinori!! It was 35 blocks away.

No one from our "party of 6" is there. They notice I am frazzled and the owner gives me his phone charger and made me feel so welcome. I said screw everyone else. I'm eating here! My waiter was a delightful man from Kansas. He was on point with my drink refills and I was triple fisting it. Water. Diet Coke. Woodford.

I refused a menu and just told the owner and waiter to surprise me with a dish. I was served the most amazing plate of pasta I've ever had. Now I don't have the most sophisticated palate and I don't get out much, but this was exquisite. Strips of pasta in. Creamy tomato sauce with crumbles sausage and peas. It was divine.

For dessert, I also told them to surprise me. It seemed to work the last time! I was brought the most amazing platter of fine Italian desserts known to man. A hazelnut ice cream sandwich. Tiramisu. Pistachio ice cream slices with a berry gelaise center and hard chocolate shell. I died and went to heaven.

Thank you il Cantinori, for taking care of me that night, charging my phone and feeding me body and soul!!

Been going here for so many years true favorite. Best is their amazing special pasts with red sauce and peas. Nothing short of fabulous. They are so nice there.  Old fashioned professional amazing service I split pasta and veal chop with my husband.   And must get their pistachio tartufo
It is really. Very expensive but so perfect. Great treat.  Old or young everyone loves this fool proof dining experience

Ellie

My family and I experienced a very poor service-related incident at this restaurant that I'm compelled to write about. The food was very good, and up until the incident, we found the service to be good as well. Upon receiving our main course, the three of us decided to order glasses of red wine, having polished off the bottle of white we had earlier in the evening. After taking our order of 3 glasses, the waiter promptly began punching in the order at a computer, which was directly across from our table. As he was doing so, it occurred to us that we should probably just order another bottle, so we quickly notified the waiter, who was still in the process of putting in the order, that we'd like a bottle instead, to which he replied "I already put the order in". This was literally less than 10 seconds after he took our order. I gave him a confused look and repeated that we'd like a bottle instead, to which he irritatedly grabbed the wine list and shoved it in my hand. Shocked, and trying to contain my anger, I departed the table for a breather in the restroom. When I returned, my family had told the waiter that the glasses were fine. The rest of the evening went on as if the above incident didn't happen (I did my best to pretend), but for me, this interaction ruined what would have otherwise been a good evening.
Great food, lovely atmosphere, great service. Outdoor dining was a bit crowded. I'll definitely be back the next time I'm in NY!

Is it proper to rate a restaurañt, for years gone by? Î tend to avoid doîng so, since, what do Î kñow? Current reviews seem favorablè enough, however, to trust that quality is maintained. Lunch could never be faulted...but...this review is for one particuar celebration, ôrdered by a bon vivànt, a regular at the timè. It was always a dish that I would rate as "top ten memorable" and one that I would not order myself....squid ravioli in a squid ink sauce. Reading a fellow yełpers lament that delicious dishes of this kind could not be found în American Italian restaurànts, I thought I'd check the present menu. Was it off menu? Secret? There, in the yelp photos was àn unusual looking ravîoli , Î hope it is the same one añd only.

This is a vibrant mainly Roman restaurant on a quiet street in the West Village, however, nothing is quiet in  the restaurant.  Voices are load and it is not an easy place to carry on a conversation.  The menu has some southern Italian dishes such as veal parmigiana.  Other dishes are without sauces like chicken Milanese.  There were no standouts here, except for the pasta dishes.  The homemade pappardelle were fantastic.

My best friend seems to love this place but I've yet to find something I like. Yes, the service is really good (when I go with him anyways because he lives by the area and always eats there) but the food isn't my favorite. I've tried plenty of their dishes and I've yet to find something that sticks. Everything is okay but nothing that I love and want to try again, I've probably tried anywhere between 10-15 of their dishes and specials and.... nada! I guess I'll keep trying because he keeps insisting we go there.

Came here for an anniversary dinner around 8:30 on a Thursday. The place was packed which was a great sign.

FOOD: The food was outstanding. Everything we ordered was fresh and tasted delicious. The winner for us was the burrata and prosciutto appetizer.

ATMOSPHERE: Great ambiance. Dimly lit and romantic but also great for group dinners/friend dinners.

SERVICE: The service is the reason why I am giving four stars. At a high-end restaurant the service should be impeccable. Our waiter was extremely rude and rushed our meal even though we had a reservation.

It's such cute coffee shop behind the NYU Law School. It's an absolute hang out spot for all the students and their service is so quick for a coffee break in between classes. Their coffee tastes absolutely fantastic- especially love their oat milk

Good!
A little pricey so it's your average New York City coffee shop. I love the blueberry muffin and the pumpkin bread is pretty good too. I did see a couple flies in the pasty case so that was a little unsettling but besides that time it's been fine.

I got the latte and muffin after checking few previous reviews. However, it was nothing g special. Muffin has some hard dry crack on top, it's kinda hard on the outer layer. I'm not sure if it's fresh or has been on the shelf for a few days.

I came here for a casual meeting. It was crowded l, a hit loud, but not too loud that you couldn't hear the other people speaking. I ordered the cardamom and cinnamon roll. Y'all, it was dry and over baked. It was very dissatisfying. The flavor was on point though. I had a latte with it, and the latte was good. One member of my group ordered a breakfast sandwich and that looked good (good enough for me to come back and give that a try).

The coffee here is just passable. It's nothing to write home about and it's served it paper cups even if you don't want to go. The tables aren't the cleanest by midday and fairly cramped. They don't make wifi available. Can't say I recommend unless you're desperately in need of coffee.

I didn't get the pleasure of ordering food here, but I ordered a latte with oat milk. It was fast and the service was good. I liked the coffee here and the beauty of the cafe really added to the experience. I would love to come here again to try some of the food and get the whole experience.

Coffee: 2/5 | Service: 4/5 | Ambience: 4/5 | Value: 2/5

I decided to stop by Irving Farm before my lunch reservation nearby to grab a coffee and get some work done. The cafe itself is really nice and welcoming on the inside. There's plenty of seating options and outlets, although no free WiFi which just seems odd. Luckily, I was able to use my hotspot, but I feel like free WiFi is the bare minimum for coffee shop amenities.

I decided to go for a skim cappuccino, which was definitely well-made but EXTREMELY small -- like, the size of a cortado -- and EXTREMELY over-priced ($5.50 for probably 10 oz).

Overall, it was a good place to get some work done, but given the lack of free WiFi and the outrageous prices/coffee sizes, I probably wouldn't return. There are many other nearby options that offer better coffee and amenities.
10/10 experience. Barista was extremely patient with my routine indecisiveness. Went with an oat vanilla latte and was very happy with the texture of the micro foam.

It's a great place to hang out for a while and their matcha latte was great! However they don't have wifi so I wouldn't recommend it as a study cafe anymore, more like a place to hang and read a book for a while. The bathroom wasn't the best though.

I've gone here probably about 5 times. The staff is never happy, and only terrible on two of the occasions. Once in 2022 I walked in without a mask, because they had a sign on the door that said if you were vaccinated - wearing a mask was optional. When I got to the counter the employee at the register started shouting at me for not wearing a mask. I told him that he could have calmly asked me and they should fix the sign on the door. He didn't believe me and when to check, then ripped it off the door aggressively. His colleague apologized for him but not a word from the aggressor. Fast forward to yesterday, I order a small coffee, which btw if you don't know its about 8oz. Luckily the guy behind the counter told me this and said that I probably want a medium, 12oz and $4.50. I took the medium, went to sign the tablet and when I didn't tip, on a cup of black coffee, the guy rolled his eyes. I said thanks and he said "ok". I'm happy to tip when I'm having someone make me something but tipping on an overpriced black coffee? It should be a pleasant surprise, but not expected.

Coffee - slightly below Starbucks quality, it's ok.

Ambience - Very sterile, essentially like the waiting room at a private equity funded dentist. It's clean but lacks soul.

Food - Pastries are dry.
Really not a matcha latte and the single staff behind the counter didn't fully steam milk either.

Great for space and proximity to Washington Square Park. The coffee here is fine, but my main issue with Irving Farm is the pastries.

I ordered an almond croissant, and the one I received was sliced (top from bottom) and pushed back together, burnt on the outside, and had almost soupy filling that I ended up spitting out... Not the most pleasant experience. I wonder where they get their pastries and how this could've happened. Not encouraging as far as returning goes. I'd maybe return just for a drink, but I think I'll stick to other cafes and bakeries for food items.

I always rank coffee spots by a few metrics: availability of free WiFi (which should really just be a basic amenity by this point, come on); a clean bathroom; and ample room to work. And I am sad to report that I have yet to find a coffee shop in NYC that hits all three. You'd think there would be a bounty of places just given how busy everyone is, the tiny apartments, and the rise of remote working, but sadly any such place either just does not exist or is an extremely well-kept secret.

Here's how this location of Irving Farm stacks up:

1. Free WiFi: Nope. I seriously don't get this. Not even a password-protected one?
2. Bathroom: A little smelly and empty toilet paper rolls. Floor was extremely sticky and the soap dispenser hailed from the restrooms at my high school. My rule is a clean bathroom means a clean kitchen but since most of the food here is pre-packaged and imported from somewhere else, it should be okay?
3. Room to work: When I came in on a weekday afternoon to escape the hammering right outside my apartment window, there were plenty of tables and seats. My wretchedly stiff back really appreciates places that offer actual chairs instead of stools.

Can't say anything about the coffee but the olive oil pound cake was tasty. Was my tea and pastry worth the almost $10, though? Nope.

I came here on a Sunday morning and there was only one guy working the register and the drinks/food so it was pretty slow and the line got long at times. The inside was large and spacious and definitely work-friendly but no wifi. There are bathrooms though!

Matcha latte ($5.75) - this tasted like a normal unsweetened matcha latte. I asked for it sweetened, as my normal place just adds simple syrup. The guy said to just use the sugar packets or honey. I did that but definitely didn't mix in well so it just tasted unsweetened. Definitely wish they just added the syrup instead.

Almond croissant ($4.75) - this was pretty big and super filling. The inside had an almond filling and little almond things on top as well. The store was busy so they forgot about it until we asked though.
I really like their overnight oats but their lattes are alright. There are some large tables if you're looking for a place to study or work, but it tends to be crowded most of the time.

Rude is the perfect word.
Please don't give me that look when i'm only asking what kind of options i have for espresso blend. And she would almost throw the tablet when flipping it for me to sign on it.
It's probably the brutal wind of NYC that got in here.
Don't expect any service from this coffee shop.

Oh coffee btw : boring.
So I had the black cake and it's so delicious it's unbelievable I thought it was something with dairy and all that other stuff in it and it just has none of that it's gluten-free and it's  awesome

So,, after smashing on some soup dumplings and other things across the street. Its only proper to get some coffee, just to settle everything up. Plus its hella cold outside and I'm about to get my shop on.

Super hipsterish. Tons of kids with laptops and tablets tapping along doing important things. Super cool industrial looking setting.

My black coffee was super delish. Pretty strong, but definitely the perfect cure for the itis.

Thank you so much for reading my review. I hope this helps with your decision making experience. Enjoy your awesome yelptastic day!!

This Irving Farm location has become the place where my friend and I meet before our book club. It's a large space, but get there early to grab a table. It gets very crowded.

In the past, I've tried their Chai latte (very good), baked goods--both vegan and regular and tea. BTW,  it is $3.50 for the tea bag regardless of size: pot of tea or mug, so go for the pot if you're there to stay.

I decided to try two sides today: the scrambled eggs ($3.00) and kale salad ($2.00). Drinks are picked up at the counter, but for food, you'll get a number which is placed on the table whereupon the entree is served to you.

A few minutes later, my meal arrived. The eggs were overly salted (I should have returned), but the kale salad was delicious, a great portion and very satisfying. In fact, I was too full from both the eggs and salad. The eggs are just eggs, without bread and the kale salad included kale, red cabbage and carrots--all julienned style. I could imagine having just the kale salad with an iced tea in the warmer months.

The line to order food/beverage  at the counter AND the restroom line can get lengthy. There is only one unisex bathroom for such a large space and I waited a good while for the restroom. Kind of annoying.

Overall, I like to chill here for a bit either alone or with friends to grab a quick bite or hot/cold beverage. And according to the volume of people, it seems they do too.
I came in here to work one morning.... There's no wifi? It's built out to be a great working space so I'm confused and pretty frustrated. Mediocre coffee

Irving Farm is a three-star coffee type of cafe with bougie prices. I've had the drip coffee and the Genmaicha tea here. They're pretty pricey! Not worth it! Just a regular tea bag is $3.50. They don't have almond milk, either (just soy), which is inconvenient. The food looks great, but it's your typical hip and healthy food for high prices and small portions. Cue the millenial avocado toast issue!

The service at this location is awful. The barista is usually impatient and kind of treats the line like a herd of cattle. I don't dig it. There's also no WiFi, which irks me. They really don't want people working on their laptops here.

One positive is the amount of space. This is a huge location so you're sure to find a couple of chairs, even on a busy Saturday afternoon. I wouldn't come here on the weekends if you're looking for some peace and quiet. It is a cafe with a lot of hustle and bustle, and lots of conversations taking place.

A chain coffee shop near the NYU campus. Nothing much to note here. This was my first time to an Irving Farm but definitely not my last as I recently also visited one in the UWS. Although I would say the 2 locations are drastically different. Got a latte, which was made quickly and tasted decently.

This spot was pretty spacious and there were lots of safeguards in place for during the pandemic, such as socially distanced but also limited seating, and a giant plexi glass between customers and the barista.

Otherwise, nothing much else to note of here.

This is a great place to study or meet someone over coffee. It can get quite loud but that just adds to the lively atmosphere. It can also get crowded at times so it may be difficult to find a seat. The coffee is pretty good (above Starbucks quality for sure).

The coffee was good, the ambiance is alright, it's a great place to do work because they don't seem to care how long you stay. Most people there are doing work on their laptops. The bathroom was not very well maintained- it was pretty gross. While I was there a homeless person walked in and sat down, then proceeded to light a cigarette inside. Overall, it's a place to get work done but I don't think I'll be coming back.

Irving Farm is a coffee shop with a simple minimalistic design, quality coffee, and high prices. The space is open and bright, with a lot of communal seating available - perfect for posting up for a little while and getting some work done. But be wary if you have a bad back, the chairs/stools are a bit too high for the tables and require some leaning over.

I ordered an iced coffee, and really enjoyed the quality of the brew. It didn't taste too bitter or harsh, even when black.

They also have a great menu of breakfast items to nosh on, as well as pastries to choose from. My brother had a BREAKFAST SANDWICH with bacon, egg, and cheese on a bagel. It was a pretty darn good BEC with gooey cheesy and a chewy bagel. I had a dish with EGGs and AVOCADO on SWEET POTATOES. The poached eggs were a little too runny (even in the whites), and the avocado was too mashed for me. Between the eggs and avocado the dish was too soft, and difficult to eat. Would have certainly benefited from some toast.

It's a good spot with ample seating to post up, and grab a bite to eat while working away.
Great coffee. Some of these reviews are for food and other drinks. But if you actually like brewed coffee, this place is great. Great clean space for working or chatting.
Very good Chai Latte and Croissant, friendly staff, and a clean environment. The only downside is that there is no wifi, otherwise it would be the perfect study spot.

I love this location of Irving Farm because it is so spacious with lots of window light and always full of students. It's a good spot to study--no wifi so bring work or reading that doesn't require the webs. Drinks are great as always--they obviously know how to roast their beans. There are a couple of vegan food options available, as well as 1-2 vegan desserts/pastries.

I appreciate that a new coffee shop has opened up in Greenwich village that is a bit more mainstream and with a ton of seating available. In addition to private tables, there are longer shared seating options, which makes this a great place to work alone or meet for group projects.

Coffee is good and baristas are friendly. I've had Irving Farm roasts at other coffee shops before, so I knew what to expect. They also have a pretty solid selection of breakfast/brunch items. I'm not sure if I'll ever have the chance to try them, but I'm glad they are offered.

There is a large bathroom in the rear for customers only, which is convenient. Unfortunately, they do not offer complimentary wifi, which makes it hard for me to study there for long.

Visited Irving Farm New York for coffee and breakfast on Monday morning. Everything about my experience was awful and would recommend steering clear.

Quality: I didn't enjoy either of the items I ordered at Irving Farm New York. My Latte was bitter, which was a first, and it was only lukewarm when I received it. I would have sent it back, but with all the chaos at the counter it was not worth my time. The Almond Croissant meanwhile was cold and stale. Why even have pastries if they are not going to be fresh.
Quantity: Both drinks and food are standard in size.
Value: $5 for a Latte. $4 for an Almond Croissant.
Ambiance: Irving Farm New York is located in Greenwich Village, just steps from NYU. It is a chic and fairly large coffee shop. It seems like a place you could hang out and do some work, until you learn they don't offer Wi-Fi. So even the best thing the shop had going for it, the beautiful space, they found a way to screw it up.
Crowd: A small before work crowd. However, because of how slow they moved the shop filled up quickly.
Service: They were way too slow for rush hour. During my short visit I saw at least four people have to leave before receiving their food and two others leave without their drinks. Others needed to exchange because the orders were wrong or the food was cold. It was chaos and embarrassing to watch.
Parking: Extremely difficult to find street parking in the area.

A coffee house a stone's throw from the heart of NYU's urban campus, two blocks from the Bobst Library, wildly busy? Go figure!

Great coffee is a good start. Great pastries and food at all times of the day helps the student on the go.

Lots of tables, unlike nearby coffee places. Lots of tables, fewer plugs, and NO WIFI. That's to keep people from camping out there all day, only at this location. Not sure if I agree with that one. Star down to the Internet Grinches.

Convenient, good vibe. Good place, even if I have to go down the street to post this. (Guilt absolutely intended.)

Wow! Let me say that this cafe has thé nicest, most friendliest staff. So nice and helpful to customers. She made nice recommendations for snacks to accompany my (exceedingly delicious)hot cocoa. I tried the rugelach. What heaven! Then I had to get some to go because I knew my cousins would love such a nice mini snack!! The inside seemed mellow. WiFi would be nice. So I just took my purchases a over to Washington sq pk.  I'd come back because my cocoa was nice & sweet.
As was  your staff!

irving farm coffee roasters is a cafe near washington square park with a small work area, around 4 tables. plenty of pastries and their chai latte very rich and sweet, just what i needed on this hot day. they have a bathroom, although no wifi.
Pre made egg sandwiches. Gross. Also very slow. Got my order wrong and were clueless how to fix it so I just paid twice.

The café itself is very spacious and optimal for studying or working. The coffee was good but there was nothing that stood out to me personally (I'm a very big coffee advocate).

Would probably come back again if I had to get some work done!

71 House Drip Coffee is by far the best drip coffee in the city. There's a subtle chocolate taste that lingers after each sip. I'm also a big fan of their Konga beans.

PRO TIP: Get a stamp card and your 10th drink will be on the house!

Came in to get a snack. Ambience is nice. Pretty loud on a Sunday Afternoon.

Has no Wi-Fi to deter long seating times. Still packed though. So I'm sure people come here for.  Coffee. I got me a blueberry crumb Donut and a Lemon Loaf for my wife.

We both were there for an almond croissant. One could say the placement of what we purchased changed our minds.

Its pricey though. That is a deterrent for me personally. 4.75 for a small donut. I can get a big one for 3 from Dough.

I would return. Only for the coffee and if I were having a meeting. I'm not sure you can work at this location because of how long you could focus( unless you had headphones) not a crazy long wait and some really tasty donut( I ate it too fast to take a picture :/)
Pot service. Honestly a tad rude. They were also out of skin milk when I came. Food was ok but on pricy side for what was
8$ for half a grilled cheese sandwich. Bonkers. Egg and cheese burrito with maybe five back beans.

I know from past experience, their American coffee tastes like dirt. The lattes are decent. But I pay premium coffee and pastry prices at a cafe for the opportunity to sit indoors at a table, and out of the elements. That justifies the price for me, I'm paying rent to sit in a nice place for a bit.

Today I went in and ordered, trying to escape the 90 degree heat and wet of a summer storm, ordered and paid for my latte and dessert then headed for a table, when the server announced they were now closed to indoor business. At 4pm!?

Why would a cafe that's been closed to business for a year in the pandemic close at such an early hour when they have business losses to make up?

Why couldn't he have warned me before taking my order? I was tempted to ask for a refund if I couldn't sit at a table, but he'd already made my coffee and put my cake in a bag. I didn't think he'd oblige. I left quite displeased. He did apologize, but a lot of good that did me with my hands full of product and nowhere to go and enjoy it.

If I'd wanted take-out, I'd have happily taken my business to the Dunkin' Donuts around the corner. In the end, with no place to go to escape the heat and nearby wet park benches (as my only resource left), I turned around and came back home.

Greenwich Village Cafes ought to be open til midnight! Why does this one close at 4pm (tea time)!?

Great coffee, especially good iced coffee, but I am more posting this in response to the dude who wrote a 1 star review and complained about lack of parking...lol.  Welcome to New York City, friend. Leave the car in Queens.

A month or two ago, I came here with some coworkers to chat and catch up during lunch outside of work. The space is pretty neat with great lighting (yes!) and a generous amount of seating, but be warned that the line gets pretty long around 1 p.m.

I also had a coffee chat with a colleague here a few days ago and got a mug of drip coffee with some milk. This was around 2:15 p.m. and I kid you not -- this coffee kept me chipper and awake until around 9:45 p.m.!

I was only partially sad because they ran out of punch cards. My colleague got his drink for free (buy 10, get one free) - I will be back to get that card! I love that this location is so near work and I can't wait to try out their pastries and other delicious drinks (like the cappuccino and chai latte) :)

Is it the best coffee I've had? No, but this place is perfect for when you want to sit down and do some work or chat with a friend in a lively environment.

Americano, skim flat white, and a morning glory muffin shown in picture.

Got ice tea and lemonade here on a hot day.   Ordering was efficient.   Got the drink quickly.   Taste great.  

The most important thing is that we got great take space in an AC environment on a hot day.  

What's not good?   Well, they need to clean the tables and space more frequently.

This local New York coffee shop has great coffee as well as a full menu of "healthy" bowls and bites.

I ordered a latte with oat milk and it was made a better than other places I tried in the city. Could be a personal preference thing, but I was happily surprised and finished the whole drink! Normally I don't.

The only downside of this coffee shop is that it's extremely loud inside. Luckily, you're pretty close to Washington park and that's a great place to take your coffee and go on a nice walk (weather permitted)
This is one of my favorite coffee places in this neighborhood.  Never super crowded and the line moves quickly.  I also really like the vegan zucchini muffin.  Not too sweet breakfast treat.
Good place to go for coffee and conversations. However very little seating available indoors.

I'm already a fan of Irving Farm from their location on the Upper West Side, so I was beyond excited when a new branch opened in my favorite neighborhood.

Thanks to the wide space fronting Third Street, there's a good amount of light in the back, as opposed to the dingy-feeling deep-innards of most NYC coffee shops. There's a slatted wood partition that keeps the back area slightly quieter than the more social anterior of the shop, which can get fairly noisy on a rainy afternoon. Tables turn over pretty quickly, however, so in the few times I've been here, I haven't had trouble securing a spot.

If you keep in mind that the place isn't really designed for comfort, then the stronger rating makes sense. The individual tables are pretty tiny, so plan on staggering your coffee, your pastry, and your breakfast. If you're brunching with a friend, sitting across from one another at the communal flat tops is the best option.

I'm not taking a star off for Wi-Fi, since 1) there's no Wi-Fi at similar coffee shops in the neighborhood or at other Irving Farms, and 2) the Wi-Fi from Amity Hall is strong enough that I'm able to write my review as I sit here. I'm taking a star off because there doesn't seem to be as consistent a selection of pastries as other locations, even in the mornings, and who the hell runs out of soymilk on Sunday at 1PM?

Skip the granola, which costs $11 for a parfait that comes in a plastic cup. Other than that, the food is great as usual (highly recommend the shakshuka roll), the lattes are smooth, and I like that they vary the menu by location.

I really enjoy this new location of Irving Farm Coffee Roasters! They have a lot of seating, so it's really great for working. Unfortunately, though, they don't have wifi, which is definitely a down-side. In regards to working space, they do have a variety of seating options, which I love. They have smaller, more intimate tables, in addition to long shared tables if you need to spread out your work. They also have some more comfortable lounge chairs by the front windows.

It's a very open space, with lots of natural lighting. It almost feels like a WeWork - very trendy and modern spacing. The coffee is good. I ordered a bagel with cream cheese, and it was pretty typical. But the service was good, and the baristas are all very friendly.

My friend and I love the lattes here because of its unique flavor. The place is perfect for chatting with people and getting work done (that doesn't require wifi). There is plenty of seating space, but it fills up rather quickly. There are also certain times were the lines can get long, but it moves rather quickly anyways. The location of this place is super convenient as well.

Best dinner I've ever had!!!!! The service was outstanding, the presentation of all meals were phenomenal, and the food is to die for it's absolutely delicious. And the setting is perfect for date night, me and my boyfriend had the best dinner date here. The fine dining was a true experience
This was a very romantic setting and delicious food. Highly recommend and the service was great. Great for parents who want to go on  a "Date night" .

Love this place great vibe , great , staff , and great food..
feels like your visiting family every time you walk in.

The food is very good. They have an old fashioned rather rigid hierarchy of service that tries unsuccessfully to make the dining experience more personal but what it ends up doing is making a difficult timing situation for service, kitchen orders and table bussing.

Our table was unfortunately seated next to a group of men who were loudly manhandling a woman who appeared to be working as an escort. The woman looked like she could handle the men but she was still clearly under duress. One very drunk and loud man grabbed the woman by her neck and tried repeatedly to force his tongue into her mouth while the other men gleefully watched.

The staff tried to do damage control by hovering around the table and trying to politely get the men to calm down. When our table complained the staff  offered to reseat us but we opted to get out of there as quickly as possible.

It is not the job of a restaurant to monitor the behavior of its guests but when the behavior starts to tip over into abuse then that restaurant starts to become complicit in that abuse.

I can't put into words how amazing the experience and food was here. From the second you walk in they ensure every minute that you are taken care of. The bread selection we got included would be a hefty appetizer at most other places and was some of the best we've ever had. Every single dish our group of 6 had was incredible and exceeded expectations. With all the Italian restaurant options in NYC, I'm so glad we picked here and will definitely be back next time we're out here.

Fantastic! What a find! The food and service were impeccable! Everyone of us (party of 8) loved our meals snd even tho we're are here on vacation we left with doggie bags to enjoy later. It's an amazing restaurant, I felt like we were in the Godfather, small. Cozy, dimly lit and Italian staff! We shall return, hopefully sooner rather than later! Thank you so much for the care you put into your meals!

To give Il Mulino only 5 stars is a crime. It is an expensive restaurant but worth every penny. We called at 5pm to make a reservation for 12+ people for 6:30pm. They were so gracious and accommodating and arranged a table for 12 plus a 4-top for us. The service was impeccable and non-stop, everything from food to drinks to water to dessert. Such a classic NYC Italian restaurant -- we will be back the next time we are in the city!'
Exceptional service & food to boot. Through the years it's sustained itself & maintaining its regular clientele.

Il Mulinos been on my radar for some time now and my fiancé and I decided to celebrate out anniversary here. We made reservations for a late dinner and was seated immediately. The wait staff was very friendly and made you feel like family the moment you arrived. Shortly after being seated we were brought complimentary bread and assortments of meats and cheeses so we didn't order any appetizers. For our drinks we both had espresso martinis which were didn't taste like alcoholic beverages but pretty strong and will sneak up on you. For our entrees I had the lobster ravioli and my fiancé had truffle ravioli, it was honestly the best Italian food I've ever had at a restaurant, the ravioli was cooked to perfection and generously stuffed, the sauce was a perfect consistency and tasted amazing. I look forward to returning

The best dining experience I've ever had. The wait staff was amazing. They are always checking to make sure you have everything you need. The pasta is extremely fresh. It melted in my mouth. They serve you as soon as you walk in with all sorts of delicacies. Definitely recommend this place.

This meal may ruin Italian food anywhere else for you. Absolutely life changing. Have been to most of the other popular Italian restaurants in the WV, and this one truly does stand out, if you can close your eyes at the prices.

Staff is super Italian and very friendly.

They start you off with free bread and meats and cheeses.

Pastas are handmade. Al dente and a little bit chewy. Freshest of sauces.

Rack of lamb is the best I've had. Almost melts in your mouth.

And if you choose to share, which I recommend you do, they split each our entrees to make it super easy.

I went to Il Mulino downtown for a nice night out with my brother. We live in Long Island and could have gone to that location, but we wanted to have a nice night out in the city. They sat us at 9:45 for an 8:45pm. There were no seats at bar so we were awkwardly lingering there. I initially wanted to come in earlier and had called. They said to come and we can get a drink at the bar. We ended up getting  there on time and couldn't sit and they didn't even offer us complimentary drinks or anything. The waiters were pretty inattentive as well. We stood around and got a drink after we could finally figure out we could be everyone was so frantic and no one was being kind. When we finally sat down I needed a second to look at the menu and the waiter disappeared for 10 mins and didn't come back after all that waiting and I had to ask multiple people to get him back.  They right away showed us the fish we ordered and then disappeared for a while. They forgot our appetizers and rushed out with our mains. When we were done we ordered cappuccinos and  I also wanted to get dessert. The waiter looked me up and down and said I assume you don't want any dessert and rushed away... I tried to wave someone down for 5-10 minutes. They basically were just trying to get us to order more drinks all night. So quick recap... sat us late, no appetizers and they assumed I didn't want dessert and didn't come back for that order. Pretty terrible service and would never recommend again. Very upsetting because we go to the location on Long Island often and even though sometimes there is a wait they are very kind and make sure we are comfortable.
Sort of cramped spacing.  Food was only average, which is unacceptable given high pricing.  Romantic atmosphere with a lot of server attention on tables.  I'm glad I tried it, but I won't be back.

Third night this week at Il mulinos.

My appetizer tonight was the shrimp in wine sauce
& my entree the sole to die for simple

Service is always 5 star after 35 years coming here it never changes
My white wine & finish my night w a expresso martini
Thank you Il mulinos for your consistency & class forever class
Service was quick and very attentive. Food was delicious. Went for my birthday with my family, had a very enjoyable experience. Get the filet mignon. Ricotta cheesecake and tartufo were spectacular.
Absolute quality to say the fucking least. I wanted to bust all over the food the second it touched my Tongue.

The Dover Sole that wasn't.   Many old school attributes make Il Mulino enjoyable.  Fast paced, a bit rushed.  If you order good wine, you will get better service.   The big disappointment was the Dover sole.   Touted as a special, it was actually branzino (maybe?).  Absolutely terrible.  Why knock the restaurant for one bad dish?  It may be indicative of the factory of food and t-shirt wearing guests that diminishes an otherwise lovely experience.

Overall we had a mediocre experience and I would not recommend to a friend, or go back. First the restaurant was very hot inside, which is understandable given its an old building, but needs to be updated. The service wasn't great, we were buying multiple bottles of wine but they were terrible about coming by to refill water or wine - and when they did it was a very small pour. The were very slow to assist or take orders in general. The food wasn't terrible, but it just wasn't great. The calamari was the most flavorful thing I tasted of the night. Otherwise pretty bland in my opinion. We ordered the calamari, Burrata, scallops, steak, lamb, two types of pasta. Again, all of it was just okay, but not very flavorful - especially disappointing for Italian cuisine.

Il Mulino might be my new favorite Italian restaurant in NYC (or one of my favorites, at least)!

Started with a bunch of complimentary small bites- amazing tomato bruschetta, fried zucchini, flavorful foccaccia (and other breads), and cheese with cured pork. My Aperol spritz was perfect, which is for some reason a rare thing nowadays (the ratios can be hard to get right).

We then got fried calamari, which we definitely didn't need and was just OK. However, even lackluster calamari can't bring down this high score.

For entrées, I got the red snapper livornese, and it was so awesome that I did indeed eat that entire huge slab of lightly pan fried snapper covered in tomatoes, capers, and olives. I couldn't find a pic of this in advance but I'm so, so glad I got it.

My fiancé got the veal parm, and despite his best efforts, could only finish half. Very thinly pounded veal, not the best he's ever had but definitely up there.

We split a side of spaghetti pomodoro, and it actually made me wish I got pasta as my entrée, it was THAT good. Perfectly cooked and the tomato sauce had chunks of fresh tomato and basil.

An old school vibe staffed by older Italian men. No dress code, or so it seemed, but you probably wouldn't feel comfortable just wearing a t shirt and shorts inside.
Entrées are a bit pricey but I highly recommend! The only downside was the massive stomachache I had after (and garlic breath).
Great food , great atmosphere and even better service . Will continue to be a repeat customer

We have been going to this spot for 20* years and not much changes. What does change are the prices. I think the price of a full rack of Lamb at $140 is outrageous , so is the 1/2 rack at $70. The Truffled Ravioli at $50 is the same. Yes, we ordered them as they are our favorites on the menu!! The taste of both are still wonderful as always. We started with the Clams which are equally delicious..  ended with the mixed Berries!! Service is always on point, although we missed Claudio!!!

This is the best place to go for authentic Italian. The food is unparalleled, the service is outstanding, and the ambiance is warm.
From the organic tomato basil sauce, to the parmigiano reggiano, this place is one of my top 3 restaurants in the world to visit.

Discovered Il Mulino since 2018 and absolutely love their food which is why i keep going back. I particularly like this location more than their uptown one as it feels more cozy and authentic. Their starters are fantastic and downright addictive. They set you up with a big basket of bread, cheese, meat, zuchinni, garlic bread, and bruschetta. Everything is AMAZING, it might be my favorite part of the meal. Onto the food we actually purchased, I was not too impressed. They have a small menu but way too many specials. We started with the calamari which we thought we ordered the fried one but somehow got grilled in a spicy marinara sauce. It was good but not what we ordered. Next I got the cavatelli with sausage and broccolli rabe. It was delicious, a little too al dente and hard but the taste was spot on, it was garlicky and very flavorful. It tasted even better the next day after microwaving. My husband got the chicken paillard which he liked but it was nothing special. Lastly we ended with the tiramisu and Italian cheesecake. Tiramisu was not good. The ratio of lady fingers to mascarpone was way off. It had way too much cream, all butter tasting and no coffee taste whatsoever. We were very disappointed. The Italian cheesecake was delicious as always. Creamy with a slight taste of almond paste. Overall we had a good time but truthfully I found the free starters and cheesecake to be the only things worth the visit. Entrees were good but could use work, might be better to have smaller menu. Service could be better. Our server was attentive but service got very slow towards the end. When we were still working on our starters a server came to clear our table and took the cheese and garlic bread we were still working on. He took it before we could say anything, later when we told him we weren't done he sent us more cheese but no garlic bread which was a shame because it was insanely good. Overall it was good but we had higher expectations.

When the waiter took our order (6 guests), he rattled off at lease a dozen specials without mentioning any prices. Assuming the prices were the same as the menu $40-$60 per entre, we picked the rack of lamb. When the check arrived, it was $140. The waiter offered no explanation other than "it used to be $90" which meant nothing to us. But for a dinner bill that exceeded $750 he did not even offer a single desert on the house, let me buy you a drink or a come back and we will take care of you. Instead his attitude was, "you must be a cheap guest" to question the bill. I live in NYC and will not return.

tripadvisor.com/ShowUser…
Absolutely delicious. Order the Ravioli. You will be charged for cancelling a reservation on OpenTable. Still highly recommend.

You need reservations and I suggest you call them in advance to get a decent time for dinner. Especially if you want to go there on the weekend. I also suggest that you dress in business attire. The interior is old and dark  but that's what gives it charm and a sense of being in your Nonna's house. The food is expensive but it's high quality, large portions and delicious. So in my opinion, it's worth every penny.  Everyone should treat themselves every once in a while.

I love that once you are seated, they provide you with dried sausage, cheese, bruschetta, fresh bread of different kinds and warm garlic bread and zucchini. It's just like being at Nonna's house for a Sunday dinner.

We come here all of the time and I always get the same special entree , Langostino with risotto because it's delicious!  However, this time I tried a different entree, their lobster special and they take it out of the shell for you too. It was huge and absolutely delicious! I enjoyed every bite!

As an appetizer we tried three pasta specials, we had gnocchi with braised lamb ragu, capellini with spicy shrimp, scallops, and mussels and carbonara pasta. They give you a dish with three divisions, so you can try a little bit of each pasta. They were absolutely delicious!

We are never disappointed when we come here.
We were too full for dessert so we just had espresso and an cappuccino freddo.

There is a public parking lot down there block too... You should really come here and celebrate an important milestone in your life!  You won't regret it!

What a wonderful Italian dining experience. The food is off the charts and the service is beyond exceptional. Fantastic wines and desserts along with the fantastic entertainment of the staff. Top of the list in my opinion

Molto bene!!!

So my cousin and I checked this place out!  He was in town for business and me, tagged along for a darn awesome dinner!!!

First off service, OUTSTANDING!  Watching the staff and how they took pride in their job and the dedicated service towards their customers was awesome!  

Right off the bat servers were on point and bringing food out right away!   It was so on point and tasty!   Bread basket, little bit of sopprasatta and cheese, a bit of zucchini and some bruschetta to start with was sooo good I couldn't stop eating it all!!'  And this wasn't even the appetizers we ordered which also were amazing!  Seared scallops, grilled octopus!

For my dinner I had the Branzino  my cousin the lamb chops!  Perfection!!!  

Drinks were were also on point deserts amazing!  And the limoncello yummmy.  

Yes a little pricy but I will admit for the service, amount and quality of food, I would pay it again and again.  Well worth the experience and highly recommended to anyone looking for a great relaxed paced and friendly meal!!!

Il Mulino Downtown a NYC landmark!
Excellent food and service. A must stop when you are in the city.

Booked Il Mulino for my girlfriends 25th birthday and WOW!!!!! This was without a doubt the best meal I've had in my entire life.

Let's start with George, our server. This man had us cracking up the entire meal. His singing and joking made for an enhanced experience. He sang for my girlfriends birthday and then he mimicked a horse by neighing - almost spit out my perfectly made margarita by the bartender.

The food was just unlike any Italian food I've ever eaten. I've had my fair share of veal parmigiana and this takes the cake for the best one by a LONG SHOT. Crispy, thin, and perfectly tender. The spaghetti a la vongole was EASILY the best I've had as well.

Pro tip - save some money and some room by not ordering any appetizers, they provide you with free antipasti (bread, marinated zucchini, cheese, meats, and bruschetta).

5 STARS!!!!

Great service and food, good wine too. The waiters were knowledgeable and hilarious. They kept our large group of 11 filled with food, wine and laughs. Only thing it this place is tightly packed and pretty small. One stall bathroom but clean and everything still flowed fine
the best service, food, presentation! A special occasion place unlike anything I've ever seen or experienced!

Some positives from the evening; the free apps served upon seating were pretty good. The rest of the meal left a lot to be desired.... Waitstaff rushing us to order before even presenting us with a drink menu kicked things off on an annoying note. We eventually get our order in, nothing overly complicated literally one plate per person, while we wait for them to fix their first mix up which was bringing one of us the wrong drink. Fine, it happens. The food comes fairly quickly, but two out of the six of us end up with either no dish or the wrong dish so we are all waiting for them to be served. Definitely getting a little annoyed at this point since the waiters have been up our butts all night and still managed to mix up the order.

However the WORST part of the meal came after we paid the hefty tab, I grabbed the receipt to confirm that tip was included and happened to notice that they had added on $250 OF FOOD WE HAD NEVER ORDERED! I was shocked honestly. The waitstaff sort of shrugged and said sorry, re-ran all of our cards and we left... CHECK THE BILL BEFORE YOU PAY. This wasn't a mix up of them giving us the wrong check it was them adding extra dishes to our bill, not a good look.

Great food and great service. Veal was tender and delicious. Pre meal appetizers well done and not filling. Finished an outstanding dinner with apple pie. Looking forward to my next visit and will order items entirely different without fear.

Back home after being away 21/2 year because of the Pandemic.
Brought the family and we all ordered our favorites. Maybe it's because the time the food is better, the same , better quality, the color of the dishes , the size of the portions, the fragrance of the butter, the cheeses.
The Lobster Il MULINO, Rack of Lamb, Salmon topped with garlic and mushrooms. Chicken Scarpariello Fenando.
Introduced my granddaughter who tasted her first serving of Parppedelli    with tomato and basil .
Home again. Normal again.

It looked good while we were waking past it and decided to give it a try.
We were given very warm welcome and given seating at the bar though eventually we were moved to a table.
I was impressed by their menu and was in mood for some delicious and greasy pasta.
We started with baked calamaris and grilled octopus. While you can't get calamari wrong, the octopus was grilled to perfection; soft yet chewy.
Next came our mains... I ordered shrimp and spaghetti pasta, my friend ordered Cacio Pepe and another one ordered gnocchi and to our surprise we all were sorely disappointed.
Pasta dishes were extremely salty and the gnocchi was below average in taste and a bit on sweeter side.
Quite an anti climax of an experience. The same night I got an upset stomach so tossed the leftover pasta that I couldn't finish at the restaurant.

Our favorite Italian restaurant in NYC!!!  Last weekend didn't disappoint!  We had a fantastic bottle of wine (recommended by GM), oysters, chicken marsala, and white truffle risotto, and tiramisu for dessert - all excellent, as usual.  Service is always awesome - they treat you like an old friend.  Can't wait to return!

3 stars for the combination of food quality and price. Prices are just ridiculous! Food is good and service is impeccable.
Atmosphere is so so - totally outdated (some may call it traditional) dining room and bar.
They give you the bill with your coffee - they want to turn their tables.
Overall an underwhelming dining experience.

I had a wonder meal at this restaurant. This venue is small and intimate compared to their Las Vegas location. The service and food were outstanding. The ambience is wonderful and you feel like you are in a large home for dinner.

I had a reservation booked on Sunday 8pm for my wife's birthday and also noted in the reservation notes that it was her birthday (and even called to confirm!). We arrived and we were warmly welcomed but the hostess decided to place us in a table right next to the kitchen (???). I kindly asked to see if we could move just one table over for more privacy but was declined without any reason. It wasn't that busy that night and there were better tables to accommodate us so that was really disappointing. The silver lining was that being so close to the servers resulted in more attentive service and friendly conversation.

I would recommend requesting NOT to be seated right next to the kitchen if you plan on going because it was really way too noisy and distracting. Other than that, the food was above average but slightly overpriced for what you get. Unfortunately, I don't think we'll be returning.

It is the single greatest service and sets the standard for service and cuisine in New York City. It is run by a gentleman named Claudio and he excepts nothing less than perfection from everybody who works with him.
Too dark to read the menu. (Granted, we don't see as well as we used to.) The food is very good. The service is also very good.
YUM. Such a fun place to go. Servers are so funny and attentive. Booked for my little sister's birthday and they went above and beyond! Dining room is intimate and not too loud.

I really wanted to give this a higher review because initially our night was fantastic, but unfortunately the end knocked off a few stars. I dined with a group of 6, we ordered appetizers, entrees and two alcoholic drinks per person. We asked multiple times if one order or two for certain dishes would suffice a large group, and were given a nod at best; no clarity on portion size, the fact that pastas are actually a half portion, or that they take liberty to portion how they see fit. When the bill came after the meal, we saw they took liberty of adjusting every single plate we ordered to double and triple the order amount, charging us for each without disclosing to us this would be the case. They also charged us for a birthday dessert we never ordered. When I went back in to understand why this was the case, I was met with an incredibly rude manager who dismissed me no doubt because of my age, spoke about me in another language to his staff, and told me this is how they do things. We received a $70 refund on an $1100 bill which didn't even cover the dessert we never ordered. At the end of the day, the prices and total bill weren't even the problem, but the lack of regard and respect to disclose these changes to your customers is infuriating. Incredibly disappointing end to what could have been a great meal and experience. Will not be back.

Now... I actually re downloaded Yelp because of how badly I wanted to give this review.
Now hopefully if you read this it'll give you some help because the service was so poor It almost made the food taste bad. The food was delicious by far. But as a black woman that goes to places I often feel the pressure of other ppls stigma.
I have to say this, if you're rich and white the service is alright. If you got money and you black the service still ain't all that.

-the first waitor seemed surprised and was excitedly talking about how it coming to eat for dinner

- first this is the waitor that served me seemed nice and asked about my day and as I proceeded to tell him "oh it was nice I bought a new book" he cuts me off and walks away saying he just had to go get the bread

- the same guy brings a dirty plate to the table for me to begin eating my small appetizers. I ask for another and it's just another less dirty plate

- my waitors were older men, and said a few inappropriate things asking when r we going to get married and I love you so much and etc (at first it's sorta funny ish (SORTA) and then it just gets weird.
He slipped up and made a joke telling me I can just go home as he left from serving the table

- I ran out of water and had to wait for a few mins before getting the attention of an employee

- I asked for the wine menu, the 2nd waitor refused to bring me a menu. I asked 2-3 times
