- I asked what wines would you recommend to go with this veal... this veal is cooked in lemon and white wine sauce, I also told the waitor that I like white and sweet wines but it was almost like he was just not listening to me
- he forgets to bring the wine out and the food comes out already
The waitor  I told about the wine literally forgot about bringing me the wine after like 15-20 mins so he's rushing out with 2 bottles of this strong ass dark and dry ass red ass wine  after already starting to eat a couple bites into my meal

- he bring me 2 different dark red dry wines to go with a white wine meal and it was like he wasn't trying to just give me the option of a different wine even after I told him I'm not a fan
- both waiters were avoiding serving me
The more engaging server was just a little to comfortable and I also felt rushed out.
- I wasn't offered a dessert menu
- one plate of appetizers was served cold and I don't think it was supposed to be served cold
- the food was delicious tho

Again I'm writing this review
Because sometimes you just wanna treat yourself to a nice dinner with great food and I wanna be able to WANT to over tip you guys, and now I'm here angry and disappointed because you guys are being like this
I know this may not be the review for a white person because we don't have the same experiences. I'm sure they'd have a great and wonderful time with wonderful service but it just wasn't the same for me.
I'm just so annoyed at how much people will go out their way to show you that they don't like you or don't want you there. That just seems like extra energy to put out that not really necessary
It's hard to avoid

ate a delicious dinner on West 3rd. Been there many times over years but not for 3 years. we got the bill. $140 for a rack of lamb special. they didn't tell us when we ordered. Gently complained. Told me used to be $90 but just raised it.
seriously? I'm done with it molino
This place was amazing all around! Highly recommend! The food was great, the service great and the restaurant has a very old school, comfortable vibe!

This honestly would be a 5 star review if our server didnt mix up 2 of our dishes. The antipasti they bring you is all so delicious. I could have finished the entire bread basket on my own but i stayed strong lol some garlicky, herby, crunchy, and even spicy breads in there all delectable. They also bring bruschetta, zucchini salad, salami, and cheese. We ordered the eggplant stack as our appetizer but somehow we received the eggplant parm even after we corrected our server while confirming the order. It was good but not what we wanted. The housemade caesar is wonderful and fresh. The cavatelli pasta (which we didnt order but was mistakenly brought to our table) was my favorite of the 3 pastas we tried, but the buccatini and ravioli were excellent as well. Veal piccata was so thin and tender. Chicken parm was also delicious. We got a dessert sampler and they also bring limoncello shots at the end which I didn't care for but is a nice touch. Incredible meal and would highly recommend!

I posted a review what's ago when we were here and it was great then and even better now. It's classic with the appetizer setup and all the food is great. The osso bucco w gnocchi was the best i've ever had. One thing here is everything is loaded with garlic which I love, but be warned to bring plenty of mints!  You must give this place a try and don't worry about the budget when you go!

OMG!!!!!!! PHENOMENAL
The food and service was impeccable. What a wonderful experience. Everything was perfect. EVERYTHING!!
Great place to celebrate a special occasion.
Thank you IL Mulino for an unforgettable experience

Indochine in NYC is a true gem that has captured the hearts of both locals and globetrotters for nearly four decades. The spicy beef salad at Indochine is a culinary masterpiece. It's a harmonious blend of flavors and textures, with tender beef, crisp vegetables, notes of mint, tamarind, and a zesty dressing that's an absolute delight for the taste buds. Every bite is a burst of deliciousness.

The atmosphere at Indochine is nothing short of gorgeous. Step inside, and you're walking in to a tropical paradise with its classic décor and lush surroundings. It's the kind of place that sets the mood for an intimate dinner date or a lively gathering with friends. And let's not forget the cocktails - they are as exotic and delightful as the cuisine, adding an extra layer of enjoyment to your dining experience. Indochine truly lives up to its reputation as a timeless classic in the heart of NYC.

The first word that comes to me regarding this place is pretentious... It is it a snobby restaurant on the wrong area, hence high prices, and not much to do about it.
The crowd is eclectic to say the least. The ambience is hopping, the music is loud, and the service is on point; that being said, the food is definitely nothing to write home about.
The sashimi was bland & tasteless, the shrimp were uneventful and the duck Was probably the best of all three, I had to have some white rice just to fill me up and went for a taco afterwards.

Since Le Colonial closed, we have been looking or another Vietnamese higher end option. We were pleasantly surprised by Indochine. The food was really good and the service was also very good.

We had:

- Branzino Crudo - very good, with micro green

- Chilean Sea Bass - delicious and very light

- Shaking Beef - very good

- Cauliflower Side - tasty

- Roasted Pineapple with Coconut Ice Cream - delicious and refreshing

Don't get me started on the people watching, probably one of the best places in the city. Overall a lovely meal!

Still a happening scene at Indochine even after all these years. Great vibe and a lot of energy. The food is very good, although the menu has been the same for over a decade. The service is good as well.

i wish i could go back in time and uneat this meal. I would only go back for drinks and an appetizer. The gin drink I got was soooo good and surprisingly strong. The prices are heinous even for new york, and trust me I love to splurge for exceptional meals. But $18 for 1 mid fresh roll. Also both rice dishes were inedible. My white friends loved everything so they are doing something right.

We picked this place for a friend's birthday on Saturday night. During the entire dinner, we had to scream at each other as we couldn't hear anything. The noise level was too high & the diners sitting next to us were nearly yelling at each other to carry out their conversations . Thumbs down. Not to my liking. The appetizer, Vietnamese ravioli was quite tasty but the main menu we had was mediocre . The portion was large enough to share but the staff should have told us beforehand as we couldn't finish the three dinner plates we ordered for the party of three with the price range of $50 per person. Two shared plates and one or two side dishes would have been sufficient for our party . Not sure if I would be back.

Came here for our Valentine's Day dinner this year. The ambiance was suiting for a nice intimate Tuesday dinner.
We sat in the perfect corner of the restaurant that was equal parts tucked away while also giving and eagle eyed view of the entire restaurant--the restaurant filled quickly. Our waitress was very attentive and the food was delicious.
I had the spicy shrimp with a side of rice , a lychee martini (strong), and ended with the chocolate mousse cake.
I would definitely go back again.
Indochine is an icon. The food and staff are phenomenal. If you know, you know. Will see you there on my next trip to the city.
The food, cocktails, ambiance, and service were exceptional. We had the kale salad and spring rolls which we highly recommend and the salmon and beef which were incredible as well

Ohmygosh! Love Love Love Indochine!

The palm wallpaper. Legendary.
So is the food & martinis.

This was always our place. All my BFF's all of us had our birthday parties & celebrations here when we lived in the city.

Moi Tippy Top fab places of all time :)...

Highest recommendations.
Loved the ambiance and my espresso martini. Also, everyone that works there is nice and attentive.

The food has a great reputation based on how it used to be back in the 80s, but the service has a terrible reputation that is very much based on how it is now.

The middling, hit-and-miss food just isn't worth the overall lousy dining experience. There are southeast Asian restaurants with much better food that don't treat you like this.

Try Falansai if you want an actual top notch dinner with staff who *don't* seem to hate you for reasons you don't fully understand.

Although Indochine still holds up against the test of time as far as the quality of food and overall ambience is concerned, the service staff leaves a lot to be desired. Was the staff trained to treat any customers not achieving maximum fabulousness with severe disdain? Or is each staff member just disgusted that he/she hasn't achieved Viral Influencer of the Year and must submit to working there (and then petulantly take it out on their customers)? Yes, you are beautiful and you are chic and you are thin and you are dressed to the nines. But please start treating your customers with warmth and respect. We're paying $22 for a cocktail and lots more for the privilege to dine there. Puh-leeze!

Timeless!
Beyond delicious offerings!
Excellent Menu!
Fabulous service!
Such a beautiful restaurant with an upbeat vibe.
Every night it's a party and we are collectively having fun.

All smiles in this palm tree paradise.

I have been coming here for decades and it keeps getting better.

The crowd is international fashionable and upbeat.
It's always a party at Indochine.

I never been to this place before and I went with my Gf . It's a cute space  and the food is ok. I would give 3 star but our waiter was the rudest person I have meet  he was tall and Asian . But to top everything a huge walk up the mirror where we were sitting while we were eating  never again .

We popped by on a Friday night after hearing many good things about this restaurant. The food and atmosphere were incredible but the service sucked.

Everyone here seems "cool" - think of a subtle almost casual yet highbrow feel. You would wear a blazer and jeans to a place like this or the likes of a tuxedo dress.

This is a great spot for people watching, but food is also noteworthy. The shaken beef was excellent; tender and well textured thick chunks of meat. The duck was slightly more flavorful - very well marinated, cut, and presented.

The only issue is that our server didn't really seem to want to interact with us (we weren't as well dressed). This is not the place to be casual.

I would definitely recommend this place for an elevated take on Vietnamese food.
Great vibe.  Classy with a touch of Hollywood.  I get a Miami Beach feel upon entering.  Drinks are great and food is a great fusion flair.  A return place for us.

One thing remains consistent since the 80s snooty service by skinny people!
The food this time was nearly inedible, cold and tasteless! I don't think they even bothered with the most basic - salt!

The booth we were given to accommodate 4 average sized adults barely worked - I guess they just want skinny people to feel comfortable. As to the ambiance, my friend was "attacked" by one of the potted decorative plants, which took about 15 minutes for our server to realize it might be a good idea to move the intruding plant.
They even managed to screw up an expresso- serving it cold and watered down.... What has happened?? Finally, it took a while to get our coats as the person getting our coats stood around, reading and laughing at something on the screen at the entrance - or was she laughing at us?? Hahaha
Please save yourself the snooty servers and expensive and inedible food and choose one of the many other fine Vietnamese restaurants.

Gorgeous restaurant, perfect for snacks and cocktails. The dim lighting, music and beautiful atmosphere made for an incredible date night. All the food was fantastic: spring rolls, fluke carpaccio, crab cakes.

Not like the old days ...

Food was meh ...

When salad is the best thing on the menu ... it's a problem.
ALWAYS FABULOUS!!! Staff is gorgeous & professional. Food was superb and drinks were divine. The setting is still CHIC AF.

If it were possible to give negative stars, I would.

Showed up with a 11pm reservation and they told us they were booked for a private event. Instead of apologizing, they attacked us saying that we booked the wrong date and it was impossible for us to have booked a reservation until I showed them the reservation in their own system. Even after that they were complete jerks and instead of admitting fault, apologizing and accommodating (or offer an alternative), they blamed it on us (even with proof from their own reservation system) and said that we needed to "move along" because there was nothing they could do. Seriously worst hospitality that I've ever seen and have never experienced such degrading, insulting service from a restaurant in my life. Turned what was supposed to be a celebration, into a night-ending moment. This place is a has been joke and I will not be back.

beautiful scene but the food tasted below average. With the only exception of the beef, all other mains and appetizers we tried were below average. Don't think it is worth coming back for food anytime soon.

It is NYFW and we knew it would be busy, our server said it was the most busy they had been in a year but we couldn't tell! We arrived early for our indoor reservation and easily waited with cocktails, got seated early and transferred our tab no problem, got another round within minutes of it putting them in. Food came out quick, and was delicious. We had the fried spring rolls, spicy chicken, shaking beef and sautéed rice... all were fantastic. Drink 1 Indochine Martini (citrusy lime), wanna have 3. Great night.

Stopped in here with my wife and 2 kids without reading any reviews or ever having heard of the place; we were going to a sunday 2pm blue man show next door.  We were very pleased with our brunch experience.  Salt and pepper squid app delicious.  Entrees were very well done (steak and eggs, mushrooms and rice, noodles and pork).  Also had a few hong kong beers that were right up my alley.  Very good coffee.  Our server was very polite and attentive... just seemed like a normal nice person.  Worth the price 100%.

I have been here before there was a Yelp.  Definitely brought me back to the 80s feelings.  I remember being more popular back in the days.  I am not sure if I picked the wrong night but it had an old people's vibe.  It became like an old people's gathering spot.  Not that anything wrong with it.  Food was delightful.  The service was decent.  I guess my expectations were too high.  But it must be good that they are still in business.

we had a really disappointing experience last night. food was mediocre, but the service was horrendous. all waitstaff was rude, condescending and patronizing. their behavior made the whole party feel uncomfortable. would not waste the time, money or effort dining at this location.

BEWARE THEY ARE THE WORST PEOPLE IN THE BUSINESS ESPECIALLY THAT RECEPTIONIST ( too much attitude for the price she / he ) gets paid TOXIC ...  AND PROMISE YOU THE WORLD AND NEVER DELIVER...I had 20 guests there charged me $5000.00 and made me sign a contract with a selected food & wines & NEVER COMPLIED to the agreement. They literally through us out 1.5 hours after we where seated. DISGUSTING
I have repeatedly called them for a detailed bill and they can't comply to that they are simply COWARDS that can't call back.

BEWARE BEWARE BEWARE...

Another NYC restaurant that has been on my list for a while, We finally got a reservation. I was excited, and now I know why, from the minute we stepped in, to the moment we left, everyone was incredible, inviting atmosphere, friendly and knowledgeable service . We started with the salmon and caviar special appetizer fresh and delicious. I had the shaken beef and it was absolutely delicious the beef was tender melted in your mouth, my partner had the duck and he said it's one of the best he's ever had. We were celebrating a birthday and had the crème brûlée for dessert and two complementary glasses of champagne I want to say thank you to CT Hedden for going out of your way and making our evening special!

Out of 10 I would give it a 7
I did enjoy being there
Cocktails were very good. And strong. Had cucumber martini.
Shared Thai ravioli. Delicious!
Shared a shaky beef and a vegetable curry stew.
Dessert was coffee cake with shaved coffee ice and caramel. It was nice enough.
All good tasting. Prices quite high and wasn't wowed by food or experience.
Service okay
Decor festive 1950s tiki-like
Very glad i went. Don't need to repeat.

My Vietnamese Barbecue chicken was literally RAW. I've included pictures as proof of the pink chicken that I took to-go, as the lighting in the restaurant was too dim to see it clearly while sitting at the table. I can't believe that I paid $40 for a raw chicken entree. We also felt rushed during our meal, but the real issue was the chicken!

Food is ok, but not worth going back for the negative ambiance.  Most discriminatory & non inclusive dining experience in NY.  They are ridged, entitled and only 2 knew how to smile.  For a 6pm reservation & empty restaurant, they seated us, a family celebration 50yrs wedding anniversary, in a dark corner on the way to the kitchen. When asked if booth is available, they said " those are for special reservations". Ours was not special?!  Each table has 2 staff waitress. Initial waitress was pleasant and explained the drink options.  The meal waitress insisted we place all orders at once since they needed their booth by 8pm. When asked how things were prepared, she said she "never ate that dish".  Later overheard her mocking our table and laughed about rushing us out of restaurant with her bar staff colleagues.  The manager never came to the table, instead was busy adjusting the lighting 4x's.  Unclear how staff of a $$$$+ establishment isn't more professional than the crumb sweeper they use. Extremely unprofessional and overrated. So much effort is made on plate presentation, they should take a page from Chef book and learn how to mirror the dining experience.

Once upon a time, this reviewer looked at one-star Yelp reviews that panned some small item and thought "That reviewer is really mean to be so harsh over something that minor...."   But alas, some restaurants really deserve one-star reviews and Indochine is one of them.

We had a 5:45 reservation, though our fabulous performance of Fat Ham was literally across the street at the Public Theater.  I don't know why I felt I needed to make it so early, but when we had a bad subway delay and dashed there to meet a friend at 6:15, she was at a very nice table,  

When I made the reservation and when we arrived, we reminded them of the 8:00 curtain,  But from the outset, the service was, I can only say "odd."  The waitresses are al dressed in what might be called cocktail dresses, so at first glance, it is hard to know who is wait staff.  (In stark contrast, the busing staff is dressed all in black, very easy to recognize.)  

The waitress had to be waved at, never did she come over and say "I am your server," no greetings, thank yous or any interest in us whatsoever.

We ordered and the dishes, first a spring roll appetizer and excellent drinks, then entrees Shaking Beef for two of us, Amok Cambodgien -- sole with coconutmilk -- for a third person, with jasmine rice, came relatively quickly.....we still had plenty of time.

The egg rolls were good, the beef delicious, the rice half a bowl but fine, but the sole was slightly sour and had it been me, I'd have sent it back, though I almost never do that when I am with a friend  

By the time we were ready for dessert...no one came to ask us....it was about 7:30, she recited the desserts to us and we ordered chocolate truffle mousse cake and coconut mousse. Both were very small portions and not particularly exciting.   They were also an astonishing $15 each....but since we never saw a dessert menu, we did not know this.

At 7:45, I somehow felt time pressure, and ran across to pick up our tickets, "just in case," and this turned out to be wise.  I sent my two friends on to the play  since you have to show vaccine cards and IDs.  T

hen, when I finally got someone to give me the bill, there were "interesting" additions to it...For one thing, we had a bottle of water on the table -- they brought it, we did not ask for it, but of course, it was 84 degrees or so.    Does one ask if there is a charge for tap water ?  I never have, but maybe I will in the future because we had a charge of $12 for 2 bottles of water.  Caught completely off guard, I went to the register -- who knew where my server was -- and told them I simply would not accept this charge.  This must happen a lot because they took it off immediately without a word.  Buyer beware !   By the time this was settled -- and I had to push them to charge my card, it was 7:55.  Two hours and a mad dash at the end ??

The rice at $5 a bowl was ridiculous, the beef for $40, with no rice or vegetables, while delicious, should have been $8-10 less, the fish was $38 and as I said, possibly slightly off, and the bland desserts were tiny and about $5-7 more than any reasonableplace would charge.  I understnad the post-lockdown pressure, every restaurant is more expensive, but this is a joke.  The drinks, really great, were $18, a bit higher than normal.

So our bill ran to $250 for a small meal, very uneven,  with disinterested wait staff, no attention to our time constraints, padded bills...  oh, and the restaurant is very noisy, if all of the above were not enough.  St. Marks Place has plenty of better choices.....

A PS,  Take a look at their online menu, every single price listed is at least a dollar or two less than we were charged, except the $15 desserts.....

---------------
Just a little PS....Have you ever noticed that when some reviews of other restaurants are critical -- and I certainly don't mean mine --  the management of those restaurants rushed to try to resolve he issues in some way, even just apologizing  ?  Well, none of the ciritical reviews of Indochine have generated any reaction at all from the Management....what does that say about their concern for customers ?
Great spot for a group dinner! For $135/person you can get a ton of food served family style and unlimited wine

I NEVER leave reviews, but I feel it absolutely necessary this time.  The food at the Indochine was ok, the service up till I paid was great.  However as Soon as I paid the $500 bill, I was asked to leave the table.  Normally I would Have left instantly.  Unfortunately my phone died so I was unable to order an Uber.  In fact the hostess stand had my phone charging.  I was very embarrassed and upset the way I was treated once they had my money.   PEOPLE BEWARE!!!!

i booked for a friend returning to visit . I rang the restaurant to explain friend was a celiac and could not eat gluten . The restaurant told me my friend had also called and that all was good . They understood her allergies . The server would help. once we told the server her restriction the server pointed out dishes she could eat . As the starters arrived my friend questioned the oil her spring rolls were cooked in. we called a passing server who immediately moved tug sauce off her plate - NOT  the sauce. She suddenly announced  .  Dont have the sauce . My friend had already had the sauce . Fearing she would throw up we left.  we paid for our 'take out'
My friend was in Tears fearing throwing up en route . The restaurant gave her a sick bag ! Seriously

Charging us
Not being across the allergies !
Not going back
Nobody attended us after we were seated for 10 min. Twice I called somebody and the person just replied with "I will get your server". Sorry 0 star service for me.

Best.Food. Ever.

Service is the only thing that was disappointing. Not the people who were bringing out the food or waiting on tables but the women who were seating us. They were very mechanical but lacked genuinity I thought. Cold. That's Sad because everything else was so perfect.

Lychee mist and BELLE DE JOUR comes highly recommended.

The spicy beef salad was extremely refreshing. It was spicy while being absolutely flavorful. The beef was the right texture with all the greens. Lemon addition was perfect.

The ravioli was basically like a steamed spring roll. The filling was a tad less on seasoning and flavor but the minute you hit the dip that dish is magical. I like when flavor adds up and takes into account all the different parts of a dish.

The shaking beef was tender and juicy and great. There not too many ingredients and that worked best for this dish. The ginger and scallion were the right additions.

Ok so we don't like chicken esp in restaurants but we thought since this was a fancy establishment we would give it a try. The Saigon chicken was so good. The lemongrass hits all the right notes. That chicken is damn good and comes highly recommended.

We had the lemon tart that is extremely tart (if you know what I mean) and it is perfect. The crust is thin and flaky and just right.

The sorbets were good but I'm not a sorbet person so won't hold it against it.

Very bad experience for following 4 reasons:

1) Table was squeezed in extremely tight corner, felt claustrophobic. Also table was wobbly (which was fixed after requesting)

2) 3/4 food items weren't good, except for the Chilean Sea Bass, which was objectively very tasty

3) Charged $12 for water (not sparkling, we just wanted tap)

4) Called in advance to let them know it was for a bday celebration and still got charged for dessert, which was implied free

More like 3.5 stars in my opinion but I'll round up here.

I had Indochine on my RW wish list for 2018 but wasn't able to get there, so I made sure to make reservations for the first week of RW 2019.

Reservations on OpenTable were pretty booked up far in advance, so I grabbed a fairly early time slot for dinner. I was happy and surprised to see that the RW menu hadn't changed much over the years. All the staple dishes are still on the menu.

When we arrived at 6pm was almost empty aside from a few tables and it was DEAD quiet. I was really hoping the environment would liven up a bit, and if definitely did by the end of our meal. Regardless, the ambiance was super cool and just as gorgeous and pristine as it looks in pictures.

I see people complaining about the waitresses in a lot of reviews, but ours was really sweet so I can't relate. Yes, all of the waitresses, hostesses, and bartenders are young hot things lol but we didn't come here to compete with them for a modeling contest. We came for the food, y'all. And the waitresses were nice! Just because they might be dressed a bit fancier than you doesn't automatically mean they're going to be rude. Now I feel like their defense lawyer, but okay... Our VERY NICE waitress brought us our menus and consistently checked on us to see if we had any questions on the menu items or needed drink suggestions. Again, in the reviews, people found this annoying but I really think they're just being attentive. You guys are a hard crowd. Damn.

Since we wanted to try as many of the RW menu items as possible, we decided to mix and match. For apps, we tried the Spicy Beef Salad which was kinda weird and the Fried Spring Rolls, which were awesome. In regards to the salad, the portion was HUGE and definitely more than enough for 2 people to split, but the beef just tasted like cold cut roast beef which was extremely strange and off-putting although the dressing was bomb. Definitely not something I'd order again (or something I'd want to pay full price for).

For entrees, we tried the Grilled Salmon which was cooked perfectly, and the Spicy Chicken. The chicken was pretty good in my opinion, but I didn't realize that it was going to be a dish of fried chicken pieces. Very interesting and unexpected, and heavy on the turmeric. We also tried each of the sides, one plain Jasmine Rice and one Sticky Rice which just looked like fried rice to me. I didn't try the Sticky Rice because the staff advised that it was made with sesame, but it didn't seem like I was missing much there.

For dessert, we tried one of each of the options - one Lemon Tart and one sorbet which comes with a scoop of raspberry and a scoop of coconut. I really enjoyed both.

It was the standard $42 pp and excluded drinks. No surprises there.

I'm happy we have this spot a try during RW because I'd be kind of annoyed if a spent a ton of $$$ on that glorified roast beef salad. All in all though, a very pleasant experience.

I was looking for an evening of great food in a cool atmosphere with good friends, so a reservation was made at Indochine. Unfortunately we never made it passed the front desk. We were met with such attitude and indifference from the Maitre D that we decided to walk away. This was beyond disappointing as it used to be such a pleasure going there- the staff was great.
Times change some things fade away. Goodbye Indochine.

Went here before coronavirus with some friends. It was packed, but the server was very enthusiastic and attentive, and the food was just outright incredible. It definitely was expensive, but if you go during restaurant week it's cheaper. So good!!!

This restaurant has been on my must go-to list for a while. I was so happy when I was able to get a reservation for 5 here for restaurant week. The vibe is trendy. I loved the decor (leaves on the wall) and how spacious it was. The wait staff are all gorgeous and looked exotic with accents. It felt as if I was on vacation somewhere exotic.

The restaurant menu looked so good, it was hard to choose. I ordered the spicy beef salad to start. I really did not like it so I switched with my husband who ordered the ravioli. Everyone else at the table seemed to like the spicy beef salad, it was just not for me. My sister's boyfriend ordered the noodle salad and it was delicious.

For the entree, my sister and brother ordered salmon, it was moist and tasty. I ordered the chicken, which was delicious. Loved that it had lemongrass flavor. My husband and my sister's boyfriend got the shaking beef. The beef was much tastier than the beef on the salad. Every entree came with a choice of jasmine rice or sticky rice. I ordered the sticky rice. It was mixed with scallions and some other veggies and was delicious.

For dessert, I chose the sorbet. I o my for coconut because I am allergic to red food dye and was nervous it would be in that. The sorbet was delicious. Those at my table who ordered the sorbet, wished they only got the coconut. They all complained that the raspberry was too tart.

We all ordered one cocktail. I had one with bourbon in it that was very tasty.

The presentation of the food and cocktails were done very well. The service was also pretty good except the waitress added Evian water to our bill. She did quickly take it off though. I did not like that the bus boy cleared the plates before we were done and that the hostess mispronounced my very easy to say name 3x even though I corrected her each time. All in all, I am happy that I went. We all had a great time.

We were all pleasantly surprised at how big the portions were. My sister and I did not even finish our meals and had to wrap them up.
The food is phenomenal. Yes, the staff are tall, skinny, and beautiful but the food was not meant for the skinny  everything is worth a try.

We were really hungry after coming out of a show nearby. The place was very lively and they had tables outside which is always my preference nowadays.  I ordered a Lychee Sake Martini which was absolutely delicious, the short ribs which were too salty, and the Korean bbq chicken which was dry and just ok.  My opinion is that this is a great place for drinks & cocktails but not for dinner.  Also, people kept coming outside, right by the door to smoke so we ended up smelling cigarette smoke during the entire meal.

This is one of the snobbiest restaurants i have visited in NYC. I am a seasoned diner all over NYC and enjoy many excellent upscale and down to earth spots but will not return here. If you are not the privileged at this restaurant, you aren't getting any reasonably good table. 4 of us were squeezed into a tiny booth which looks more like for 2-3. The cold and unbending hostess won't give you anything better. Mind you service is excellent and friendly and waitress was truly wonderful. Drinks were pretty good. Food was hit and miss. Kale salad and crab were delicious. Eggplant was average. Duck was superb. Veggie summer rolls pretty good. Founder in curry was not bad. Dessert was ok. If any of you know Le Colonial on 57 st that shut it's doors
Few years ago, it was in some ways similar to Indochine but they rivaled Indochine is flexibility, friendly hosts and warm welcoming vibe which a Indochine lacks.

The hype around this restaurant is the real deal. If you can manage to find a reservation for Indochine do not pass up the opportunity. The ambience, drinks, food and service make this pricey restaurant worth it. Perfect for a special occasion to celebrate!

i came here with friends last night for dinner and thought the food was really good, service as prompt and we didnt remember ever having to wait for anything. lovely restaurant nice décor and ambiance. . . very surprised by the food since they only had 3.5 stars but every single dish we ordered was amazing.
Absolutely amazing food and ambiance. Do try the fish and the beef salad. Will definitely be back.

So the crab ragoon and appetizer plate where you could sample everything was delicious. I went here the night of my 30th birthday from Raleigh. And everyone in my party loved the appetizers bit didn't like the main meal. In all of our meals, the meat was dry and overcooked. Very disappointed with that. The atmosphere was great and so we're the appetizers which is why I will still give it 4 stars. Hoping it was just a bad night for meat.

It's tucked away on Jones street, which means when you're wandering among West Village restaurants on a Saturday without a reservation, you might actually get a table here with less than an hour's wait.  Nothing in particular stands out, so it's rarely a sought-out destination, but it's quite good.  I'd put it in the under-rated category.  My entre was the "Chicken with 40 cloves of garlic."  I couldn't count all 40, but I continued to taste them a day and a half later.
I Sodi is amazing, the food is to incredible, the service impeccable, and the atmosphere is great -- you feel like you're in Tuscany. Definitely make sure you go here!

First time at the new location and it's just as great as it always was! My boyfriend and I put our names in on a Monday night at 6:08 PM and were seated at the bar at 7:27. We shared:

+ Tartara
+ Fried artichokes
+ Chestnut tortelli (seasonal special)
+ Lasagne
+ Marmalade crostata

We went the day the NYT review dropped, so I'm sure it's an even worse wait now, but always worth it.

TLDR: Save your time and money and head to Via Carota if you can

Started off with the bread and olives- pretty standard except the bread felt a little too grainy for my liking.

Got the artichokes soon after and they were good but definitely could have used a dash of citrus to break up the heavy oil and saltiness of the dish. Just a squeeze of lemon and it wouldve been great.

The pastas looked and sounded so good but were ultimately pretty average to disappointing. The texture on both the gnocchi and lasagna were great but the sauce fell so short. I ate maybe less than half of the lasagna before feeling sick of it.

Really don't find that this place deserves the hype/long wait times that it gets, and not sure why as the food is just fine and the service is subpar, I'd say. On a Thursday at 6:30 pm, they had a 3.5 hour wait for the inside, so we dined outside immediately - great!

The starter bread (for $5 FYI) is solid - the bread is a bit mealy, but great olive oil and olives as well. I thought the fried artichoke appetizer was pretty good, considering they're not my favorite vegetable; I was impressed with how crispy they got them to be and I thought they were flavored nicely, although I got a bit tired of them by the end since they end up just being like fries.

I was disappointed I'd say with the pasta. The gnocchi I got was cooked so beautifully (like perfectly collapsed in my mouth), but the sauce was extremely bland. Nothing interesting about it at all that I think calling it a bolognese was a stretch. The presentation was mid with the weak shredded cheese on top and I wasn't too thrilled about the final product. Very similar comments about the lasagna too.

Service was pretty slow and not super attentive I'd say, but I get it, they're busy! Wouldn't come back on my own as the food didn't impress though.

One of the best meals I've had in a while. I Sodi is simple, refined, and understandably hard to get a reservation for. The servers know an incredible amount about what they are serving and seem to respect the establishment. Feel free to ask your server to make you a cocktail based on a specific description of what you're in the mood for and they'll seemingly read your mind and bring out exactly what you were looking for!

We started with the fried artichokes and a salad with apple, parmesan, walnuts, etc (not sure what it was called). Both were great, but the fried artichokes were definitely a hit. They are apparently their most popular appetizer.

For mains, my group shared the famous lasagna, the pappardelle al limone, the ravioli burro e salvia, and one of the specials, a lamb pasta in a burgundy sauce. We totally discovered why the lasagne a sugo was such a special dish, and as for the others they were all great, with the pappardelle Al limone a surprise hit (cooked in a parmesan sauce, it had a wonderful parmesan-lemon flavor).

Overall, I Sodi is a great dining experience. The inside of the new location is cozy and lively. If I lived in NYC, I would definitely make this a regular spot for nice Italian food. Shoutout Devon for being an amazing server and reading our minds when we described what we wanted to drink!!

It's been one of New York City's best Italian restaurants for years. The new location is great; slightly less cramped, and the pasta is as good as ever.

I think some people miss the concept of ISodi and expect saucy meatballs and fancy salads; leaving disappointed.  It's not trying to be Bad Roman or Via Carota (both great). In my experience, Rita is cooking food her parents and grandparents would have cooked. Expect simple quality ingredients, incredibly well prepared, and served without pretense.

If you go, get a Negroni. They're all delicious and have been some of NYC's best Negronis for years.

Came right at 4:30 pm and was able to get bar seating immediately. Friendly bartenders provided expertly crafted drinks and served our food. Started with bread and olives - bread was warm and delicious with olive oil. Started with a great antipasto platter with delicious meat, cheese and honey. On special was the fried artichoke hearts which was incredible. We split the meat lasagna, spinach and ricotta ravioli, and Parmesan limone pasta. They were all delicious but the meat lasagna was phenomenal and stood out. A nice small restaurant that gets busy and hard to get a reservation. It was a fun and enjoyable experience.

Oh I Sodi! I have dreamed of going to I sodi and never thought I would be able to get a reservation.  My friends and I were lucky enough to snag a table of 6 at 8:15 pm on a Friday the day of and were PUMPED! The vibe and ambiance inside was incredible. There are two dimly lit two rooms, one by the bar, one through the back and then a stunning outdoor patio. One compliant it is VERY quiet inside which I didn't expect and isn't what you typically find at the highly sought after and vibey WV spots. The waiters like many other yelpers have said are slightly pretentious and overall really not that helpful. We did find ourselves waiting and waiting for them to refill our wine glasses, and his took probably over 20 minutes before they were filled. Which is fine but not something you would expect at a place which such status.

The apps very great! The fried artichokes are a must, the meat and cheese board was delish and the burrata was good but not a must get. The lasagne sugo  was by far my favorite pasta dish and the special of the evening the pesto pasta  was very unique and delicious. I've had better cacio e Pepe and limon style pasta but they were still very good.

We were too full for deserve but the espresso martinis were good! I would def go back to sit on the patio!

FYI / PSA - I didn't catch it on the menu if it's there but so-so bread and olive oil will cost you 5 beans. So if wait staff asks if you want it, you know before the bill comes. :-)

It's deceptively small as you only see the front room when you walk in, but we asked and they had a back room and an outdoor space for those nice days. It was packed for a Monday so we were lucky to be seated.

Service was fine. The bruschetta I would get again - the cheese and tomato combo just worked for me. I thought the lasagna was over cooked. With all the layers maybe this is how it's got to be but not my preference. I finished most of it anyway because that's what I do. My friend enjoyed her pasta and has been here multiple times.

No dessert or bathroom visit.

Started with the fried artichokes. Tasted good but it needed a wedge of lemon or some sort of dipping sauce. It is also a huge dish. The two of us could only finish half of it.

The lasagna was gummy but had a meaty sauce. It looks great but disappoints at the end of the day.

The orichette was thick and doughy. It was handmade but that doesn't always make things better.

Service was attentive and good  though.

Best meal of our trip to New York. Reservations are impossible to get, but went with our good friend who lives nearby, is a regular and we thankfully got right in. Our server, Chris, was friendly. Professional and warm. Every dish was simple, but delicious, made with the highest quality ingredients.

We started with a round of Negronis and the fried artichokes which were so crispy, salty and highly addictive! Then we ordered a bottle of exquisite Chianti and had two salads between the 4 of us - the Valeriana  (mache, pecorino and balsamic vinegar) and the Rucola e Castelmagno (arugula w/ castelmagno cheese) - both were incredible - and the arugula was just 3 ingredients - arugula, olive oil and cheese - but again, perfection.

For our next course, We split 2 pastas, the Cacio e Pepe (spaghetti chiatarra w/ black pepper and pecorino) - one of the best I've had - and spinach Ravioli Burro e Salvia (spinach and ricotta ravioli in a traditional butter and sage sauce) - so good.

For our entree, the 4 of us split the Ribeye special "for 2" - but it more than fed 4. We ordered it medium, which was perfect for us - still very pink, more like a medium rare. So flavorful. Also had a side of the spinach (very fresh) and the dainty peas (purposefully well-cooked, but a little mushy for me).

Then, we saved just enough room for two affogatos which were incredible, and one espresso martini, such a warm, cozy, friendly place. We thoroughly enjoyed every minute, and hope we are able to return next time we're in town.

The place was cozy and simple. It was hard to score a resy so I had high expectations. Given how hard it is to get a resy, you will have better chance lining up when it opens and get a bar seat. We ordered several dishes:

- Burrata E Prosciutto: the burrata was fresh and the prosciutto was yummy
- Maltagliati sul agnello: this was one of the specials. It was handmade pasta with mushroom and lamb. The pasta texture was so yummy and the sauce was tasty
- Lasagna sugo: this was what I Sodi was known for. Personally I'm not a mushy lasagna person so even getting half of the dishes was too overbearing. I mainly tasted the meat and the sauce, did not taste much of the pasta sheet texture when eating. The burn on top was a nice touch.
- Cacio e pepe: we got the lasagna and the cacio e pepe at the same time and decided to go with the lasagna first. By the time we got to the cacio e pepe, it was kinda hard and cold, so I was not impressed at all. The pasta was cooked al dente, the sauce was not impressive.

Overall, only 2 out of 4 dishes were good. The two famous dishes were either not my cup of tea, or I didn't give it a fair chance (given I didn't taste it warm). As for me, I prefer other Italian spots in the city than here.

TL;DR: Rita Sodi presents her self-taught flair in form of simple no nonsense Tuscan. The food boosts elegant simplicity; don't expect pastas basted in overpowering sauces. Worth of visit for the incredible lasagna alone.

I recently visited i Sodi and had a wonderful dining experience. The standout dish for me was definitely the Lasagna a Sugo, which lived up to the hype with its perfect pasta-to-sauce ratio. It was very memorable; all the ingredients blended in amazingly. The pasta sheets practically "melted" in your mouth, against the sharp cheese and rich beef. Plus, the portion was huge, easily feeding 2-4 people.

While some of the other dishes weren't as memorable as the lasagna, I did enjoy the burrata, which has Marea's & Rezdoras beat by a long shot. The burrata had a surprisingly tangy taste while being incredibly creamy and milky.

The cozy atmosphere of the restaurant added to the experience (only 8 tables), and the service was excellent. The waiters even offered us a drink while we waited for our table to be ready. Overall, while there are other good Italian spots in the area, i Sodi is definitely worth a visit for the amazing Lasagna a Sugo alone.

I don't know why people are not rating this place as high as it deserves. Yes, staff is a little pretentious and it is hard to get a table but the food is excellent. Stopped in without a reservation around 5-5:30 and wait was about an hour. Started the dinner with an order of Burrata then meat lasagna and orecchiette with sausage which was the special for the night. Both our meals and the starter were excellent. Our server asked us if we wanted bread but he didn't make it clear that they charge for it. It's not much, 5-6 bucks and we would have said yes if we knew they charge for the bread, but I thought it was odd that they offer bread as a menu item while it's not on the menu. Tiramisu was really good, mostly cream but tasted good.
Small cozy dining room. Totally recommend and I'm glad we were able to get a table.

5 stars for the Lasagna a Sugo!! This is the reason we came here and it was worth the hype. Perfect ratio of pasta to sauce. Didn't want it to end!

Also recommend the Tortellini stuffed with prosciutto if it's still on their specials menu. We got this as an appetizer and it was served in a nice broth

The rest of the dishes were good, but honestly not as memorable as the lasagna.
- Pappardelle Al limone: very light sauce so mixed reviews from the table. I personally liked this
- Fried artichokes: a little too fried for me. Could hardly taste artichoke
- Oxtail pasta: this was on their special's menu. The sauce was delicious but didn't pair well with the wheat pasta
- Tiramisu: this was a little different than traditional tiramisu. The top was super creamy/ custard like and very little espresso taste since there weren't soaked ladyfingers throughout. Personally would pass on this

The place is super small/cozy - makes sense why it's so hard to get a rez here. The service is excellent and waiters offered us a drink until our table was ready. Overall, worth it if you can snag a rez, but there are equally good Italian spots in the area

Honestly this place exceeded my expectations in every way. The lasagna is definitely worth it. Best lasagna I've ever had. The sheets of pasta are super thin and plentiful. Cutting into it feels like butter. The faro salad that was on the specials when I went was great. I'd skip the rabbit but we also got the pesto pasta dish and it was actually the best pesto I've ever had. Perfect nutty flavor and not too oily. 10/10

I Sodi is a small, dark, intimate Tuscan restaurant and dinner experience (although they are moving to a larger location sometime in the near future).

I was able to snag a reservation for four for 9PM and we ordered an app, a good number of pastas, and a little dessert family style. The carciofi fritti was great - the fried artichoke was crispy but "meaty" (in a good, hearty bite way?). It did not necessarily need it, but thought an aioli or sauce would've been a nice addition.

For the pastas, all were pretty solid. Both the meat and the vegetarian lasagnas (A Sugo and Carciofi) were pretty good, better to share and get a taste of versus get as your own entree. The Tortelli Di Castagne, the oxtail and mushroom pasta daily special, and the white truffle pasta daily special were good and I thought the caramelized onion and lemon pastas were the main standouts. The Tagliatelle Con Cipolla was like a French onion soup in wonderful pasta form and the Pappardelle Al limone was delicious, lemony, creamy goodness. The Paccheri Strascicati had a hearty meat sauce, but was a little too al dente. Zero regrets trying more of the pastas than fewer, but in hindsight do wish we tried a proper main while there.

For drinks, I tried their classic Negroni and another variation the server recommended. Both were good and did the job. I thought similarly about the desserts as well. We got the Torta Di Cioccolato (Flourless chocolate cake) with scoop of ice cream (gelato?) and tiramisu and it was a nice finish to the meal.

Well! Love Via Carota, love Buvette, was excited to try the food here. Not a great experience. After a lecture from the host on reservation vs wait list (we had a seating at 6:20) we were seated at a small table. As it turns out, the table abuts a wine storage room (??) so I had to get up twice during dinner, in heels, to let servers in. Really unprofessional. The wait staff blamed their architect. Lol.

Food was ok, but not what we expected. First, when my husband, who doesn't drink alcohol, tried to order a soda, he was told that the restaurant doesn't carry Coca-Cola products. Fine, but what soft drinks do you have? He was offered nothing but water. The artichoke starter and pastas were good but not great. (For what it's worth, our server butchered the Italian pronunciation throughout - better to just use English.) Pork secondi was not good at all and the spinach - no flavor, no seasoning at all - truly, tasted like a frozen block my mother used to reheat. We won't be back.

It was my date's bday and so we decided to go here to celebrate. He had it on his bookmarked and so we thought it would be a nice treat to check out a restaurant that both of us have never been too.

The ambiance was cute and warm. Though the table was quite annoying as the legs are located on all four sides instead of having a pillar right at the center. If there was a pillar then I would have felt more comfortably seated. Either case, this was minor in comparison to the food.

We ordered a slew of dishes. Starting from their fried artichoke hearts to their brussel sprout with cheese, to their charcuterie. For entree we ordered their pasta with cheese and peppers and lasagna.

Everything was a disappointment. Their artichoke does not come with any dipping sauce so just eating pure deep fried artichoke was way too much and oily. I felt like I was eating a bag of chips. Their brussel sprout tasted microwaved (according to my date's opinion) and sprinkled with cheese. As for their lasagna, it tasted like it's been sitting around all day and only sliced up when ordered. I dunno but for $28 a dish, I expected more. I thought each lasanga dishes would be made to order but it seems like it's precooked and then cut per order.

The only dish that was decent was the pasta with cheese and peppercorn and their charuterie. Both my date and I was left feeling disappointed and oh yeah....if the restaurant offer your their house bread, please note that it's $5 a roll.  This irks me because there were no mentioning on their menu that their house bread roll were $5.

Either case, there are so many italian eateries in this neighborhood and I would strongly suggest to think twice before going here. The quality of the food does not stand up to their price tag.

The only thing that I liked was that my date was happy that we went out and got to experience something we both can agree that we didn't like.

One of the best places for pasta in all of NYC and beyond. The setting is perfect, great neighborhood, and phenomenal staff. The lasagna is what made them famous and make sure to get it! They even have a vegetarian version that is also amazing! A very filling meal and worth every penny

Absolutely delicious restaurant in West Village! Came here and put our name down as a walk in on Friday at 4:45 and we got a table about 45 min later.

We went the full special menu and got truffle pasta, oxtail and mushroom pasta and roasted carrots. All were amazing. The truffle had a nice truffle butter and fresh truffle shaved on top. The oxtail and mushroom had every flavor one could want and had a very wide noodle shape which was a fun change of pace. The carrots were honestly the best part though, they were roasted long enough to fall apart with a fork and had a nice balsamic flavor to them.

Highly recommend this spot if you can get a table or a spot at the bar!!

This place is the perfect example of how reviews are completely flawed. This is an excellent restaurant.....period. You gave this place a 3.7?  You had bad service or have no taste in food. Every single thing we had was absolutely delicious from the pastas and the insanely delicious Lasagna to the ribeye steak which was literally perfection. Everyone who gave this place a 3.7 should understand you literally don't know food and should stick to 5 napkin burger.

I really enjoyed the lasagna and ribeye steak here!  
I actually liked the steak here way more than 4 Charles prime rib.

It's a very intimate restaurant as it's not very big, the waiters are quite knowledgeable in the wine list that they have.

If you manage to get a reservation here, order as much as you can!

Such an amazing dining experience and by far the best meat lasagna of my life. The restaurant itself is small so I would highly recommend having a reservation. Our group of four came on a Friday night at prime dinner time and every single seat in the house was full, including all bar seats. Service was incredibly quick, efficient, and helpful with our menu selections.

We got the prosciutto and fried asparagus chips to start. Four our mains, we had the cacio e pepe, ravioli, meat lasagna and one of the daily special pastas. We finished our meal with the tiramisu and panna cotta. Everything was delicious, flavorful, and cooked to perfection. I highly recommend this spot and they even deliver with DoorDash and I'd have to say, the lasagna does travel well.

I had an appalling experience here, which is extremely disappointing because I frequented I Sodi as well as the sister restaurants (Via Carota, Buvette, Bar Pisellino) frequently during the pandemic.

We had a mix up with our reservation information and the host's behavior was outrageous. He was condescending and rolled his eyes at us. It was beyond belief to be treated with such rudeness when we were prepared to spend +$300 on dinner for two for a special occasion.

I usually aim to look for the positives in my reviews (my profile speaks for itself with +40 5 star reviews) and in the case of such a bad experience would normally reach out directly to the restaurant before posting on yelp, but the phone line is unattended and, even more shockingly, there are many other similar reviews on yelp and google calling out this exact host's behavior - so it's hard to imagine the restaurant takes their hospitality seriously when this behavior apparently goes unaddressed.

I'm sure they will continue to fill tables with tourists, but this is no way to run a restaurant if you want to attract locals, and it's clear the operation is resting on their laurels. There are many more hospitable restaurants on this block worth your money on this block, let alone in NYC.

We finally tried the famous Isodi lasagna. I loved it (10/10). It was one of the best lasagnas I have had in my life, but my husband said it was only alright because their lasagna was not cheesy enough. Some people might say it's dry.. but hey, it was worth trying it! It's definitely a different style of lasagna. We also ordered orecchiette with sausage which was the special for the night, this one was extremely salty for me and I honestly did not like it (2/5). Special salad (bean with basil/mint) was delicious. We couldn't finish everything and we were very full at the end. They also have great wine selections, cocktail (Especially negroni) was delicious, ambience was great, and service was great.

I was really looking forward to having dinner at I Sodi, but I left disappointed. First off, it is nearly impossible to get a reservation. I went on Resy as soon as reservations opened for the date I wanted to have dinner and nothing was available. However, I emailed the restaurant and Chris was nice enough to get me a table for the date I wanted. Prior to dining at I Sodi, I informed the restaurant we were celebrating a 30th birthday. Unfortunately, there was no candle or acknowledgment with the dessert we ordered. We ordered a bottle of wine that our waiter recommended -- the wine was awful and was insanely marked up. For appetizers, the Fried Artichokes were pretty good and the portion size is large. The bread is nothing special so I would recommend skipping on that. The Cacio e Pepe was fine -- it lacked flavor. The pasta with marinara sauce and cheese was good. The Eggplant Parmesan special was nothing special. The Lasagna is the only dish I would go back for -- that was delicious. We ordered an Affogato for dessert, but we received two desserts that we did not order; when we told the server, he took them off our table rather than offering to let us enjoy them as they were sitting at our table for quite some time. Overall, the food and service were just okay. For the price of the entire meal, I was disappointed.

I visited I Sodi with a girlfriend during a weekend trip to the city. We were able to get seats at the bar right away and the service from the bartender was fantastic! He was able to recommend wonderful wines to both of us based on what we were looking for. He was also helpful when it came time for our meal selection - ensuring we picked options that paired well together.

We split everything and my friend even had some leftovers that she was able to bring home for dinner the next day.

You can't go wrong with Cacio e Pepe - it was one of the best I've had! We also HAD to try the lasagna after seeing it all over Yelp and it did not disappoint. I would definitely visit here again and either get the same dishes or try something new - the menu had plenty of options!

This place is insane. I've been here twice within a month because I couldn't stop thinking about their menu.

Whatever popularity ISodi has is worth the struggle of fighting for a table. I did both the walk in bar seat and the table via reservation seat. Amazing both times

They're famous dish-- the lasagna was huge it's really flavorful. The texture it was a bit mushy which is different but not bad. The cheese sprinkled on top is perfect. I reheated it for lunch the next day and it was still amazing.

The cacio e Pepe was the best I'd ever had. Like, I'm my entire life. So creamy yet light. At risk of sounding like a broken record, it was so flavorful (because I'm convinced every dish on their menu is insanely flavorful).

The service is good. They could be a bit more kind, especially given how few tables there are. Speaking of tables, the interior at isodi is romantically lit the tables are near each other but not too squished. It's intimate and cozy with an upscale vibe.

I left isodi telling all of my friends they needed to visit. Stat.

Solid Italian spot in the village. We had their meat lasagna, oxtail tagliatelle, artichoke salad, and flourless chocolate cake. I didn't think the lasagna was that memorable as it felt a bit dry, however - the oxtail tagliatelle (their daily special) was INCREDIBLE. We sat at the bar which was a great vibe and the bartenders were friendly. Their cocktails were also strong.

Nice cozy restaurant. The food and the service are all good. The drinks are mostly negronis and martinis but pretty good as well.

They hit above their weight from appetizers to the mains. Worth going to if you are in the area for no frills Italian dishes.

I've been wanting to try this place for a while now and it lived up to our expectations! No wonder it's hard to get a reservation, since the interior is quite small - they really fit as many tables as possible in! The atmosphere is nice though and dimly lit, and the service was quick.

For the food, we shared the lasagna with meat sauce and the tortellini special of the day. We also got bread and olives (which was $5, not included).

Lasagna - worth the hype!! I loved all the layers and it was filled with meat sauce. Not too oily, saucy, or cheesy at all! And we were able to comfortably finish it despite the generous portion.

Tortellini - I love when you can taste that the pasta dough is handmade, and this one is just that! The broth is super nice, light and flavorful, and complements the tortellini well!

They have a wonderful selection of Italian wines as well and our server knew exactly what to recommend to us!

Right away when I saw the menu, I knew I wanted that multi layer Lasagna a Sugo! I've only seen a multilayer lasagna like that in instagram photos, but the real thing doesn't disappoint! I ordered it to go so the photo doesn't do it justice, but it was hands down the best lasagna I've had so far!

So...I Sodi was high on my list of restaurants to visit as it is widely considered one of the best Italian restaurants to go to in NYC.  I woke up at 12am to get the reservation and snagged one for a Friday at 4:45.

Honestly I wish I had just gone somewhere else.

I don't understand the hype here.  There was a line of people already waiting when me and my wife got there and honestly I was super excited to experience what even Infatuation called one of the best pasta restaurants in NY.

The service was ok, nothing to write home about.  The waiter offered us the homemade bread which we accepted but found out it was a $5 charge when we got the bill.

Now comes the food.  I ordered 3 pasta dishes and a meat dish since I wanted to try as much food as possible at a place that is considered one of the best.

Lasagna a Sugo: Like other reviewers have mentioned, this is probably the main dish that is recommended here, but it lacked in a lot of areas.  The dish came barely warm, and it was very soft in texture.  Not terrible, but not at all what was expected.

Pappardelle al Limone:  Well cooked pasta with butter, lemon, and pepper.  Ok?  Anybody with the ingredients available can make this, and possibly make it better.  Just very basic.

Ravioli Burro e Salvio: The best dish in our opinion.  Nothing to complain about here.   Great sauce and great pasta.

Cotolleta alla Milanese:  At first glance and taste it was perfect.  But when you cut deeper there is too much fat left on the pork, which for our personal preference is not a great texture to bite into.  Very gelatinous fat, but I will say it was seasoned well and fried perfectly.

The drinks I can say were spot on and delicious, at least for us.  

Really left disappointed here especially considering the hype.  We have visited other highly regarded Italian restaurants in NYC, which I will not name as to not make you guys think this is a biased review, and have had so much better experiences.  We have other places on our list that are highly regarded, but our experience here has made us possibly change our minds in visiting them.

Crossed our fingers and walked in to I Sodi on a rainy Friday about 5pm. Two seats at the bar just waiting for us, it was fate. Started with two negronis which were dynamite, $18 which is reasonable for NYC prices. Artichoke salad was honestly skippable, but they more than made up for it with their special: heirloom carpaccio w/ goat cheese. Got it in right before the season ended! Of course, had to get the lasagna and finally see for myself if it could meet the hype: it exceeded it. I don't normally order lasagna but this one blew us away and it is an absolute MUST TRY. Overall, four cocktails, two starters and and entree was about $125 pre-tip. I felt that was fair and I would absolutely return here, if they'd have me!

A resounding yes on I Sodi! Worth the hassle of getting the reservation.

We started with the artichokes which were amazing! They were beautifully light, with each leaf separating into crisp layers, while the heart was soft. I would definitely order this again.

For mains, we ordered a special porcini lamb pasta and the meat lasagna. I really liked the porcini lamb pasta (it tasted much better than it looked). The pasta came in these wide sheets that picked up the sauce well. The lasagna was also great and I enjoyed that it wasn't too saucy.

We finished with a flourless chocolate cake. Decadent and creamy, without being overly sweet. Definitely a great option, especially if you're impartial to chocolate, but otherwise it might be trying something else on the dessert menu.

It can be difficult to get a reservation here because it's such a small space inside, but I really enjoyed the experience! I'd love to come back soon.

Another amazing meal here. As always, we ordered way too much food: antipasto, a special side of carrots, three pastas (lasagna sugo, cacio pepe, and an orecchiette with broccoli rabe and sausage special), and two desserts (the flourless chocolate cake and gelato -- one scoop of chocolate and one scoop of stracciatella). We didn't finish everything and we were still very full at the end.

The lasagna is perfect and a must any time we come here. We hadn't done the cacio in a while and it is still among the very best in the city, but I'd still be willing to try something different next time given the heaviness of this and the lasagna (and all the amazing other options). The orecchiette was one of the best versions of this dish that I've had. The antipasto and desserts were amazing as well, as always (the stracciatella gelato was new to us and really great). The carrots were excellent too and I'd definitely consider getting these again if they had them next time.

This was one of my best meals! I had high expectations before getting a last-minute reservation, and I Sodi met them.

The atmosphere: it was a small restaurant with only around eight total tables. Half of the room is the bar, but the feel is like you're in the chef's apartment. It feels very intimate. I enjoyed the design.

The staff: was very kind and attentive. Our waitress was always around when we needed her and ensured we were well looked after. She was also very good at giving menu suggestions.

The food: was immaculate! The chef can make simple dishes incredibly flavorful and luxurious. The lasagna, Cacio e Pepe, and special oxtail pasta were all some of the best I've ever had. The flourless chocolate cake was also superb!

Cleanliness: the place was in order and nicely cleaned.

Husband and I walked in on a Friday night with no reservations and miraculously got in - this was right before they made the move to a larger location and we thought the smaller venue was perfectly cozy (although I'm excited to see the new spot!)

Drinks were excellent - we both love Negronis and the Negroni menu was to die for. So many options and the ones we ordered were very well made.

The food is what really stood out. My husband, notorious for not liking artichokes (a personality flaw that breaks my heart), couldn't get enough of the carciofi fritti appetizer, and neither could I. The real star of the show was their lasagna, which is what they're known for. Neither I nor my husband particularly love lasagna - I tend to think it's all just fine, and it wasn't very high up on my list of things to order. The server recommended it however and we are so glad we followed that recommendation - it was easily the best pasta dish we've had in ages.

We can't wait for them to open in their new spot so we can have dinner there again!

We walked in on a Saturday night and got there just before they opened at 4. We were seated at the bar and thrilled to have gotten in. I had high hopes for this restaurant; but it was really good, not great. Service is wonderful and wine is good. The pasta is divine but heavy. Don't skip dessert- you can't go wrong!

The verza salad may have been our favorite dish of the night. It was very creamy and delicious. We also really enjoyed the fried artichokes appetizer. For our main course we split a variety of pasta dishes along with a pork cutlet. My favorite pasta dish was the caramelized onion pasta. The meat lasagna was very good as well though I do wish it had been baked for slightly less time as the sauce was a bit dry.

This establishment is getting 2 stars due to very poor customer service!!! First of all, making a reservation via Resy has not been working through their website. Due to this, I have tried calling the restaurant maybe 10 times and NO ONE answers the phone. How do you run a business and not answer your phone? When it finally goes to voicemail, you can't leave one since the user didn't set it up. It's such a shame because I would love to try this restaurant out, but they are not helping their patrons!

Honestly not an Italian food expert but I've had better Italian food at an Olive Garden. Service was terrible--not sure if standard for NYC restaurant. Food took forever...forgot to bring bread, rushed through first courses only to wait an hour and 15 for dishes. Over hyped. Port cutlet cooked well. Cacio e pepe good. Tomato salad really good. Everything else was meh

Dinner for two at the bar with less than a twenty minute wait?  Yes, please!  I have been hearing/reading about I Sodi for years, and actually feel bad for restaurants like that because impossibly high expectations can be hard to satisfy.  We went in absolutely thrilled to be there and excited try the food.  Service was friendly and sans attitude. Towards the end of our meal, the bartender was lost in the weeds and everyone at our end of the bar had to wait for a variety of things.  In the meantime, it was fun to watch prospective diners timidly enter the dining room only to be tossed back into the vestibule of shame by the unflappable host.  

The dining room was warm and intimate, with a pleasant buzz.  Excellent negroni to start, great bottle of wine, and then the food...some hits, some misses.  Bread service got things off to a great start - loved the salted and peppered olive oil for dipping, and the delicious olives.  Steak tartar blew our minds - maybe the best ever?  But the artichoke salad reminded why I wasn't such a big fan of artichokes to begin with.  The ravioli completely satisfied, but the lasagna will reign supreme as the biggest dining letdown this year.  After seeing photograph after photograph of its beautiful, bechamel slicked layers, imagine our disappointment to find it completely dry and un-voluptuous.  And the tirimisu was worse - way too much mascarpone, way too few boozy ladyfingers.  

We were almost won over by I Sodi, but Il Buco kind of serves the same purpose, and it's not impossible to get into.  We came, we saw...

Walked in early on a Thursday evening and had to wait 15 minutes for seating at the bar. The restaurant is small and intimate. Service was excellent and staff was friendly. We started out with a couple glasses of wine, bread, olives, and the Burrata. The Burrata with prosciutto was excellent! For our mains we split the Cacio E Pepe followed by the Fried Pork Chop. Both were delicious! I am a big fan of Cacio E Pepe and I Sodi's did not disappoint. Pasta tasted freshly made and the sauce was perfection! Highly recommend all dishes. Reservations are difficult to get. If you arrive around 5pm the wait is not too long for bar seating.

Phenomenal lasagna. Phenomenal food, and the host could be a little mean if you are putting your name down / waiting to get seated, but it is understandable after all since this is a roughly 30 people spot restaurant and everyone and their mothers are in town trying to get a seat. Portions are a lot bigger than you think, and the wait for 2 people on a Friday night at 5:30pm is 3 hours. Still better than the impossible Resy to nab, which fwiw comes out at midnight.

Isodi: An Evening of Romance and Great Food

My girlfriend and I celebrated our 5-week anniversary with a date night at Isodi, and it was quite an experience. Initially seated in the garden, we enjoyed the ambiance, but found ourselves next to some enthusiastic village gossipers. Thankfully, the staff was incredibly accommodating and moved us inside to escape the scorching 90-degree heat and 80% humidity at 9 pm.

While the free bread was a bit dense for our liking, the real star of the show was the lasagna. It was truly out of this world, and it got us pondering whether Isodi or Don Angie's could claim the title for the best lasagna in town.

Isodi's brand-new decor and vibe added to the overall experience. The attention to detail in creating a cozy yet chic atmosphere was impressive.

As a self-proclaimed picky eater, I have to say that I sodi exceeded my expectations. It's a place worth revisiting for its great food and fantastic ambiance, making it perfect for a romantic night out.

Ladies and gentlemen, gather 'round because I've got another culinary tale to spin, and this time our adventure led us to the enchanting realm of I Sodi. Prepare to be dazzled!

From the moment we stepped into I Sodi, it was clear that we were in for something special. The atmosphere was cozy and inviting, making us feel like we'd just stumbled upon a well-kept secret in the heart of NYC. But the real magic happened when our waiter, Chris, waltzed into our lives.

Chris, the culinary shaman of the evening, was nothing short of amazing. He greeted us with a warmth and charm that instantly put us at ease. His wit and kindness added an extra layer of delight to our dining experience, and we knew we were in good hands.

Now, let's talk about the food. Chris, our trusty guide, recommended the lasagna, and folks, let me tell you, it was like a comforting hug in your mouth. Imagine layers of pasta, cheese, and rich, savory sauce coming together in a harmonious symphony of flavors. With each bite, it felt like all the worries in the world simply melted away. It was the kind of dish that makes you believe that, yes, everything is going to be okay. The fried artichoke was also so crispy and nothing like I've ever eaten before

Our meal at I Sodi was nothing short of incredible. Every dish we tried was a testament to the artistry of their kitchen. From the appetizers to the desserts, each plate was a work of culinary genius.

But it wasn't just the food that made our evening memorable; it was Chris, our culinary shaman, who elevated the entire experience. His recommendations were spot-on, and his service was top-notch. We can't thank him enough for guiding us through this gastronomic journey.

In conclusion, if you find yourself in NYC and in need of a remarkable dining experience, look no further than I Sodi. The food is exceptional, the ambiance is inviting, and Chris, our waiter, is the icing on the cake. This is a place where culinary dreams come true, and we highly recommend it to anyone seeking a memorable meal. Thank you, Chris, for making our evening unforgettable. Cheers to I Sodi, where food is a warm embrace for the soul!

Everything was perfect. The service, the wine, the lasagna, the broccoli and sausage pasta.

I didn't know lasagna could be that good.

I Sodi has the noteriety of being the hardest reservation to get in nyc, and while i always love a challenge if the food lives up to the hype, this place is decidedly is not worth the trouble. my friend wanted to go here for her birthday dinner and made a reservation for 4 people right when reservations were released, and still was only able to get a table at 5pm.

the restaurant is cozy and chic, service was attentive and friendly, but the food left me underwhelmed.

we ordered a number of dishes so i was able to try a bit of everything, we ordered some appetizers, one of the salads which was forgettable, the artichoke fritti was also a miss for us as it was over fried, but my friends enjoyed the steak tartare. their lasagna tasted pretty good although served lukewarm, be warned it's extremely dense and rich, after a few bites we were done honestly. they didn't have the tagliatelle capriossa on the menu, or any pastas that featured tomatoes for that matter because the waiter said they were out of season... so I ordered the lemon papparadelle and it was just fine. one of my friends who is gluten free got the short rib and polenta but it was such a small portion of short rib she was still hungry.

I Sodi was i guess decent enough, but with so many other excellent italian restaurants in the city, i would say don't bother setting that alarm at midnight to get a reservation here.

Good clean place. Has good quick snack foods like empanadas and fully stocked fresh squeezed fruits and vegetables bar and prices are reasonable.

What I mean by fully stocked is that they have a variety and options of  proteins, fruits, vegetables and Wheatgrass. etc.

Giving them a 3 solely based on how delicious their smoothies and juices are.

Aside from that, if you're ordering food, make sure you order at least 35 minute before you actually need it. It takes forever.

They also have a rewards card but it is extremely misleading. The card says "Buy 8 Get 1 Free Small Green Juice or Medium Fruit Smoothie". Depending on who rings you up, they have their own translation of this. One woman will punch it based on how many smoothies you buy (2 smoothies 2 punches or 1 smoothie 1 punch). Makes sense. Others will punch it based on your number of visits (2 smoothies in one visit 1 punch).

Today I went in and ordered 2 smoothies. One Medium Green Machine and one Medium Berry Blast (fruit smoothie). I handed her my card which has 7 punches (1 more punch for 1 free) and she told me that I got two mediums. Right. One medium green smoothie and One medium fruit smoothie which is part of the "reward". Once I pointed it out to her she goes "oh well we can only punch it once because it's one punch per visit". So I proceeded to tell her that the policy was stupid and doesn't make sense because the card clearly states BUY 8 GET 1 FREE. Then I had to go back in because she never punched it for my 8th time

If this place doesn't want to give out things free, I respect that. Just get rid of your stupid punch card that makes no sense.
