There is few places you may visit in the city, even as a native New Yorker, where you feel as important as Aron Judge at Yankee Stadium, Il Mulino Uptown is it!
Let's forget how FANTASTIC the food is, the service is 1000% better!

I travel around the world, eat at many places, yet when I comes to feeling at home with amazing food, I will always crave the love at this establishment.

With a staff that will do ANYTHING to make sure you experience is unmatched, this is all thanks to their amazing Mangar Wayne! He has taken this place to new heights not just in customer service, but in sheer culinary bliss.

Anytime you want that staple, that at home feeling, and the place you will always craze to return, go see Wayne and Il Mulino Uptown; I'd say tell them I sent you, but you'd get treated just the same.
Great food, atmosphere and service. Would recommend to anyone in the neighborhood looking for an Italian meal

I rarely ever post so when I do it is most definitely saying something. I went to Il Mulino - Uptown for a much needed girls night, first time ever at this restaurant as well, and I left speechless. Everything from the moment we walked in to leaving was spectacular. We started with drinks and appetizers then entrees and desert. The entire time the staff made sure every detail was on point. I do not think we said one word during dinner that's how amazing our food was!!! The General Manager, Wayne came over to ensure we were happy with our food and when asked if there was anything to make it better we were silent.

I cannot say enough about the quality and taste of the food from the Burrata, Baked Clams, Branzino and finishing off with desert.......I have no words except spectacular. Spectacular service from the second we stepped inside, food, ambiance, the level of care each employee puts in and the finishing touch of the GMs care and diligence to customer service....this restaurant shot to my favorite in the city. My girlfriends and I will be making this a favorite and we already have plans to go back next weekend!

From a self proclaimed "Platinum Palate" foodie that's very mindful of everything I consume, Il Mulino has been and always will be the top tier five-star choice in fine Italian cuisine for me! From the unparalleled service to the insane bread they bring to the table, their vast selection of fine Italian wines and incomparable dishes, I am a regular fixture at this location. I cannot recommend them enough!
As for my favorite dishes, I highly recommend the jumbo red prawns, clams casino  and their specials of the day. Hell, I could easily recommend everything on the menu! They literally have the best bolognese I ever had in my life

These days, you can encounter heavily marketed competition who has social media clout resulting in overpriced, subpar dishes. I shopped the over hyped competition recently (which shall remain nameless)  only to run back to my 5 star staple in my 5 inch heels. Don't believe the hype in these other over amped places. It's very important to be able to discern between truly fine food and the clout associated with heavily marketed restaurants.  I frequent Italy often and this is on par with the cuisine that I eat frequently when I am in Milan and Puglia. Don't "play your palate" and don't disappoint yourself. Treat yourself to the best Italian in New York City for sure, possibly the best in the US!

A college recommend that we have dinner at Il Mulino and we thoroughly enjoyEd our experience from the charming and courteous staff through the delicious pasta and dessert. It was some of the best Italian food I've had outside Italy. We enjoyed it so much that we went back a second time during our week-long visit to New York City. I highly recommend it; excellent food, great atmosphere and wonderful service. You won't be disappointed.
The chicken parm is amazing. Location is great. Can't wait to be in the area again to try all the other apps we didn't get.
Looking for a very intimate perfect setting for a  nyc date night .. well here it is the best service the best food! They really make you feel like part of the family..

Celebrated my birthday on Saturday! I have to say that this is the most popular Italian restaurant in New York ! Food was wonderful! We started with a combination of appetizers made with Argentinian shrimp , vongole casino and amazing Cesar Salads made in front of us . The mains where pappardelle with black truffles for all and Dover Sole ! Amazing servers very caring and knowledgeable! Wine list was extravagant! We had Cristal and  a vintage bottle of Solaia 2004 ! Loved the red roses and the retro decor .

I visited the Uptown location (60th Street) and I had an amazing time. My husband and I were celebrating our anniversary, we didn't mention it to them but it's like they knew we were celebrating something...
Service was amazing and food was just on point! Next time you visit ask for Wayne, he will treat you like royalty. We felt like we've known him for years.
We will be back!
Wonderful New York style Italian. Service was impeccable. Prawns were a bit overrated in my opinion. Wonderful wine selection.

We dined here recently on a busy Saturday evening and the experience was a frenzied circus and NOT an enjoyable dining experience.

Pros:
Food all excellent at fair NYC prices.
Excellent complimentary Parm Cheese, bruschetta, eggplant and different types of bread to choose from.
Seated immediately at our reservation time although at the worst table in the restaurant.

Cons:
The waiters and busboys literally run around the restaurant like chickens with their head cut off. It seems like they're all on speed or catnip. It was laughable and strange and made us feel like they were trying to turnover the tables as fast as possible without regard for how it made customers feel.
We had so many waiters and busboys serve us we didn't really know who to ask for anything. They are all nice just too many and chaotic.
Don't dare ask for any additional complimentary bread or cheese as they will pretend like they didn't hear you and walk away.
Don't dare ask for a better table as they will pretend they didn't hear you.
The volume in the restaurant is off the charts loud as the tables are on top of each other in what is a very small dining room to begin with. Our table of 4 couldn't hear each other talk all night and were constantly bumped into by waiters, busboys and other customers.
This restaurant has such great potential since the food is excellent but they seem to be more concerned with speed, table turnover and using every inch of space rather than providing a relaxing dining experience.
We will not be back. There are too many great Italian restaurants in NYC that provide a fine dining experience without the circus like pace.
MANAGEMENT RELAX & SLOW THINGS DOWN!

Cannot say enough good things. I had to go off menu with their specials and so did my fiancé, but suffice it to say, everything they make is PERFECT. I could have used a few minutes alone to cool down after those figs and Gorgonzola. It was a special romantic bday dinner, and every single part of the evening was perfect. They are generous and thoughtful in their service, and they go out of their way to make your experience meaningful.

Eat here. I'm serious.
My favorite restaurant in the whole wide world. The best service, best food, and such a cozy and comfortable space. My home away from home.

All pasta made on premises daily so you know it will be fresh. Dining at a location where Obama and Clinton met deserves high expectations. Seafood linguini and veal parm was flavorful and quick to serve. Enjoy the tiramisu
Place was extremely loud and the tables are crammed together. We couldn't hear each other talk

First thing to know is this restaurant has different ownership than the original village Il Mulino . Similar but less extensive format and good food. BTW do not try to use a Il Mulino gift card here. Will not accept. Lovely space, good food , great service and upper east side pricing....come prepared and don't expect Il Mulino.
Not the original Il Mulino in the village, but just as good. A bit crowded and noisy but service and food could not be better. Looking forward to going again.

I rarely do these type of reviews because I am in the industry but I feel like I have to let people know what they are possibly getting into.

Last night I dined at Il Mulino to celebrate my birthday with my best friend. She is disabled in a wheelchair which I stated in the reservation. Upon arriving we were met with the manager who was rude from the start. He said the only place for us was the table in front of the door and window because her wheelchair was too large to sit at a table in the back. We knew that this was BS bc 1) we can see and 2) it would have been a state violation. He just did not want to make room for us. Faced with this type of discrimination before, to prove a point my friend asked to use the restroom which is located in the back of the restaurant. Shocker- we had no issues getting to the back. We noticed open two tops we were able to be seated there away from the cold and draft.

Once seated, our waiter and other staff was nice and courteous. There were times during our dinner when we and other tables near us heard that same manager yelling at wait staff and being nasty to them.

As for food- the only thing that we enjoyed was the Papardelle Bolognese. The other dishes we ordered (Lamb Osso Bucco, Pollo Crosta, Broccoli Rabe, Mushrooms) was lacking in flavor and/or really oily. For instance we got a side of Wild Mushrooms which turned out to be sliced white button & cremini mushrooms, re-hydrated shitake with onion and bell pepper doused in olive oil. Nothing wild about that and with a $17 price point you feel cheated.

With all the hype and history attached to this place, they over sold and under delivered.

Il Mulino used to be a great restaurant before the pandemic. The staff is awful and the food is no longer what it used to be. It is no longer worth the money. If you want some old NYC ambiance, sure. But know that you can do better food, better ambiance, and definitely better prices. This place is just a name.

From the first moment at the table when you are swarmed with attention and food to the end of the meal, this is a top end dining experience.   The tables are small and close together creating a lively atmosphere.  The service is good, albeit filled with upsells.  The pasta was the highlight with perfect al dente bucatelli and spot on rigatoni.   Sauce was excellent.   Wines were over priced, but quality.   So much food that we didn't need dessert.   This time we got a concert from Maximo and the whole restaurant sang in Italian with him which was....odd... but enjoyable

I have been a fan of this place since i visited the downtown one decades ago.  The Uptown place misses.  There is an odd smell in the restaurant that others have noted.  The meal felt rushed and the decibel level for a three quarters full room had 3 of us yelling across the table to be heard.  Do not get the chicken palliard.  It is not prepared in the traditional French method and was very bland.  Do get the veal parm.  I am impressed with any dish that can have that level of shape transformation. The lobster and squid ink pasta was excellent.  It the prices were not obnoxiously high, i would probably have leaned into a 4 star rating.

I was excited to eat here but unfortunately it was very underwhelming. The food was bland and really nothing to write home about. I am on the hunt for my go to Italian restaurant in NYC and sadly this one is not it.

Also, the restaurant workers sit and eat in the same dining room where patrons are served. This does not create the right dining experience, in my opinion.

When I think of this place, the huge Parmesan wheel comes to mind. I like the experience they provide, old school Italians with a kick. They serve carved to the plate Parmesan cheese along with antipasti and fresh bread. Yummy, taste great. Calamari and marinara sauce were fantastic.

My entree however not so much. The shrimp scampi had a weird taste to it. I would have to guess that the shrimp were farm raised. The corn meals they feed sea creatures at farms gives them a different flavor as opposed to wild caught. The garlic was strong but whatever the shrimp was made of was stronger. I would make the suggestion for wild caught and to source shrimp from South America, worlds' greatest.

I tasted flourless chocolate cake, Tiramisu and ricotta cheesecake. They were all super good, delicious! My drink was nice and fused to perfection. Topped the night off with rare champagne, not prosseco, for those jokesters lol

For years I'll Mulino was a favorite splurge- great service and some of the best Italian food in NYC.  

Then they opened locations all over the place.

I ate a meal there tonight and it was awful.  Half of the food was inedible, the rest was just unpleasant.  I was stunned, but the waiter was not- I guess he is used to clearing away plates full of uneaten food.

I paid a pile of money and stopped for patsy's pizza on the way home.  It's an end of an era- I'll Mulino now sucks.

Would give my dinner here a 3.5 stars if I could. The restaurant smelled of marijuana and was uncomfortably hot inside. I think they were understaffed because it took us almost 45 minutes of being seated to order our food, and that was after actively flagging someone down. We told them we were celebrating a birthday and if they could bring out a candle or something in the dessert and our request was ignored.

I'm usually a huge il mulino fan but for the high price tag, you expect good service with a great ambiance and we got none of that. The food itself was delicious and came out very hot but that was about it.

If you want to be told to come in 2 hours earlier to get a table you Requested and to find out you still won't get that table, come here!!!
if you say you're very upset with the table that you've been given, because you requested, management will give you an answer like well... if you don't want sit here, eat elsewhere.

The dinner the service was perfect loved it.

Management on another note is extremely rude to tell us to go eat elsewhere if we're not happy with his table after we were told if we come in at 6:30 instead of 8:30 to get the table we requested that's absurd.

Keep in mind, our dinner ended around 8:12 pm and the table we requested had left by then. It's not as this table has a better view or anything we just didn't want to sit anywhere near people in a closed space due to the pandemic. They created these "outside" spaces with no airflow so of course a covid trap.

Let's keep in mind this is New York City we have over thousands of restaurants so we will no longer come to this restaurant and provide business here.

PS: we would dine here at least once every 2 weeks just thinking how they would treat first time customers.

Love the food, tolerate the service, choke on the pricing. Welcome to Il Mulino home of $50 pasta and gold-plated fried Calamari.

Pre-Covid a visit here was highly anticipated owing to the exquisite freshness, skilled plating and consistent excellence of the kitchen. On the downside, service can be all over the map... attentive and anticipatory one week and Lon Chaney the next - completely invisible.

It's Manhattan so prepare to pay but if they expect a king's ransom, consistency at a minimum should be on the menu. Five stars for the food, one for the random service. Let's call it a three.
We were terribly disappointed in restaurant. There's an odor which seems like exterminator or sewage problem.

This company is the worst of the worst. They donated a voucher for dinner to the make a wish foundation. I bought this voucher. With covid the Il Mulino in my city never reopened so I called the NY office and spoke with Wayne the regional manager and he said no problem whenever you come to NY we will honor it. A year later I spoke with Mariana and then with Andrea and I clearly explain the voucher situation and he says no problem and books my reservation. We get there at 8:30 for dinner and at 9:30 they say they can't honor the gift certificate.  They keep us waiting till 10:30 with no service.  What kind of organization would take back a charitable donation and not serve you? Andrea was so rude and it was embarrassing for my son to see how terrible some people and companies can actually be. They ruined our last night in the city.
My first time at this location.  It Lived up to the Il Mulino tradition.  Great place to spend an anniversary with my wife.

You could not pay me to patronize this business. Even if they offered me free dinners for life. This IS THE WORST, Absolute worse experience a human could fathom which regards to service. Food was also mediocre at best.
Let me start off with this trip to New York City for my daughter's birthday in February 2022. I have not posted as is so much to write about my experience. My daughter had a reservation for I think six people and decided it had to cancel three or four guest from her table. Immediately the person who took her car or who she saw while she was there was very annoyed and irritated that they had to change the number of people visiting in fact she was told if they do not keep the reservation they will be charge a $400 fee. On top of that they change my daughters location and made her and her a few friends sit in the front next to the door which is very very cold I believe it was snowing during that time. I2 was at the same restaurant with a client/vendor having dinner and arrive prior to my daughter Arriving mind you we had dinner and I dropped $600 for three people. Again the food was mediocre at best. My daughter was seated with her friends and they ordered through meals and one of the meals was very very spicy and basically just the flavor was not there she asked the waiter did she could talk to the manager because she didn't want to bit her frustration over the reservation the manager sitting at the bar ignored her. He ignored the whole table. I went over there and asked him to come have a conversation with us as I discovered he was Italian and my family living in Italy may help keen over some of the frustration. He agreed to come and then turned around and sent another server to our table. The server offered to take off the one meal that they were complaining about. That just was not enough because all we wanted to do is have a conversation with him. He comes over with the most disrespectful attitude and basically said I know you just don't want to pay the bill and told the server just to take the whole bill off and walked away. There was a lady sitting at the bar who was also talking to this manager and saying that she just didn't think we wanted to pay the bill. It's pretty ironic I just spent $600 an hour before and all of a sudden we are complaining not not wanting to pay your bill but just the attitude and the service with this reservation. I will say this at first I thought maybe he was racist because it's easy to fall into the gap. But after looking at some of the reviews I don't think that's the case. I understand we are in New York City and I understand New Yorkers tend to be more upfront then the service that you get in California where everyone caters to you but what I don't understand is that he felt it was his duty or obligation to demean us look down on us and be downright rude crude and disrespectful. I would never patronize this business I get in my life and all my friends go to Columbia and NYU and all the parents to visit their kids at college I will make sure that I will notify them to steer clear of this establishment.

Let me start off by saying i have been to their downtown location before and was so excited to go back to this closer location. We had a reservation for Friday night at 8. Service was good, but so much staff means everyone is constantly walking around a small tight space. It gets busy and loud, tables are very close to each other so you can hear your neighbors conversation. Their complimentary starter is SO good, its honestly one of the reasons i went back. They start you off with a piece of cheese, salami, fried zucchini and bruschetta. We asked for a second one because truthfully i could eat this alone all night. We got one of their specials for our appetizer- shrimp wrapped in bacon, it was good but nothing extraordinary. It was a bit on the salty side. Next, i got the linguine with seafood and my husband got the rib eye. Rib eye was phenomenal, cooked evenly and very juicy. My linguine was disappointing, it had way too much oregano and was not spicy at all, it was dry too. We ended with the Italian ricotta cheesecake which will always be my favorite. It's soft, creamy, and tastes like almond paste, very different from American cheesecake. Overall we had a good time, but our check came out to over $300 and considering I didn't enjoy my entree, it didn't feel worth it.

I've decided that whenever I come to New York I'm coming here  literally the service here is A1 ! I can not get over how sweet and carrying these people are! They make my experience so much worth it and food is amazing  !!! must try can't wait to be back

Disappointing on so many levels.  Noise level was ridiculous.  Service while attentive seemed to want to rush us.  Best part of the meal was the complimentary bruschetta.  I ordered the pappardelle with sausage.  Very strange dish.  It was pasta in a very gloppy, tasteless red sauce with what appeared to be small sausage meatballs.  "Homemade" tiramisu was nothing special.  Limoncello, also apparently made in house, however, was one other bright spot.  I was invited by friends who were in town who chose the restaurant and picked up the check.  I truly feel bad for them.  There are so many good dining options in the city.  By all means, avoid this pricey and substandard one.

I love this restaurant it is so nice it's not just the food or the atmosphere is the way to people treat you with respect and dignity no matter what color you are they were welcome you here you don't even have to be dressed up all fancy and stuff I had on hoodie the second time I went the first time I went I wasn't dressed for this restaurant either but they did not and have never did not need service and because of that it is one of my favorite places to go to while on the upper Eastside.. So someone took me to the restaurant back in July 20 21 and all I can remember it was the truffle pasta it was absolutely delicious also the appetizer they bring out with the tomatoes is absolutely phenomenal.. that misfit quiet not a lot of people I always go for lunch so I've never been there in the evening time but they say it gets pretty busy but I've never experienced it being busy yet I just like this place it's real quiet very discreet and you guys should go check it out definitely have the truffle pasta

Had dinner here last night before a show, and all of us walked out with a terrible taste in our mouths - literally and figuratively.  Can't say that it's not worth the price (which is ridiculous), because it's not worth going to at any price.  The only pleasant person there was the hostess.
Here are the highlights:  When one of us (we were 4) asked the surly waiter to repeat the specials, the the waiter responded with "well what is it that you want to know," then he told us that he was going to bring us our "freebies" (not something you would have possibly heard in the real Il Mulino).  When one of us asked for a little more of the bruschetta (a "freebie"), the answer was you'll have to pay for that.
The wines (again overpriced at $30+ a non-generous pour) are a C+ at best.  I ordered a Sancerre which I've never gone wrong with, and what came out was bland and watery.  My husband was kind enough to take it off my hands.  Having learned my lesson, I asked to taste a rose which also had practically no taste.  Then I asked to try 2 other whites.  Both were extremely disappointing and tasted like they came out of the same watered down bottle.  I had everyone at the table taste them to make sure it wasn't just me, and we were all in agreement.  After that the manager came over, sat close to me and rudely said "so you've tried all our whites, what is it that you want?!"  I ended up ordering a red that a friend was having, which was passable.  When I later (away from everyone) told the manager that he embarrassed me by making it seem like I wanted "free" wine, he became angry and almost aggressive.  

Finally the food - we were all disappointed, but mine was inedible (don't know if that was the manager's revenge).  The clams were made of rubber and the porcini ravioli tasted like they've been in the freezer for at least a year.

I hope the original Il Mulino downtown is still what it was!

Four us were there for dinner last night. We were given a great table.
I have always been a fan of the location south of Washington Square and
have been to this uptown location a copile of times.

Our dinner was a big disappointment.  Our waiter Z was friendly but rarely visited our table. We asked for bread several times. We asked for olive oil
4 times before we got it.
The wine steward was nice and we liked our bottle of wine. My wife wanted a glass of Sancerre.  After the fourth request it was finally delivered.
This was accomplished by flagging down staff as they passed by. It was a near constant struggle to get service.

We will not be back.

I eat with my dad at one of the outside tables 2 weekends ago. We shared  the escargot which were delicious. My dad had a steak dish and he enjoyed it. My shrimp scampi was OK but nothing spectacular. It was a long wait in-between courses and it took a very long while to have a order taken and at the end of the meal to have a check brought to us. It was obvious when the staff was waiting on regulars whom they hovered over and gave all their attention. At times I felt completely ignored. We've eaten in many of the best restaurants in New York and you shouldn't have to be a regular to get excellent service. My dad is also elderly and when I asked them to repeat the specials in a louder  voice so he could hear them, it was repeated but even I, with perfectly good hearing, barely made out the specials. I felt it was overpriced and there were several other all old school Italian restaurants that we frequent, that I much prefer.

what a marvelous restaurant in New York , with such an incredible team of professionals working there!  
Rubi is such an incredible manager, very kind and professional.
I super recommend this restaurant!
over here the food is so delicious and the service is spectacular... ...

thank you for your kindness and I can't wait to be back to such a beautiful place. Top top

Hands down fave restaurant in manhattan
Third time there and always amazing
Staff is so classy, yet warm and informative.
Their bruschetta is to die for. Perfect amount of garlic.
Red wine selection is out of this world
Do try their gluten free clam sauce linguine. Generous portion of clams even tho I order half size since I can't box anything (staying at hotel)
Love sitting at the bar- again, everyone is so hospitable.
Can't wait to be back.
We had the place to ourselves from noon to 145.  Private dining.  Great service. Great food.  Home run.

I came here during this past restaurant week once we arrived we were seated right away & once seated they start u off with quite the selection of breads , some salami & bruschetta add some fresh Parmesan cheese & then garlic pickle type chips oh man a lot of picking before your main meal, great tasting focaccia bread & bruschetta good salami & cheese.
Wine I had some Pinot Grecio never a bad option.
For appetizers we went with Meatball not bad good taste & the Fresh mozzarella & tomato great tasting fresh mozzarella.
Main dish I had the Chicken scarpariello very good great flavor to the chicken nice tasting sauce, not a huge mushroom fan but these were nice & fresh so it wasn't bad at all my friend had the Salmon w veggies very good tasting piece of salmon.
We also gave the Spaghetti carbonara a try wow .. so good great tasting pasta.  
For dessert we tried the Tiramisu not bad & the Pear ahh this was ok.  
Small location, nicely decorated .. prices r high but w restaurant week they are more doable.
My only complain was the service although it wasn't bad it was too rushed, waiters/ bus boys rushing to grab plates.. really not letting u finish pretty annoying to feel like u have to swallow your food & get up & run not a fan at all of being rushed didn't take off the extra star simply because the food was very good.

Sooo Disappointed. This was one of my most favorite NYC restaurants. The service tonight was beyond horrible. Initial waiter was impaired and could not remember the specials. After a long wait and complaining we finally got someone to take our order. Food was great and have no complaints about it. Was both amazed and shocked that after asking for a dessert menu nobody came to the table for 39 minutes. After complaining again a lady came and and told us some pathetic options. This used to be a first rate five star establishment. The service tonight was worse than a Dennys.

Very bad service!

The waiter was very impatient from the beginning. He was chewing something when talking to me. When I showed him the dishes on the menu that I'd like to order, he arrogantly said he can't see it while he was just standing beside me!

When the dishes came, I found he finally messed up our dishes and gave us the wrong ones. When I told him so, he was very impatient and seemed to be angry on me. He even heavily hit the wall on his way back!!

We are Asian. I am not sure whether that's the reason he treated us so, but I saw he showed totally different attitude which is humble to those tables with American.

It was really a terrible experience that I've never had!!

I just had the most disappointing Restaurant Week lunch at Il Mulino Uptown.  I have eaten at the Downtown location many times and it was wonderful.  The meal today was so medicore that I was shocked.  Ordering off of the Restaurant Week menu I ordered the ravioli which was frozen in the middle and when I sent it back they only gave me 2 because I ate half of the one that was cold.  My friend and I both had the Veal Marsala it was OK but not the quality I would have expected from a restaurant of that caliber.  The room is stuffy and pretentious but most importantly the food was not what I was expecting.

Love this place and have always ventured to the original location downtown. We didn't want to make the trek from midtown so we tried the uptown location.

Not sure why there are bad reviews. We felt the service was excellent. The food and experience where the same as if we went to the original location. Wow was it good! One of my favorite Italian restaurants in NYC. The food is consistently great!! My only grip would be the up charge on the wine. But this is NYC so I am use to that.

If in the city and midtown or uptown; you no longer have to go the original location.

Always an amazing experience here. The service is what you expect of a quality restaurant and the food is as well. You will never be disappointed with the Italian cuisine.  It's traditional Italian with no flare or fusion of any kind but the taste is elevated and the consistency is bar none.  The wine selection is also very good but dramatically reduced because of covid. I visited before covid and now during covid and nothing has changed, thankfully.
I'm so glad to be back here and thank you to the staff for working so hard.

Had a lovely lunch at Christmas there with my best friend. The whole experience was 5 star. Such a warm welcome from the manager and the staff. Rare to see for the past few months. Everything was spot on. The place was bursting from good energy. The food as you can see was done impeccably. Special thanks to servers from Montenegro and Croatia. Go Balkan!

Stopped up for an impromptu lunch at Il Mulino during restaurant week.  Had an amazing experience.  3 course meal for $39 and I was so full I passed on the dessert!  Started with the prosciutto with melon and berries.  So fresh and tasted amazing.  Had the veal parm for my main course.  One of the best I ever had.  Pounded real thin and the cheese was amazing.  And I can't forget about the service.  I had lunch at the bar and Wayne (regional manager) was amazing...beyond friendly and attentive.  He and Laura went out of their way to make it a great dining experience.  Can't wait to come back.

Terrible service. My boyfriend and I came here for my boyfriend's birthday (I put a note on opentable) and the servers only gave us the restaurant week menu and assumed that we wouldn't order anything from the regular dinner menu. Other tables were offered both menus so I'm not quite sure where does the discrimination come from? The entire time the servers had attitudes.  Service also felt rushed, we finished our meal within an hour.

Food was good though. But I won't be here again due to the service I received

Found this amazing, beautiful restaurant and decided to try it.

The owner Giovanni was so polite and accommodating when we arrive.  My friend and I ordered, Caprese and tuna tartare to start.
Both was very delicious and fresh.

Salmon and penne pasta were also very good and made to perfection.

The server Luigi was very friendly and professional.

The bottomline - we were 100%  satisfied customers.

Highly recommended!  

The food was very fresh and tasty.

This is honestly my worst experience in NY. NEVER go there unless you want to be forced to pay $26 tip without even knowing. First of all service is horrible. Wines and cocktails are HORRIBLE. Pasta was OK but definitely not worth $22 per dish.
In the end when we asked for the bill, our server just came to our table and took the credit card without showing the actual price to us. After that, when he brought the receipt we saw that he wrote HIMSELF $26 TIP!!! I started complaining and he said 20% is minimum tip everywhere in Manhattan, I said that it was not written anywhere and we had no chance to even see the bill we have to pay! After giving us attitude he gave us back the $26 saying he was right and its legal. When its so obvious if that was legal he would never give me back the money.
Honestly STAY AWAY from this place.

I'm a big fan of the corner trattoria or osteria. Nothing is more fun than finding a small, cozy restaurant where you can become a regular.  This was my hope for Il Riccio.  Unfortunately, it didn't work out that way.  The space is neutrally decorated.  The host and waitstaff were pleasant.  We were served uninspiring bread after being seated "not worth the calories," according to my wife.  My wife enjoyed her glass of Sauvignon Blanc. I tried a glass of Nero d'avola and another of Montepulciano and wasn't feeling the love.  The best part of the meal was my tricolore salad with Parmesan cheese.  Great combination and perfectly dressed.  My wife's branzino was meh.  I ordered the disappointing special of veal scaloppine with artichokes.  The veal was rubbery and hard to cut.  The plate of complimentary biscotti was a nice touch.  Unfortunately, they were burnt.  I ended the meal with a prosaic cup of cappuccino.  

There are many better places to eat.

Had lunch menu
Tricolore salad and Salmon main course.
Excellent food, the service is great.
I don't understand why this place doesn't have more stars.

I had previously given the restaurant four or five stars because it is very good. We went there all the time.  However, I was in an accident and am now in a wheelchair.  I called to make a reservation and whoever answered, told that they were not wheelchair accessible.  Further they told me that the restaurant is too small to be able to accommodate people in wheelchairs.  So much for them.

This is an amazing restaurant it's beautiful and makes you feel like you ARE in Italy. The food is superb the staff and owner are exceptional and don't get me started on how wonderful the food is. It's a great restaurant and I highly recommend visiting this gem!!

I came here after the Met Museum on a cold Friday night in February. I had searched Yelp for an Italian restaurant on the Upper East side near the museum and Il Riccio came up, usually I would go to Celeste on the UWS for Italian food after the museum but we needed to stay on the East side so we came here.

The service was fine and all of the folks working there were very nice and attentive.

My issue was that I found the food to be mediocre and the portions to be small for the prices charged. The bread was meh, the rigatoni with eggplant was average, the saffron ravioli, my friend had, was heavy on the saffron flavor and not special. The wine list only lists bottles, but they do serve by the glass, you have to ask what wine they have by the glass... I find that a little strange too, why not list the "by the glass" wines on the list?

I asked the waiter how long the restaurant had been open because I found it odd that there were only 38 reviews, the waiter said it's been there for 16 years...

Next time I'll go with my gut and eat at Candle 79 (right next door to Il Riccio) if I have to stay on the east side after a visit to the Met.

My daughter and I were looking for a "new" place on the UES and found of Il Riccio's website to be inviting.  My daughter was especially eager to try the rice balls, which were a favorite of hers when she studied in Italy.

The place is small but cute.  Except for the fact that it is on busy 79th Street, it reminds you of small restaurants on the Amalfi Coast.  Nice room in the back.

Menu was limited, although there were myriad specials offered.  The food did NOT live up to expectations.  Bread basket was "not worth the calories" as another Yelper noted.

The rice balls were no longer on the menu; many items listed on the website were no longer offered.   My appetizer, roasted asparagus with gorgonzola sauce, seemed like over-boiled asparagus with a bland white sauce splashed on and then some salty cheese baked on at the last minute.

Decided on the Frito Misto, usually an appetizer but here, offered as entrée.  It was good but the rather small portion, at $28 and served without even a basil leaf, was not enough.  My daughter's pasta, with asparagus and ricotta, was just "OK".

Service was attentive - a little too attentive.  Asked several times if we were ready to order, even though we told the waiter we wanted to order appetizers while we decided on entrees.

Another case of a lovely little neighborhood place that you want to love failing to deliver on a restaurant's most important charge - the food!

I went there last night for dinner. The most impressive thing was a pumpkin display to honor Halloween. I had to waive down the server to take our order. I ordered Grilled Salmon with spinach and it immediately hurt my stomach.
After the plates were cleared away, they dropped these Italian free (but kind of dry) biscuits on a plate, but didn't drop dessert menus. Apparently they recite the dessert menus. but the servers were doing the thing where they walk by but don't look in your direction, despite the place not being busy at all. FINALLY, after what seemed like an eternity, I flagged down a server and asked "CAN WE ORDER DESSERT?" and got tea and gelato, which was fine.

IF you are looking for good in the neighborhood, go to the Atlantic Grill.

Poor service, the waiter didn't seem to care about us, didn't check on us, nothing!
Be very specific when you choose a bottle of wine, point to your choice. If not, they may select a similarly named bottle on the 'reserve list'.  It'll cost double!
Il Riccio has lost its edge. Gotta find another Italian restaurant in the neighborhood.
Must try!! It's incredible Italian food, the desserts are heaven as well. Il Riccio is my go-to for takeout/delivery. I only wish they had beverages on the menu for delivery....

Great lunch special
Choice of salad pasta & dessert!
The gelatin of ricotta & honey is outrageous!
This places was really awful. Service at the end was bad, food was really bad. Literally made me ill. Even the bread was stale. I don't suggest this restaurant. Go somewhere better.

Ordered delivery that never came. Called twice. I was told the first time that the order would be ready to leave in ten minutes. The second call, 20 minutes later and 20 minutes before the restaurant closes, was told it was already out for delivery. Never came.

This restaurant is a nightmare to order from.  The person who took my order was extremely rude.  I gave him my cc and he called back that my card was declined.  I told him no way as I have to debt on any cards.  I then had to call the cc company and was on the phone for 20min to find out that he did not add (he did not ask me either) for the 3 digit code. I called him back with the cc company on the speaker phone and he did not want to hear it.   Food not so great either.  very rude people.
not getting my business anymore.

This is our go to for Italian take-out, but there have been some misses.  Surprisingly, the Penne with Meat Sauce was just not good.  It lacked flavor and there wasn't enough pasta. It was just a bunch of crumbled meat and carrots and not what we had in mind.  We had to doctor it a bit.  Also we did not enjoy the Fritto Misto.  The batter was very bland and the seafood was lackluster.  It was particularly disappointing given the price.

That said, what we do like, we really like!  They really do use fresh tomatoes and so the pasta dishes with emphasis on that are really tasty (for example, the Spaghetti with Crab Meat and Fresh Tomato).  The flat rigatoni dish is delicious as well!  The eggplant parmigian is wonderful!

I've had two of their chicken dishes and they were fine, just nothing that I go there for, but not lacking in flavor like the aforementioned dishes.

Cute little restaurant.  We were coming from an event on 80th and found this on the corner.

We stumbled in around 10pm on Friday.  Decent crowd.  They sat us down promptly.

We had some drinks.  The food was decent, nothing great really, but it was a convenient place to sit and have a few drinks.

Was for dinner couple nights ago with my partner.
The waiter was lost....most of the wines on the list not available, why presenting the wine list??
Took most of the time to get my bottle of montepulciano.
Food was fine..... some wrong with managment.

First course:

Some fried tasteless flat cake that they tell me contains eggplant and seafood. I taste neither. This may be fried air for all the flavor. Can't wait for the next course!

Second and third course came as one, thankfully. This helped us escape earlier. Pasta was too Al dented and clams were tiny. Veal was wasn't balanced, too much lemon and not enough butter.

Places like this baffle me. Pictures of celebs on their walls makes them credible?

Times Square has better food. Upper east side is perfect for rich people with no taste or tourists with no clue. Don't waste a dollar here.

Your welcome.

I reserved a table online specifying I came with a friend on a wheelchair. They were not prepared and the Maitre D was very unfriendly. We didn't feel welcomed at all in the place. Bad service (empty plates on the table for a long time, waiters never look at our table). Table near the bathrooms, kitchen and coat check and not to mention the food that was awful. They definately didn't want us there. Anyway that's ok we will never come back!
Best veal parmigiano  ever , good food , good service  , beautiful  ambience , real Italian  food

It's like this place and it's people get me. Really get me. I looked at the menu for a pasta dish that I was craving but they didn't have it so I was about to settle for another dish when the waiter told me their dinner specials and voila! The special of the night was exactly what I was craving. Their pasta is chewy and fresh, and served steaming hot with flavorful sauces and whatnot. Rounded out the meal with a cup of their cappuccino and biscotti on the house. Kissed my fingertips at the end of the meal...yeah it was that kind of good ;)

I had not ever been to this restaurant even though it is in my neighborhood. I decided to give it a try. Called and had my dinner delivered and it was excellent. They even included some delicious biscotti, which I don't generally like, as dessert. I decided I would go there and eat in. When I got there I saw that their  health code grade was pending. I don't eat any place that does not have an A rating. I know it is difficult because the streets are so chopped up and there are rats all over. I know the restaurants try very hard to keep their kitchens clean. I am not saying this restaurant has any rats but it did not have an A grade. I did not go in but called about a week later to see if they had gotten their grade. Either the owner or the manager, whom ever answered the phone, said "oh yes they always have an A grade. "I said if I come over will I see it in the window? "Oh no "they said we didn't get it yet. I called three more times about a week apart and whomever answered the phone said no we don't have it go somewhere else!
Not very nice.

I'm surprised this place has never been reviewed here considering it's been around on 79th St. at least as long as I have, which is a year and a half.  I suppose I'll have to say something useful for a change.

Il Riccio is a great little low-key Italian joint.  The menu is small, but authentic, and the wine list is fabulous.  My dad's boss took us here last night because he likes it, and this is a man who boasts rarely bothering to go to the same place twice.  Major food-snob... I'm still deciding how I feel about him.

Anyway, I had this salad with avocado, asparagus, carrots and beets, which was pretty ok except that I hate asparagus, carrots and beets and have no idea why I ordered it.  But I ate it.  Then I had lasagna with meatballs and prosciutto, which was super good.  Could've been a little hotter, though.

But what stole the show was my dad's Dover sole, which he had filleted with a little butter.  It was SO good.  It was on the specials menu, which is good because I'd otherwise be spending $50 on it every night.  My dad's not a big eater, so I ate half of his fish and couldn't even handle how delicious it was.  I still can't handle it.

The service wasn't that attentive, though, which is sad because the water boy was really sexy.  I kept downing my water so he'd come back to me, but sometimes he was nowhere to be found.  So much for true love.

Oh, but everyone here is middle-aged and richer than you, so watch out.  It seems like an okay date place despite that, but Candle 79 next door has a sexier ambiance.... or so my window gazing tells me.

Anyway, it was a solid experience.  Come visit!  Nobody ever visits my neighborhood..... :-(

UPDATE: Here is an additional sad face for Yosh, who is also sad nobody visits us.  :-(

I do not undersdtand the other reviews rating this restaurant 4+ stars.
I should have paid attention to the few in number.
My experience was disapointing; expensive fare, bland taste and nothing remotely interesting about the feel and vibe of Il Riccio.
Service seemed okay at first until I heard different "specials" being offered at another table.
They had several nie desserts on display but they were not offerred to us.
We don't get to NYC more that a few time per year and I feel so let down when we have dinner in a place like this. We won't get that time back.
There are so many decent places in NYC so don't waste it here.

So I came here with someone who knows the owner, and I got to try a medoly of dishes, of which were all really good.  The appetizers were amazing!  They make these zucchini fries, which taste JUST LIKE french fries, but their healthier for you, considering it's still fried, but who cares it was great.  Their cheeses and sliced meats were fresh and melts in your mouth.  To tell you the truth, I can't remember what my main course was because it was a couple of months ago.  I also remember all the desserts we tried.  We tried some sort of lemon and nut pie, dark chocolate cake or mousse, raspberry and blackberry tart, and tiramisu.  To tell you the truth, the only one I didn't enjoy as much was the lemon and nut pie, because I'm not a fan of citrus-y foods other than fruits and citrus in my salad, that's it.  

Oh, it's also a really small, quaint restaurant with a nice faux patio at the back.

My boyfriend and I came here for Valentine's Day around 6 PM. Restaurant definitely grew more crowded later on and there seemed to be a lot of regulars. First impression was that the staff is very nice and cordial, and I appreciated the fresh roses and chocolate hearts on our bread plates.

The menu selection had a good variety. Did not look at the drinks menu since we were not planning on drinking, but others tables had both wine and cocktails.

Bread basket came fast and there was a ton of bread in there, I wonder if any table ever finishes all the bread? Bread was soft and fresh, and oilve oil was good. We shared the anchovies appetizer which was really delicious, there was a good amount of acidity in the red peppers paired with the saltiness of anchovies.

For entrees I had rigatoni with prosciutto and vodka sauce, which was very good albeit slightly salty but that is to be expected with the prosciutto component, either way my boyfriend and I still finished the entire plate. My boyfriend had the special heart-shaped lobster ravioli, which we both thought were a bit "meh", although the fresh tomato sauce was excellent. The entire time our water was filled every 10 minutes or so and we were checked on twice by our waiter, which is nice. They also played jazzy-romantic music in the background and continued to dim the light, so atmosphere was definitely romantic, but it seemed like a family place because were were plenty of families sitting in the back with young kids.

Our plates were always quickly cleaned and they even cleared up the bread crumbs when we finished our entrees, overall service was excellent (almost to the point where it makes me feel guilty). A plate of biscotti was brought to us but we were both very full; coffee was offered but we declined because it was nighttime. We did not have dessert here because we were planning to go elsewhere.

Overall, crowds tended to be older but it's definitely a great place for couples as well as families!

Lovely birthday meal here: ravioli in saffron sauce and a chicken dish. The place was, oddly, empty on a Saturday at lunch time (a time when fools line up in the cold streets for cheap burgers).. One other table, and when they left, the owner's family occupied another table.

I will gladly go back!
My go-to for pasta delivery.  The food is always great and the delivery is fast.  Love this place, and it's a gem on bad weather nights.

5 stars for the food. Delicious and tastes very fresh. We had a chicken pricciuto dish and a stuffed ravioli with a delicious cream and veggies. The wine tasted great and the tiramisu was probably the best I've had. The only minus was when the server came out and said "freshly made hot coffee"...in burn-your-mouth hot mugs. Since it was 3.p.m, an odd time for lunch-I'm sure what he did was just microwave the coffee from that morning. In any case, I loved the food and won't mind going back. (Someone mentioned the bread was bad, and yeah it was)

Just enjoyed a delicious dinner at Il Riccio. My husband and I loved our homemade pastas. I had the crabmeat with fresh tomatoes and mozzarella pasta which I enjoyed with a crisp chardonnay and my husband raved about perfectly prepared homemade angel hair pasta with fresh vegetables. The homemade biscotti at the end were delicious as well.  Service was excellent and the glass enclosed garden room in the rear was charming.  The bill was extremely reasonable and we will return soon.

I brought my very well-travelled food snob dad here, and he loved it. I convinced him to try the pasta with vodka sauce, and we were both amazed. The blueberry tart and drip coffee were also spectacular.

The service is very good, the ambiance is nice yet relaxed, and remarkably for New York--it's not too loud!

Came here alone on an early Monday night.  Place was completely empty.  Staff was very nice---and there was a lot of staff---who, while I ate just stared at me.  I really hate that!  Another table of 3 came in 25 mins later and staff didn't move to tell them specials.  I had to punch staff.
I ate a wonderful avocado salad appetizer and 1/2 portion of orecchiette with sausage and broccoli rabe.  It was fattening / high cholesterol -- and yummy.  It's okay in small portions.
Seems to be local joint.  Looks like I'll be frequenting it!;-). Also, it takes Amex Delta card which is 3x the points!!!! Hello!;-)

My husband and I had the most delicious dinner last night at this charming neighborhood restaurant. My branzino was perfectly cooked and utterly delicious as was the broccoli side dish. The wait staff was attentive and did not rush us and the wine selections were excellent. All in all, it was a lovely evening!

Very poor expereince. Burnt appetizers and when we sent them back, the owner claimed "it's fried" and should be burnt.  Food otherwise was mediocre. Waiter was pleasant.  Spece was cramped and unappealing.  Would never go back.

Was a bit reluctant to pay going on $20 for the gluten free pasta with clams but was mightily impressed, both by the perfectly textured pasta and the numerous succulent clams in a finely balanced red sauce. Chicory salad with blood oranges and fennel was well balanced and light.
The Italian managers have a "Soprano's" energy: the greeting almost felt aggressive. On the other hand, the waiter looked down his nose when we didn't order three courses.
But over all a good experience that I'd repeat if I were in the neighborhood.

I went here with my family for dinner and we were all very pleased with il riccio! The food was delicious and service was wonderful. We were seated right away and the waiter helped us pick out some appetizers for the table. My boyfriend got the gnocchi which was delicious and I got the macaroni with crab which was awesome. Everything was very flavorful and you could tell it was made fresh. I will definitely be returning!

Found Il Riccio by accident--we were walking by and hungry for lunch. Couldn't have been more pleased. Intimate--even romantic--little restaurant, pretty perfect in every way. The gazpacho exceeded all expectation, superb Caesar salad. Overall terrific experience.
Overpriced and food not very good. Years ago it was fine but the quality and taste of the food has really slipped.

I did not have a particularly good experience here. Usually when announcing the specials the waiter announces the prices so you don't have to ask and appear cheap or price conscious. So anyway I ordered a special which he called striped bass and when the bill came. it was almost $40. But if it was great it would be worth it. It was not. Just ok. Striped bass is a big fish. But he served a small whole fish which if they scaled it and grilled would be good. But since the scales are on you can't eat the skin. And it wasn't grilled but oven baked. And it came with a salad which should have been brought out earlier but it wasn't. And bread was not warm but stale.  Or getting there. Sorry guys it will take more than a charming Italian accent to make it.

The pasta dishes were good depending on what, though gnocchi = awful. This place lost major points on bread. How is it possible that you get served low-quality, vaguely wheat-y, super-light, cold, and flavorless bread at a well-rated place during a Sat lunch?? The back terrace area we sat in had good sunlight due to sun roof, but all of our feet were freezing. Servers were abrupt and pushy. And let's not forget the B rating. I understand this could be due to luck, but knowing people who run food places, this is a point of concern for me. On a positive, I think this place can easily accommodate 20+ groups if you desperately need to find a place.
Food was fantastic, service was fantastic! Beautiful atmosphere and wait staff is very very attentive and knowledgeable about the menu.

I've liked this restaurant in the past, but Sunday night, with several dining companions, we had very so-so food, and the music level was too loud -- we couldn't have an easy conversation. We were seated near some invisible speakers, and though we asked for the music to be turned down, it wasn't. Eggplant was rubbery, and sliced beets seem to come from cans. It is a small room and bright enough noise-wise with people talking; it doesn't need music on top of that. The wait staff is very nice and service is good, but the food wasn't up to it, or the ambiance. I was disappointed because I have enjoyed eating there before, but will reconsider next time.

Small place with freshly made Italian dishes. The food menu is limited, but they will make something up special if you ask. The atmosphere is just ok. It's a neighborhood restaurant that makes good Italian food and has a very good wine list. Expensive. If its convenient go, if you can travel you can do better.

Closest I've had to real ITALIAN cuisine! Everything is homemade and you can definitely tell....
You get fresh bruschetta with your bread.
For an appetizer get the Filetto Di Carne Al Pecorino Tartufato ... it is so fresh and so light

I love the gnocchi here especially because its all homemade (sauce and pasta)

Delivery review. Occasionally ordered from here -- not amazing but decent pasta, even if overpriced. I could kinda deal with you being always late and my food being cold - ok, I'll use the microwave. But I call to nicely mention that you never give silverware and you yell at me on the phone?  No thank you. I am done with you.

Wow, I fell In love with Italy through this place. Rough edges on service but still great. Came here for lunch on our way for a meeting. The host was great, gave a detailed version of the specials of the day and everything else that was available so no need for the menu. He had a thick accent but he didn't mind repeating or explaining some of the stuff. Food was great and it turned out to be a good outing.

Two recent Tuesdays I've joined two friends at this great restaurant for a post-meeting dinner.  The food has been delicious, plentiful, and reasonably priced.  The service has been great and we've been seated immediately.  I don't know much about wine but the ladies with me know a lot :) and were quite happy with the offerings.  Looking forward to returning!

Simple straightforward Italian food, prepared impeccably.  The owners and waitstaff are friendly and professional - such a relief from many newer places that know and care very little about service. It's the UES, so clientele skews a little older and it has a loyal fan base.  Good thing - cuz as a result, the restaurant is super accommodating if you're a picky eater or are having a craving.  The wine list is excellent, with exclusive imports from Italy that I haven't had elsewhere.
Great food, great service, Mario is amazing!!!  Don't miss out on the best kept secret!

Ils Wayport is a good addition to the area. The ambience is lovely. Each and every single thing that we have purchased was incredibly fresh and flavorful. The servers are incredibly friendly and polite. A very remarkable experience at Ils Wayport.
Who did t live grilled meat skewers?? Plus,They let you spill shit everywhere and don't throw you out in the street. For this i am thankful...

A nice small place with loud food!

We had a group of 7 without a reservation and got a table in 10 minutes. The place was tight and busy. We had to almost yell to speak with each other. But that could have been due to the number of people.

From what I was told, this was very close to how a restaurant in Japan would work. A lot of food on sticks, is my best crude description.

There were many things to try from fried quail egg and fried mochi to tripe and the classic chicken or steak. To be truthful it was hard to share these items. Sliding a small segment from each skewer, so keep this in mind when ordering with a group.

Our bill came to be around $400 with the sake, which is a really great price point for 7 people. We were completely full having some food left over.

Great food experience place or a second date place.

This place is great for a place hangout. It is definitely a bit loud inside. However very intimate cute atmosphere.

The food was ok. I think the hot pot was good. Izakaya wasn't impressive in my opinion. Service was very quick and price very reasonable.

Food is good. Most notable is the service staff is incredibly attentive. They are constantly observing the tables and making sure guests have everything they need. My water was filled immediately each time it was empty, and they would replace napkins and plates as needed, all without prompting. The most active service staff I have seen outside a Michelin star restaurant.

The clientele was 100% Asian on a Saturday night, providing further evidence the food is considered a good representation. Both the Yakitori and the grilled seafood items are great choices.

Only negative, some item have thick aioli based sauce without mentioning it. We had to return a squid because it was smothered in some, and get a new one without the sauce. The menu just said "grilled squid" with no mention of sauce.

A friend and I came here for happy hour and we came right in time, because the place was quickly packed by 6:30pm. Service was fast but we did feel a bit rushed, like they were waiting for us to leave. The inside was cozy and a good spot for after work.

For happy hour, I had the cassis oolong which was pretty sweet and tasted like I had ordered oolong tea at a bubble tea shop. I also had a lime chuhai which was quite sour, which I guess is implied in the name.

We also ordered the Ebi Mayo, which was fried shrimp. I understand mayo is in the name, but there was a lot of mayo and it tasted pretty sweet, which I did not prefer. We also had the salmon onigiri, which could have used some more salmon and more furikake.  

Will come back to try more of the food, because the yakitori looked promising.

Overall a great experience.  We were trying to get into another izakaya in NYC but the line was so long we decided to give Toribar a chance.  Situated downstairs from the street we ducked in and was greeted with the  welcoming irrashiamasse in Japanese.  It was not very busy when we got there around 5pm just in time for happy hour beer and select drinks.
We ordered skewers and small plates all very delicious.  Service was good! Place filled up rather quickly and they also have street level seating outside in a tent.

This was more of a 3.5 star experience, but I ended up rounding down. We arrived pretty early, around 6pm, and there were a lot of tables available on a Tuesday night. But as we continued eating, the tables filled up.

I don't have anything particularly awful to report; it was really just that we felt the food was just okay across the board. Nothing stood out to make me feel like this was a place that I have to come back to or recommend to other people. However, again, that's not to say the food was bad. We had a great and filling meal here. I just don't know what I'd tell you to get if you came here.

We saw a lot of reviews recommending the okonomiyaki, so we got it. I found this one to be much more soft and borderline soggy than others I've had before that have been crispier (which is what I prefer). I also felt the yakisoba lacked some flavor.

The one thing I found here that I haven't seen anywhere else is the mochi wrapped pork. SUPER interesting flavors and textures that was different from anything I've tried before.

Food is good and reasonably priced for NYC. It is a loud and fast-paced place. That may be good or bad depending on what you are looking for. Definitely not a place to relax and have a conversation - eat, eat, eat, drink, drink, drink and get out kind of place
Really good karaage and skewers! Lively environment and a great late night spot. Their karaage was super crunchy and juicy while their izakaya was also really flavorful.

solid izakaya in midtown! it gets busy quickly, so i recommend coming earlier

the food: everything was actually so good so i don't think you can go really wrong here, but a few standouts: takowasa texture was so yum and for yakitori i liked the chicken thigh with scallion, gizzard, and pork jowl the best!!!

the drinks: i had the oolong chuhai and calpico chuhai!! oolong was my fav

the space: smaller side and little dark, it was ok!

Legit love this spot! Hidden gem on the lower level. The food is amazing ! And definitely asked for a Frozen Midori sour, it doesn't offer frozen on the menu but if you ask they'll make it.

Must try the okonomiyaki, yakisoba and yakitori ! Hamachi as well! Everything is good here ! Can't go wrong ! All their stuff are affordable as well.

Vibes (4.5/5): this place has a solid playlist and warmed dimmed lighting giving it a cozy and inviting feeling, especially on a cold day.

Chicken thigh skewers (4.25/5): we got the one with the spicy yuzu green sauce and sea salt. It was surprisingly good.

Pork jowl skewers (3.75/5): this one was not bad and has a nice char to it.

Short rib skewers (4.5/5) were our favorite. It had a perfect ratio of fat and meat making it extremely juicy with a burst of flavor. Very good. I'd go back for it.

Yakisoba (4/5) normally I don't like yakisoba but it overall has good texture and flavor.

Shishamo (3.75/5) an order were 2 skewers of mini whole fishes. It was not bad.

The dishes were executed extremely well and believe me when I say we tried around 15+.  Servers were highly attentive in a good way.  Will visit again.  So far for Japanese Tapas I think this was the best so far !

This place exceeded my expectations!

Service was okay, but the food was better than expected. We ordered a variety of dishes, and I would also recommend that for sharing! Each dish comes when they are ready, but they all came out pretty fast.

Everything was seasoned well and the drinks here were also good too. The ambiance is pretty nice, as they really tried to make it like an izakaya.

I've come here twice and gotten an yuzu drink and several yakitori sticks of grilled chicken, asparagus, mushroom, and shrimp. Each one is simple and delicious. I've also gotten a few things from the main menu but was too full to enjoy them at the time. The place is small but inviting - we came late Saturday and it was just busy enough to make it feel lively but there was no line and it wasn't too loud. I will come back again!!!

My wallet hurts. I was excited coming here thinking I can try a little bit of everything. Some reviews say this isn't enough food and some say they were full after $30 pp. My bill came out to $80. I don't mind paying when I get great food and service, but it's not so here. For the same price, my meal yesterday night at 8282 in LES was way better.

I arrived at 10pm - quite convenient they close so late. Inside was only half full but still felt quite loud with their blasting music. Inside was too dark for my liking too. Walking out felt like a relief because the stairs had nice little lights to guide you up and down the stairs to the actual restaurant. The street lights were also brighter than inside.

I ordered a bunch of skewers over two rounds. I wanted to try out both salt and tare before deciding which one I like more. I like how they give you a stack of order sheets, so I can always refer to the menu while waiting/eating and no need to ask for additional sheets to order more.
Best: short rib
Nice: chicken thigh (I can't decide between scallion and yuzu but slightly leaning towards scallion), eggplant, king oyster mushroom
Mediocre: meatball, ebi (shrimp (they didn't clean out its intestine)), asparagus, zucchini
Meh: chicken wing (it was so little meat and so dry)

I ended up liking salt more than tare. The tare didn't add much flavor imo. Salt more obviously added more flavor and it didn't feel too salty.

Their lemon wedge is barely a wedge. It's not user friendly because it's too small. It just folds sideways rather than fold onto itself to squeeze juice out.
Out of the two seasonings you can sprinkle on yourself, I like the red one more than the green one. The green one doesn't add much flavor. The red one isn't spicy but adds a bit of umami and texture to meats.

I ordered two rounds because I wasn't full after the first. I wasn't exactly full after the second either but I stopped feeling empty. I was debating whether to get takoyaki or onigiri to wrap up my meal, but I stopped. Their specialty is yakitori anyway. My wallet started hurting immediately after I ordered the second round, but I also had my hopes up for the new items in the second round. They were mediocre.

Service was lacking. It took longer than desired for someone to get my two order sheets or to refill my water when it was ~25% for a good while.

I can't tell whether I'm glad I tried it but I don't expect to come back.

LOVE the motsu nabe; slight chewy texture from the intestine and the broth was RICH with chicken flavor. It is a must get after some rounds of drink. I ordered it when the weather outside was past 90 F. No regrets. Just wish the AC was stronger inside.

I love that this place open past midnight. It is definitely bookmarked on my 'after midnight' to go places.

Not a big fan of their chicken skewers; chicken breast was very dry. Their coating of their fried skewers also did not stick.

Coming back here for their nabe!

Have been meaning to go to this spot for the longest time and finally did! Sat outdoors in the enclosed sidewalk space away from all the smoke.

Service was speedy and excellent considered we were outside, even though they were super busy inside. Yakitori came staggered so we could enjoy them at the perfect temp.

This was my first time here! It's on the lower level and walking in, you immediately feel like you're in a different space. The interior is dark but there's many people enjoying their food, and you can tell the place is going to be good!

I was seated promptly and ordered the tako wasabi, agedashi tofu, seafood okonomiyaki and assorted yakitori.
The tako wasabi came first; it was fresh and really good! The raw octopus had a good bite to it, kind of chewy and crunchy at the same time? The wasabi was a fresh note and it came with a few pieces of seaweed that you can wrap it with. 5/5

The agedashi tofu was also really good! I haven't had this in a while so I was pleasantly surprised by how good it was. The tofu was deep fried tofu served Ina. Flavorful agedashi sauce with Bo too flakes sprinkled generously over the top. I do wish the tofu was more deep fried / crispy because the sauce had drenched the tofu until it was a bit soggier than I liked! 4/5

Seafood okonomiyaki was also really good. At first glance I thought the portions were a bit small but I think it is very filling and that was definitely enough. Be careful when eating this as it comes out really hot! Perhaps it could have been a little bit more crispy on the bottom but otherwise really solid. 5/5

The assorted yakitori that I had ordered were also delicious. Cooked well and with care. 5/5

Definitely recommend coming to this place! It's especially great as it is open late so whether you want a whole meal or a late night snack, this place has it!

The food is really good & fresh but the service and staff was really strange. Stopped by solo around 6:30pm on a Saturday and sat at the back bar in front of the cash register area. Got a nice view of all the skewers cooking!

What I mean by strange is that, even though the music was loud & it was busy, the staff was relaxed and chatting to each other around me - in perfect English. Just some young adults from Queens or New Jersey or something, maybe NYU Students. But the times they asked if I needed anything or I asked to order an extra skewer or for the check, whichever staff member it was spoke in an ETHNIC ACCENT (like an ESL Japanese, Chinese, or Indian person)...then returned back to standing around & chatting about their boyfriend, holiday plans, with their co-worker in a perfect American English way. A few girls were possibly speaking a Thai dialect to each other, but then switched back to perfect English. I literally watched an interaction with the brunette cashier seating a couple, explaining the ordering menu in perfect English, minutes later giving me the check with a sort of thick Brazilian or Russian accent.

Maybe they thought I was a tourist, but still; not PC to imitate accents in ANY job. I don't think the business is Japanese-owned, all the staff greets customers the Japanese way. Fine, Gyu-kaku does this, but why play pretend in accented English the rest of the night. If I noticed this, I'm sure plenty of other customers noticed the way their server spoke. I don't think a business should have to pretend to be a Japanese-owned  Izakaya, it's pretty clear all of the staff are all American young adults (and manager's name on their business card too). As long as the respect for the food is there.. The staff service & attention was very good though- it's just the accents...

The food was really good, for about $34 I ordered (more like a light meal, Would have been more filling with a beer):

Skewers: fresh & juicy, came out at intervals, about $2.50 - $4 each

- Shishito Peppers (salt)
- Smelt (Tare- sweet soy sauce seasoned)
- Pork Belly wrapped Mochi (salt) *highly recommend if you like gnocchi texture
- Chicken Neck (Tare)
- Thigh Drumstick (Tare), slightly underdone, nothing special

Couldn't decide between the Takoyaki, Rice Ball, or Toribar Slider. Chose the slider and it was a super soft lightly crispy Chicken Katsu sandwich, with a big slice of tomato, fresh cabbage & mayo, pickle, Katsu sauce, on a soft brioche bun. SO Good, SO messy. SO tall that you have to take 2 bites to taste it. Came out at the end of the meal & glad that I tried something different. Probably not an authentic dish, but liked how they created this one.

Lots of tables were eating Nabe, a simmering stew/soup with fresh ingredients cooked at the table. The Yakisoba (noodles) and Omelette dishes looked great too. Skewers seem to be the main dish here. The Rice Balls looked okay, wish they were grilled, but I think they're just rice and seaweed. I want to come back to try other dishes, but I don't know if I want to deal with the accents of the staff again. Pretty Immature, it must be a super awkward work culture there, join the group in playing around with the customers & pick an accent to imitate! Maybe it helps buffer late-night drunk tables. Maybe they should watch the Yale Professor who mocked a Chinese accent during the 2022 commencement speech.
I've been here twice now - quality of the food and the service are so great, I'm definitely going to continue bringing friends here!
This place is DA bomb!! Have been to many Yakitori / Izakaya places and this one has been the best so far.

This is been one of my favorite dining experiences as of late. I have not been to Japan yet, but in all of the stories my Japanese family members have told me, this restaurant would match the vibe of restaurants in Japan. The space is slightly loud, but has a wonderful energetic air about it.

What we ordered: yes, we ordered the skewers, but what really stole the show was the chicken karaage and agedashi tofu. The flavors were there, but not in an overpowering way.

The prices are a little high, but it is worth it. I would love to come back sometime to try more on the menu!

It's funny, I've always been all about trying somewhere new, and in a city like this, where I've finally been able to live for an extended period of time, I find myself returning places I enjoy more often than not; izakaya is pricey as hell but just as delicious too-

Little skewers are the only way people should be eating at this point; and that egg omelette thingamajig I always get is phenomenal too!

They'd get a fifth star if they were more approachable, both in warmth of character and affordability.

Was packed for Monday night yet the service was relatively quick and attentive. Ordered a bottle of sake, Otokoyama, where they instantly brought out complimentary cabbage salad. Their yakitori menu was impressive, better selections of organs than Torishin, and Toribar's yakitori was the winner by far. Mostly locals for Monday night which felt homey and comforting. This cute izakaya has few seats at the yakitori bar and more tables to dine in. Must try if you are in the area!

Came here on a pretty late evening and it was packed- but we were seated almost immediately (after they displaced a party of two to the counter)

We ordered a bunch of yakitori, onigiri (not pictured) and other dishes. I would definitely recommend the onigiris!! They're packed with stuffing inside. The yakitori was great, they came out one by one and they had a designated plate on the side to drop them off.

Overall a solid and cute yakitori restaurant! Minimal smoke and smell so you don't need to worry about smelling like grilled meat afterwards!

Yakitori izakaya close to my office. Business is not by Japanese. But this place is more authentic than other izakaya in the city. Good quality yakitori. Kushiyaki were good too.

I tried here again but yakitori was not made well and was a mediocre quality and fresh cabbages were no longer offered here.
Definitely not as good as used to be.

Came here on Tuesday night at 8:30 pm and it was almost a full restaurant. Obvious very popular and in midtown no less. There is also outdoor seating (which was not full).  I prefer tapas style food and this izakaya did not disappoint. Try the yakisoba and the saba mackerel. Everything we had was good. They also did yakitori style skewers and all is good to share. The ambience is dark so don't expect a bright pub style place for an izakaya.

Came here on a Friday night (around 6:30) and a table for 2 took around 10 min. But soon after I noticed there was a line so be sure to come early. The wait staff was pretty good even though the place was really packed and busy.

We came here for the yakitori but also ended up getting the karaage and okonomiyaki which were both really good. For the yakitori we had a few from each category. The chicken ones seemed a bit dry but thr others came out really nicely. My favorites were the pork jawel and the pork wrapped enoki.

It's very easy to keep ordering here so try to keep a mental count of how much you ordered in total since it can get expensive very quickly. Oh if you end up setting at the bar you get a nice view of all the cooking and if you're lucky they might even give you free yakitori if they made extra!

Local Japanese restaurant with fabulous flavors! The main restaurant is located in the basement of a building and there was a outdoor seating on the main street.

Our party of 4 arrived at 7:30pm and was seated immediately, hostess checked our vaccination cards and ID.

Food- 5 stars. Started with spicy salmon onigiri, various kuskikatsu, gyoza and asahi beer/ delicious! Also tried the Tsukune meatballs, toribar slider, pork jowl and the pork belly okonomiyaki.  Each order was amazingly good.
