Service was great until the kitchen missed my chicken kaarage and that took 20 minutes to arrive after we ate all the other entrees.  I had to ask the waiter twice about the entree and I noticed the entree was served to other diners. I was pretty annoyed it took so long and I ended up taking the entree to go.

Ambiance- 4 stars.

Denied service at 1:20 because they closed their kitchen at 1:30 on a Friday, even though they close at 3.

As such, this place is inauthentic. The whole point of an izakaya is to be a late night oasis.

Also, servers seemed to lack polish.

Edit: okay, I arrived at 1:39. Thanks for checking the security camera. Really makes me want to return and revise this to a glowing review.

Fantastic wait staff, fantastic music, fantastic skewers (chicken thigh with yuzukosho), fantastic drinks (orange cocktail) and good pop music. Just go. Easily the best drink n snacks I've had in ny and prices were very reasonable to boot
Much much much much much better than a similarly rated izakaya joint I had near Times Square: If you pass on this place you're missing out

This place was delightful and just what my wife and I were searching for - a solid yakitori place without stress. It's a charming old school type of location with super nice service, genuine yakitori menu and comfortable atmosphere. We go for yakitori on East and west coast large cities (my all time fav in USA in in LA) because the real deal is hard to find in our home region and we both miss it occasionally.

This is a solid choice and I would gladly revisit!

Izakaya Toribar is pretty convenient because it is one of the few places in the area whose kitchen stays open past 10:30 pm. While this was great for me, I found the food pretty meh - not bad, but not great either. Part of the "meh-ness" could have been placed on my shoulders. I placed an order to go, but had to take a 30-45 minute cab home.

That said, the restaurant looks like a great social spot.

3.5 Stars

Was pleasantly surprised to find a yakitori place near me and ordered a handful of skewers, Takoyaki, and some drinks.

The Bad
The problem stems from gas cooking. I understand there are probably laws against indoor charcoal grilling but I can achieve better blackening from my cast iron pan.

The Good
Has a cool hip-hop vibe which would be good for (small) group outings

Authentic izakaya serving various Japanese foods.
Nothing fancy but simple and well made.
My favorites are the grilled skewers with the tare sauce: chicken, vegetables, seafood.
They have draft Orion  and a good sake selection.

Their new covid outdoor space is nice and has A/C.

All this to say that I would have given 4/5 because the food is great but not 5 stars, however the fact that you can eat there after midnight with the same attention to food and service is worth the fifth star.

Keep it up.

Basement entrance level and they have those covid outdoor seatings in the front street level.

I like the tucked away ambiance.

Service was attentive.

Beer goes well with bbq skewers and other dishes on the menu.

Tako wasabi opened up the palate as an appetizer. Takoyaki was a like comfort dish that melted in your mouth like a savory pancake puff.

Bbq skewers, I couldn't get enough of! I adored their chicken hearts, pork jowl, shishito peppers and pork wrapped around asparagus. All of their skewers were lovely.

Fried skewers, were on the dot. Not much to commend, but fried well and the sauce provided, complimented it.

Squid that was grilled, is a must order. It was the last dish and not only fresh, also nicely cleaned, presented well and cooked.

Yum and nom away here!

Late night munchie favorite spot!

Food was great, service was even better!
Our server helped us with recommendations and accommodations. She's was the best !!!
We sat outside in the cabin and she made sure it was cool and comfortable for us.
Definitely a must eat and will be going back!

THANK YOU!

We stopped by this place for a quick nightcap. It's such a cute little place that is tucked away in NYC and a romantic spot for late night snacks and drinks. We ordered a couple skewers and they all tasted great. My favorite is the pork jowel, chicken thigh and cartilage skewers because I like the crunch texture. I ordered the Kikushi Karakuchi sake and it was great - had to be my favorite sake I tried. Especially if you're looking for something refreshing but punchy and on the drier side.

We've been living in the area for a while and wish we tried this spot earlier. The service is great, food is delicious and well priced for the area. If you're coming in a weekend I highly recommend a reservation. We got here at 5pm on Saturday and the tables filled up quickly.

FYI they are strict with checking vaccination cards and matching it to your ID

Visiting the city and came here around 11pm on a Friday night. There were two seats available at the bar and we were seated right away. We ordered many dishes including the eggplant, scallop, shrimp, mochi and sweet potato skewers as well as the pork belly wrapped mochi, gizzards, ebi mayo, fried oysters, takoyaki and gyozas. Everything was delicious. Highlights were the pork belly wrapped mochi, fried oysters, takoyaki (best I have had) and the ebi mayo. Gyoza was also excellent. Chicken drum was just ok.

They were pretty busy but we got our food as it was made. Really enjoyed this restaurant!

Staff was extra kind, comped a round of drinks, and even gave us a few free skewers after they asked us to move tables mid-meal (which is a minor inconvenience that has happened to us before several times, and other restaurants' did not offer as much kindness).

The food and drinks are also excellent, particularly the zucchini skewers and the shojito were highlights. We will be back frequently!

Really really authentic izakaya. The yakitori is so well done--flavored deeply, not too salty, very juicy, and nice char. My favorite was the okonomiyaki! The pancake was thick and chunky, exactly like Osaka style! There were 5 pieces of pork belly laid on top, and bonito flakes dancing on top of that. It was one of the best okonomiyaki I've had outside of Japan! It was served in this deep 6 inch cast iron skillet so it stays warm. Get this!!
The cocktails were good, but mostly because I have a predilection for Asian drinks.
Solid izakaya spot and the food is good! Try to reserve before you go because it fills up fast and the wait can get long. The skewers and okonomoyaki were great.

Amazing yakitori! This is one of my favorite places for skewers. My favorites are the chicken thighs and shishito peppers. I like them salted. It can come with tare sauce too. They have a good amount of choices for drinks. There are happy hour drink specials Mon-Thurs from 5-7pm.

The restaurant is down the stairs. Small and cozy and with bar seating. Inside can get noisy and the music is running, but is good if you don't want to overhear the next tables over talking. They also have a decent sized outdoor seating area on the street. Outdoors seems more quiet and has more lighting. The ambiance indoors is dimmer lighting and can be romantic.

The staff are nice and friendly. Although sometimes it gets really busy, probably around 7-9pm prime dinner time, so you'd have to try to catch the staff attention if you want to get something. They do look when you wave, so it wasn't a long wait at all.

In NY, craving sake and tapas?? Look no further then this izakaya. They have a good selection of drinks, food to go with the drinks, and their music choice brought me back to the good old days. When you step into the place, it feels like you are transformed and distanced from the rest of new york. They did take their time making our food, but we weren't in a rush, and everything was pretty tasty.

There was a small wait on a Friday night but we choose to sit at the bar and watch the chefs make all the food. They check thay you are vaccinated if you dine in. There are plenty of skewer options to choose from and there are also heartier food options such yakisoba and rice balls. There was an extensive list to choose from if you want japanese alcoholic drinks as well.

For regular skewers you can choose either salt or tare sauce for flavor. I recommend just choosing salt. For fried skewers, you have to order a minimum of 5 sticks. I highly recommend trying quail eggs or the mochi. I ordered the vegetable okonomiyaki and asked them to hold the bonito flakes or kasuobushi to make it a vegetarian dish and it was no problem for them. For drinks I got the grapico which was non-alcoholic and super yummy as well.

Solid choice for a happy hour drink special night before 7pm. Good attentive service. Try to be seated away from the downstairs staircase as it smells.

Pork, beef, and dark meat chicken skewers ate great.  

Draft beer was great at happy hour price $5. At $8 not a great buy. Korean soju is served at $16 a bottle which is more than most Korean places but more bang for your buck than sake or Japanese shochu.

Takowasa and takoyaki were solid.

Weak points
- free flavorless cabbage
- white meat skewers were dry
- yakisoba was flavorless

Would come again -
Amazing and great food. I love it. Highly recommend.. must coke good food the soup is really good
Great ambience and service. Nice late night food option. Most of what we ordered was nice, however, the yakisoba had a strange cinnamon-like flavor which made it unpalatable for us.

Haven't reviewed in a while. Just haven't found anything worth the time until now. New cart on the block and lucky me, it's my favorite cuisine - Thai. Menu is limited so far but I prefer the "do one thing and do it well" strategy over being a "jack of all trades, master of none." They make the prerequisite Pad Thai with your choice of chicken, shrimp, tofu, veggies, or "mock duck." Really good in my opinion. Reminds me of my favorite Thai place in Jersey.

Good portions. Friendly and fast. It's freshly made and piping hot. They switch up the appetizers daily. Sometimes they have chicken satay, dumplings, or fish tofu.

So far they have been there every day so I  appreciate the stability. Nothing worse than getting hooked on a new food cart then having that cart disappear, leaving you high and dry (I'm talking to you Yogi!).

Would be nice to see maybe 1 or 2 more entrees added with rice. We'll see moving forward. Enjoy!
Very Special place very authentic Japanese sushi and food. My friends Shoko And Jun are always the best.

I have now tried ordering twice from this expensive restaurant. The first time, the Lady called me 30 minutes later to say they had no Toro (which was why I chose them in the first place)

Now, today, I tried again. Online ordering said it would be an hour but I did it anyway. An hour later a guy from door dash calls to say the restaurant is closed. I call and no one answers.

Now I am starving and have to start over. I will never order from this place again. Shame because the people who review it favorably say very nice things about the sushi.

It was late on a Thursday night and 2 of us were looking for a later sushi dinner. As most places were closing, we were fortunate enough to have been welcomed by Jun and Shoko, the owners of Inase. We were sat at the small but quaint sushi bar in the back. This place immediately felt authentic.  

Inase is the definition of a hidden gem. Their fish is truly top notch. Jun is the owner and sushi chef and he walked us through all his fish, most of which is flown in from Japan. We started with the 10 piece sushi and each piece was more delicious than the last. Everything was incredibly fresh. Both pieces of toro melted in your mouth, as did the uni, the well treated squid, and just about every other piece. The tuna scallion roll that came with it was equally delicious. All of this + a salad for $60, great pricepoint for fish that was on par with omakases that charge 3X elsewhere.

While most people talk about the fish, it is often the rice that separates a good sushi restaurant from a great one. The rice here was delicious and unique. Hard to put my finger on exactly what they did with it, but it was excellent.

After our pieces, we moved onto a couple hand rolls, which did not disappoint. Delicious ingredients, crispy seaweed and overall amazing. One of them was spicy tuna, which chef Jun prepared right in front of us. None of them premade spicy tuna slop that other places serve up. He hand chopped fresh delicious high quality tuna, seasoned it with some delicious spicy seasoning and it was probably the most delicious spicy tuna I've ever had.

Beyond the incredible sushi served, it must be noted the amazing care and attention to detail chef Jun puts forth. He takes great pride in his craft and it shows. Both Jun and Shoko were so lovely and accommodating.

Do yourself a favor and try this place. You will not be disappointed. It's better than any of your neighborhood go to sushi joints and on par with fish quality of top omakases.

A++

We enjoyed this neighborhood sushi restaurant very much. The ambiance isn't as fancy as other boutique omekase restaurants in NYC but their fish quality is spectacular, as most of their fish is imported from Japan. All of the bites of sushi and sashimi were amazing. Excellent service with a nice selection of alcoholic and non alcoholic beverages. We eagerly plan to return for take out!
I ordered delivery. The fish was slimy and old. This is not only frustrating, but downright dangerous.

Inase is a special place. There are many sushi restaurants on the upper east side, but with all due respect, they tend to be indistinguishable from one another, offering the same product and similar ambience.  Inase is different. It is run by a couple and offers an intimate, authentic experience. The sushi is unlike anything I've tried; much more delicate and fresh than what is normally available. There are many unique items, like Japanese Yam and Fried Oyser, that I havn't seen elsewhere. And the price is comparable to other spots that are not (exlusively) Omakase. Highly recommended!

We decided to try this place for sushi tonight. Sushi were so fresh and fire. We also tried fried tofu in soup and fish cake(owner recommended), for these we have to come back for more. Even you see "the only pick up" signage in the front, they are still opened for seating too. The owner are 100% full of service mind and make our night like eating at home;)))

Professional sushi roll restaurant!
My favorite is salmon skin roll. Very crispy and fresh!
I will come back soon.

Sensational sushi!!!
Family run with lovely service and cozy intimate surroundings. Can't wait to return!!!

Excellent sushi. We were both really impressed with the quality of fish. Everything we ordered was delicious. I recommend the rainbow roll, it was so fresh.
Some of the best sushi I've had in NYC.

A Michelin-starred Japanese chef recommended this gem very early in the pandemic, which has turned into one of our favorite Japanese restaurants in NYC. If not located all the way on the Upper East Side, we would probably come more often. It's literally a husband (Executive chef Junichi Itatoko san) and wife team.

After numerous pick up orders, I was able to finally dine at the restaurant last week (and they are open on Sundays) and try their wonderful sushi omakase, which has to be the best value omakase in NYC. Most of the fishes and uni are imported from Japan, and the $120 omakase included prized items, such as otoro, Hokkaido uni, shima aji, botan ebi, aji, kamasu, kinmedai, etc. Not only do they excel in sushi, but also cooked dishes, i.e. that grilled sawara on the omakase menu was amazing. Also, not on the menu, they made us before for takeout a really nice beef sukiyaki upon request.

Service - wonderful

Highly recommend

Hope to come again soon.

: 9 calendars

Note: They provide an outdoor table, upon request. Only recommendation I have to the restaurant is maybe make the inside more inviting. It seems a bit cluttered inside.

Banging Sushi restaurant with fresh, inexpensive seafood imported directly from Japan that on dishes alone would be a 5/5 but unfortunately is complemented with an absolutely awful indoor/outdoor dining layout. Better served as a takeout spot. $10 a roll. 4.25/5 stars as a dinner spot.

I ordered the special sushi dinner and the fish did taste very fresh but it was kind of disappointing that I got the same fish twice and all of the pieces weren't unique. I don't like uni because it tastes too fishy for me and I thought they would substitute it with something of the same price/quality, but it didn't seem like it. I would recommend this restaurant for the freshness of their fish, but not because of how unique/special the special sushi dinner is.

Amazingly fresh sushi! We ordered through Grubhub and got our delicious sushi and Chirashi bowl. Great sushi pieces that included uni, botan ebi and toro. And hamachi Kama was perfectly cooked! Can't wait to order again.
Great food, very friendly, fresh quality sushi and quick delivery! Definitely worth trying I'd say f for your first experience, dine at the restaurant.

Must try! My husband and I opted to try out the omakase here rather than our usual go to restaurant on the UES. We loved everything about Inase. The atmosphere is quiet and comfortable while service was friendly and efficient.
We opted for the $120 omakase. Everything piece of food served was fresh and delicious.
The first course was a plate of perfection, from the tomatoes soaked in dashi broth to the shrimp toast.  The sushi itself was very fresh and served in large pieces with the perfect amount of rice to go with it. We enjoyed talking to the sushi chef during our meal as he made the whole experience relaxed and still enjoyable. My husband and I walked out really full and happy that we found our new go-to omakase spot.

Since COVID, we have been getting takeout from here on a weekly basis. Their food is always fresh and delicious. Chef Jun and Shoko have prioritized quality and maintained a strong relationship with their customers!

Today we dined outdoors, as they set up a few tables for seated dinner. We especially loved the amuse-bouche, homemade tofu with ginger and scallion. Everything was fabulous as always!

We came to this restaurant 5 years ago on recommendation from my gfs Japanese colleague.   When you walk in, you realize that it seats maybe 15 people.  The great couple who own this restaurant are also the chef and front of house.   Their omakase is fantastic and they provided amazing service for our 4th anniversary.   Never had chawanmushi until that omakase and it was soft and delicious.

We tried to walk in one time and were asked to come back.  Highly recommend calling ahead for a reservation.  Great, fresh sushi you need to eat!!

this is a place that actual Japanese people come to eat. They have a variety of Japanese newspapers and tourist information in the Japanese language. The menu is legit Japanese. The sushi was okay but the truly special items were those on the specials list.
there is a very nice private table behind the screen. This is where we sat for a very nice atmosphere.
Inase is my usual go to sushi place since it's so close to my apartment. The staff are very friendly and the sushi is solid.
Terrible experience!  About 45 min after order went through on DoorDash we got a message that the restaurant had 'rejected' the order.  No further word, and, no dinner.

Had sushi for delivery, good sushi. I wish I could visit in person I am sure would have been better experience.
Would love to try their appetizers too next time.

Placed an order tonight and there was an issue (not the restaurant's fault at all!), but once food arrived it was delicious as always. The owner then called just to follow through and make sure it had arrived and all was well. As always, both owners were fantastic and very kind.

I did Omakase dine in a few weeks ago with a friend, and it was incredible. The food was delicious, fresh, innovative and just all around amazing. The chef went above and beyond explaining what each dish was, which fish was which, etc. Even better, both the owners are warm and friendly people, and made us feel like we were having a michelin star meal at someone's welcoming home.

Incredible sushi is one thing, but incredible sushi coming from such great people is even better. Could not recommend Inase more, either for take-out/delivery or for dining in.

Holy moly I've never had Omakase before but man am I glad I chose Inase for my first go at it! We opted for the $100 omakase which was 15 courses including 1 salad, 4 types of sashimi, 1 uni steamed egg custard (yes you read that right: Uni. Egg. Custard.), 8 nigiri, 1 optional hand roll/sushi roll (opted for this plum octopus hand roll), 1 fried veggie tempura, 1 fish & mushroom tea-soup, and 1 mochi ice cream.

Not only was each course of this meal amazing, well-balanced, and carefully curated by the chef - who only speaks Japanese by the way, very little English so much so he provides you the handbook and points out which fish and from what origin he is using - you leave feeling comfortably full and fully satisfied. The chef's sweet wife works front of house and is the serving staff for this little joint and makes sure service is perfect and your plates and area are always clean throughout the meal and she checks in on you as well. By the way, you can ONLY have the omakase at the sushi bar.

15/10 for value, service, quality, and overall wonderful experience! Looking forward to my next omakase adventure!

10/10, excellent, will order again! I stumbled across this place and will certainly be coming back. The food is delicious. I ordered a California roll and a salmon and avocado roll. Both were amazing and the fish is so fresh. The couple that owns this place was so friendly and kind. We talked for a few minutes. Please give this place a try.

The mom and pop digs that you definitely hoped to stumble upon serendipitously (and of course gut check on yelp beforehand!), this sushi spot is a real charmer. You can tell this operation is a labor of love and that the chefs put real attention to detail into the quality and presentation of their food. The sashimi was incredible, and would honestly recommend it over rolls. The maki was a tad bit underwhelming even though fish quality was fresh, just because the rice was maybe a little undercooked and underseasoned. Otherwise, I could not rave more about how gorgeous everything tasted. Highly recommend the miso black cod if you're willing to splurge
Our favorite sushi! Delivery or dine-in. Support local and eat at Inase! Owners are amazing and fish quality is the highest!

Long overdue review for the best hidden gem of the UES. Bf and I have been semi-regulars since we found them a year ago (shortly after the present owners took over the place). Jun and Shoko are a wonderful couple.

Jun's skills are spectacular - do the omakase if you have time.

If you're looking for pretentious interiors and lackluster quality, this is not the place for you. Inase offers a no-frills, intimate setting with dynamite food quality.

The baguette and chuwanmushi are awesome. Then we just let Jun serve us whatever he wants.

Inase is very different from other sushi restaurants I have been to. We tried sushi rolls so I can only comment on that. The rolls are definitely bigger with substantial amount of fish in it rather than other additions you find in other restaurants. The only thing I missed was the level of spicyness. We ordered spicy tuna spicy salmon rolls but none of them were spicy at all.
Will be back to try other specials.

I'll be back to this hidden gem in UES. The $150 omakase was totally worth it both quality and portion. Very authentic in a Japanese owned mom and pop. My favorite pieces were the conch, the blackthroat sea perch, and the toro hand roll. My husband and I'll be back!!! The older Japanese couple who owns this are so cute.
Amazing quality great price for the rolls. Salmon Avocado roll is my go to order. Their shrimp and vegi tempora appetizers are fire.

I LOVE the sushi, sashimi, and noodles. Everything is extremely delicious, fresh and very traditional Japanese food. I studied in Japan and I love Japanese food. When i came home to nyc, I've always been looking for traditional Japanese food that taste the same as Japan.

Lovely place! A different sushi experience, more intimate and home feeling than usual. You can talk they have a lot of regulars and their sushi did not disappoint!

Omakase $120

Appetizer trio - monk fish liver, persimmon and spinach with tofu sauce, fish cake baguette toaste
Uni chawamushi
Sashimi- horse mackerel, toro, scallop, octopus, prnns
Grilled salmon with young pickle ginger

Nigiri
Chu toro
Yellow tail
Golden eye snapper
Snapper
Stripe bass with soy mort
Pike mackerel ***favorite
Amber jack
Maine sea urchin

A hidden gem!!  Came here on a Friday night with a reservation made at 7:30. Seated promptly as soon as we arrived.
We were given a table at the back of the restaurant with a bamboo screen so we have more privacy . Even it's just the two  of us we felt spacious .
We decided to try their $120 omakasei- it was totally worth every single penny! On the menu it says it includes 4 kinds of dishes, 10  sushis  and dessert. We were impressed- especially the 4 kinds of dishes were all surprises!!!
The highlight among the 4 dishes was definitely the blue fin tuna  fish bone! What it means  is that u would b served with a fish bone with tuna still on the  bone and u have to scope out the tuna to enjoy  it. Absolutely impressive! And the fish  had to b  very fresh and it literraly melted  in yr mouth!
The other dish we enjoyed a lot was the boiled egg-  again it melted in Our mouths! U could taste the egg along w all  the seafood in the dish!
And all the suShi was sooo  frEshh  - a must try if u r in the neighborhood!
One more thing- It is ruun by  a Japanese  couple. The service was  very attentive  anD we all enjoyed the dinner!

Hands down the best sushi you will get in NYC. My Japanese family and I come here regularly because the fish is often freshly delivered from Japan, and the owner/lady who works here is so incredibly kind and heart warming. 10/10 recommend if you want authentic, top grade Japanese sushi. Also the ambience is great--relaxed, aesthetic, and overall a great time.

We just stopped in for dinner tonight and had a nice experience. The restaurant itself is small only with a few tables and a sushi bar. We called ahead for a reservation as you can't walk in, but the tables were not full.  The restaurant seems to be family run, as there were some kids around.

As for the food, we both did the $60 omakase (there was also a $80 and $100 option). When we sat down the waitress was super nice and checked to see if there was anything we didn't like which I appreciated. She then brought out a salad and a miso soup. The sashimi plate was next and the fish was very fresh. After that she brought a plate of 8 pieces of sushi. The sushi was great but already had wasabi and soy sauce on each piece (as is normal per omakase). My only complaint was that some of the pieces had slightly too much wasabi and it was a little overwhelming - although still really good! Next came an egg custard dish with seafood that was different than anything I had before but We both enjoyed it. Lastly, you had an option of ice cream for dessert.

Overall this is a good spot to come for high quality neighborhood sushi!

This family run restaurant is a hidden gem.

I went for the omakase and thought it was a great value. They promptly asked if we wanted easier to eat sushi that are more familiar to westerners or Japanese fish. They also asked if we wanted all sushi or sushi and sashimi.

For the price, it is a great value. You can high quality cuts of fish and a good variety that you may not always get at your run of the mill omakase.

Be sure to get a reservation, the sushi bar is only 6 seats.

I would put Inase in your regular rotation of any sushi lover's NYC must try list

A gem! Pleasant and friendly couple who serves a high-quality omakase for a reasonable price. Was very impressed. Had pen shell, something I had never tried before and it's become one of my favorites. Would definitely go back again.

So apparently Inase changed management a few months ago.  There are a few differences but overall I'm happy they maintained high quality food and friendly atmosphere/attitude.

1.  No more lunch service and crazy good lunch special with $25 chirashi sushi. :(   They say they might bring it back a bit later though

2. The sushi rice now is made with a special red rice vinegar, actually more tasty than before!  Especially in chirashi sushi they used to have a sauce that was a bit too salty and sweet

3. Fish quality is excellent. Every tasted flavorful and fresh. Generic americanized sushi places that specialize into rolls cant hold a torch to this place.

4. The chef/waitress couple are cordial like previous management but even more sociable and talkative.  I am looking forward to sitting down for omakase next time we have a chance so we get to chat with the chef.

5. The new premium chirashi serves with amaebi (sweet shrimp) and uni (sea urchin). Regular chirashi is replaced by "bara" chirashi in which the pieces are cut much smaller but still top quality and flavor.  If you enjoy the amaebi and uni the premium chirashi would be definitely worth it.

6. The matcha, salad, and miso soup are all decent but unfortunately slightly less tasty than how we remembered under the previous management.

Overall, I believe new management is doing an excellent job continuing a wonderful restaurant.
If you regularly order special rolls, this restaurant may not necessary be your cup of tea.  If you enjoy top quality sushi at a reasonable price (rather than those $$$$ places) this restaurant is for you.

If you're looking for a low key atmosphere with top quality fish, this is your place.  A neighborhood gem that is seemingly off most people's radars.

The restaurant itself could use some updating (fresh paint, some new artwork, etc) but it almost adds to the charm.  

This is a tiny mom and pop sushi restaurant (the restaurant has new owners since August) who go a step above the competition.  Much of the fish is from Japan and you can tell that the owners care very much about providing an authentic and delicious dining experience.  

Prices, are a bit higher than the typical local sushi spots (amura, sushi ren, etc.) but you're getting much much better quality food.

We tried several of their sushi rolls, hand rolls, sashimi, the sushi dinner (amazing value at $33), miso cod, and the mushroom soup and it was all terrific.  They serve traditional style sushi, so don't come expecting many specialty rolls.  

As a side not, all the tableware used (plates, cups, etc) were beautiful.  

With so many great sushi options in the area (ishikawa, gari, tanoshi, poke, etc.), Inase stands out for providing a great balance of casual dining and top quality food (there's not always time for a 2-3 hour omakase).   It's a great weeknight option and can't wait to go back!

Hidden gem!  In terms of quality and value, this place tops most others in New York, and certainly on the UES. It's a "hole-in-the-wall" place with a small sushi bar and half a dozen tables.  The fish is freshly sourced and of the highest quality, yet prices are kept very reason.

Definitely give them a call before heading over, as they can be fully booked some evenings. Better yet, call a few days in advance.  However, sometimes you get lucky and can get a table right away; just depends on the night.

For a splurge, do the omakase (two options $80/100) -- the chef curated menus depending on the season and it's epic.
We went on Monday. They just reopened under new management. Everything was fresh and a/c felt so good. Friendly staff, clean and the taste was amazing!

Last minute Valentine's Day search for omakase and found this hole-in-the-wall gem in the neighborhood. Decor is no frills basic. Service is very friendly but on the slower side since it's a family operation with husband as the only sushi chef and wife is the waitress and everything else. When it comes to the omakase, wow wow wow! We picked the $80 omakase, which came with dish of appetizer with squid, clams, monkfish and stuff shrimp baguette, followed by uni egg custard with shrimp. These 2 dishes were so good. The 8 pieces of sushi that followed were the freshest we ever tasted and each piece was favored wonderfully, didn't need any soy sauce or wasabi at all.  The hand roll was crunchy and yummy.  My husband actually wrote on the napkin "best sushi" in the middle of the meal, which is completely unlike him!! The $120 omakase included a special of tuna bone rack, which chef gave us to try and it was out of the world.  Sorry happy we found this gem, already making plan to go back when kids are bacK during spring break!!!
One of the best... just walked by and found. Haven't had sushi since the lock down started.

Wife and I had a great conversation with the staff. She and her husband took over the restaurant in August of last year, but kept the same name. She was very friendly and was attentive to our table-constantly making sure our food tasted great. Her husband is very skillful at making sushi. Every order of sushi tasted wonderful-fish was fresh, rice was cooked perfectly.

We'll definitely be back.

The sushi is very decent--as other reviewers have commented on.

A strange point--every roll was made with brown rice, which I thought was extremely weird.

The service at this restaurant is extremely slow, even though I understand that this is a family restaurant and they don't have an extensive service team. However, it is unacceptable to make your customers ask for basic things like napkins, chopsticks, and soy sauce. You have to wait several minutes for each of these things to be brought to you.

Moreover, a $7 bowl of miso soup here is served lukewarm. The hot tea was also lukewarm. At least the sushi was not lukewarm.

A overall very disappointing experience. There are a lot of great/mediocre Japanese restaurants in the UES. This place is simply too expensive for what it aims to be--an authentic, high quality Japanese place (it is not worth it). A light dinner for two (no drinks) comes out to be about $100.

Called to make a reservation two days before and it wasn't a problem. While I was there, it seemed like people were making reservations an hour or so before coming in and that wasn't a problem either. When I got there the restaurant was pretty empty so it looks like you can just walk in but I had thought I saw them turn someone away so it might be best to make a reservation. I think the problem might be that it's a tiny place with what looked to be one sushi chef and then the hostess/waitress/busser (I think she might have also helped with some of the hot foods). Needless to say, they could have probably used another staff.
I was surprised after my meal that the place wasn't more busy because the food was excellent. I sat at the 5 seat sushi bar which is omakase only. There were 3 options at $60,80,100. I opted for 80 and then the traditional style over the regular style. The meal started with a simple salad, then the chawanmushi which was perfectly cooked with a nice smooth texture, then a plate of 8 pieces of sashimi, then a whole fried fish from japan, then 8 pieces of sushi, a broth with fish and mushrooms, and then dessert. I was impressed by the variety of the fish that I was served from the abalone, to the gizzard chad, to the sardine, to the giant clam. Everything was fresh and delicious.

One of the best and most authentic places in UES. We've been going there for many years. They are a neighborhood gem, and their quality of food and service continues to be amazing during Covid. If anything their level of customer care has increased. Jun and Shoko really treat their customers like friends, and one of the times we ordered take out a few weeks ago they even gave us reusable masks.
Worst sushi in the hood don't waste your money. Go next door to PuTawn for better food and service or sushi go to Sushi of Gari.

So I know my first review of Inase Restaurant was poor, but that was in regards to the mixed up service and not the review of the food quality.

After deliberating for awhile, I decided that I would head over to Inase for the second time to see if my first review was indeed properly reflective of Inase's quality. I am happy to say that my first review is now completely and utterly outdated and incorrect.

I went ahead and opted for the $75 Omakase course, and I must say everything was FANTASTIC. I am usually a little intimidated by the general atmosphere of the high-end sushi restaurants - the atmosphere is rigid and almost too palpable, the courses need to be enjoyed precisely as instructed by the chef, and it is in no way or form the most comfortable experience for people who are not used to the customary experience of Omakase.

Dining at Inase was nothing but a comfortable and warm experience. Although the restaurant might have been moderately decorated, the Omakase course that was served was exquisite and rich in content and taste. The sake that I paired with the course also went splendidly well with the selection provided by the Chef; I must say Inase offered me one of the better Omakase experiences that I've had in New York so far.

So here I am, trying to rectify my first review: if you are looking for a quality Omakase experience - also very affordable! - without the usual rigid formality, Inase is the perfect place to go!

Romantic little gem on the upper east side. Charming interior. The vibe here is about taking your time, very European pace, which we love. They won't even give you menus until you've gotten your drinks and had an amuse bouche and some bread. Overall attentive and kind servers who know why they're doing.
Standouts:
beef carpaccio. SO much flavor.
House-made pastas
Off-menu dishes that you have to know about to ask for.

Long time favorite that we'll keep going back to.

That little quaint Italian restaurant of fame and song, Italianissimo Ristorante is an understated gem. We have eaten there at least a dozen times without ever having a complaint about the incredible food and service that met us. The owner chef is Italian which may account for his understanding of what is the essence of fine Italian cuisine. You name the category and you should check off the excellent box in all of them. While small in size, it makes up for its genuine Italian charm and spirit. We simply cannot say enough good about this place. Weekend nights may be a bit busy, but do not be dissuaded from calling for a reservation. You will never be disappointed by your choosing Italianissimo for a memorable dinner.
Had a fantastic weeknight meal here. The homemade fettucini was the star, such a nice texture and great portion size! Excited to come back soon

Wow, I haven't had pasta this good in a long time! The menu was just filled with delicious sounding dishes, but with the recommendation of our server I went with the rigatoni dish with the smoked mozzarella. Not much more I can say beyond that it was fantastic - just the perfect amount of cream, tomatoes and cheese. Can't wait to go back and try some of the other things on the menu!
I came here for the first time. The food, ambiance and service were beyond amazing!! I highly recommend this spot. We had the specials, both were next level amazing!!

I ate dinner at Italianissimo and it was excellent! I had a great experience. Delicious food and an attentive, knowledgeable, and friendly wait staff. I'm looking forward to dining at Italianissimo again!

I really don't like leaving negative reviews about a restaurant, primarily because it is largely a matter of personal taste right? However; in this case, I KNOW a good Chicken Parm when I taste it and being an Italian rest. in NYC this should be basic.

To be fair, it wasn't on the menu, but this dish (my dinner companion) also had it so it wasn't only my opinion.
It was HORRIBLE! HOW can any chef ruin a simple Chic Parm?
There were strinbeans that were MUSHAAD.

It was the worst dinner I think I have had in MANY years.
I feel badly saying this since were are all trying to recover from 2 years of HELL, but you need to up your game please.

Visiting from out of town and enjoyed a delicious meal for our anniversary at Italianissimo. The atmosphere was perfect, the staff gracious and attentive, and the food was amazing!!! I highly recommend and will make it a regular stop on our visits to the city. A hidden gem on 84th St.!! Can't wait to go back!!

All of the food was incredible. This is one of the best Italian places in the neighborhood. All of the servers were so nice and the experience was beyond amazing. The energy of the restaurant is so pleasant and I truly recommend you try this!

Really great atmosphere and has that quaint feel about it. Food was excellent . They have amazing pasta. Had the soup to start (seafood chowder) that was the special which ended up being $30 when we got the check which seemed steep for soup considering the rest of the menu was priced reasonably. Anyway, it was very good and they had an impressive number of specials considering the size of the place.

This place was amazing! They really treat you well here. My friends and I came and they brought out nice bruschetta and bread, which was delicious. I ordered pappardelle and it hit the spot. The mushrooms were a perfect touch to the dish and I highly recommend this pasta. The ambience is very nice and this is a perfect place for a date spot. My only complaint is I checked in and received a 10% off pasta coupon but they wouldn't let me use it.
Every time I'm in NYC, this is a must go to! Wonderful service, amazing food. You can't go wrong no matter what you choose. Fine homemade Italian food. Don't miss out on the Zabaglione for dessert!!

If you eat at the restaurant it is excellent.
If you order in or take out you cannot believe it is the same restaurant! I have ordered in numerous times and not ones wasn't even close to my experience when I ate at the restaurant.
Edgar, I do not know if he's the manager, I know he is not the owner, is very rude. Again, if you are at the restaurant he's very nice but when you call for delivery not so much. He rushes you off the phone so that you cannot tell him What it is you want or if you want to add something. If you should have a complaint it is your fault! They never have a complaint about anything?! He also turns away business. I have been ordering the tre Colore salads about twice a week. One day when I called he told me I had to order some thing else or he would not deliver that to me. I live three blocks from the restaurant. I stopped ordering from them since that day and that was before the pandemic! The bread could use a major upgrade but the fried zucchini is superb .I ordered a pasta Primavera. The vegetables were a goodly assortment but the pasta was like straw ,of course when I mentioned that to Edgar I was told it was al dente! I do know the difference between al dente and straw!

I love this restaurant. The food is wonderful and authentic.

I've been supporting them during covid with delivery. Honestly, you can't go wrong.

By far the best Italian restaurant in the city. This restaurant is the perfect escape from reality, with authentic food, amazing wine, and an incredibly kind staff. You can tell every plate is made with the perfect mixture of attention to detail and passion. The flavors are legendary and the memories you will make while sitting in this quaint and beautiful restaurant will be memories you'll never forget.
Absolutely amazing. No words, seriously. I didn't want to post a review and let the secret out about how amazing this place was.

Charming neighborhood Italian on a side street. The staff were warm and welcoming.  Wine by the glass was tasty and reasonably priced.   The bread was good.  The salad and fried calamari were good.  We had chicken and veal entrees.   They were pretty good but our friends really liked their pasta. Pasta may have been the pro move in this case.  We were full after dinner but were served a plate of cute sugar dusted mini-cookies.  The prices are a bit less than average for the area.  

A nice change of pace in a sea of UES Italian restaurants.

At 6:55pm I called and ordered dinner for delivery and mentioned that the menu offered a 20% discount: "call us directly and get 20% off."  

Shortly after ordering the restaurant called back to tell me that their 20% discount is only for cash customers.  I pointed out that the menu says nothing about cash only, and the person calling said he would give me 10% off under the circumstances, and I agreed.

An hour and 20 min later I called to find out where my delivery order and I was told that I had cancelled the order.  

So here's my review:  Never Again!

Not American Italian, no meatballs and spaghetti, you have your pasta then your meat or fish, real Italian. A menu to explore and then the specials. The staff is efficient and friendly. The outdoor seating is nicely done, well spaced tables with white table cloths and real cloth napkins. Outside is very nice but I like indoors, nice old New York Italian restaurant atmosphere and subtle music. A special place!

This is my favorite neighborhood UES Italian restaurant for all occasions. A hidden gem located between 2nd and 3rd (closer to 3rd) on 84th st. Great service and food. Cute inside atmosphere. I recommend the Penne Bosco e Mare ($19.95).

I am in love with this place! The service was outstanding the waiter was very attentive and the food, my god, so delicious ! The food came out nice and fresh and just so much flavor. This is the perfect place to go to for date night!

Will definitely come back!

This small but beautiful Italian restaurant has served the UES for a long time.  The standard menu of classic dishes is always supplemented by daily specials, many of which are hard to resist.  The food is delicious and the service is excellent.  This is our Toto neighborhood Italian restaurant that's not a-red sauce place.  It is classy.

Wowzie wowzie wowzie is all I have to say.  Been coming to this hood for over 20 years and would have never found this place had I not stopped in the thrift store next door, and so glad I did.  This place is unbelievable from start to finish with some of the best wait staff I have encountered in a long time.  If you don't go here to eat your a fool and that's all I have yo say the end!

Picked up a friend and asked where we should eat?    He was at a loss so we drove around the Upper East Side, and spotted this hole in the wall.  Finding a spot was challenging but we did and walked in.  
We were enthusiastically received and seated at a great table.  
The restaurant felt cozy and had a nice number of people.
To start, the owner brought out a splendid bottle of red wine, that wasn't on the wine list.  It was rich and earthy!
We shared a mozzarella prosciutto and tomato.
All really delicious.  
The entrees were veal piccata and a special rigatoni pasta with meat sauce. Finished with Desert    Cannoli and espresso.  All superb
We were so glad we stumbled into this gem of a restaurant.

Sadly I can't comment on the food because they declined to seat me, a single woman, when there were several open tables both inside and out.  They claimed they had too many reservations.  Fine.  However when I returned an hour and change later, there were still several open tables.  I wasn't aware this kind of flagrant misogyny still existed in this form, but I guess I've learned my lesson.  My $80 and $20 tip went to a much more deserving place down the street.
What a find! Must of passed this place a million times. Lovely space, amazing authentic italian food and impeccable service. All at prices that don't break the bank. Can't wait to go back!

Great neighborhood place. Went with a friend for an early NYE dinner. Cocktails, perfect, reasonably priced bottle of Barolo, perfect, cold seafood salad and asparagus, prosciutto and Burrata, perfect.  We shared a pasta and a chicken special and the chef graciously split the entrees for us in the kitchen, perfect.  The service was attentive.  Highly recommend Italianissimo Ristorante.

I love this place! The other day we came by when they were on break between lunch and dinner. When they saw us looking in the window, the manager came over and said "come on in! You're hungry and the chef is here anyway!"

This is exactly the kind of restaurant you want to have in your neighborhood. The food is amazing, the service is spectacular and friendly, and the ambiance is busy but chill.

Definitely definitely definitely get the parmesan crusted filet of sole.  You'll be a happier person for having done so.
My order was delivered promptly and the dishes were quite good...particularly the Filet of Sole Francese. I would definitely order food from this establishment again!!! I'm

This is our go-to Italian since even before the pandemic, but particularly so since then.  Edgar and team have always been friendly and happy to see us!  Our faves are the veal chops, the pesto pasta, linguine with clams (white sauce; but red is available too) the Antipasto Freddo and then leaving room for the tartufo!  Don't forget martinis and wine to round out the meal.  I can't wait to go again!

I went here over the holidays and probably would have given them 4 stars based on that prior experience however I went last evening with my family and it seems to have deteriorated considerably since December... or perhaps we just had a bad experience.  The wait staff were friendly and efficient initially however as the meal went on the wait time to put in our dessert order then get our check increased considerably.  The food is the primary area of concern however.  Crab cakes were unidentifiable.  small, hard and rubbery.  If we hadn't ordered them I couldn't have guessed what they were.  The muscle appetizer had an overwhelmingly bad flavor to it, like very old seafood ;-(  My Entrée, a simple past dish with chicken, had a burnt flavor too it, as though they cooked the chicken very fast over an open flame and although it didn't appear burnt it tasted quite burnt.  I recognize that restaurants are very challenged at the moment so my primary motivation for writing this review is in hopes that they can right the ship

After several delicious takeout experiences from Italianissimo, I decided to make the epic four-block trip from my apartment to check it out in person. It was well worth the journey!

I've now been there twice and plan to make it a go-to spot for great Italian food.

The place has a cozy, comfortable West Village-like feel to it.

The food never disappoints. On my most recent visit, I had the Pollo Alla Romana, which had a tasty artichoke and mushroom sauce and a nice big portion of chicken. And we were recommended a fantastic Barbera wine.

The staff is knowledgeable, polite, friendly, and accommodating. They allowed a few small substitutions for one of our meals without hesitation. And right as we were about to leave, they surprised us with a dessert to share with candles, after overhearing we were celebrating a birthday. The whole restaurant (even other tables!) joined in to sing happy birthday. It was a pretty magical night.

HAIR IN FOOD HAIR IN FOOD DONT YOU LIKE A BIG BLACK HAIR IN YOUR FOOD!!!!

If someone asked me to write a song about this restaurant that would be my chorus. HAIR IN FOOD HAIR IN FOOD DONT YOU LIKE A BIG BLACK HAIR IN FOOD.

The Gist:
So there was a long black hair in between a bed on mussels and shrimp. Paid $29.95 for a dish that was inedible and then the owner refused to pay. He offered us another dish (probably with a side of spit) but told us he couldn't refund it so we should call seamless. When we called seamless they needed approval from the restaurant. The vet kind seamless customer service rep reached out to the owner and he hung up on them. Ya douche move from a bush league restaurant.

Outcome:
Seamless is great! They refunded our money and gave us a $10 coupon for the restaurant of our choice.  As for the restaurant.... well it was the fist time and last time ordering from these gibroni

Love this restaurant! Italianissimo is an authentic neighborhood gem but one we love to share with friends, family and out-of-town visitors. It's a quiet, intimate lovely setting that allows for conversations without any need to raise your voice.

The food is excellent - great pasta (the seafood fra diavolo is just one example), excellent calamari and zucchini apps to name a few and a great array of chicken and fish dishes. Always a good selection of specials.

The service is extremely warm and friendly. A place where in short time they'll know your beverage preferences.

Italianissimo Ristorante you are most certainly awesome, I had an incredible experience here yesterday. The look of this place is really pleasant. Italianissimo Ristorante has a fantastic Caesar Salads, this dish will blow you away with its fantastic taste and flavor. The staff was fantastic and really accommodating. Overall, liked this place and will def come back to try other things on their menu.

Highly recommend! Coming from a native Italian New Yorker,'this place is a hidden gem.  Everything was fantastic.  Started with the hot antipasto plate shrimp cocktail and the mussels in white wine.  We were soaking up every bit of it all with the bread. Could have just had double the apps and been happy. Then I had the rigatoni in a pink meat sauce and my boyfriend had the chicken Francais which was sooo darn good. I forget what my cousin had, but she said it was delish.  Best part was the tiramisu... the best one I have ever had in my life.
The atmosphere was wonderful. Peaceful, and sexy ... classy, yet comfortable....  I can't wait to go back!

A forgotten gem. We have never had a bad experience here. Came here 2 weeks ago and the food and service were great. Came tonight to eat indoors and were not disappointed. Steak was excellent and Halibut special was spot on. One of the real differentiators was the hostess Lisa. Makes you feel like you are home. Highly recommended.

Food was OK, expected bigger portions for the rollitini. Two tiny eggplant rolls for 11,00? That's exorbitant, especially if the food was previously frozen. The pasta was a well done dente, the sauce pretty good, but the cut up chunks of Polly-O? Not ok. Just keep it consistent with the parm and black pepper.

The desserts are the best. They are pricey, but very worth it. I'd come back for the desserts alone. Had the Biscotti dessert with the wine. Had a few cookies left over, and asked for a to go bag. The waitress/hostess put it in tin foil and made a bad out of it. ::Gush:::

However, The best part was opening the bag and seeing some extra little cookies along with the biscotti.

Service and such attention, along with great desserts make this place a revisit.
Strong drinks, good pasta, attentive & kind service + complimentary bread & bruschetta. Nice quiet and cozy interior too!
UES local diamond in the rough.  Fave local Italian restaurant with friendly wait staff, great specials, and quaint atmosphere. Good date place as well as family spot.  Check out the bananas flambé.

Italianissimo just gets it right. The food is excellent - everything is great, but I usually end up with at least one of the always extraordinary specials; most recently, fall-off-the-bone osso buco with perfect fresh pasta. The wine is plentiful, they have a full bar, and the service is kind and neighborly; it's one of few places I truly feel like a "regular".  It is of course an ideal date spot, but also wonderful for group dinners. Once, we asked if it would be OK to bring a cake for a celebration - not only did they serve and slice it for us, but each slice was beautifully plated as if it were from their own menu (note: the desserts from their own menu are also amazing, no need to bring your own cake, get a cannoli). The rare neighborhood gem that's also worth a trip.

Wow!  First word that comes to mind.  We walked around the UES to look at all of the places we found on Yelp and this was the first on our list and the one we choose.  What a great decision that was!  
First - hands down and a bow to the staff.  From the moment you walk in so friendly and helpful with menu seating to food selection and anything you need!  The menu and chef - Whoa! Amazing food, great sized portions and everything we ordered was prepared and served better than expected.  Big thank you to the chef for the fresh fruit with our Port at the end of the night and a huge thank you to all the staff.  Excellent experience and we will be back!
The food in here was excellent, I had the penne with asparagus and shrimp in a pesto sauce. The people that works here are very nice.I would recommend this place to anyone.

Absolute gem! The waitstaff are kind and accommodating. The tables are well spaced so it is covid safe. I went in late November, so I'm not sure if more heat lamps were added but it was a bit chilly(obviously what's going to happen while sitting outside, but more heat lamps would've been nice).   Our meal started and ended with complimentary small bites and our main courses were delicious.

What a lovely neighborhood restaurant! My husband and I shared a delicious grilled portobello with burrata appetizer, followed by veal piccata and sole francaise, each presented beautifully and served with mashed potatoes and sautéed green beans.
In addition, the service was warm and friendly as was the ambience. I especially loved the extra little touches like the yummy bruschetta at the beginning of the meal and the light, crispy cookies at the end.
We will definitely be returning to Italianissimo!
This is a great little restaurant great service wonderful food great ambience when you come here you feel like you're in a little restaurant in Italy   perfect place

Took my mother here this past weekend when she was visiting NYC, as she had been to this restaurant when visiting eight years ago and had fond memories of it. Thankfully, it did not disappoint. Everything was spot on - the food, service, and charming, cozy atmosphere were all excellent. It's small, about a dozen or so tables, so make a reservation ahead of time.

Lovely dinner with friends last night. It had been a few years since my husband and I went to Italianissimo and last night we returned with another couple. The food was very good, we started with the fig and burrata appetizer which was not as good as I had hoped, the figs were flavorless, but other than that everything else was great!. The salad special with anchovies had a lovely delicate dressing. My main of Papparedelle alla boscaiola was perfectly cooked and so rich I couldn't finish it. My husband had the bronzino special which had a lovely flavorful almond crust. We made room for the affogato dessert as it combines two of my favorite things - espresso and ice cream - YUM!
Service was very good except they forgot to bring the tea for one of our guests until after we had the bill. Other than that service was attentive.
Over all the prices was moderate for the area - 4 people, wine, apps, salads, mains (3 pasta, 1 fish) and 2 desserts came in at $250. Worth it for a leisurely 2.5 hour excellent meal. We will return!

So, Italianissimo. For those of you who do not have a working knowledge of the Italian language, the suffix -issimo is the greatest of superlatives. So there is, for instance, Bravo and then there is Bravissimo which is a much stronger version.

So what does Italianissimo mean? A basic translation would be "The most Italianist thing ever"

And I say, without affection or qualification that this is true -- but only if the word "Italian" means "night of nausea and gas"

Let me start with the good. Italianissimo (ugh, that name) is a really cute a charming looking restaurant and the service is really terrific. The waiter was friendly and funny and, well, just everything you want in a waiter in an Italian Restaurant. In fact, this review would have been 2 stars if not for the delightful waiter.

On to the food. Three courses. Hot Italian Appetizers. A pasta with mushrooms and then the veal piccata. There is something you will notice about the sauces. You know that thick almost gelatinous texture you get from corn starch at take out chinese places when you order General Tso's chicken or Sweet and Sour Pork....well, somehow they have translated this into various Italian(issimo) sauces. Frankly, it isn't very good.

The food wasn't disgusting or inedible nor was it poisonous, but I will say that it wasn't very good and was just like a mix between Italian food and Chinese food.

The after effect was a night long of feeling terrible.

I do not see myself going back there in the future. Just down the block is the excellent Elio's which turns out winner after winner. I grant that Elio's is probably 20% more expensive, but it is 200% better so, at the end of the day, it is a value.
Intimate small restaurant that is delicious, quiet and warm. Feels like old school nyc. Love the cookies at the end. Also great for delivery.

I love this food cart - it's the closest I've found to home cooked Indian food in the city.

Earlier you get there the better since they start running out of items.

Indian Fast Food Cart you are truly remarkable, I had a spectacular experience here today. Unique place. Every single thing that I have actually tried has been pretty flavorful. The crew is incredibly courteous. I really liked that. You all should check out this beautiful place.

Worst and spoiled biryani ever!

Stay away. I went to this cart around 3pm for late lunch. Not only it was worst biryani I ever had. It stunk. It was spoiled and yet was being sold to customers.

This place is value.  This place is the true money spot.  But for some reason, all the bankers and hedgefund guys don't usually come here.  It's usually just me and my wise wallet.  Satisfying lunch for $6.  It's hard to beat that on Park Ave.  

A well-placed visit to mobile India will bring sweet tidings of chicken tikka marsala, vegetable side, above average white rice, and "naan" (it's really a pita).  There's a vegetarian option as well which looked good.  Plus you get all the Indian condiments that you usually find at Indian buffets and restaurants.  Definitely a go-to spot for lunch.  It's also stands adjacent to a wide open plaza with man-made ponds that you can sit right by.  Perfect for those days when you just don't want to go back to the office (which is Mon-Fri, 9am-5pm).

Damn You Indian Cart. I have been sitting here for 15 minutes staring at my screen being completely unproductive. I don't even think there was any brain activity going on for that span of time. All the energy I could possibly have went straight to digesting the 3 pounds of food I ingested about an hour ago. And now, I am lethargic.

Did this food coma really only cost me $6? Did I really finish all of my chicken tikki masala, mystery vegetarian side, and endless rice? Yes, yes and yes. Now I am drinking some coffee, trying to revive my vital signs.

This cart has pretty good food. cheap. fast. like everyone says. it's not that busy, so it's a good alternative when you find yourself not wanting to wait 5-10 minutes for truck/cart food. My biggest complaint is that they do not include naan, instead they give you an Indian tortilla, which is not as good as its Mexican counterpart. But maybe this is a good thing, because I do not need any more carbs today.

I'm surprised that this cart isn't on Yelp yet.  If it already is, I'm sorry for creating a duplicate entry (it won't be the first time - but I do correct my mistake, if I find out that I am, indeed, mistaken).  Anyway, enough hypothesizing and apologizing.  Let's get into this little review of the Indian Fast Food Cart on Park and 53rd.

The link you see above is to Midtown Lunch, which is a great source of Midtown luncheoning knowledge.  I wanted to steal his pictures, but instead, I did the right thing of linking.

Okay, really, let's talk about the Cart, now.

It's cheap.  It's fast (well, it's already made, duh).  Okay, sometimes, not so fast, when there's a long-ass line (for a good reason).  It's nice to sit outside by the fountain and eat among the bodies that are fellow Slaves of Midtown.  Sure, there's a sort of an ants-like dis-likable quality to the whole experience, but it's good for people-watching, so you smother the bad with the good.

Back to the food itself: It's not the best Indian food you are going to experience.  I know this, despite the fact that I am not Indian and I won't even start to pretend like I know Indian food well.  But I, too, have these things called taste buds, and they have told me that they find the food from Indian Fast Food Cart to be agreeable.  I've also a note from my money clip, something about how it likes the Cart because it gets to hold on to more dollar bills than, say, a trip to a roofed restaurant with tables and chairs.

So this place is outside my normal lunching area, but I had a meeting over there right after lunch so I wandered over there early to get a quick bite.  I was walking up Park deciding what to get, and I saw the little cart.  How could I resist.  I miss the old buffet of Rangole for a cheap Indian lunch, but I digress.

From the looks of it they have a vegetarian special lunch platter ($4) and a protein lunch special ($5), along with a few regular items.  I opted for the Tikka Masala which was okay (I had low expectations so that helps).  The chicken was tender, much to my delight.  The sauce was about what I expected, not spicy and not that complex, but it was okay.  The vegetable curry that it came with was really good, I didn't know what to expect from the menu, but were really good.  It also came with nann, but it seemed more like a pita cut in half to me, but it was $5 I can't complain.

I got there at or before noon, so I did not see any line, but have heard that it is possible later in the lunch hours.  If I was in the area more often for lunch this would become a new favorite, but I am not, so it is still a special little treat for me.

I sat on the front ledge of the Seagram's Building, so that always add to the atmosphere.  There are no restrooms obviously.

One of the better chicken and rice places I've been to. The Express Power Lunch on Pearl and Wall is better though.

- Foam container w/ 3 sections.
section1: pea/onions in curry - this sauce was kinda spicy in a good way and had more substance than the chicken's curry sauce. - very tasty!
section2: curry chicken - boneless, very tender, flavorful!
section3: basmati rice - white, unseasoned - nothing special

They also gave a half cut pita (wrapped in foil) but it was cold and a tad stale. I took a bite, spat it out, and threw it in the trash.

Total came out to $6

While taking a break and grabbing a coke in the office break room, some of my team members was chowing down some indian food.  It looked awesome!  Asked them where it was and down the elevator I went for lunch.

This cart is run by two ladies off of Park Ave and 53rd street ~ about a block from where I work.  By the way, the ladies are really sweet and very nice.  I ordered the rice topped with chicken and some orange curry sauce.  In addition, they gave me this fluffy pita bread and a side of salad. Took it back to the office and dug in... .. ummm ummm ummmm!! It was soo good.

For only $6, this will naturally become a weekly event for me!  yeahh...Now, if I can find some Vietnamese Vendors, I would be in heaven!

Cheers and enjoy.

The somosas that I got here were great for $1 a piece.  

I revise my former review.  Had the entrees here totally delicious for $5-$6 a box.  I usually get the chicken tikka with a side.  It's the perfect portion so I don't feel like I'm gorging myself yet I'm perfect full.

Surprisingly good Indian food from a cart! I got the chicken curry on rice w/ a veggie stew side for $6. There was no line when I went around 12:30 PM on a Monday.  The chicken was very flavorful and the portion was just right for a hearty meal. However, the pita thing they give you is disgusting. It seemed underbaked and doughy to me. Where's my naan?!

Don't forget to drop by the cart next to this one to get a refreshing smoothie.

The food is flavorful fresh and amazing !!! You can choose your spice level and there are always new special options on the menu daily. He has 3 different locations two in Manhattan and one in Long Island city! He is super friendly, funny and personable ! Can't wait for this food truck to expand to a restaurant.

occasionally have lunch at this cart. Being indian myself, I appreciate the 'home food' appeal of their offering. Nothing is too greasy. The price is also very good for what you get- $5 for 2 veg curries, rice and a roti. in the past they use to give you a piece of pita but when i went today I got an authentic indian roti. It was thin and soft and decently size - perfect for mopping up the curry.

It's not my favourite place to eat but it is a nice standby.

I have lunch from this cart a few times a month.

I always get the vegetarian platter which costs a very reasonable $5.

The food is pretty good considering it is from a cart and the portions are big.  Furthermore, the cart is very clean.  

One big drawback, unfortunately, is the bread.  Indian cuisine is famous for its great breads.  However, this stand usually gives you a tasteless side of pita.

I would recommend adding a lassi to your meal.  Lassis run $2 and are very good.

Overall, this stand is not the best Indian food I've ever eaten -  but it definitely gets the job done.  It's worth a visit.

Delicious. Fast. Cheap.

Tried the veg option and was very happy with my selection. The wannabe naan wasn't anything to write home about... but the rice was fluffy, the two veg dishes were very tasty and the spicy pickle + onions were nice complements.

Would absolutely recommend to others!

As everyone else has said, great food for not a lot of money. I got the biryani, which was heavenly. The ladies are nice and efficient and everyone around you will be super jealous of your awesome food.

Lines were decent at this food cart with about 10-15 people in line at prime lunch time, 12:30 pm. We figured, if there's a line like this, the food must be somewhat good. So we figured, what the heck, let's give this Indian Food Cart a try.

We waited about 10 minutes, averaging about a minute a person to pay and serve. Finally got to the front and ordered the Chicken Tikka Masala ($6.00) from the two ladies. As I ordered, I never noticed anyone more miserable than these two ladies. I don't know if it was the heat wave that NYC has received (with 7 straight days of above 90º humid weather), or if they did not like their job, but generally people in the service industry are happy or try to put a smile on their face. The one lady took my money and bagged the food and nan wrapped in aluminum foil, as the other lady served the food into the styrofoam container. As I walked away, I hoped their mood didn't speak for their food.

I finally got back to my office and opened the container, and noticed three separate areas for the food, one with the chicken tikka masala, another with the mixed vegetables (onions, peas, and carrots(?)) in some sort of spicy curry-like sauce, and the basmati rice in the large area. The chicken in the chicken tikka masala was tender and tasty (only slightly spicy) but I found the sauce was a little runny (my coworker got the chicken curry which was also a little thin in consistency but had a nice kick/spice to it). The mixed vegetables in the curry sauce was thicker in consistency and pretty delicious. I wish they would have used that sauce for their chicken dishes as it left me wanting more. The basmati rice was nothing to rave about, as it was normal rice with slight seasonings, noticeable only by those with a sensitive palate. But with all the spices going around, the rice could have used a bit more flavor. The nan was a big disappointment as it was just warm pita bread.

In all, I thought an Indian Food Cart is pretty original, as you don't see many others like it. For $6, the dish was decently good and I'd probably go back to try one of their spicier dishes. It was worth trying out, but don't expect anything extraordinary from here.

OMG, their food is so good.  Fresh, spicy and lick the container fresh.  I first saw this place on my way back home a few months ago and remembered reading about this place in Midtown Lunch. For around $10, I got their chicken curry over rice with daal (never had lentils this good anywhere) and veggie.   Since it was early evening they only had the okra left which I didn't care of due to the sliminess but everything else was sooooo delicious.  

I have seen them at that corner for a few weeks so if you spot them, please let me know.

It's cheap, it's fast, and it's Indian food.  

Is it the best Indian food you'll ever have? No. Is it a perfectly decent fast, cheap lunch?  Yep.  Is it better than quite a few other places, that will cost you more than $5 or $6 in the neighborhood? Yep.  Is the bread kind of a sorry excuse for a pita or naan that was possibly run over by a large cement truck? Yes, unfortunately, to that one, too.

It's a surprising amount of food for $5 (veg option).  Maybe their styrofoam containers have some sort of black hole action, but it always seems like the never-ending amount of rice.  I usually vaguely regret eating the entire container, because I then spend the rest of the afternoon in a very full, sleepy kind of daze.  But, I guess it's a good sign.

Malai kofta's on Monday.
Good Halal cart, clean and friendly service. The rice is not my favorite but usually never is, their white sauce is fantastic and the lamb combo platter is the way to go!
The rice-daal and samosa chat were good. Not expensive. The guy at the cart is friendly and has a different menu everyday
I just tried looking for this cart I don't think it exists anymore as I could not find it. All I saw was a cart selling fruit salad and juice.

I worked around the corner from this place for a couple years and lived on their food. It was a great vegetarian option in an area you wouldn't expect to find anything worthwhile. The weekly menu had a rotating list including chana masala, a couple of kinds of Dal, a kidney bean dish, as well as korma and kofta (the latter two were not my cuppa tea). The convenience of the cart is awesome, they work fast, so even if there's a line the wait isn't long. The chappati was sub-par but everything else is delicious and surprisingly well-spiced.

Eat here about once a week, can't go wrong for the price, vegetable platter and a soda costs $ 6.00 bucks. I can only speak for this one, I have never had the meat platter which is a dollar more. Usually you get some chick peas in a curry sauce and a separate vegetable or vegetables in another sauce. The sauce ranges most days to being a little spicy to moderately spicy. Platter comes with rice and usually a piece of nan bread, sometimes a regular pita which I am not a fan of. Some days you get a garnish or some onions and a really hot little green pepper, watch that guy he has a bite! For a buck more you can get a samosa, but it's usually to much food for me. All in all a good lunch, I think it's better than a few of the sit down places I have tried in the area.
I love this place, but I have not seen them for quite a few months now.  Does anyone know if she relocated elsewhere?

Not always there.  Often times this cart will disappear for a few weeks at a time (when they are there, don't show up after 2pm because they are usually sold out by then).  The address on the van that pulls the cart is an Indian restaurant in Astoria/LIC (does anyone know the name or a phone number? -- would be nice to be able to call in advance to see if the cart will actually be there).

Not impressed. The "veggie platter" consisted of a lot of rice, a LOT of chickpeas, a side of carrots/peas/green beans/corn (like you could buy in any American freezer aisle, but with Indian flavors), and naan. Everything was incredibly salty but only mildly spicy. I hope the other options are more interesting, but as I suspect they are equally salty, I will pass.

yum! they always give so much food. and the lady is a nice person. for only 6 dollars i get my stomach super filled with food. they give alot of meat, and i love their vegies, especially the cauliflower. like this more than the desi food truck.

Hidden Gem on the UWS!

Food/Drinks: 5/5
I was in the mood for my pasta cravings to be filled and Il Violino did not disappoint! Typically, I'm either in a classic pasta mood or eager to try something new.

The menu is complete with your traditional Italian pasta meals (i.e. penne alla vodka) and more unique items IMO like the Orecchiette Broccoli e Salsiccia - which I've never tried and can't pronounce but it was delicious! My partner is Italian so it's nice when a place gets his seal of approval *chef's kiss*. Truly quality Italian!

There's also something for those who aren't in the mood for pasta as well.

Service: 5/5
Our waitresses recommendations were ON POINT! I'm always pretty indecisive so it's nice when people are patient with me lol. She provided me with a few options for drinks and I loved the Riesling she recommended.

Our food came out so fast which was amazing (and a rarity in the city) because we were starved lol. She checked in on us frequently to make sure everything was going well!

Vibe: 5/5
The warm and cozy atmosphere made me feel like I had discovered a neighborhood secret upon walking in.

The owner radiates warmth and friendliness and adds a personal touch to the restaurant. Also, we love to see a woman-owned restaurant!!

If you sit inside, it's very much a homey feel (also loved that I could people like I was in an observatory). There is also outdoor seating nicely decorated.

We came here for an impromptu  date night but it felt like such a special occasion due to the atmosphere and service!

Perfect spot for an anniversary or even something more chill like a pre-show dinner at Lincoln Center or a day in Central Park!

Food is dull and unspecial. Portions inexplicably variable. Service slow and indifferent. Cooked food overcooked; food that should have been served chilled was not.

Snotty host who hasn't caught on that checking out your customers head to toe (not in a good way) is so aughts, and isn't done anymore. It's like, relax sir - this is a mid-at-best, utterly unremarkable place, on the *upper west side.* You're not Le Bernadin (which shouldn't act that way either btw).

I don't necessarily think this place is bad, but it also has a lot of competition. In the end, it's not horrible but nothing stands out.

The service was attentive. Food was ok. Decent but nothing rave worthy or that would make me specifically want to come here again.

Atmosphere is casual, which I liked. Just seemed like people from the neighborhood having a meal. No crazy blasting music. Not trendy (in my opinion, in a good way).

The food came out really quick. There's always a thin line when food comes out quick. It makes me think it's just been chilling there for hours or it was just frozen and then microwaved.
