I don't know if either is true, but the perception matters. But, the food was decent. My friend and I both had pasta cravings, so it hit the spot.

Service was attentive but felt slightly rushed, but I didn't think the server was rude or anything. Just more to the point.

I'd come here again just because the location is convenient. The service was quick, so if I ever want a quick meal that isn't fast food - it's always a good to have a few of those places in your restaurant arsenal.

Spent my birthday here and wanted some authentic Italian food and service. We definitely got that! Amazing Pinot Nero wine from Sicily, Gnocchi with Bolognese, endive salad, burrata, lemon ricotta cheesecake,  AND cannoli.  Our servers were some of the best and most attentive we have had anywhere. Loved being able to walk there in Manhattan's Upper West Side, and sit in the atrium for dinner. We walked to Central Park afterwards for a nice evening stroll. Prices were good, and overall SO happy to have spent a special evening at aol Violino!

It's rare that I give a one-star rating, but it's also rare that I encounter food at this price level that is prepared so indifferently. Case in point is the grilled branzino. This was a plate with a grilled white fish filet, but without any sauce or seasoning - just plain. The carrots and broccoli accompanying it were steamed, but also served plain. No sauce, no dressing, nothing - just dry. For $38, even in the Lincoln Center area, I found this kind of shocking. My dining companions reported that their entrees were similarly unimpressive. This is diner food, make no mistake about it, but not even at NYC diner prices.

I will say that the service was good - a very attentive waiter, but that doesn't by any means make up for the poor quality.
Started with the minestrone which was thinner than what I'm used to but still chunky. Ordered the Capesante (scallops), so buttery and fresh.

Old School Italian restaurant.    Very friendly staff - host and waitress.   Service was indifferent but the people were very nice at the restaurant.   Nice looking restaurant with open feeling and great seats at the windows.     Chicken Parm is very tasty and nice big portion.

Great salmon appetizer.  Gnocchi boloñesa was light, perfect  gnocchi.   Arriichetti with sausage and broccoli rabe was in a lovely light sauce.  Wines- merlot and gavi di gavi we're well presented.   Panna cotta and chocolate desserts were lovely!    A really great meal!!
Service was professional and gracious.
We came without a reservation and appreciated the accommodation!

Il Violino has been on the UWS a long time.  Many years ago I ate there several times but, when the food wasn't up to the standards I expected, I stopped going there.  I walk by this place hundreds of times during the course of a year; so today I decided to try again and see if it was any better.  It wasn't.  For what you get it is overpriced.

I sat in the shed, which was pleasant, and ordered the eggs benedict  $24.95 and, for an extra $5. you can get a mimosa or sparking wine.  I really wanted a screwdriver or bloody mary but wasn't willing to pay an additional $14.  The drink came promptly, and they brought a nice piece of bread with olive oil (actually the best part of the meal).  Unfortunately they didn't bother to give me a napkin; so I had to use my handkerchief.  When my benedict arrived, they still hadn't given me a napkin or tools to eat with (ridiculous).  I had to ask for them.

The benedict overall was disappointing.  It was two small eggs, with very little sauce over a mound of sauteed spinach and a small piece of Canadian bacon served on the typical English muffin. The spinach was stingy and not too tasty.  I would have preferred either no spinach or having it on the side.  They pile on the spinach to bury the fact that the rest of the portions were very small and inadequate.  On the plate, also, were some chopped up potatoes with onion & red pepper (ok but not great).  I ate the benedict (what there was of it) & left most of the potatoes.

Overall, this was a disappointing experience, and I think I should have stuck with my original resolve; however, after so much time, I thought I would give them another chance.  I may return one more time and try a pasta dish.  If that disappoints, then I'll never again go back.

A fantastic Italian experience with great food and service! Highly recommended.

The greeter is very friendly, we got our preferred table and a great intro. Then our waitress was helpful, fast and friendly. All food and drinks were delivered on time. Excellent service.

The Seafood linguini was very tasty, well prepared pasta with great flavor and plenty of seafood. The Gaspaccio Pomodoro was great for a very hot summer day (highly recommend to pair with Prosseco or Cold Beer). Burrata with Prosciutto was a great appetizer for 4. The risotto and the chicken Parmigiano were also very well prepared, with the risotto being the strongest because it gave us a great party of cheese flavors!

We could not get to dessert, so we will come back soon and will do an update! Until then, a perfect score for a well rounded experience, service and food!

There's literally always something wrong every time I come here (I've come three times and no more moving forward).  Whether it's the rude waitresses or the incompetent ones, it's never ever a smooth and enjoyable experience.

Really good food. Spent about 300 for a double date and that was with 2 apps and a bottle of wine. Must try! We had the lasagna, the fish special for that night, the stuffed ravioli and the eggplant lasagna. For the apps we ate the calamari and the bruschetta.
Very disappointing experience! Food is ok but the service is horrible! Will never recommend this restaurant to anyone!

Ambience: nice
Service: good
Food: very meh
Expected it'd have good food because it was kinda cozy in there.
They can do much better.
They should hire a chef who can cook, that's all.
And it ain't cheap..

Great spinach salad. Tossed in a tangy lemon or not sweet vinegarette - then drizzled with balsamic reduction. Perfect conbination of flavors. Also only $12. My husband got the meatball sub & liked it. The dipping olive oil was also very nice.

Pictures do it no Justice.

The waiter kindly explained all details, no need to egen read the menu!

We had
- Cold seafood salad with fresh calamari and endive leaves
- Black linguini with prawns
- Lasagna
- Valpolicella Zena
- A biscotti each

Munch, much bytter than most places...
I went here with a friend and really enjoyed it. The atmosphere is also great. On the weekends, they often have live music. Delivery also holds well.

You walk in and you're welcomed into a small but such a  great restaurant. Came in around 4 sat at the bar. Had great drinks, caprese salad and then lasagna.  We will absolutely be back. Love the ambiance and everyone was so welcoming and friendly. Can't wait to come back!!

I had dinner here last evening, April 25th. I made a 5 PM reservation through the restaurant's website which utilized Open Table. The reservation for 2 made the day before was easy to make. Our table was available when we arrived and all was going well. The food was very good. I had the Lasagne, which was a good sized portion and was very good, not the best I have ever had, but good. Dessert however was a disappointment. My dinner guest and I decided to share an order of Tiramisu. The waiter tried to explain to us how it was served but we went ahead and ordered it. what we got was a small cup filled with something approaching my idea of what Tiramisu is supposed to be but wasn't. There was little cake in it and it was mostly a creamy combination that, while very tasty, was way too small for the price charged.

After we finished dessert, we were presented with the check. After it was paid, the maitre di came over, interrupted our conversation and asked us to leave as the table had been reserved by another party. We had only been there for less than 90 minutes and when I made the reservation, there was nothing said about any time limit. I and my guest were quite offended, especially after I had plunked down $100 for just 2 entrees and one tiny dessert. I will not being going back there again.

We had attended the NY Film Festival, & wanted a meal as we headed out. Il Violino looked inviting, & seemed to have a decent Italian menu. It was a busy Sat. night, but they seated us reasonably quickly. Our server had a funny-sort of attitude when we first sat down -- perhaps she was having a tough night? (She warmed up to us by the end of the dinner, when she realized we spoke Spanish -- she was clearly not Italian.)

The food was not memorable, but was decent. My fish entree was well-prepared. The wines were about the same -- good, but not memorable. We'd been spoiled by a truly bonafide Italian restaurant the night prior much further north up the West Side, so this was more touristy, perhaps, being close to Lincoln Center.

We've lived in Italy, so are a different sort of clientele. I don't think I'd want to return or would recommend it. But it was an adequately pleasant Sat. night dinner.

However, a caveat: of course, this is Manhattan!, But be aware that it was not inexpensive. Our two glasses of wine & two entrees, no appetizer or dessert, cost $100.

Had a reservation at Il Violino the other day to have dinner before the evening Opera around the corner, and this was a very nice experience to have before the show.

Restaurant is intimate and not too high brow, more mellow and casual for a dining experience. A lot of history here too, this place has been around for a long while.

Rez is necessary for dining, as well as Covid Vax cards, as NYers are well aware, and seating is minimal, not too many tables.

The service was really great, had a very nice server from Europe who was kind, professional, and caring while serving us, she did a great job.

We got a bottle of white wine which was delicious and sweet, I had some Truffle Pasta with Mushrooms which was good, and that's essentially the deal with this spot.

4 stars, enjoyable time, good casual dinner choice for Opera goers.

We were in the city for the Nutcracker ballet. Of course everything around the Lincoln Center was 45min+ wait, (we missed our reservation due to traffic) so we ventured a couple blocks looking for something good. This place had seating for 4. Food was good. I had the risotto seafood dish, it was a little too wet for me but good nonetheless. The waiter told use they had a full bar when he gave us a wine list. I wanted a Moscow mule, and was then told their was no ginger beer  so idk what a full bar is then. Anyway, I would recommend

My boyfriend and I stopped by mainly because of the musicians in the front of the restaurant performing. I forget the groups name but they were GREAT and made the night lively and energetic.

I ordered the Cesar salad and the spinach and ricotta cheese raviolis. The food was underwhelming and unappetizing. The raviolis were hard and did not taste fresh at all. The only decent thing about the dish was the creamy sauce it was cooked in. The Cesar salad was also a miss, not sure how you can get something as simple as a salad wrong. It tasted like they used either a different type of dressing or the dressing went bad.

The service was mediocre. The waitress was kind and polite but service was really slow. It took them a while to take my order and to also check in to see how the meal was going. At the end of the night when we got the check I was really surprised to see that they charged for the takeout containers. Not sure if this is a new thing or a NYC thing but I have never been charged to take my food home.
Fantastic!! Sauces for all three dishes, Alfredo, Bolognese.  Mussels, Gnocchi, Caprese, service, ambiance, just fantastic all around!  Will recommend to anyone for a great night out in NYC!
Good pasta with a cozy ambience. The calamari was the best I've had in a while. It fits Lincoln Square very nicely.

- my friend who lives up there, loves this place
- I didn't particularly care for the food
- A lot of other people at out table shared the same review
- service is really nice, you feel cared for once you are there
- this seems like the kind of place to celebrity spot
- lasagna was too cheesy
- friend didn't like the risotto
- wife ordered lamb, she thought it was alright
- my other friend cleaned the plate of mushroom ravioli
- bread for the table is extremely soft, like a pillow
- my friend says they do meats really well
- other friend sed chin part was just alright as well
- they stayed open late for our party which was nice of them
- everyone enjoyed the tartufo
There's a lot of variety on the menu, with classic Italian American dishes and more modern choices. Our server was excellent and had a great sense of humor. The food was quite good

Don't ask to split a check.  They won't do it in the obvious way. They will give a total bill and you have to do the math. And if 2 order the same item, one has to pay for both and work it out between you.

Great place, with cozy atmosphere and delicious food.
Daniela give us the best service in NY! She is such a sweetheart!

Walked in here hoping for good food since the space felt cozy. However, the food was very disappointing. It is definitely overpriced as well.

We got the carpaccio, endive salad, and fettuccine con scampi. The bread for the table was stale and it tasted like it was toasted hours before being served. The carpaccio was lacking depth. The endive salad was ok -- something you could quickly throw together at home. Lastly, the pasta tasted like pasta you would expect at a food truck, but for the price of $34.

The server was okay, but had a little tude.

After "Camelot" at Lincoln Center, six of us had dinner at Il Violino on Sunday @ 6:30 p.m. The wait staff was courteous and prompt. The drinks, salad, and dinners were excellent. A gift to the palate. When the check came, we were  pleased because it was quite reasonable. After this satisfying experience, we will be returning with pleasure... GG
Came in for a late lunch and ordered the prix fixe menu.  Tasty!!! Great value. The pasta primavera was excellent!

We've been strolling by Il Violino for the last year determined to dine there one day because this place gets an A+ for their efforts rising from the ruins of the pandemic and cheering up the UWS neighborhood. They were one of the first restaurants that built a cute outdoor dining cabin on Columbus Ave and decorated it (now they have a 2nd dining cabin on the W 68th St side of the restaurant).  During XMAS they had a charming mailbox display for Santa on the side where families could pose and take photos and they always have a rotating live music lineup for brunch or early dinner.  Last Sunday we finally dropped in (without a reservation around 5:30pm). Columbus Avenue is closed to cars for OPEN STREETS NYC on Sundays (until November 14) so we asked to be seated outside in the street on a picnic table under a big umbrella if possible.  The hostess was so sweet, said she had a reservation for a large party there later that night but allowed us to have the table if we ate fast.  We said no problem, we were hungry!  The waiter was kind and professional even though my husband was acting like a jerk, complaining why did the clams in the white clam linguini that he wanted to order was going to be served with shells (said he hates having to dig them out) and saying he was cold outside, wasn't excited by the menu, blah blah blah... I just ignored him and ordered a glass of Chianti and the Bolognese lasagne.  Added on the fried calamari appetizer too.  When the food arrived at our table, my husband's mood quickly changed.  He couldn't stop eating my lasagna and we both slurped up his clam linguini.  We thought we were in for regular NYC Italian cuisine.  We were wrong.  The food was amazing, like we were dining al fresco in a cozy streetside cafe in Italy.  Such a pleasure to people-watch passerbys and see a group of teens filming themselves skateboarding in the open street.  Then a beautiful rainbow appeared in the sky.  It started to lightly drizzle before the sky opened up with a sudden downpour.  We pulled the almost empty plates closer to us, huddled under our cafe umbrella and continued eating. It was glorious.  The rain stopped, the sky turned pink and people (including us) started posing and taking photos in front of the rainbow (which was more intensely colorful by then).  The streets were wet and shiny.  Had to order the tiramisu to finish off the amazing dinner.  The only thing that would've made the evening more magical is music from the Russian accordion player who busks outside near Fairway sometimes. Il Violino is an UWS treasure.

Very good atmosphere and our waiter was very good. Very pleased with our service and food as well. We also ordered dessert and coffee and it was comforting to end the meal with.

The interior is tight but great! Very unique set up and it is for sure a good time! The outdoor street seating can get quite cold in the winter but perfect on warmer days.
Quaint corner spot in the upper west side of Manhattan. Live music ... perfect summer Sunday afternoon in NYC. The food was superb. And it's dog friendly

Worst restaurant experience ever. They tried to ID me for ordering Penne Alla Vodka and then kicked out my entire party because some people were sharing dishes instead of ordering their own. Overpriced mediocre Italian food. Cant believe how poorly this place is run. By the way Penne Alla Vodka is a PASTA not a DRINK. Smh. *:(*

The food is delicious! I recently ordered delivery via Postmates - the takeout could have been packaged better (as some of the penne alla vodka sauce spilled), but I understand the limitations for takeout and they did wrap the tin container in plastic wrap so there was no major external leak. The penne alla vodka was delicious and pasta is was al dente. I've also dined in this restaurant previously and highly recommend for a great meal.

Il Violino is the quintessential neighborhood Italian restaurant, except it's located on the Upper West Side (which translates to $$$). It most definitely caters to the 50+ crowd with their children and grandchildren. My boyfriend and I came here this past weekend after watching a movie at the nearby AMC theater. We were definitely the youngest people in the restaurant as per usual and were treated as such like at most restaurants I go to.

What I did like about Il Violino was that we were seated right away and in the atrium overlooking Columbus Avenue. Perfect for people, or puppy watching!

The bread service was nothing to write home about. We were each given two slices of bread, which were fairly large but lacked any real texture. I'd say the bread was a step above Wonder Bread. A nice crusty rustic bread to dip into the olive oil would have been more pleasing. The real highlight of the dinner though was my lasagna entree.

Calamari Fritti [$16]: I thought the fried calamari was a little bland and not crispy enough. It's like the calamari was pulled out of the fryer a minute or so too soon and someone forgot to sprinkle the salt on top. The marinara sauce it came with was fine, but it didn't add anything to overall flavor of the fried calamari.

Lasagna alla Bolognese [$23]: Is $23 a little expensive for lasagna? Yes, it is. Was the lasagna the best I've ever had? Yes, it was. The first bite was a perfect piece of bolognese ragu. I can't tell you why it was perfect, it just was. The lasagna itself was smothered with cheese, the edges of the pasta were crispy and delicious. I'm still dreaming about the lasagna.

Tartufo [$11]: Ugh. They tried to fancy up the tartufo by coating it with cocoa powder. Any old school Italian place in Brooklyn coats the tartufo (usually filled with vanilla ice cream) with a hard chocolate shell. This is the only way it should be done.

I had a glass of the Riesling [$12] which was fine, I like Riesling.

My boyfriend had the Linguine con Cozze e Vongole [$27] which had clams and mussels in it. He said they were fishy. I could attest to this as I could smell it across the table.

The bill came out to close to $120, not including tip.
I'd come back just for the lasagna and skip everything else.

Good neighborhood spot for Italian food. Had dinner there and my friend ordered a burrata which the waitress had offered as an appetizer special, then she returned to tell us the last one had been ordered so it wasn't available. I had gluten free and it was above average. I would return but it's not a special occasion place.

This is one of the first places where I had the pleasure of dining at with my girlfriend at the time.

At first, the super quiet environment felt different as this was my first time dining at a fine dining restaurant. The service however was welcoming and truly made me feel at home.

I ordered the bolognese and she ordered the Linguini Vongole, while waiting for our food, we were blessed with bread that was truly wonderful. Although we are no longer together, the memories of the food here live on and I can tell you I have never had a Bolognese anywhere else in New York.

Seafood wasn't my thing at the time and i can say that the vongole was amazing and as I mentioned earlier, the bolognese really hit home and knocked my socks off.

Over all a super memorable experience and would highly recommend to anyone looking for a quaint delicious night out

I came here for dinner last night with my friends after watching the Opera. We sat in the outdoor seating area which was super cute and festive for the holidays. It also had heating which was a huge plus during this cold winter night. I ordered ravioli which tasted amazing. My friends tried the minestrone soup and they couldn't stop praising it. We also appreciated the pleasant service
Beautiful Friday evening on Columbus Ave enjoying wonderful meal and live music. Carmen and Daniel keep it upbeat f

I stopped by for dessert and coffee. It was a good experience. The price was exorbitant and the food was above average. They were on a strict time table and it was definitely felt when I was at the table but this is a good spot for a quick meal.
Happened to pass by on the 12th. Did not eat here but certainly experienced the spirit of the season! The light display with added Pazzaz from the tractor trailer was over the top.

Comfortable "old school" ambiance, friendly attentive service, tempting menu options, generously stocked bar, under the direction of a lady who ensures that guests enjoy their experience here: a gem in the Lincoln Center area!

My boyfriend and I love this restaurant. It's definitely our go-to place in the neighborhood. Our waitress Georgiana is always a pleasure!! She's very friendly, considerate and courteous. We always feel very taken cared of- we thank you! The service and waitstaff are very swift and prompt. I'd like to point out how delicious the food is ! Everything on the menu is delicious, Everything ! Thank you chefs..Soooo tasty. They have a brunch prefix menu which we always order from that includes a drink. We usually order the eggs benedict (amazing) with a mimosa or Bloody Mary. Today I decided to try the main menu and I'm so happy I did. The chicken marsala is ridiculously delicious. Also, who ever made my old fashioned, thank you !
The ambiance is very warm and relaxing yet also professional.

I have been going to this restaurant for a few years.  I have always enjoyed it.  
I WAS  ESPECIALLY PLEASED  with Thanksgiving.  I ate outside in the safe newly made wooden framed outdoor arrangement  It was wonderful!  It was festive,the service was amazing, food was top notch, every course, beautifully prepared,  happy surroundings, Very clean, very safe. The three of us all felt the same. In fact, i want to make it a new tradition.  
Whatever the circumstances going forward regarding travel, and eating. I want to come back year after year.  I could not have been more pleased!

What a great cozy little restaurant. The servers were all super nice and we only waited the most 15 minutes for a table on a Friday night. My boyfriend and I both ordered the same dish, fettuccini con scampi, but we swapped out the original sauce for Alfredo. For me the Alfredo could have been a little more flavorful but overall it was super tasty. For desert we had the chocolate torte and the tartufo. They were both delicious. I will definitely be back.

Violino on the upper west side 180 Columbus Ave at 68 street. This is an amazing Italian restaurant with great food great wine and a awesome atmosphere. The employees are so nice and the food is so good. They have a nice bar if your just looking to have a drink and food or you can sit down and enjoy the great food. With the covid restrictions you can enjoy a nice lunch , dinner or appetizers  outside in their beautiful decorated outdoor restaurant with Santa greeting you for the new year. Show your support for our restaurants since the Mayor or Governor won't . Enjoy this great place  for dine in or take out. I myself rate this place a 10 out of 10, the chic parm is to die for and the pasta with vodka sauce is amazing.
stopped her for a drink and a bite before an event at the kaufman center. service was quite and pleasant, will come back for an actual dinner!
Guilty pleasure, simply delicious! When wanting to splurge on something indulgent & fun perfect stop!

I really love it here! The staff are extremely kind and the ambiance is perfect for working or socializing. There's tons of space, which makes it easy to come at any time of day. They're also open until 7, which is nice for an after work coffee.

This place used to be great, but it's steadily gone downhill over the past few years. I keep thinking I'm going on "off days," but enough of those and it's clear  it's just the norm now. The biggest negatives are prices, which have gotten prohibitively expensive, and service, which is inconsistent and just unfriendly at times.

Yes, it's New York, and yes, prices have gone up everywhere, but they've shot up here more than nearly anywhere else on the UWS. A regular latte is $6 after tax, and if you want it iced, that's closer to $7 (as an aside, I will perhaps never understand the surcharge for iced drinks; you get the same amount of espresso with a bit more milk, which hardly seems like it should cost 50+ cents).

This also used to be one of the friendliest cafes in the neighborhood, and while there are some great baristas here, it can be very hit or miss with others. It's less of "oh I miss how it used to be 5 years ago" and more that it's started feeling like you're imposing on them by ordering anything.

If the coffee quality or neighborhood feel made up for it that would be one thing, but compared to spots like Black Press or Solid State, it just doesn't feel worth it anymore.

No WiFi.
Everything is pre-made and you can't add or modify any food item.
Disappointed that I went here

This is a popular cafe in the UWS! It's got good coffee and pastries, though on the pricier side for sure (not surprising for the area). Unfortunately there's no wifi here, but I like to come here to read or write so that's no problem for me. I always see a lot of people here doing some work, reading or chatting as well. I've never had a problem finding a seat, as there's plenty of seating both in the front and back section of the cafe.
This is a good place to catch up with friends or come get some work done if you don't need wifi.
Great place to grab a coffee on your way to work. Have not tried the pastries yet but they looked absolutely delicious

Lack luster and expensive in my option. I was struggling to decide what I wanted and the baristas suggested the matcha (their favorite). Is that a red flag for a coffee shop? Went with a cortado, it was really good. Wish they had flavors listed on their menu as someone after me ordered a maple latte and I would have loved to do a maple americano. Sandwich was fine, but the bacon was cold and the cheese was scarce so it was just plain old eggs and cold bacon on a warm bun.

The biggest downside, no wifi!  Came here hoping to work but after ordering and sitting down to set up I saw the no wifi sign. Ugh! Was able to complete a little writing and side work, but couldn't get down to what I really needed to get done. Big disappointment for me honestly, especially with an empty cafe.

Overall a cute and aesthetic coffee house, but not suitable for what I need a coffee house to be.

A friend recommended this coffee shop to me a while back, and I am so glad I finally got to come! It is quite spacious inside and would be a good place to get work done or do some reading. I got an oat cappuccino, which was good but nothing special in terms of the espresso flavor. The pastries looked really good though, so I would want to come back and try them! If I am in the area again, I would definitely bring a book with me to chill inside!

A great little coffee shop on the Upper West Side. Their Cinnamon Cardamom Bun is awesome, though messy, and goes well with their hot peppermint tea. Their croissants looked incredible, too. Lots of people were sitting in here to work on their laptops. I had a business meeting here for over an hour, and it was a great place to chat.

Lots of space and seating that's worthless since they have no wifi and receives no outside service (I couldn't even connect my hotspot.) Also, enjoy paying 8 DOLLARS for a mediocre latte to sit in a place that, once again, has no wifi.

I was here before the holidays. Great outside seating! Irving Farm Coffee is a favorite of mine. I remember when it opened on the Upper East Side. I had a delicious Bacon Egg and Cheese Sandwich.
I also visited other locations with my Yelp friends. I love the food for some reason. The sad thing is that two of the three locations I've reviewed closed. They were closer to home than this one on the Upper West Side. The third location I've been to is in Gramercy Park and I didn't care for that one. It's too small a space.
So here I am on the Upper West Side at 79th Street praying this location in my old neighborhood stays open. I can't visit as frequently. It's the same delicious coffee and pastries. I like the vibe here and employees are nice as always.
I'm recommending.....

Good lattes, albeit overpriced for what they are. Still in search of the perfect cafe to work or read in, but this one is not it. They play really loud music for some reason so impossible to work/write/read. Honestly it's even difficult to maintain conversation with the level they keep the music at. The search continues...
I really love this coffee shop, the space is large with warm lighting. Ordering a cup of coffee & opening up my laptop. It's a wonderful way to spend an afternoon over there

The hubby and I needed a caffeine fix and added Irving Farm to our list of roasters to check out during our most recent trip to NY.  

The shop was way bigger than I thought it would be and had plenty of seating inside.  It's a long, narrow shop on the upper west side that you walk downstairs to get to.  There's seating in the front of the shop and then more seating and a long table in the back of the shop.  

The hubby ordered a hot drip coffee while I did a double espresso and grabbed a bag of their beans while I was at it.  The coffee was carefully crafted and results were smooth and no bitterness to them.  

Next time you're there, stop in or check them out online and order some beans and merch from them.
Just yes. Omg U love. Coffee is amazing, food is delicious, vibes are great Love the service!!

Lattes are over steamed ; not drinkable (airport location);

Though the ambiance is welcoming and overall clean appearance and kind staff.

first place i stopped at after i landed on nyc. now def do navigation because i literally walked past place.

wanted a latte with a picture in it. theres simple syrup and raw sugar at the counter if you needed it more sweet.

and of course a salmon bagel because i was in town. they dont offer lox bagel but they had smoked salmon and it was so good! (glad they didnt have lox so i ended up with this!)

Irving was ranked one of the best coffee shops in NYC by Lonely Planet unfortunately I have to disagree. You walk in to a cramped bar area where a crowd of people are either waiting to order or waiting for their order. There's no where to properly stand and no proper flow. The cappuccino was pretty typical to any other small coffee shop in NYC. The roast tasted more like a blonde roast than dark. Definitely on the mild side for those that don't like coffee super strong. The milk was also overheated leading to large bubbles in the foam and not the best mouthfeel. Ranked this place 3 stars due to lack of uniqueness, taste, and ambience.

We came to this breakfast joint on our last day in New York. This restaurant was near the hotel. We were able to pick up food online. I had the veggie breakfast burrito, which was better than I expected. Definitely recommend coming here if you like breakfast food.

Honestly an okay place to grab a cup of coffee. Looks cute from the outside. There is sitting inside, but all the tables were taken when we came in on a Sunday around lunch time. To be fair it was raining outside, so maybe it was busier than usual? It did take a while to make our drinks, which we didn't mind. I had an oat milk latte which was alright, and my friend had a chai which she also said was okay. All in all, might be a good place to grab coffee if you live in the area or walking by, but not worth a trip.

I came her looking for a two things: a cup of coffee and a comfortable place to read for an hour. I got exactly what I was wanted and more.

The drinks are quite good and the baristas are so quick! My wife and I ordered an oat milk latte and a cortado. Both drinks were waiting for us by the time we scoped out seats and set down our bags.

The weather outside was miserable, exactly the rainy, January Sunday in New York that will eventually drive all New Yorkers to move to Florida before we die.

Irving Farm was the perfect respite from it all. Despite the inclement outside and the fact that it was 3:30 on a Sunday, Irving Farm offered plenty of space and comfort. The commodious backroom provides an ideal place to kill time with a good book and a hot drink.

My favorite oat milk latte in the city is here, and my favorite study/working environment is here. So close to where I live and nestled in a very cute area. 2 good size seating areas - one in the front and one in the back. The seating area in the back has loads of seating with a BEAUTIFUL skylight making it the most perfect place to get in the zone. People are always working here so it is a great understanding of quiet coffeehouse vibes.

Perfect marriage of coffeehouse and library ambiance!

Where is a really long line goes out the door street. Only one person working. Every seat is full. Only seats in outside. This place needs to pay attention to the place next door add staff and make a killing!

My local Irving Farm is in Millerton, NY. I have gone there for years for great food, espresso & ambiance. But lately something has gone very wrong; the food has cheapened, the baristas seem inexperiened and the counter help untrained. Too bad. I won't go back.

Pros: latte and banana bread were delicious, lots of seating available

Cons: no wifi, cold inside, understaffed
Rude staff and my ham & cheese croissant had almost no content inside the pastry. Wasted my money and time by going here. The area is very nice though and the ambiance was okay.

If you are looking for a quaint coffee shop to read, do work or to catch up with a friend, I would highly recommend this location. They actually have a lot of seats inside and out which is so unique in NYC. They have a great selection on their menu, although I passed by later in the day, I would love to see more selections, so maybe I will check them out early in the morning. I tried their cardamom and cinnamon bun and a house chai latte and it was the perfect treat to the afternoon. The place is super clean and the staff is super friendly. Would definitely come by again!
What I love about this place: tons of seating, great coffee, cozy place for work and reading, restroom is available. One downside: no wifi...

Came here on a Saturday morning to try their coffee since it was reccomtnded by a friend that lives in the neighborhood & while the latte was good, the terrible service did not make the $7 worth it. The girl was so rude & unwelcoming. What a terrible way to start anyones day.

Ample seating and well-spaced. Some surprisingly nice natural lighting for an underground café. Very quick service, but the coffee is expensive and tastes pretty average. Decent study spot as long as you keep in mind that the wifi is slow here.
cute place, and there's always a line.  I don't get why.  I don't love the food here, but the atmosphere is super cute

Such a large space for working as long as your work doesn't involve wifi. They don't have wifi as they will smugly tell you if you dare ask. Also this is one of those places that tightly controls your sweetener options to syrup, brown rocks that don't dissolve, and Stevia. If you're diabetic and think Stevia tastes like medicine, you're out of luck! Splenda?! How low class of me. Just way snobby and the bathroom toilet was covered in feces.
Just a heads up that there is no wifi here! (Folks are just using hotspots, etc.) decent coffee and good for meetings
the coffee is so good n the oats r literally delish n vegan. what's not more to like!

Really beautiful cafe but extremely overpriced. One chai latte with almond milk was almost $7. NO WIFI. I always understand this in tiny cafes where they don't want customers sitting and working but this is such a huge cafe with lots of seating so it doesn't make sense. With more remote workers looking for work spots on the rise, they really need to get in the game, add wifi, and lower their prices. The staff wasn't helpful or friendly either. I won't be back.
What a bad cappuccino, used to be great, seems to be losing its vibe. Train your baristas please.

The coffee was good and the service was ok. Was in the area and my friend wanted to come here because she liked the coffee. It was a Sunday afternoon and it was drizzling so we decided to pop in here while we wait out the rain. I got the latte with whole milk. Unfortunately, the place was a bit busy so there wasn't really seating available inside, but we asked to wait. Luckily someone left while we were waiting for coffee and was able to go in. There seemed to be a decent amount of space, but they might be following social distancing rules still.

They ended up closing at 3pm. It's weird to me places close down on Sundays in a city like New York, but it's great for workers so they can have some real time off and spend it with friends and families. Overall, not a bad place to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon

This place was lovely! I always walk past it when I walk my dog but I never got the chance to stop in, that is until I woke up way too early for work the other day! I stopped in around 8AM on a Wednesday and there were enough seats for everyone.
I ordered the bacon egg and cheese and it was phenomenal! The egg was nice and runny, and the bacon was crispy and delicious! So tasty, kept me full the rest of the day!
The cold brew was excellent too! They have soy milk and oat milk as dairy substitutes.
They also have a little refrigerated section with cups of yogurt, orange juice, water bottles, etc.
my boyfriend got the bean breakfast wrap (idk if that's actually what it was called.) but it was VERY heavy and filling! Came with a little side salad too.
We also split the Brazilian cheese bread and it was INCREDIBLE!
Will definitely be returning!

For me, Irving Farm has been a good cafe for slowing things down and escaping from the usual pace of the city. I go every few weeks for a leisurely coffee and an occasional breakfast sandwich, always with reading material in tow.

Both the drinks and the food are great, and there are fresh pastries brought in from known bakeries. The menu is on the pricier side, in my opinion, so you'll pay for the quality.

The place doesn't have WiFi, and my cell usually has poor signal, especially in the seating area in the back. I personally like having a place to go that forces me to unplug, and while I see some customers on their computers, I'd recommend this cafe for offline reading and/or good conversations with.

UPDATE (12/9/2018): photos of cappuccino and their overnight oats jar!

Coffee is good. I ordered iced vanilla latte and it was delicious.

Breakfast burrito was good too- they do put chipotle sauce so it's an Americanized version of a breakfast burrito but the bacon is LEGIT. Not too fatty, not too crispy, and just right.

They have indoor seating area available towards the back of the store and it is socially distanced out and I felt safe eating there. They get busy most of the time so be sure to not be in a rush when you enter.
What a vibin coffee shop! Really good pastries and scones! Would definitely recommend.

Weird, I'm told this one of the better cups of coffee in the city, cool. I'm in line thinking thus COVID thing is killing the place. There's one person working the bar, she looks tired. The more complex the order the greater the line grows!

Hope the coffee is special

Very large space in a very central location on the uws! I found their coffee to be absurdly expensive- especially in comparison to other local cafes- and honestly subpar. I would go back for the ambiance but def not worth it to take something to go.

I absolutely love their iced oat latte! it's kinda pricey but it's super delicious. they have brunch as well and probably will try that next time! the inside is also really nice, has a great seating area for those who want to dine in. will be coming back again!

Despite it being after 11 on a Saturday on the UWS I managed to snag a table and had the most amazing veggie breakfast burrito ever! Paired with a chai latte and I was good to go. It did take a bit because the cashier was also making the food! But that's the way of things these days, I guess. Overall I'd go back on a warmer, not-raining day and grab it all to go and sit in a park with it.

Made my way back to Irving Farm nearly 5 years later from my last review and while Covid's definitely had an impact, coffee and pastries are still top tier.

If you've not been to Irving Farm before, you'll find that the layout of the store front is nestled down a small flight of stairs into the actual coffee shop. Because it has a deep inner seating area, from what I remember, the outdoor seating arrangement leaves much to be desired though is still about average for most coffee shops operating through a pandemic in NYC.

Entering the shop, you're greeted with the echoes of what once was: a spacious opening into the coffee counter. Imagine this space cramped with small intimate tables and the sound of music and conversation and you'll have a better impression of how this shop can and, and by all accounts, should feel.

I visited in the early afternoon on a Sunday without much of a line so there was a lot of space between the few people inside. Things still moved fast leading up and into the register despite the single barista behind the counter. The narrow space leading from the entrance to the register was cramped and make for an awkward shuffle as you inched away from those leaving the registers.

I ordered a large cold brew and an Olive Oil Orange cake, both made the wait and cramped quarters worth the visit. Note: if you're looking to enjoy your coffee and treat but there's no available seating outside, take a small walk two avenues west to Riverside Park where there are benches galore. Much scenic as well.

I'm not going to lie, I miss the way Irving Farm felt inside. It's a nice coffee shop gem in the heart of the Upper West and it's good to know that while this gem might not look or feel the same, it still tastes how I remember.

P.S. Once you're up at the register you'll see a fridge blocking the further ends of the coffee shop; past this spot is a hallway opening up into a much more spacious seating area that could easily seat upwards to 20 people. When I think about this Irving Farm location, that's what comes to mind. Coffee drinkers, laptop workers, and food eaters alike in a cramped yet shared, communal space. There's a skylight inside here, a big rectangular block of light in the ceiling. You can make it out in some of the photos on yelp and online but, really, you really have to be there to see it - make sure you do.

Drinks where great!

Food was disgusting and came cold. Cold eggs? For how much money? Embarrassing. They say they have a kitchen but it's someone throwing cold sandwiches onto a panini press.

PRETTY AVERAGE ! We've had a hard time finding a good coffee roaster cafe to grab lattes since we arrived in New York on Saturday afternoon. My wife found this place online...a few blocks from our hotel on Broadway. We stood at the service counter to order and I asked for porcelain cups because number 1...we don't like our coffee in paper cups and number 2...I am not going to write a good review for coffee served in paper cups. BOY WONDER the hipster cashier was not having any of it and it was paper cups or nothing. BOY WONDER also told us every place in New York was serving in paper cups. Well Hello smarty pants because we enjoyed cappucinos in porcelain cups the previous day at the cafe next to our hotel on Broadway. So we ordered 2 x Double Shot Lattes with 2% milk. They didn't take long despite the place getting very busy soon after we arrived. They looked creamy when we took the lids off the paper cups and tasted acceptable. For a coffee roaster cafe I was disappointed in the flavor which was non-existent. GIVE THIS PLACE A MISS !

Now I am learning to be a coffee pundit. Thus I went to lots of coffee roasters on my recent visit to NYC. They have pour overs, and many different varieties of coffees from all over the world with ingredients I would have never thought of (ie:  peanut butter).  I even told them what I want and they educated me a little, thanks for helping Irving Farm.  I also love that they don't have wifi, which means talk to the people, or the person you came with or enjoy a good read.  

The environment is relaxing and hip for sure.  They even have classes you can take to learn the genius of coffee.  I really felt like this was taking coffee roasters to the next level, I loved it all.  

Plus we had breakfast as well, their homemade cheddar and chive biscuit with scrambled egg and my choice of guerye, was a perfect breakfast sandwich (it was huge and filling, look at my photo I added to Irving Farm to see.  But it was very good and for $5.50 you can't beat that price in NYC.

There are many locations throughout the city, so Irving Farm can become your favorite coffee roaster in NYC no matter where you are.  Enjoy, I can't wait to enjoy when I'm back in the city again.

I was looking for a very casual coffee shop where I could get some studying in and have a good meal with coffee, and Irving Farm fit the bill. You seat yourself and the majority of people are in their laptops or reading. The atmosphere is quiet with a couple of parties having quiet conversations, and also clean with great wall decorations.

I ordered the Harvest Bowl which was much larger than I expected, a great problem to have. Maybe it was the quinoa or the sweet potatoes, but I was stuffed and had to toss the last few bites. Seriously delicious, filling, and healthy. The coffee was also good. A large variety of options and they make their single pours with a Kalita. Hard to find many faults.

It is a pretty nice and spacious coffee shop. I came here for brunch/snack and was very nice, quick and pleasant. I could sit and talk without bumping into other people and hearing what they are doing and talking about. Food options are good for people with dietary restrictions.
They also had water and cups so you do not need to request, just come and take.
I was not impressed with dirty bathroom... it was 1 pm and bathroom was pretty dirty. I think it needs to be cleaned more often

This kosher bbq establishment is definitely a staple to most of the the upper east siders. There were people coming and going the entire time I was there. Although it looks like nothing special and it's unassuming, the food was pretty good.

This is not a normal restaurant with a waiter service, but you order at the front register. Getting the food took a little while, which surprised me because I figured most of the food should be cooked all day. They use plastic forks and knives which I believe is normal for bbq, but just felt cheap since the meal cost $70 for two people. The pickles were not my favorite. They seemed cheap and the potatoes were too soupy for my taste. Brisket was very tender though and fell apart. The beef sandwich was very savory and the bun was delicious.

I probably would try another establishment before going back here again.

Korean Chicken dry as a bone. Doesn't taste Korean. I'm Asian. I know.  I ordered melon juice and got peach tea instead.  Would have liked it better if they called me and asked for an alternative if they were out of melon juice. I ordered a beef brisket sandwich and got dry pot roast without spices instead. Mashed potatoes came from a box, and aren't real. Boy, do they taste that way. Deserts have more moisture and flavor than this food!

I really feel like asking for my money back. I'm not coming back. It's a shame that the whole Upper West Side is becoming as flavorless and expensive as the Upper East Side. Next time, I'm sticking to Dinosaur BBQ. They get what BBQ is all about.

Mediocre at best.

If you are reading a 4 or 5 star review, I wouldn't trust the credibility of those reviewers for future reviews.
To best describe this overhyped restaurant in one sentence is: very pricey for very low quality food. Most dishes (burgers / sandwiches) do not come with any meaningful sides.
While the quality of the burger meat is below average, the preparation of the burger meat is even worse. Staff did not follow instructions for customer preferences (sauces on side, medium well), however, there was no attitude, and the new dish was prepared without any hassle (surprising for a place like this). I find it especially curious that the burgers at "Izzy's" are even worse than placing the simplest raw burger (from the grocery store) on the grill for just a few minutes. More than $25 for a soggy bun, poor quality and rationed vegetables (onion/tomato/lettuce) is the clearest sign that this place has atrocious management. "Izzy's" tries to pour a tremendous amount of sauce on the bun (in order to take away from the terribly plain taste), so please be mindful of this. Note: Tempura/Spice make very flavorful burgers, worth giving them a shot (though that area is some distance from "Izzy's").

"Izzy's" 'brisket' sandwich was just really BBQ Sauce (with Brisket).

Disappointing. Avoid.

1.5/5.0

Yikes. I don't know why people eat here?? The quality of the bbq is OKAY and yet they charge prices as if you're eating at a Michelin bbq joint. I still think the best barbecue (so far) is Hometown.. but the crazy thing is their bbq is melt in your mouth crazy, with unique staples like their Hometown bbq sauce, and yet with a price tag that is fair!!! I mean, $55 for ribs? You can get steak at so many places for cheaper than this.

Here we go:
Brisket - 3/5 - Flavorless and a little dry

Creamy Slaw - 4/5 - Good, could be creamier

Pulled Beef Fries - 3.5/5 - Too sweet, and was waaay too salty. Was expecting a real pulled beef texture, but this one kind of clumped together and was hard. I think there was also some portion of mashed beans in the recipe .. eh

House Slaw - 3/5 - Eh

Burger - 3/5 - Needed more sauce, patty a little dry, bun wasn't my favorite (also dry) .. I mean, look at the photo

Honestly, if the food was normal prices comparable to other bbq spots, the review might be worth one more star, but it's almost insane how much they charge for mediocre food. Would not come again. Would not recommend. Would not be deceived by the crowds of people that come here every night.

The Dino Ribs were awesome;  seriously one of the most terrific delicious meats I have had in a very long time.  The meat melted in my mouth and the rib just fell off the meat.  The flavor can't be beat.  
We will definitely go back.

So... not worth it. My sister-in-Law Recommended this place since it kosher. We ordered the brisket sandwich, shredded beef empanadas, shredded beef sandwich, sweet potato. The brisket was dry, the empanadas were ok. The sweet potatoes is a whole sweet potato not typical candied yams. Not really worth it. A lot of money for something not super special.

Finally tried Izzy's BBQ (because my work was comping our meal so I could finally justify a $25 sandwich). Ordered the brisket sandwich, which was full of flavor and texture. Brisket was nice and tender, but the sandwich definitely could've used more sauce as it was a bit dry. Fries were very meh. Would like to try their pulled BBQ beef sandwich next time.

We ordered $350 in takeout & 2 of our orders were wrong. The restaurant refused to refund the NON Gluten free meal they sent us in place of gluten free, also another meal was missing the advertised guacamole & tortilla.
The brisket was dry & almost inedible!
DO NOT PATRONIZE THEM!

I googled bbq in Nyc and stumbled upon izzys. I'm looking for someone to cater my baby shower event and the Instagram photos with food looked amazing at this place, so I took the liberty to go try it first. I took 4 friends and we ordered ribs(we later find out it's 1 rib) and some tri tip that was only enough for 2 people. The meats were extremely dry! the baked beans also dry, vegetables did not look appetizing they were over steamed and goey. Mashed potatoes were watery. Everything was a mess and not to
Mention you serve yourself . FOR $190.00 BILL I SHOULD NOT HAVE TO SERVE MYSELF, especially not terrible food. I suggest you go to Maybels smokehouse in Brooklyn instead, you get a bang for your buck and quality meats!

This is a nice place to enjoy a BBQ Brisket sandwich.
We really did not have anything else on the menu.  
Food is very good and tasty.  
The rest of the restaurant is a no frills outdoor picnic type establishment.
I would not call it dining.
Due to Covid, seating is scarce.
Prices are okay.

Worst food ever. The fact that they cALL THIS BBQ is an insult to all the people in America that painstakingly take the time and effort to create such high quality and delicious smoked meats.
I got brisket sandwich and was basically the worst roast beef I've ever put into my mouth. Sometimes there was a hint of smoke flavor but not really. The giant Chunk of super chewy brisket right in the middle made me want to chuck it at kitchen staff and see if they could consume the giant rubber ball of fat.
If you like a massive pile of dog food on your plate at a premium price, this is the place for you.
Oh, and what's up with the potato soup,er..."mashed potatoes"
Biggest waste of $40 in my life.
Biggest BBQ disappointment of my life
Biggest restaurant experience disappointment of my life
If there is a God, this place will disappear ASAP and be forgotten forever

My friend and I went for a quick late night dinner on a Monday night and were happily surprised. I highly recommend the burnt ends, the mashed potatoes, the pickles, and the veggies! The chimichurri chicken was also great. I genuinely don't know why there are such bad reviews on here. I think it's a good little spot!

What a joke! Ordered back ribs yesterday -  I was given bare bones!!!! Can not believe I payed $55, seem like they cut all the meat off to make sandwiches for other customers.  Can't believe this, going to my regular Dinosaur BBQ in Harlem today.

The food is pretty freaking great but the prices are insane. I paid over $20 for a chicken sandwich. For takeout. They need to get a reality check. Agree with other reviewers-Dinosaur is a better bet.
Please read "Your Mom's Y" review below. I cannot think of a worse experience EVER, of food in NY. This was just awful. If you value your money and your stomach, never order from this place.

Very good casual Kosher BBQ spot. Will eat here again for lunch if I'm in the area. They have a location on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and Crowne Heights, Brooklyn. Haven't tried the one in Brooklyn yet, but will check it out sometime.

My DH and I shared the ribs; they were seriously delicious! The portions were generous and the service was great. Fries were hot and crisp. The house salad has a wonderful balsamic vinaigrette on the side. Two thumbs up; it's a great place!

Where's the smoke?  Meat is nice and high quality but as a fellow pit master myself I was looking sooo forward to this.  Maybe it's the UWS location, but this was braised (nicely tho) brisket without an ounce of smoke and a totally insipid bbq sauce. For $25 a sandwich, you gotta do more.  Sad because I really want it to work.

Table was not cleaned when we went to sit down. For the prices they're charging, they could at least make the place look even half as good as a McDonald's. Food was meh, only reason it's not a 1 star is because the staff were friendly

The pulled barbecue sandwich was quite good. However, it was $26+ including the tax. The sandwich was modest in size and came with no sides. Small indoor dining is packed and a smallish outdoor dining area is being erected. Long lines for takeout.

I liked the food it was good but the chimichurri  had an unnatural after taste but I highly recommend the plain half chicken best I ever had highly recommend this place and the chicken and pastrami if they have it

Comfortable seating outside on a beautiful day. I waited while my friend grabbed a slice of pizza. When you visit NYC you have to have pizza! I had a taste of his. It's not bad. I'll be returning when I'm bringing my appetite. It's kid friendly so bring your family!
Enjoy

My wife wanted to try some Korean food in NY's K-town and we were actually at another restaurant across the road, but it was so packed with a long wait that we decided to try some other place. As soon as we exited onto sidewalk, we looked up and saw this place across the road on the second floor. The name sounded cool and the name reminded me of a K-drama I watched some months ago, so I thought, why not check it out.

Once we entered, we realized that this was more a cool bar eating joint for the young'ish clubbing crowd, but hey, we still looked young'ish, and decided to stay. The place was pretty packed with our only choice left of a table by the restroom and kitchen or at the bar......we chose the bar.....and were so glad we did. The place is dark, but so vibrant, colorful, with wall hung flatscreen TVs playing K-pop videos with its music blasting overhead....not the best place to be if you want to talk without shouting, but still a great place for watching people hanging out with friends and having fun.

So, here we were trying to blend in by ordering a couple of beers. The bar tender was super nice, cool, and seemed so happy with what he was doing....enjoying the music by giving little spurts of entertaining dance moves and singing along to the blasting music.

So, we knew we were there for something to eat, so took a look at the menu.....and decided on the Seafood Pancake and Spicy Chicken Cheese. Ok, so this was a bar so we didn't expect the greatest quality food, but DAAAAANG!.....what we ordered was actually really good! The seafood pancake was soft and full of seafood....not crispy at the bottom.....but it tasted soooooo good, especially with beer! Then the spicy chicken cheese......DAAAAANG again! Steaming hot, spicy (but tolerable for me), and tasted absolutely delicious!

Yea, we ended up in this noiser than expected place, but it was a fun experience, with good service, entertaining K-pop videos on TV and a fun-to-watch dancing bartender......who was always nice enough to check on us......and totally yummy food. So glad we came here at least once.

Visited this place twice while on vacation in NYC. My friends and I had such a great time!!!!!! The food was yummy and the drinks were amazing. I stopped drinking pretty early and the bartender made me the most delicious yakult mocktail.
The staff there are so nice. The decor is on point and the music is always so good.

Def going to come back!

Definitely one of my favorite spots in the city.

Great Korean food & drinks, amazing vibes with the music and ambiance. Best thing of all is the amazing staff, especially Victor.

Strongly recommend as a place to drop by.

Been here many times surprised I never left a review.

This place is always a good time even on a Monday night! Went here today for a shareable dish and soju with a friend. The Bulgogi was on point, the soju was cold and the waitstaff was very good always there when you needed him. I look forward to coming back to the kpop party again soon!

This was such the perfect night cap, we stumbled upon this bar after karaoke and its such a fun place. My friends and I ordered drinks and some drinking food (pork feet and gizzards). I was pleasantly surprised by how good the food was for being a late night spot. I think ordering beer is the way to go, their cocktails are too sweet.

Came here with a few friends on a Friday night. There was a long line and we had to put our name down. After about 45 min we were able to get our table. The environment was fun and lively, they were also playing upbeat Korean songs. We ordered the Seafood Pancake, Creamy Tteokbokki, and the Squid and Pork. The dishes took a while to arrive but all 3 were absolutely delicious. My personal favorite was the seafood pancake. They also offer free rice on the menu but after asking 3 times, they still didn't have any ready so we decided to give up on that. We also ordered beers and soju and drank somaek. Everything was super tasty and I had a lot of fun with my group! Definitely recommend if you are in ktown!

I was lucky enough to have the privilege of spending my 27th birthday, celebrating with 21 people at Itaewon. There's something really special and authentic about this bar and restaurant. Food is amazing, drinks are insatiable, and what separates this place from all other places are the team tonight. We had the privilege of meeting the owner of Itaewon Andy. Andy toasted to my 27th Birthday and had the room sing for my birthday party. His service team tonight Aisha, Victor, and Hector elevated my birthday tonight's celebration to really make me feel special, I am forever grateful!!!

The vibes here are amazing! I love this LGBT owned Korean bar/pub in Koreatown. They have really nice cocktails and delicious appetizers and entrees. The fries were crispy and loaded with meat and kimchi. The pancake was peppery and had lots of fresh and flavorful seafood in it, with a great soy dipping sauce. However, my favorite was the tteokbokki! The cheesy spicy goodness on each rice cake was so satisfying and they gave a wonderful amount. Also, our server opened up a bottle of Peach Soju for us in such a cool way! The servers were all so friendly and accommodating. I can see myself coming back to catch a drink and some quick bites with friends!

I was in New York for a bit with my girlfriend and I started missing soju--so natural we went to Koreatown and we saw Itaewon Pocha from street level.

Hey, we thought. Looks lively enough.

We went into the building and walked up a couple flights of stairs to something I was not prepared for. We walked into K-pop blaring on the speakers and Korean music videos on the television--but as I looked around, I noticed Korean people were few and apart. Initially, I was a little taken aback because back in LA, there would be more Koreans. However, after the initial shock, it was actually pretty cool. It felt like a celebration of Korea and its culture. There were groups of Caucasian girls belting out the lyrics of New Jeans, groups doing the dances to their favorite K-pop hits, and overall the vibes were fun.

Unfortunately, we got to this spot after their kitchen closed so we weren't able to try their food, but next time I'll definitely try.

However, the server and manager David and Victor were amazing and accommodating. The customer service was top notch and at the end of the night, even though my girlfriend and I regressed into bumbling idiots after a long night of drinking, I'd like to think they didn't pass too harsh of judgement on us when we made our exit. Or maybe they did--I don't know, I might have been a little inebriated at the end.

But this place is a cool place to come as a non-Korean if you're into the K-pop scene. And if you are Korean, this place definitely is interesting to check out if not for the people you meet and see, then for the great service.

Budaejigae: delicious! Had extra non traditional ingredients like bow tie pasta but it was still good and plentiful. Has kimchi, cheese, green onion, clear noodles, rice cake, spam, sausage, pasta and baked beans.

Soju: jinro grape flavor. Always slaps.

BEWARE: they include tip in your bill (I was dining with one other person). Keep your eye out for that. No warning or call out is made in menus or by servers.

Ambiance: fun, colorful, lively, not strictly kpop.

My bank blocked my card because of a security threat. It was me, buying drinks all the way in NY at 1am. I am my own biggest threat. Cali to NY to experience the night life of NY, what a trip.

.:: Food / Drinks ::.

Korean Fried Chicken Wings (6pcs) $13.95: Chose the soy garlic wings. It was a bit dry. And the flavors werent quite developed yet. It was a bit bland

Oh Mija $16: Jinro soju, schisandra berry, lemon juice. Not bad, a good drink overall. Sweet but slightly tart. Not too strong

.:: Service / Ambiance ::.
Terrible host lol. My friend and I stood at the host stand for a good 8 min with no one batting an eye at us. The host / waitress were on their phone and paid 0 attention even when I try to get their attention. Our waitress looked so unhappy to be there. Our food came in a timely manner though when we finally got her attention to put our order down. We came on a Wednesday night, it wasnt crowded at all around 12-1am.

The place was very vibrant, colorful, and festive. Poppin 2000's rnb music like tpain etc.

Itaewon Pocha and Pocha 32 feel almost identical. Both are great for food and alcohol. This gives me "guy in a suit from a K-Drama stumbling upon a street food vendor in Korea late night drinking Soju alone" vibes.
A touch of Korea right in the heart of NYC's Koreatown.

After karaoke, a couple of us decided to keep the party going by coming here for drinks and snacks. The space is on the second floor and you get seated as soon as you get your ID checked. The music is blasting and it has a colorful and dark drinking vibe that feels just like the pubs in Korea.

We got the Chumchurum Soju ($15.95), Cocktail Soju ($38.95), and Bulgogi Kimchi Fries ($19.95) to munch on. The fries are pretty small and pricey alongside the drinks. Most of the bars/lounges in KTown are pretty similar. It's a fun time nonetheless, but can get quite pricey.

While I love the concept of this place, it is pricey and the food quality doesn't match with the price. This is a Korean style bar therefore it will be a bit loud and it is a place that you can come drinking with your friends. However, when I ordered one of the most common Korean drinking food, rice cakes, I was disappointed by the flavor. The sauce was too sweet and there wasn't a lot of fishcake in the rice cake. Additionally for the assorted tempura, it was just dumpling and kimmari. For the same price, I would rather go to Yupdduk and get their rice cakes with more options. The service was okay here, they were not as friendly and a little more rash when taking your order and serving your food.

Fun vibes! Lovely interior! Came here on a whim wanting snacks and drinks. The cocktail sojus are good, wish there was more alcohol content -- was not feeling buzzed. Skip the fries, get their wings instead. The army stew was questionable. Would have wanted ramen instead of bowtie pasta. Other than that it's a cute spot. The service here is ok. Nothing crazy.

Peach cocktail soju: $38.95
Army stew: $30.95
French fries: $11.95
Their lychee martini was a favorite and the food is super filling so definitely bring a friend to share! I wish we could've gotten more, but that's for a next time!

Came pretty early so was the first one to get here before it started packing up. Vibes is nice with the music and K-Pop blasting. The food was great though! Their seafood rice cakes, meat dishes, and rice (even though it's free for the first bowl and you pay for every other bowl after that) were all so tasty and filling! We also got their mixed sojus as well and they were tasty too, although rather light in terms of alcohol content. Service was pretty attentive too.

Your typical late night Korean food and drinks spot. We got sat near the front entrance so it felt like the waiters and hostess kinda just watched us eat. Our waiter was kind but the hostess was more attentive and was quick to help us when needed.

We got the pork belly, Bulgogi fries, and the creamy ramen. Hands down my favorite pork belly ever! It's so fatty and delicious but is balanced with the thinly sliced green onions. The creamy ramen was so good too but have large chunks of onion and the bacon was a bit chewy. Super good and a fun spot for a night out!

I've gone here plenty of times, and always experience a decent time here until recently. The music was super loud, and I wasn't able to talk to my friends because of the loud music. Staff was a bit slow and the restaurant wasn't even busy, this was around 5-6p. I ordered the army stew and I've gotten it a few times but this time around, it came with beans and pasta?! I never had army stew with pasta and beans before I was a bit disappointed, I also asked the staff about it and they gave me an confused look... And the army stew cost about $25+ for such a small portion.. The last time I was here, it was totally different without the beans and pasta and it was a good big size portion enough to share with for 5-6 people but with my recent visit the army stew was only good enough for 3-4 people. Overall, was a bit disappointed with my recent visit.

Came here on a Saturday evening right at opening and we got a table with ease. The space slowly filled up, but I would say that this is busiest for a later dinner for sure, so if you come here earlier, you'd have no issue grabbing a seat and eating before it gets super noisy.

The service was okay - there were clearly a lot of servers in the small space, however it was hard to flag someone down when we needed them since they usually just loiter by the entrance and don't walk through that often. The food and drinks nonetheless came out pretty quickly and we didn't have to wait too long for water refills.

The soju cocktail was a little expensive, but I do love how the lychee came with real lychee blended in. Everything else we got, from the fries to the rice cakes to the pancake, tasted good, but again a little pricy. Nonetheless, this is Manhattan, so it was to be expected. I'm glad it all tasted nice and was cooked well in the end.

Overall, fun spot for drinks, food, and friends. There were tons of large groups around us and I found it to be a great place to hang out and eat - I wouldn't mind coming back with a larger party for a good time in the future.

Had a great time with my friends. Every time I'm in NY for a concert, I always bring my friends here because the vibes are great and food is large portioned so great to share. Despite there being a lot of us, we always get sat right away. The staff let us queue music when we tipped and played along with our table even if we were a little tipsy. This made the night so memorable! Should've left a review years ago but we'll definitely be back!

Was looking try out a different Korean food spot and found this place. I ordered the seafood cheese rice cake which was pretty mediocre. The proportion of rice cake to seafood was kind of off. There weren't that much mixed seafood in the dish I felt like I was really only eating cheese and rice cakes.

Despite this dish being mediocre, it's still a cool place to check out with friends or a group of people with the party like ambiance.

This place was pretty colorful and I went with my coworkers

I thought their prices were slightly high and the place was really small. If you go with a big group, I'd recommend going somewhere else

Such a cool spot to chill with friends, we loved it so much we came back twice on our trip. Their food looked really good but we didn't get try any :(  we got their drinks and they played some bangerssss. The servers were also so friendly and fun!

My husband and I were looking for a new place to try nearby our hotel. We found Itaewon Pocha, and figured it was super different from the normal spots we usually go to. We both were excited to try Korean food. It was a late night, but thankfully the restaurant stays open super late on weekends. The place is pretty hidden. The spot is very popular, as we had to wait on a long lune just to get to the entrance. We waited for at least 25 mins. Once inside we saw how packed it was, and knew the food must be good if everyone was here lol.

We ordered soju, which was super sweet. It was hard not to order 5 of those bottles because it really doesn't taste like alcohol, but it will sneak up on you if you aren't careful. We ordered the fried veggie dumplings and Tteokbokki with assorted tempura. The food come out quickly which was great. Service was super friendly and helpful with answering all of our questions. The waiter was very patient with us. The food was really good! I loved the dumplings best. The atmosphere was nice. It was a very loud and fast paced place. There were also K-pop music videos playing on the tv's, which was nice. All in all I had a great time.

LOVE the ambiance here! Came here with a few friends for happy hour and we were seated very quickly. Cool lighting and fun decor on the wall and hanging from the ceiling. The kimchi pancake and veggie dumplings were pretty good, but the best part was our waiter opening our soju with a little swirling production. Would recommend!

Came here around 6:30pm on a Saturday to meet friends prior to a bday party. I wasn't the one organizing so I didn't have any details, so when we got there we just asked if we can sit at the bar until the entire party comes. The hostess, shorter blonde gentleman, right off the bat was giving us an issue. Asking us a thousand questions about the party. Again we weren't the ones organizing and it's not uncommon to meet people prior to a party for drinks. Anyways, bartenders and other hostesses were nice.

The rest of the party comes and we join the table, and it ends up another friend showed up and the same hostess came and started lecturing the entire table about how we should've made a reservation and literally started coming at me (someone who didn't plan this) about I said it was 2 people and now it's more -- mind you, I clearly stated I have no idea how many people and I'm fine sitting or standing at the bar. We even said it's fine if the extra person doesn't have a seat since we were leaving soon and he continued to badger us about how we need to make reservations next time. Like yes we realize that now BUT unsure how that helps in the moment. Another server tried to accommodate us and the host came over and told them to stop. Pretty ridiculous.

Food took forever but was tasty. Drinks were good and the servers were helpful in helping us choose. Inside was cramped but cute. Bathrooms were atrocious but what can you expect.

Train your hosts better because not everyone is going to have a reservation and if can't accommodate just simply say no, no need for a lecture that spans 5 minutes like it's truly not that serious esp when we were just asking not even complaining. We kept saying everything is fine if they can't accommodate.

Need a wing, man?! Itaewon Pocha got you! From, their Korean Fried Chicken Wings to their variety of drinks, you'll like it so much you'll put a wing on it!

Itaewon Pocha, located in Midtown, is your place to be at if you're looking for Korean comfort food. They have a variety of Korean street food and the entire setup is a vibeeee! From the bright lights inside to their colorful decor, it'll have you feeling like you're at a disco, so have your cameras ready for the Instagram pics! The perfect spot to hang with friends before and after a fun night out! Hector, Emily and Victor, thanks to your amazing hospitality and recommendations, we'll be seeing you soon!

What We Ate

For appetizers:
*Bulgogi Kimchi Fries (possibly made in Heaven, so good!)
*Sweet Chili Korean Fried Chicken

For entree:
*Spicy Chicken Cheese
*Seafood Fried Rice

What we Drank
*Oh Mija

Be sure to check them out next time you're in K-Town, you if you're looking to have a great time!

please DO NOT go here. TERRRRIBLE SERVICE.

- my beef with this place is that they have randomly switched their staff to 0 korean people.

now. we order a bunch of food and we notice that they bring the food out but no silverware. we also ordered soju and they didn't bring out shot glasses. i kid you not, it took nearly 10 minutes to get anyones attention because all the staff just sit by the bar and be on their phones. and also messing around with each other. i had to physically get up twice to get what i needed, or scream at the top of my lungs "excuse me!"

they are not attentive at all, nor do any of them know what the menu consists of.

like you're telling me i have to order and speak in english.. at a korean restaurant? huhhhh?

now. it gets worse

we ask for the bill, which takes about 30 minutes for them to remmeber to bring it, and notice that it's already 20% tipped.

i'm like oh hell no that's not happening. i am rarely stingy w tipping but when the service is THIS bad, nahhh. i look at the menu and it says 20% will be added for 6 parties or more. we had 4 people..

i ask one of the servers to take it off and he goes "oh we always have the 20%". ???? i've been to this pocha over 10 times and i have never once seen that. we literally point it out on the menu, how it says 6 parties or more, and he goes, "um that's our policy now. everyone's paying 20% grat" and then WALKS AWAY.

yooo when i tell you... i am never coming back here again.

not sure if the owners or management changed, but y'all need to get your service in check.

the food was average and tasted even worse after experiencing bad service. there are TONS of pochas in ktown, and id suggest going to anywhere else but here.

Located in Korea town in New York, I think it's in the Chelsea area on the second floor is this pub bar called itaewon Pocha which reminded me a lot the actual Itaewon in Korea. International flags, they have gender neutral bathrooms and a perfect place to start drinking and to have bar food. They're open late night and we got here around midnight on a Friday night/Saturday morning. We were pretty tipsy after bar hopping and I knew we needed to get some food in our system.
